object short description: This four-armed Mahākāla is holding a sword (khaḍga) with his two right hands, a khaṭvāṅga and kapāla with his two left hands.

Object image caption: Bhindyaḥ Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-04
object short description: This Caitya is established in the Bāhā’s courtyard. The statues of four Bodhisattvas and four Buddhas were installed on the niches of its four cardinal directions when it was initially constructed. However, these images were stolen in due course of time, thus the empty niches of the Caitya were filled in with new statues in VS 2069.

object short description: Inside the sanctum sanctorum, a stone statue of Akṣobhya has been placed facing north as kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ. Another stone statue of Akṣobhya, positioned little higher than kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ, has also been placed behind it. The locals have no information about this statue.

Object image caption: Vasu Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala in front of the kvāḥpāḥdegaḥ, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-06
Vasu Bāhāḥ, Amitābha Mandira next to the kvāḥpādegaḥ, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-06
object short description:
This temple was built using the leftover bricks and other terracotta artefacts from the restoration of Mahābuddha Mandira, which was destroyed during the earthquakes in 1934 CE (1990 VS). A stone statue of Amitābha has been installed in the sanctum sanctorum of the temple.

Above the sanctum sanctorum is a terracotta toraṇa, a face of Bhairava, and a dharmacakra. To the north of the temple, there is a terracotta statue of Mañjuśrī and three dharmacakras, and to the east of the temple is a dharmacakra with three terracotta statues of Amitābha.

Object image caption: Saṅkaṭā Ilānani, statue of Garuḍa, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-07-29

Object name: Statue of Mañjuśrī, Tārā and carved Vajra
Object image caption: Saṅkaṭā Ilānani, statue of Mañjuśrī, Tārā and a carved Vajra, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-07-29
object short description:
दिगिको मोहोडा भागमा गवाक्ष बनाई मञ्जुश्री, तारा र तोरण सहित बीचमा बज्र कुँदिएको शिलाफलक स्थापना गरएको छ । बीचको बज्र कुँदिएको शिलाफलक दिगिको गुह्यकक्षमा स्थापित चक्रसम्वरको प्रतिक मानिन्छ ।  

A Vajra statue adorned with a toraṇa has been placed in a niche (gavākṣa) on the eastern wall of the Digi. It is flanked by statues of Mañjuśrī and Tārā on either side. The Vajra is said to represent Cakrasamvara as consecrated in the Digi's Āgaṃ.

Object image caption: Saṅkaṭā Ilānani, statue of Mahākāla, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-07-29
Saṅkaṭā Ilānani, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-07-29
Saṅkaṭā Ilānani, statues of 4 Siddhas, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-07-30
object short description:
बौद्ध दर्शन अनुसार अष्टसिद्धमध्येका चार सिद्धहरूको मूर्ति सङ्कटाको मूर्ति स्थापित भूमि तल्लाको पश्चिमी भित्तामा टाँसिएका छन् । 

The statues of these four Siddhas are placed on the western wall of the ground floor where the Saṅkaṭā’s statue is also kept. According to Buddhist philosophy, there are eight Siddhas in total.

Object image caption: Saṅkaṭā Ilānani, Pāḥtāḥkhvalā, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-07-30
object short description:
सङ्कटाको मूर्ति सामुन्ने ढुङ्गाको पात्र राखिएको छ जसलाई पाःताःख्वला भन्ने गरिन्छ । यसमा दैनिक नयाँ जल हाल्ने चलन छ जुन भक्तजनहरूले ग्रहण गर्ने गर्छन् । 

This stone pāḥtāḥkhvalā sits in front of the statue of Saṅkaṭā. It is filled with fresh water every day. This is taken as prasāda by the devotees.

Object image caption: Saṅkaṭā Ilānani, statue of the main deity in the sanctum, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-02
object short description:
B. Bhattacharya (1968, 154-155) ले व्याख्या गरेको संङ्कटाको प्रतिमालक्षणसंग यो मूर्तिको लक्षण मेल खान्छ । मूर्तिमा भएको दुई हातमध्ये दायाँले खड्ग र बायाँले पाश समातेको छ । सङ्कटाको बायाँ खुट्टाको घुँडाले भूमिमा टेकेको छ भने दायाँ खुट्टा हल्का उठाएको छ । धातुको मूर्तिमा कमरभन्दा तलको भागमा धातुकै जामा लगाइएको छ । चक्रसम्वरको आगंमा हुने गरेको सङ्कटाको सानो धातुमूर्तिलाई आदर्श मानी यो मूर्ति नेस १०७० मा बनाइएको हो । हाल उक्त सानो धातुमूर्ति यही मूर्तिको सामुन्ने राखिएको छ । 

The characteristic features of this statue of Saṅkaṭā match the description of Caṇḍaroṣaṇa’s iconography (in B. Bhattacharya, 1968, 154-155). The deity carries a sword (khaḍga) and a noose (pāśa) in his right and left hands respectively. His right foot is planted firmly on the ground whilst his left foot is slightly raised. The deity is wearing a metal jāmā (a kind of long garment) below his waist. This statue is based on the small metal statue of Saṅkaṭā kept in Cakrasamvara’s āgaṃ. The metal statue is presently displayed in front of this icon.

Object image caption: Saṅkaṭā Ilānani, Yaḥsi, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-01
object short description:
यो यःसिँ प्रत्येक पाँच वर्षमा नागबाहालमा हुने सम्यक पर्वको एक हप्ता अगाडि नागबाहाःमा खडा गर्ने चलन छ ।  

The Yaḥsi is traditionally erected a week before the Samyak Mahādāna festivities in Nāga Bāhāḥ. This takes place once every five years.

Object image caption: Micchu Bāhāḥ, durgatipariśodhana caitya, view from E (August 2019)
object short description:
This durgatipariśodhana caitya lies to the north of a dharmadhātu maṇdalā in the Bāhāḥ premise. The barechuyegu (cūdākarma) of the young boys of the Bāhāḥ are performed infront of the caitya. This caitya made on top of a four cornered platform has four Buddhas in four corners. The Akṣobhaya Buddha on the eastern side of the caitya is flanked with a toraṇa of Five Buddhas and a set of lions on two sides. The niches on top of it are also flanked by Buddhas. Lotus pedestals can be found on two storeys of the monument object with four goddesses in each of their four corners. Lāsyadevi is located to the southeast, Malādevi can be found to the southwest, Gitādevi has been placed to the northwest and Nityādevi is housed at the northeast. The niche contains statues of 24 gods and goddesses alongside their names. These names are as follows:

East: Akṣobhya, Kṣitigarbha and Ākāśagarbha

Southeast: Māmakī Tārā, Gaganagañja and Ratṇapāṇi

South: Ratnasambhava, Sāgaramatī and Vajragarbha

Southwest: Pāndarā Tārā, Avalokiteśvara and Mahāsāmaprāptā

West: Amithābha, Candraprabha and Jālibanīprabha

Northwest: Tārādevī, Aviprabha and Pratibāṇakūṭa

North: Amoghasiddhi, Sarvaśokatamaṇirghāṭanamati and Sarvvanīvaraṇavi (ṣkambhī)

Northeast: Locanā Tārā, Samantabhadra and Akṣayamati (Gutschow 1997, 51)

Object image caption: Micchu Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from E (August 2019)
Micchu Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S (August 2019)
Nṛtyeśvara Mandira, Gulugulu Dyaḥ, view from SE (November 2018)
object short description: In the northern entry way to the courtyard are three small niches housing four stones which are worshipped as Gulugulu Dyaḥ. Music learners rub their hands on the stones believing that it will help them learn faster.

Object image caption: Nṛtyeśvara Mandira, stone pillar with monkey holding an oil lamp, view from N (November 2018)
Nṛtyeśvara Mandira, śikharakūṭa caitya, view from W (November 2018)
Nṛityeśvara Mandira, view of well from NE (November 2018)
Thyākā Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātujinālaya caitya, view from NE (July 2019)
object short description:
This caitya stands in the middle of the Bāhāḥ courtyard. Four caturmāhārajas face in each of the four directions and are placed on the vedikā. On top of the lotus petals, one can also find four Bodhisattvas facing in the four cardinal directions. Above another two layers of lotus petals, there are images of Buddha, also in each of the four directions. On top of these images, one can find garbha, harmikā, trayodaśabhuvana and a parasol.

The caitya is damaged in some parts. The plinth is also damaged where the inscription has been written.

Object image caption: Thyākā Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from N (July 2019)
object short description: This statue of Gaṇeśa is located on the southern wall of the Bāhāḥ. Gaṇeśa has four arms and is holding a japamālā and a radish in his right hands and an axe and a sweet ball in his left hands.

Object image caption: Thyākā Bāhāḥ, Mañjuśrī statue, view from E (July 2019)
object short description: A statue of a six-handed Mañjuśrī has been installed on the southern wall of the Bāhāḥ. Mañjuśrī is holding a khaḍga and an arrow in two of his right hands and is performing varada mūdrā with the third hand. He is holding a book, a flower and a bow in his left hands.

Object image caption: Thyākā Bāhāḥ, statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from E (July 2019)
object short description: This small statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara stands to the north of the main statue. His right hand is in a varada gesture and his left hand holds the stem of a blossoming lotus flower.

Object image caption: Dupāt Capāḥ, image of Nāmasaṅgīti, view from W; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2019-03-12
object short description: In July 2015, Sanāḥ Guṭhī installed an image of Nāmasaṅgīti in a narrow space between the shrine of Gaṇeśa and the main door of the Capāḥ. Nāmasaṅgīti is one of the important manifesta­tions of Mañjuśrī, embodying the wisdom of all of the Buddhas. He has one head and twelve arms and is seated in dhyānamudrā (a meditative posture). His uppermost arms are above his head and are shown performing uttarabodhi mudrā (a gesture symbolising the state that follows enlightenment). Two further hands at his breast level are performing dharmacakramudrā. Two more hands perform tarpaṇamudrā (offering water with a bowl), whilst two more are holding a bowl that is placed upon his lap. The two hands at his shoulder level are holding a sword and a book placed on a lotus, whilst his final two hands are holding a bow and arrow.

Object image caption: Dupāt Capāḥ, Nāsadyaḥ (March 2019)
object short description: Earlier, the Capāḥ had a shrine to Nāsaḥdyaḥ on its upper floor. After the structure was rebuilt, the shrine was relocated to the second floor. People worship Nṛtyeśvara when they start to learn music or a dance form, or before they present an artistic performance to the public.

Bhelāchẽ Phalcā, statue of Viṣṇu and Lakṣmī, view from NE (February 2020)
object short description: Viṣṇu holds a śaṅkha in his upper right hand and a gadā in his corresponding left hand. His second right hand holds a cakra and his second corresponding left hand holds a lotus. Lakṣmī´s right hand is performing abhayamudrā .

Object image caption: Bhelāchẽ Phalcā, statue of Lakṣmīnārāyaṇ, view from SE
object short description: Nārāyaṇ holds a cakra in his upper right hand and a gadā in his corresponding left hand. His second right hand is performing abhayamudrā and his second left hand embraces Lakṣmī. Lakṣmī's is performing the gesture of varadamudrā with her right hand and abhayamudrā with her left hand.

Object image caption: Bhelāchẽ Phalcā, statue of Viṣṇu, Lakṣmī and Sarasvatī, view from NE (February 2020)
object short description: Statue of Viṣṇu and his two wives: Lakṣmī on his left, Sarasvatī on his right and his vehicle Garuḍa below. Viṣṇu holds a śaṅkha in his upper right hand and a gadā in his corresponding left hand. His second right hand holds a lotus and his second left hand holds a cakra.

Object image caption: Bhelāchẽ Phalcā, statue of Viṣṇu, view from NE (February 2020)
Jena Bāhāḥ, Durgā shrine, view from N (September 2019)
object short description: There is a small Durgā shrine to the west of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala. The entrance has a chepu inscribed in the toraṇa. A pair of lions guard the entrance of the temple. Inside the temple, one can find tiles depicting Durgā and five aniconic stones.

Object image caption: Jena Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N (September 2019)
Jena Bāhāḥ, Rādhākṛṣṇa shrine, view from W (September 2019)
Jena Bāhāḥ, Licchavi Caitya, view from N (September 2019)
object short description: The caitya stands testimony to the bāhāḥ's heritage. Like other Licchavi caityas, its niches are empty and it contains 11 bhuvanas. The part above the bhuvanas has been lost. Cement has been used to join the garbha and harmikā.

Object image caption: Ubāhāḥ Bahī, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-15
object short description: In NS 1007 (CE 1887) Dhaṃcāmuni installed this Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala.

Object image caption: Ubāhāḥ Bahī, statue of donors from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-15
object short description: The figure in the middle of this statue of three devotees praying is larger in size, meaning that it probably represents the male head of a family. He is flanked by a male figure is to his left, and a female figure to his right. There is no inscription available to offer any further information about these devotees.

Object image caption: Ubāhāḥ Bahī, bell with inscription, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-15
object short description: On the 8th day of the dark half of Āṣāḍha NS 944, Ganhudeva and Āgamadeva donated a bell to the Vihāra. On the 13th day of the dark half of Bhādra NS 967, Dhanapati, Lachimi and others replaced the damaged old bell with this new one. This bell also displays the names of the previous donors.

Object image caption: Ubāhāḥ Bahī, Licchavi Caitya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-15
object short description: The bottom of the Caitya is now underneath the ground. The harmikā above it has been attached using cement plaster with kumbha. It is clear that the upper part, including the harmikā, does not date back as far as the Licchavi period.

Object image caption: Ubāhāḥ Bahī, Mahākāla statue, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-15
object short description: The south-facing statue of Mahākāla is standing in samapāda, holding kartanī in his right hand and kapālapātra in his left. He is also pressing khaṭvāṅga with his left hand. The wooden toraṇa above him has an image of Vajrasattva in the middle. On the ground in front of this image one can find a maṇḍala of navagraha (nine planets).

Object image caption: Ubāhāḥ Bahī, Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-15
object short description: This Caitya was established in NS 1130 (CE 2010) by Vakil Raj Shakya and Dhana Shobha Shakya in memory of Durga Maya Shakya and Buddhi Raj Shakya.

Object image caption: Ubāhāḥ Bahī, Pañcāvalīyukta Caitya, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-15
object short description: There is no inscription to provide information about the installation of this Pañcāvalīyukta Caitya. Śākya (1994: 69) mentions that this Caitya was constructed on the 12th day of the bright half of Āśvina in NS 985.

Object image caption: Vīra Vināyaka Mandira, Stone statue of Gaṇeśa, view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-06-01
Hiti, Bhagīratha statue below the water spout, view from W (December 2019)
object short description: According to one strand of Hindu mythology, Bhagīratha was a king who pleased the goddess Gaṅgā and Lord Śiva by undertaking penance. He spent a long time sitting on the bank of Bindasura, and in doing so he managed to bring the Water Goddess (i.e., Gaṅgā) from the sky down to the earth. As a result of this, many of the conduits of the Kathmandu Valley hitis that were built before the Malla period display carved images of Bhagīratha beneath them.. The king is shown in a standing position and holding a conch with both of his hands.

Object image caption: Hitī, Jahrũhiti with a statue of Gaṅgā above it, view from N (December 2019)
Hiti, a statue of Gaṅgā, view from N (December 2019)
object short description: The statue has been placed on the plinth above the water reservoir.

Object image caption: Kālikā Mālikā Mandira, lintel of śikhara temple, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description: The lintel was a part of a small śikhara temple. Two hinge bearing holes (or mortises) indicate that a small door controled the access to the temple's sanctum.

Object image caption: Kālikā Mālikā Mandira, stone memorial pillar, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
Kālikā Mālikā Mandira, anthropomorphic stele, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description: The figure represented in this stele seems to execute a praying gesture. No sexual attributes are visible and its exact identity could not be acquired neither from informants nor from iconographic details. It remains safe to consider it as an ex-voto installed to thank to a deity or to request from it the grant of wishes.

Object image caption: Kālikā Mālikā Mandira, architectural element, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description: This architectural fragment was probably a part of a small śikhara temple, where it could have been a part of a wall section or a doorstep.

Object image caption: Kālikā Mālikā Mandira, architectural element, view from SW; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description: This element was most likely a part of a small  śikhara temple. The upper part may correspond to a capital, suggesting that it was situated at the lintel level of the temple.

Object image caption: Unaca Bhājubala Bāhāḥ, statue of main deity Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-07-20
Unaca Bhājubala Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-07-20
Unaca Bhājubala Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-07-20
Unaca Bhājubala Bāhāḥ, statue of Prajñāpāramita at the southern side of Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-07-20
Unaca Bhājubala Bāhāḥ, statue of Lokeśvara at the northern side of Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-07-20
Unaca Bhājubala Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-07-20
Unaca Bhājubala Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-07-20
Unaca Bhājubala Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-07-20
Unaca Bhājubala Bāhāḥ, Mañjuśrī Pādukā, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-07-20
Unaca Bhājubala Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-07-20
Ārīthāy Ināy Phalcā, statue of Garuḍanārāyaṇa, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-13
Ārīthāy Ināy Phalcā, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-13
Śaṅkhadhara Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Manḍala, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-08
object short description: The Dharmadhātu Manḍala is built on a two-storied vedi with eight corners, but the vedi contains no images of Bodhisattva. Previously, the dharmadhātu had a metal vajra, but this was stolen a few years ago. The dharmadhātu was built in NS 988 when the vihāra was established.

Object image caption: Śaṅkhadhara Bāhāḥ, Caitya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-08
object short description: The structure of this caitya seems different from other caityas. The vedi is made of bricks anda clad with a copper repousse plate on top. This plate contains carvings of flower motifs and images of Buddha's vehicles and Lokapāla gods. To the east, one can see Vīṇārāja flanked by two elephants, the south contains an image of Khaḍgarāja flanked by two horses, Caityarāja is flanked by two peacocks to the west, and aDhvarāja flanked by two Garuḍas (a mythical bird) on the northern side. The shape of the Garbha (kumbha) is also unusual for a caitya. The small niches on each of the four sides contain images of Buddha made from cement. The section above the harmikā also is clad in copper. This caitya was established together with the bāhāḥ.

Object image caption: Dampāchẽ Phalcā, statue of Gaṇeśa, placed in a niche of the back wall, view from E (October 2019)
object short description: Statue of sitting Gaṇeśa with four arms. The statue holds a garland and a radish in his right hands, whilst his two left hands hold an axe and a sweet ball.

Object image caption: Dampāchẽ Phalcā, statue of Sarasvatī placed in a niche of the back wall, view from E (October 2019)
object short description: The statue of Sarasvatī has four hands: the right hand holds a rosary made of beads, while the left hand holds a book. The remaining two hands hold an instrument called vīṇā.

Object image caption: Ichẽ Śikharakūṭa Caitya, statue of Vajrapāṇi Lokeśvara on the southern face of the Caitya, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-30
Ichẽ Śikharakūṭa Caitya, statue of Maitreya Buddha on the eastern face of the Caitya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-30
Ichẽ Śikharakūṭa Caitya, statue of Mañjuśrī on the northern face of the Caitya, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-30
Ichẽ Śikharakūṭa Caitya, statue of Ratnasambhava on the southern face of the Caitya, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-30
Ichẽ Śikharakūṭa Caitya, statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara on the western face of the Caitya, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-30
Ichẽ Śikharakūṭa Caitya, statue of Akṣobhya on the eastern face of the Caitya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-30
Ichẽ Śikharakūṭa Caitya, statue of Amoghasiddhi on the northern face of the Caitya, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-30
Ichẽ Śikharakūṭa Caitya, statue of Amitābha on the western face of the Caitya, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-30
Nhāykã Bahī, images of Mahakāla, Gaṇeśa on his right and Mañjuśrī on his left, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-10-30
object short description: The image of Māhākāla was consecrated in NS 623 (1503CE).

Object image caption: Nhāykã Bahī, Dharmadhātumaṇḍala, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-10-30
object short description: This dharmadhātu was renovated in NS 905.

Object image caption: Nhāykã Bahī, Aśoka Caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-10-30
Naka Bahī Phalcā 3, Mahākāla shrine, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-09-16
object short description: The Mahākāla shrine is a remnant of the Phalcā and was once attached to the western wall. With the exception of its head, the stone statue of Mahākāla is heavily damaged.

Object image caption: Pulcoka Lohãhiti, kalaśa, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: A stone water vessel is placed on the third plinth of the Hiti on top of lotus petals.

Object image caption: Pulcoka Lohãhiti, statue of Akṣobhya in the wall of the entrance, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: Akṣobhya statues are placed on both sides of the entrance.

Object image caption: Pulcoka Lohãhiti, statue of Sarasvatī in the western wall niche, view from E (January 2020)
object short description: Stone statue of Sarasvatī is attached to the wall of the third plinth. She is holding a vīṇā with two hands and a rosary and a book with her other two hands.

Object image caption: Pulcoka Lohãhiti, statue of Varuṇa, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: A deteriorated stone statue which is attached to the wall of the third plinth is called Varuṇa.

Object image caption: Pulcoka Lohãhiti, statue of Nāgarājā, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: A stone statue of Nāgarāja is attached to the southern wall of the Hiti, above the conduit. Seven Nāgas surmount him. He displays varada gesture with his right hand and holds the tails of other Nāgas in his left hand. In earlier times, people used to worship these Nāgas on the day of Nāgapañcamī.

Object image caption: Pulcoka Lohãhiti, detail of water spout, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: The stone spout has a crocodile motif. A pipeline from a roar pump is connected to this spout. Khanal (2068, 25) mentions that there is a Bhagīratha statue under the spout. However, dirty collected water covers it.

Object image caption: Pulcoka Lohãhiti, aṣṭamaṅgala, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: An image of a water vessel with eight auspicious symbols is made above the spout. The symbols are covered with five serpents.

Object image caption: Tārā Nani, Āryatārā (inside a protective frame), view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-19
Tārā Nani, Prajñapāramitā (inside a protective frame), view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-19
Tārā Nani, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya (A), view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-19
Tārā Nani, Mahāśānta Śveta Dharmacakra Tārā in the sanctum (inside a protective frame), view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-19
object short description: It was not possible to photograph the statue without the protective frame.

Object image caption: Tārā Nani, Narasiṃha, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-19
Tārā Nani, well, view from NE; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-21
Tārā Nani, Jarũhiti, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-21
Tārā Nani, Ratnasambhava, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-21
Tārā Nani, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya (C), view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-19
Tārā Nani, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya (B), view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-19
Pinchẽ Phalcā 2, with dhahmā from the Matsyendranāt chariot in front, view from NE (February 2019)
object short description: Some phalcās in Patan have a dhahmā (a long wooden beam from the base of a Matsyendranāth chariot) in front of them. This particular dhahmā is worshipped as Bhairava. It is in a heavily damaged condition.

Object image caption: Pinchẽ Phalcā 2, statue of Jorgaṇeśas, view from N (February 2019)
object short description: This statue is attached to the southern wall of the phalcā. Two images of Gaṇeśa have been carved into a single stone and share similar attributes. Each of them has four hands, with the upper two hands holding an akṣamālā and axe. Similarly, their lower right hands are performing varada whilst holding a radish and their lower left hands are shown holding a sweet ball.

Object image caption: Kuladīpā Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-02-19
Kuladīpā Bāhāḥ, Ramyakūṭāgāra Caitya, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-02-19
object short description: On the lower part of the caitya, the four usual Bodhisattvas are placed in the centre niches and the sixteen Bodhisattvas in the remaining ones. The middle part of the caitya is occupied by four Mahābuddhas with eight arms and four heads. In the remaining niches are found Bodhisattvas and Lāsyādevīs.

Object image caption: Kuladīpā Bāhāḥ, Ganeśa, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-02-19
Kuladīpā Bāhāḥ, Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-02-19
Bhindyaḥlāchi Phalcā, relief statue of donors, view from E (March 2018)
object short description: The two donor statues show Jagata Avāle and his wife. The paintings of flower designs and five dhyānī Buddhas (Ratnasambhava, Akṣobhya, Bairaocana, Amitābha and Amoghasiddhi) at the top, as well as the paintings of parrots, svastika, eyes, and a pūrṇa-kalaśa (a jar filled with water) on the right and left sides were painted in 2007 CE on the occasion of Kājīlāla Avāle's jaṃkva. According to an Avāle family member, the icons of the phalcā depict the couple Jagata (Gvārā) Āju, who served in the Rāṇā Government, and his wife. He was of a higher status and was permitted to ride a horse. Jagata Avāle donated this phalcā six generations ago. An older statue of the donors was removed/stolen in the late 1990s and replaced soon thereafter.

Object image caption: Bhindyaḥlāchi Phalcā, statue of Sarasvatī, view from SE (February 2020)
Vatsalā Mandira, Kalaśa, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-09-08
Vatsalā Mandira, Kalaśa, view from SE; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-09-08
Vatsalā Mandira, Kalaśa, view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-09-08
Dhaḥmā Phalcā, view of the painted front of the dhaḥmā (May 2019)
object short description:
This Phalcā is known as the "dhaḥmā phalcā" because the dhaḥmās (the longitudinal main beams) of the Matsyendranāth chariot are stored here. 

A dhaḥmā is a shaft which is upturned at one end and passes through a chariot between the wheels. It is sometimes referred to as ghaḥmā. There is always a painting of Bhairava on the face of the upturned part. This is covered by a gilt copper image of the same deity. The dhaḥmā itself is considered to be Karkoṭaka Nāgarāja, the serpent deity who, legend tells, stretched itself across a river from one end to the other, thus enabling the king, a priest and a porter to cross the river when they went to collect Bungadyaḥ. However, the water of this river turned everything that touched it into stone. It was this power that gave it the name Śila Nadi: the stone river. The serpent deity crossed the river after helping the trio. As it crossed it accidentally let the tip of its tail dip into the river. The part that touched the water immediately turned into stone and fell off. This is why the other end of the dhaḥmā does not have a pointed tip like a serpent's tail (information by Rajendra Sakya 2015).

The four dhaḥmās measure ca. 60 cm in height, 1500 cm in length and 40 cm in breadth. They are damaged.

Object image caption: Māhādyaḥ Nani Āgama, Rāmeśvara Mandira, view from top (September 2019)
Pūcva Cvaya Bahī, Hanumān, view from N (February 2020)
object short description: This image representing Hanumān is placed at the outer entrance of the Bahī, to the left wall of the entrance. Triangular hole and two eyes are the symbolic representation of the deity.

Object image caption: Pūcva Cvaya Bahī, Mahākāla, view from S (February 2020)
object short description: Statue of Mahākāla is placed in a niche. He is standing on a corpse holding a kartṛ (cutter) in his right hand and his left-hand holds a kapāpāpātra (skull bowl) and claspses a khaṭvāṅga. There was a maṇḍala as an icon or Pratītyasamutpāda in front of the statue. Nowadays, the object has been preserved inside the esoteric room of Malekus.

Object image caption: Pūcva Cvaya Bahī, Digudyaḥ of Malekūs and cave, view from E (February 2020)
object short description: There is a shrine of lineage deity of Malekus in front of the outer entrance of the Bahī. The Malekus, came from Banepa worship Caṇḍeśvarī as their lineage deity. In front of the small statue of Caṇḍeśvarī there is an open space paved with flagstones. Some locals tell that there are tunnels below it, through which one can arrive at Mangalbazar and Shantipur of Swayambhu. Malekus worship their lineage deity by sacrificing goats.

Object image caption: Pūcva Cvaya Bahī, Padmoparijinālaṅkṛta Caitya, view from SW (February 2020)
object short description: This Caitya was made by Malekus in 1407 CE (NS 527). Previous brick-made structure was renovated in 1715 CE (NS 835) and given the present form. Nāgas are worshipped in the small pit located beside the Caitya, to the north.

Object image caption: Pūcva Cvaya Bahī, Mañjuśrī, view from S (February 2020)
object short description: There is a small shrine of Mañjuśrī outside the courtyard of the Bahī. Inside the shrine, there is a statue of Mañjuśrī and an aniconic stone, which is worshipped by Maharjans as their lineage deity.

Object image caption: Pūcva Cvaya Bahī, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from SW (February 2020)
object short description: Four Buddhas are placed inside the niches of four cardinal directions of the Caitya.

Object image caption: Pūcva Cvaya Bahī, Caturvyūha Caitya, view from S (February 2020)
object short description: This Caitya stands on a big stone pedestal. Four Bodhisattvas, Maitreya to the east, Mañjuśrī to the north, Padmapāṇi to the west and Vajrapāṇi to the south are placed in the Caitya.

Object image caption: Pūcva Cvaya Bahī, Mandaḥpāḥ, view from E (February 2020)
object short description: Generally, caityas can be found in the courtyard of a bāhāḥ or a bahī. However, in this courtyard there is no caitya. Instead, there is a mandaḥpā or padmamaṇḍala (a stone lotus). Originally, the lotus had 12 petals, but four of them are already broken.

Object image caption: Pūcva Cvaya Bahī, Digudyaḥ of Maharjans, view from S (February 2020)
object short description: This aniconic stone is the lineage deity of Maharjan clan of Pulchok. Previously, their lineage shrine was placed in Shantabhavan, Sanepa. Every year on the 6th day of the bright fortnight of Māgha and on the 3rd day of the bright fortnight of Vaiśākha they worship in the shrine.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, aniconic stone worshipped as Gaṇeśa consecrated in the sanctum, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-04
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Lion (A) flanking the main entrance (to the left while entering inside), view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-04
Gaṇeśa Mandira, lion (B) flanking the main entrance (to the right while entering inside), view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-04
Gaṇeśa Mandira, bell at the southeast corner of the Temple, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-04

Object name: Lāṭīkoilī Temple, stone image of Nandi
Object image caption: Lāṭīkoilī Temple, stone image of Nandi, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-20
object short description: The base of the sculpture contains an inscription dated of VS 2042 (1986 CE).

Object image caption: Hariśaṅkara Mandira, stone statue of Hariśaṅkara, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-03
object short description: This Hariśaṅkara statue is similar to the one in the Hariśaṅkara Mandira in Patan Darbar Square (LAL1280). Śiva is depicted on the right-hand side, and Viṣṇu is depicted on the left-hand side. The former is carrying a trident (triśūla), a sacred drum (ḍamaru), rosary (japamālā), and kamaṇḍalu; the latter is carrying a conch (śaṅkha), sacred wheel (cakra), gadā, and padma so that the statue has eight hands in total. Pārvatī and Lakṣmī have been carved on either side of Śiva and Viṣṇu, respectively.

Object image caption: Mahālakṣmī Mandira, pillar (B) with a lion on top, erected in front of the entrance, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-08
Mahālakṣmī Mandira, stone statue of unidentified headless donors on the southern wall of the lion pillar (LAL0020-004), view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-08
Mahālakṣmī Mandira, pillar (A) with a lion on top, erected in front of the entrance, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-08
object short description: Nāike Niramāna Siṃha, an artisan from Jombāhāḥ, erected this lion pillar with the help of his family.

Object image caption: Mahālakṣmī Mandira, aniconic stone worshipped as Manakāmanā, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-08
object short description: Beneath some niches in the rear wall of the temple, one can find a circle made of stone and worshipped as the head of Manakāmanā. The popular Manakāmanā temple inthe Gorkha district of Nepal is thought to represent the body of this aniconic deity. Local residents believe that one should pay a visit to this deity (pictured) after visiting Manakāmanā in Gorkha. The Devamālāvaṃśāvalī mentions that King Siddhinarasiṃha Malla commissioned a shrine to Manakāmanā in NS 750-751.

Object image caption: Mahālakṣmī Mandira, aniconic stone worshipped as Viśvakarmā, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-08
Mahālakṣmī Mandira, stone statue of donor on the southern wall of the lion pillar (LAL0020-004), view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-08
object short description: The plinth to the south of the lion pillar (LAL0020-004) holds a statue of an unidentified female donor facing west in prayer.

Object image caption: Mahālakṣmī Mandira, stone statue of donors on the northern wall of the lion pillar (LAL0020-004), view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-08
object short description: A plinth-like structure to the north of the lion pillar (LAL0020-004) holds the statues of four unidentified donors.

Object image caption: Mahālakṣmī Mandira, aniconic stone worshipped as Mahālakṣmī and toraṇa above it, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-08
Cvay Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya enshrined as the Bāhāḥ's primary deity (kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ) in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-01
Cvay Bāhāḥ, statue of Devotees (B), view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-01
Cvay Bāhāḥ, statue of Hanumān inside a wall niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-01

Cvay Bāhāḥ, statue of Devotees (C), view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-01

Cvay Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-01
Cvay Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa inside a wall niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-01
Cvay Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla inside a wall niche, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-01
Basantapura Duī Devala, south-eastern side of the western temple, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-02
Basantapura Duī Devala, southern side of the eastern temple, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-02
Jāhārkoṭa Devaldhara, fountain, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-27
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ, Lokeśvara south, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ, Śāriputra, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ, Maudgalyāyana, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ, Lokeśvara north, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ, Sarasvatī, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ, lion north, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ, lion south, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ, fragments of a Phalcā, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
object short description: The small statue is framed by a much larger timber-carved frame and a tympanum. It is quite possible that this small statue is a replacement of a larger statue that might have been installed earlier. The large pedestal and base stone would also suggest that they once supported a larger statue.

Object image caption: Yatkhā Bāhāḥ, Caitya, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ, Lokeśvara Shrine, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Lũkhusi Sarasvatī Phalcā, the statue of Mahākāla, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-29
Lũkhusi Sarasvatī Phalcā, the statue of Sarasvatī, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-29
Kinū Bahī, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from E (September 2019)
object short description: The structure of the caitya appears to be a recent construction. The inscription mentions that the earlier aśoka caitya was reconstructed. It is possible that the earlier caitya was covered by this new structure.

Object image caption: Kinū Bahī, statue of Mahākāla, view from S (September 2019)
object short description: Mahākāla is standing on a corpse. He is holding a kartṛ (an axe) and a kapāla (skull bowl).

Object image caption: Kinū Bahī, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: This octagonal maṇḍala has images of eight Lokeśvaras in eight directions.

Object image caption: Kopeśvara Mandira, Nandī, view from S (May 2019)
Kopeśvara Mandira, Gaṇeśa shrine and statue of Gaṇeśa, view from S (May 2019)
object short description: There is a Gaṇeśa shrine near the temple. The shrine is covered by a metal roof and is attached to the southern wall of a private home. The statue has four hands. Gaṇeśa's two upper hands hold an akṣamālā and an axe, while his lower left hand holds a sweet ball. His right hand is badly damaged.

Object image caption: Vajra Gaṇeśa, guardian stone lion (B), view from NW; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Vajra Gaṇeśa, Copper repousse of Gaṇeśa, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Vajra Gaṇeśa, guardian stone lion (A), view from N; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Om Bāhāḥ Dune Nani, Sukhāvati Lokeśvara, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-14
object short description: This statue of an eight-handed Sukhāvati Lokeśvara has been attached to the southern wall of the Bāhāḥ. Above the three heads of Lokeśvara's fourth head can be found above his three other heads. His śakti Tārā sits on his lap. Two of Lokeśvara's hands are performing a the dharmacakra gesture. The image is so faded that the objects he is holding in his other hands cannot be identified. However, this statue resembles an image of Sukhāvati Lokeśvara printed by Bhattacharyya (1958, 263). Using this image as a reference, it seems likely that he is also holding a book, a bow and a flower in his three left hands, and a garland and an arrow in his two right hands. His last right hand is probably performing the varada gesture.

Object image caption: Om Bāhāḥ Dune Nani, Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-14
object short description: This small statue of a standing Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara is attached to the wall south of the courtyard. His right hand is performing varada mudra whilst his left hand holds the stem of a blossoming lotus flower.

Object image caption: Om Bāhāḥ Dune Nani, Caitya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-14
object short description: This Svayambhū Caitya stands in front of the sanctum of the Bāhāḥ. The section above the ambaḥsā is gone. Northwest of the caitya is a pillar to hang a bell, however the bell is also missing. There was once a fire alter to the west of the caitya, but this collapsed during the the 2015 earthquake.

Object image caption: Om Bāhāḥ Dune Nani, newly constructed house at the place of the āgãchẽ, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-14
object short description:
The āgãchẽ is located to the north of the sanctum. The dilapidated god house is currently (early 2019) under reconstruction. The estimated budget for the reconstruction is Rs 30 Lakh. 22 Lakha, and the collections raised by local people have already been spent. People are trying to get the remaining funding from the Lalitpur Municipality. The building's carved toraṇa has been preserved in Śraddhāmān Śākya's house. This torana contains an image of Vajrasattva holding a vajra with right hand and a bell with his left hand.

A new building is currently being constructed at this place.

Object image caption: Kṛṣṇa Mandira at Dau Bāhāḥ, statue of Garuḍa, view from S (October 2018)
Kṛṣṇa Mandira at Dau Bāhāḥ, statue of Viṣṇu, view from N (October 2018)
object short description: This image of Viṣṇu is in a standing posture, and has been installed at the northern corner of the sanctum. At the bottom of the image, there is a small image of Garuḍa paying homage to Viṣṇu.

Object image caption: Kṛṣṇa Mandira at Dau Bāhāḥ, Statues of Kṛṣṇa, Rukmiṇī and Satyabhāmā, view from E (October 2018)
object short description: Kṛṣṇa is in the middle playing the flute, with Rukmiṇī to his left and Satyabhāmā to his right, both in the act of dancing. The archaic image was stolen; these images have been newly installed.

Object image caption: Amṛta Hiti, three stone mirrors, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-04-07
Amṛta Hiti, waterspout north, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-03-21
Amṛta Hiti, Śrīdhara Viṣṇu, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-03-21
Amṛta Hiti, waterspout south, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-03-21
Umāmaheśvara Mandira at Cāka Bāhāḥ, close view of Nandī from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-02-09
object short description: A stone statue of Nandī has been placed to the east of the temple. The statue faces towards the sanctum.

Object image caption: Pãmāe Guthichẽ, statue of Viṣṇu (damaged), view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-26
Pãmāe Guthichẽ, statue of Sage Agastya, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-26
Pãmāe Guthichẽ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-26
Pãmāe Guthichẽ, statue of Sage Agastya, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-26
object short description: The statue of sage Agastya sits atop a water pot holding a trident and water pot in his left hands and some beads in his right hand. His other right hand is shown in the process of performing a blessing.

Object image caption: Pãmāe Guthichẽ, statue of Viṣṇu, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-26
Kāyegu Nani, Dharmadhātu Jinālaya caitya, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-12
Kāyegu Nani, Aśoka Caitya, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-12
Kāyegu Nani, Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya in Āgã Nani, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-12
Kāyegu Nani, Dharmadhātu, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-12
object short description: This dharmadhātu is installed in front of the temple, behind the other dharmadhātu.

Object image caption: Kāyegu Nani, Maṅkaḥ Chẽ (community building), view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-12
object short description: This Maṅkā Chẽ was destroyed by the earthquake of 2015, and is currently (2018) under reconstruction. Its previous structure was built in a pagoda style, but in VS 2037 the old structure was deconstructed and rebuilt. The stone inscription dated NS 948 informs the reader that there was a phalcā that on the ground floor of the construction.

Object image caption: Kāyegu Nani, Sarasvatī Shrine, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-12
object short description: This west-facing shrine is situated to the east of the central temple of the nanī. There is an image of Sarasvatī in the middle, and to the right and left of it are images of Gaṇeśa and Mahākāla respectively. Above these images is a construction in a shape of a chatramukha toraṇa. Above the toraṇa, a stūpa stands upon a single pillar. This is a modern construction.

Object image caption: Kāyegu Nani, Dharmadhātu, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-12
Kāyegu Nani, Hāratī Ajimā, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-12
object short description: This statue is installed on the eastern wall of the temple, and is located in a niche at the center of the Kāyegu Nanī.

Object image caption: Kāyegu Nani, Dharmadhātu, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-12
Kāyegu Nani, Gaṇeśa Shrine, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-12
object short description: This south-facing shrine is located in the Cukucā courtyard. Within the shrine is an aniconic stone image that is worshipped as Gaṇeśa.

Object image caption: Kāyegu Nani, Vajra, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-12
Si Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from S (July 2019)
object short description: Bodhisattva images can be found on the eight faces of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala and a vajra has been fixed on top. The dharmadhātu was stolen some years ago. The thieves ran away and threw it into the Pimbāhāḥ pond. It was reestablished after it was retrieved from the water. Now, it is caged inside iron rods for its protection. A metal vajra lies on the western side of the dharmadhātu.

Object image caption: Si Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala with vajra, view from N (July 2019)
object short description: Images of eight Bodhisattvas have been placed on the eight faces of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala. A metal vajra has been fixed on top of the maṇḍala. The vajra is tied to an iron plate to protect it from thieves.

Object image caption: Si Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from E (July 2019)
object short description: The Mahākāla Cheli lies to the south of the esoteric shrine. An east-facing Mahākāla with five heads and four hands resides in the shrine. He is holding khaḍga and kartṛ in his right hands and khaṭvāṅga and kapālapātra in his left hands. Alongside this statue, there are also metal images of Amitābha, Śākyamuni, Mañjuśrī, Nāmasaṅgīti and Vajrasattva. These images were recently installed by a group of women who regularly recite Nāmasaṅgīti in the bāhāḥ. The inscription placed inside the cheli is no longer available.

Object image caption: Si Bāhāḥ, vṛttākāra caitya, view from SE (July 2019)
object short description: This caitya stands on top of a rectangular plinth. A newly added image of Amitābha can be found on the lower part of the western side. Two layers of lotus petals are above this and are topped with images of Buddhas on each of the four directions. Above these images, one can see kumbha, harmikā, trayodaśabhuvana and a parasol. The caitya has been painted in different colours of enamel. Ilā̃ is hanging above the caitya. A deteriorated and completely illegible stone inscription stands on the ground to the west of the caitya.

Object image caption: Jothā Bāhāḥ, Thainā, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-19
object short description: This octagonal maṇḍala has images of the Eight Lokeśvaras in each of the eight directions. It was constructed in Vaiśākha, NS1057.

Object image caption: Jothā Bāhāḥ, statue of donor, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-19
object short description: Towards the east of the śikharakūṭa caitya one can find an statue of a donor. The donor sits on a lotus and is facing west. Śākya (1994, 89) states that this is the statue of Lohaṃmaṇi Āju. There is an inscription behind the statue, which has been carved in the same stone. The lower part of the inscription of NS 793 is broken. Any information about the person who installed it has therefore been lost. However, some text can still be deciphered, telling the reader that images of Amoghapāśa Lokeśvara and Ārya Tārā were installed.

Object image caption: Jothā Bāhāḥ, Thainā, Mahākāla statue, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-19
object short description: To the north of the main entrance of the monastery, one can find an image of Mahākāla attached to the wall. He is holding khaṭvāṅga and katṛ with his two right hands as well as daṇḍa and kapāla with his two left hands.

Object image caption: Jothā Bāhāḥ, Cāka Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-19
object short description: This caitya stands on a small rectangular plinth. It is covered by a vedikā, and contains statues of lokeśvaras at each of the four directions together with toraṇas. Above the statues, one can find a bhaṅgī and above this are images of Dhyānī Buddha, again with toraṇas at each of the four directions. Above this statue, there is one layer of lotus petals, garbhagṛha, harmikā, 13 bhuvanas, pinnacle and chatra.

Object image caption: Khvāya Bahī Cidhaṅgu, Śikharakuṭa Caitya, view from E (January 2020)
Khvāya Bahī Cidhaṅgu, Mahākāla, view from S (January 2020)
Khvāya Bahī Cidhaṅgu, Hanumān, view from S (January 2020)
Khvāya Bahī Cidhaṅgu, Maitreya, view from E (January 2020)
object short description: Maitreya Buddha in a bhaviṣyavyākaraṇa posture. The statue's right hand is performing a gesture of varada (suggesting boon-granting) whilst its left hand performs abhaya (a gesture for the removal of fear).

Object image caption: Sarasvatī Phalcā, statue of Sarasvatī, view from S (January 2019)
object short description: A stone statue of Sarasvatī is attached to the southern wall of the Phalcā. The niche in which she is located is decorated with a carved wooden frame. The four-handed goddess stands with a rosary in her upper right hand whilst her lower right hand performs the varada gesture. She is holding a book and a hook in her upper left and lower left hands respectively.

Object image caption: Dhvākhā Phalcā, māne, view from W (October 2019)
object short description: This prayer wheel (māne) has been installed at the southern corner of the Phalcā and is located to the east.

Object image caption: Sanjyalbādā Devala, memorial pillar, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-03
Sanjyalbādā Devala, northern śikhara, view from south-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-03
object short description: The two āmalaka rings on top of the śikhara are placed directly on top of each other.

Object image caption: Sanjyalbādā Devala, southern śikhara, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-03
Taleju Mandira South, the toraṇa after restoration, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-06-23
object short description: Twelve statues attached to the toraṇa were stolen in the early 1970s. A group of local artists fabricated replicas of all 12 statues based on historic photographs by Bannerjee and Mary Slusser. They were made in the tarditional lost wax casting process and fire-gilt.

Object image caption: Taleju Mandira South, the golden door after restoration, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-06-23
object short description: Missing pieces of the gilt copper cladding were replaced and two new lions, supporting the columns, fabricated. Newly added metal parts were covered with gold leaf rather than fire-gilt.

Object image caption: Taleju Mandira South, Yamunā after restoration, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-06-23
object short description: The water goddess Yamunā guards the shrine's entrance.

Object image caption: Taleju Mandira South, Gaṅgā after restoration, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-06-23
object short description: The water goddess Gaṅgā is standing on her vehicle, the crocodile (makara) in a crossed-leg position. She holds a jvālānhāykã (a mirror) in her left hand whilst performing the gesture of abhaya and holds a lotus flower with her right hand.

Object image caption: Oku Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala 1, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
object short description: The octagonal maṇḍala is surmounted by a vajra. The upper part of the maṇḍala is covered by a brass plate.

Object image caption: Oku Bāhāḥ, stone pillar, view from SE; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
object short description: Before the current one was installed, there was a wooden pillar at this place. In NS 996, Kabibāhāḥ Devaju replaced the worn-out wooden pillar with this stone one. On top of it, he fixed a metal statue of a lion holding a flag.

Object image caption: Oku Bāhāḥ, statue of Lohãmaṇi Āḥju, view from SW; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
object short description: A legend about Lohãmaṇi Āḥju (who is also called Ratnamuni Śākya, and was alive around 300 years ago), a member of Oku Bāhāḥ, has come into the local community. According to this legend, he found a golden jackfruit flowing on the Lũkhusi river, and offered this jackfruit to the Buddha statue at Lagankhel. A small statue of eight-handed Mañjuśrī has been placed in front of the statue of Lohãmaṇi.

Object image caption: Oku Bāhāḥ, Aśoka Caitya, view from NW; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
object short description: This caitya is covered in a gilded metal sheet that runs from the dome to pinnacle. Small prayer wheels surround it.

Object image caption: Oku Bāhāḥ, statue of Lion 1, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
object short description: Two statues of sitting lions were installed in the courtyard of the vihāra. The statues seem to have been heavily influenced by European art. There is no inscription.

Object image caption: Oku Bāhāḥ, Śārdūla statue 1, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
object short description: A pair of statues of śārdūla, donated by Harṣarāja Śākya of Nhū Bāhāḥ, have been installed on either side of the entrance to the sanctum.

Object image caption: Oku Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala 3, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
Oku Bāhāḥ, statue of Prime Minister Juddha Śamśera, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
object short description: This statue of Juddha Śamaśera Rāṇā is located at the western corner of the courtyard. He collected funds for the renovation of the bāhāḥ after it was damaged in the 1934 earthquake.  Śrī 3 Ajarāmaraṇa Mahārāja is inscribed on the belt of the statue; this is the title of Juddha Śamaśera. In his right hand, he holds a metal sheet upon which the words 'aparamitā dhāraṇī' have been inscribed.

Object image caption: Oku Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala 2, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
object short description: The octagonal Maṇḍala is surmounted by a vajra.

Object image caption: Oku Bāhāḥ, Aṣṭakoṇākṛti Caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
object short description: The upper part of the caitya (above the vedikā) is constructed in an octagonal shape and contains images of Bodhisattva. A nāga and a row of lotus petals have been placed on top of it. There are statues of Buddha at each of the four sides, and images of Tārā have also been placed above the row of lotus petals.

Object image caption: Oku Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
object short description: Two-armed Mahākāla holding kartṛ, kapālapātra and khaṭvāṅga. This statue was installed at the south-east corner of the Mahākāla Phalcā.

Object image caption: Oku Bāhāḥ, Bvasala statue 1, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
object short description: A pair of statues of standing horses with a horn donated by Īśvararāja Śākya. These were installed on either side of the entrance to the sanctum.

Object image caption: Oku Bāhāḥ, Garuḍa statue 1, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
object short description: Two statues of sitting Garuḍas donated by Śubharatna Śākya of Oku Bāhāḥ. These were installed on either side of the entrance to the sanctum.

Object image caption: Bhurtī Ekledevala 3, stone lion, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
object short description:
This stone lion, found lying in the ground near the temple, may have been installed on top of a temple's pediment, or in front of a door.

It evokes similar sculptures placed on temples' pediments in Uttarakhand.

It was visibly 'repaired' with cement.

Object image caption: Junbesi Manor, traditional gate, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-05-02

Object name: Bhurtī group of three śikharas, central śikhara
Object image caption: Bhurtī group of three śikharas, central śikhara, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
object short description: Markings in red indicate that the temple was dismantled and rebuilt. Cement seems to have been used as mortar.

Object name: Bhurtī group of three śikharas, southern śikhara
Object image caption: Bhurtī group of three śikharas, southern śikhara, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24

Object name: Bhurtī group of three śikharas, northern śikhara
Object image caption: Bhurtī group of three śikharas, northern śikhara, view from south-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
Agnimaṭha, aniconic stones worshipped as Gaṇeśa, Siddhilakṣmī and Kumārī, view from E (September 2019)
Agnimaṭha, Viśvakarmā shrine, view from S (September 2019)
object short description: A Viśvakarmā shrine has been established to the north of Agnimaṭha. There is no statue in it, only an empty niche.

Object image caption: Agnimaṭha, residence of the priest (agnihotṛnivāsa), view from E (September 2019)
object short description: There is a two-storied Agnihotrī Nivāsa (house of Agnihotrī) to the west of the Agnimaṭha premises. This house was built during the time of Visvajvālānanda Rājopādhyāya (Śreṣṭha 2013, 13) for Agnihotrī Brahmin couples. However, since it was impractical for couples to leave their own house and live in the Nivāsa it was used to house them only whilst they performed the daily worship. Nowadays, the Nivāsa is used during some special worships, feasts and other religious activities.

Object image caption: Agnimaṭha, Varūṇa tree, view from S (September 2019)
object short description: A Varūṇa tree is a tree that grew from a stick that was buried by Brahmins who were on their way from Maṇicūḍa to perform fire rituals. Among the 14 Varūṇa trees in the maṭha's premises, one of them has grown out of the Maṭha wall. Although the tree obstructs the way, it is believed that it shoud not be cut at all. Passerbys must therefore make their way around the tree. A legend tells that during the Rana period a Rana arrived on a horse and was frustrated by the tree. As such, he made someone cut it. However, the khukūrī which was used to cut it broke and blood began to pour out of the tree. After a week, both the Rana and the person who atempted to cut the tree passed away. Since then, the tree has been left in peace. The priests of the Maṭha claim that the tree is 4,500 years old (Śreṣṭha B.  2007, 27). Every year, the trees flower and produce amalā sized fruits. It is belived that Brahmins would once accept the fruit and meditate for many months.

Object image caption: Agnimaṭha, jaḥrũhiti, view from E (September 2019)
object short description: There is an unused jahṛũhiti in front of the main entrance of Agnimaṭha. The hiti displays images of the sun-moon, snakes and fire. Previously the water from the hiti was used for worship and cleaning the maṭha. In 1964, however, the municipality provided a water tank for the maṭha and the hiti fell into disuse.

Object image caption: Śvetabhairava Mandira, domed Bhairava shrine, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-10-21
object short description: Domed Bhairava shrine at the southeastern side of the Śvetabhairava Temple at Ikhalakhu with a Bhairava painting believed to be a replica of Ṭīkābhairava, with three stone lotuses in the threshold and a lotus pattern in the ceiling. All portals at the sides are closed with stone imitations.

Object image caption: Śvetabhairava Temple, statue of Umāmaheśvara placed outside the temple; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-10-21
object short description: A small statue of Umāmaheśvara at the northwestern side of the Śvetabhairava temple. The inscription indicates that it was donated by Siddhirājadeva.

Object image caption: Śvetabhairava Temple, mhdana vanegu figure for prostrations in front of the southern side temple, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-10-21
object short description: Stretched anthropomorphic figure on the ground for prostrations

Object image caption: Śvetabhairava Mandira, Śivaliṅga attached to the temple, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-10-21
object short description: Stone liṅga in the ground at the northern side of the Śvetabhairava Temple

Object image caption: Śvetabhairava Mandira, Kumārī stone in the ground of the domed Bhairava shrine; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-10-21
Ālko Gaṇeśa Mandira, Gaṇeśa statue in the sanctum, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-04-07
Ālko Gaṇeśa Mandira, aniconic stone, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-04-07
Ālko Gaṇeśa Mandira, aniconic stone, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-04-07
Ālko Gaṇeśa Mandira, Nandī statue (bull), view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-04-07
Ālko Gaṇeśa Mandira, Durgā statue, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-04-07
Ālko Gaṇeśa Mandira, aniconic stone, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-04-07
Mahālakṣmī Mandira, statue of Lion (A), view from NE; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-11
Mahālakṣmī Mandira, statue of donors, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-11
Mahālakṣmī Mandira, bell (A), view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-11
Mahālakṣmī Mandira, stone toraṇa above the door, view from S; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-11
Mahālakṣmī Mandira, bell (C), view from S; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-11
Mahālakṣmī Mandira, Mahālakṣmī Shrine, view from S; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-11
