Mahālakṣmī Mandira, Lion (C), view from SW; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-11
Mahālakṣmī Mandira, bell (B), view from S; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-11
Haugaḥ Ganedyaḥ Phalcā, Gaṇeśa shrine, view from S (July 2019)
object short description:
The shrine is located inside the Phalcā. It remains unclear whether the Phalcā and the shrine were constructed at the same time or if the shrine was added at a later date. Inside the shrine, an image of Gaṇeśa indicates that he is the main deity. Two brass images of rats can be found in front of this statue. 

Gaṇeśa is sitting in a sukhāsana posture on top of a mouse. He is holding an axe and laḍḍu with his left hands. One of his right hands holds a radish whilst the other one holds akṣamālā.

Above the image are two brass plate toraṇas.

Object image caption: Haugaḥ Ganedyaḥ Phalcā, aniconic stones of Bhairava, view from S (July 2019)
object short description: Three aniconic stones are located at the rear wall of the Phalcā and are worshipped as Bhairava.

Object image caption: Haugaḥ Ganedyaḥ Phalcā, jarũhiti, view from W (July 2019)
object short description: There is a stone Jarũhiti attached to the western wall of the Phalcā. According to Furukawa/Shrestha/Bajracharya and Ogasawara 2010 (p. 121) this was built in the Malla period. Though the community cleaned and repaired the system in the 2000s, it is no longer in use because of its piped water system and water tanks. One stone inscription can be found on top of the structure. The inscription mentions its construction and the establishment of a guthi. Dãju Bhāro and Rājakarṇikāra Cikidhikala Bhāro facilitated the hiti and also donated land to fund it. The inscription also mentions the necessity of giving paddy (45 Pāthis) to a person who fills up the water in the Jarũhiti on a daily basis.

Object image caption: Āna Bāhāḥ, Mañjuśrī Pādukā, view from E (June 2020)
object short description: This Mañjuśrī Pādukā (feet of Mañjuśrī) has been established to the east of the Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala. The name of the donor is not recorded, but according to the locals, Viśvavajra Vajrācārya established it. The donor has arranged to celebrate the anniversary worship of this Pādukā on the 8th day of the bright fortnight of Kārttika on the day of death of his mother Gyana Thakuṃ.

Object image caption: Āna Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from E (June 2020)
object short description: Viśvavajra Vajrācārya and his family established this Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala. The anniversary worship of the Maṇḍala is performed every year on the 8th day of the bright fortnight of Kārttika.

Object image caption: Āna Bāhāḥ, Aśoka Caitya, view from NE (June 2020)
object short description: Built on a brick plinth, this Caitya has four Buddhas in four directions. Eight auspicious symbols have been made with cement on its plinth.

Object image caption: Āna Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from E (June 2020)
object short description: Statue of Gaṇeśa placed to the left of the entrance.

Object image caption: Āna Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya in the sanctum, view from E (June 2020)
object short description: This stone statue of Akṣobhya faces east. Locke (1985, 50) erroneously states that Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara is placed in the sanctum.

Object image caption: Āna Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from E (June 2020)
object short description: Statue of Mahākāla placed to the right of the entrance.

Object image caption: Puṇyacandra Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S (June 2019)
Lvahã Hiti, statue of Umāmaheśvara, view from NW; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-11
Lvahã Hiti, water spout, view from NW; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-11
Yampi Mahāvihāra, Akṣobhya Buddha on the north side of main deity, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-11
object short description: To the right of the image of gandhuri dyaḥ is a room with an image of Akṣobhya Buddha inside it. Local inhabitants consider this to be a separate monastery.

Object image caption: Yampi Mahāvihāra, Śikharakūṭa caitya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-11
object short description: This caitya is situated in front of the image of kvapādyaḥ of the bahī. There are images of four bodhisattvas in each of the four directions. On the western side is an image of Padmapāṇi, who is flanked by his śaktis. In the upper part of the caitya one can find images of Dhyānī Buddhas which have been newly installed by Lākhecā from Oku Bāhāḥla. These have replaced the old images of Buddha. The part above the chatrāvalī is not available in this caitya. There is an oil-lamp balustrade surrounding the caitya. Hodgson has sketched this caitya (see in Losty, 2004, 93).

Object image caption: Yampi Mahāvihāra, temple of Āryāvalokiteśvara, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-11
object short description: Inside the temple there is an image of standing Āryāvalokiteśvara with two hands facing north. The upper part of the temple is bell-shaped. An oil-lamp balustrade surrounds the temple.

Object image caption: Yampi Mahāvihāra, Amitābha statue on the south side of the main deity, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-11
object short description: To the left of the image of gandhuri dyaḥ is a room which contains an image of Amitābha Buddha. Local inhabitants consider this to be a separate monastery.

Object image caption: Yampi Mahāvihāra, statue of Sunayaśrī Miśra (the founder of the Vihāra), view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-11
object short description: Every year in the month of guṃlā, the historical materials of the bahī are exhibited. To the south of the main sanctum of the monastery, a seat (salaṃśā) is made and a statue of Sunayaśrī Miśra, the founder of the Vihāra, is placed on it. He is worshipped as Ṣaṭakoṭī Āju (Khatāṃ Āju). Some of the legends tell us that his name is linked to the story that he once earned six crore ‘karoḍa’ (sixty million) rupees.

Object image caption: Yampi Mahāvihāra, Mahākāla statue, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-11
object short description: To the left of the main entrance of the bahī is an image of Mahākāla. This image has been installed recently (writing in 2018). The archaic image of Mahākāla has been placed in a small room which lies behind this image.

Object image caption: Yampi Mahāvihāra, shrine of Amoghapāśa Lokeśvara, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-11
object short description: Inside the sanctum of the shrine, one can find an image of Amoghapāśa Lokeśvara with eight hands facing west. There are false doors in the northern, eastern and southern walls. In the upper part of the caitya one can find images of Dhyānī Buddha. The part above the chatrāvalī is not available in this caitya. An oil-lamp balustrade surrounds it.

Object image caption: Nāsaḥ Chẽ, Nāsaḥdyaḥ represented by three wall niches in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi: 2021-06-13
Nāsaḥ Chẽ, Hiphaḥdyaḥ shrine, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi: 2021-07-03
Dhana Bāhāḥ, bell, view from S (June 2019)
object short description: There is no inscription on the bell. The bell stand was in a dilapitated state and was replaced by a newer one in 1921 (NS 1041).

Object image caption: Dhana Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from N (June 2019)
object short description: This octagonal dharmadhātu maṇḍala is located towards the east of the śikharakūṭa caitya. Eight Bodhisatvas stand in the eight faces of the maṇḍala. At some point, an oil lamp balustrade was built around the maṇḍala; this has covered the inscription.

Object image caption: Dhana Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from W (June 2019)
Śākyamuṇi Buddha Shrine, Statue of Śākyamuṇi, view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 20210531
Cī Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-12
object short description: This image of a standing Gaṇeśa with four arms shows the deity holding a garland and a radish in his right hands and an axe and a sweet ball in his left hands. The image is located on the west side of the main shrine of the vihāra.

Object image caption: Cī Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of Nārāyaṇa, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-12
object short description: This image of Nārāyaṇa is located on the eastern wall of the vihāra. He is holding a wheel and a lotus (padma) in his two right hands and a club (gadā) and conch in his two left hands.

Object image caption: Cī Bāhāḥ Nani, Vajradhara, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-12
object short description: Vajradhara is located on the eastern wall of the vihāra. In Vajrayāna, the First Buddha (Ādibuddha) is regarded as the highest deity, the origin of even the Five Dhyāni Buddhas. When represented in human form, he takes the name Vajradhara. He has six-arms. His two main hands are crossed against his chest in the gesture of vajrahuṅkāra mudrā, holding a vajra and a bell. Two additional right hands hold a sword and a noose and two left hands are broken. However, one can presume that, in line with this iconography, he would have been carrying a kapāla and a noose in these hands (Bhattacharyya 1958, 44).

Object image caption: Cī Bāhāḥ Nani, Mahākāla, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-12
object short description: Mahākāla is placed on the west side of the main shrine of the vihāra. He is holding a kartṛ (chopper) in his right hand and a kapāla (skull bowl) in his left hand, which also clasps khaṭvāṅga.

Object image caption: Cī Bāhāḥ Nani, Mañjuśrī, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-12
object short description: The four-armed standing Mañjuśrī is located to the east of the main shrine. His two main hands are held in dharmacakra mudra, whilst two additional hands hold a rosary and the scripture of Prajñāpāramitā. Local people worship this as Sarasvatī. The face is covered by thick layers of vermillion powder.

Object image caption: Cī Bāhāḥ Nani, Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-12
object short description: Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara is located to the west of the main shrine of the vihāra. The statue's right hand is in varada gesture whilst his left hand holds the stem of a blossoming lotus flower.

Object image caption: Cī Bāhāḥ Nani, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-12
object short description: This caitya is different from other śikharakūṭa caityas. Statues of stone lions have been placed on the four corners of the vedi together with motifs. On the eastern side, an image of Akṣobhaya can be found together with devotees and elephants. The southern side of the vedi has an image of Akṣobhaya with horses to his left and right. Motifs of leaves have been placed on top of the Buddha image. Conventionally, Prajñāpāramitā is placed on the right-hand side and Lokeśvara on the left-hand side of the Buddha, but here their positions have been reversed. Images of peacocks also flank Akṣobhaya, and a decorative toraṇa made of stone has been placed above him. On the nothern side of the vedi, an image of a water vessel is surrounded by serpants with Garuḍas placed to its left and right. There are many cracks on the caitya and cement mortar has been applied to repair them.

Object image caption: Pālu Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from N (June 2019)
object short description: This statue is attached to the southern wall of the sataḥ. Mahākāla has five heads and four hands; he holds a khaḍga and a kartṛ in his right hands and a khaṭvāṅga and kapālapātra in his left hands.

Object image caption: Pālu Bāhāḥ, statue of Hanumān, view from W (June 2019)
object short description: This shrine is on the eastern wall of the sattaḥ, which is located to the east of the god-house (dyaḥchẽ).

Object image caption: Pālu Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from E (June 2019)
Pālu Bāhāḥ, vajradhātu caitya, view from N (June 2019)
object short description: Buddha statues are placed at each of the four cardinal directions. An ilā̃ has been fixed above the caitya.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ, Vasundharā, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
object short description: Bhīmarāja, Buramāyā, Āśākājī, Sānubhāī, and other family members jointly established the statue of Vasundharā.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of Vairocana, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-28
object short description: Āśākājī, his wife Kulamāyā, and their eldest son Hemarāja constructed this Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, Amoghapāśa Lokeśvara Degaḥ, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-29
object short description:
There are no documented evidences to appoint the initial construction of this temple. However, according to the locals, it was built by Nhucchevīra Śākya about a century ago. His youngest son carries out the daily worshiping in this temple.

A caitya had been established in the temple as a pinnacle. There are erotic carvings at the bottom of the struts. The doorway is crowned with a wooden toraṇa, depicting Vajrasattva at its center. A statue of Amoghapāśa Lokeśvara had been installed inside the sanctum. A new statue was established a few years ago after the old statue of Amoghapāśa Lokeśvara was stolen. A statue of Padmapāṇi is also established in front of Amoghapāśa Lokeśvara.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-28
object short description: This octagonal Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala has no images of the eight Lokeśvaras on any of its eight sides. Upper part of the Dharmadhātu Maṇdala is covered with carved copper plates.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, Nāmasaṅgīti, view from S; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
object short description: Bhīmarāja, Buramāyā, Āśākājī, Sānubhāī, and other family members jointly established the statue of Nāmasṅgīti.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, Hyāũ Cibhāḥ, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
object short description: Initially, this Caitya was painted in red, and for this reason, it is called Hyāũ Cibhāḥ. In the womb of this Caitya, there are no statues in three directions, however, a statue of Vairocana is placed on its western side. Every year on the tenth day of the dark fortnight of Pauṣa, the annual worship (varṣavardhana) of Hyāũ Cibhāḥ is performed. On that day, another brass caitya used to be displayed at the south of the main Caitya, however, this tradition has been stopped for the past few years.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of Mahāmañjuśrī, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
object short description: The statue of Mahāmañjuśrī was installed by Harṣarāja, his wife Canamāyā, and other family members during the renovation of the shrine of Gaṇeśa and Mahākāla.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of Ratnasambhava, view from S; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-28
Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of Amitābha, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of Mahākāla, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
object short description: Every year on the first day of the dark fortnight of Phāguna, sanāḥguthi is observed and Mahākāla is worshiped with ornaments.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
object short description: This statue was established and worshipped as kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ before the enlargement of the Śikharakūṭa Caitya. After the Caitya was renovated and enlarged, a bigger statue was established as kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ and this original statue was shifted to its present-day place.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, vajra, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-28
object short description: The vajra was donated by Herā Bahādur.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-28
Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
object short description: Tuyisĩ, his wife Puṇamāyā, and other family members constructed this Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of Amoghasiddhi, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, Dabū, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, Pañcāvaliyukta Caitya, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
object short description: This Caitya was constructed by Bhīmarāja, Buramāyā, Āśākājī, Sānubhāī, and other family members.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of Donors, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
object short description: Names of the donors are not clear as the inscription has been eroded. The locals call them Tavadhika Āḥju and his wife.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
object short description: Every year on the first day of dark fortnight of Āśvina, Gaṇeśa Guṭhī is celebrated worshipping the Gaṇeśa statue. On that day, another golden statue of Gaṇeśa is displayed in front of this statue of Gaṇeśa and the members of the Guṭhī stay awake all night.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-25
object short description: Akṣobhya is worshiped as the kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ of Śikharakūṭa Caitya, but this is not the original kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ. Following the renovation and enlargement of the Caitya, the original statue (LAL0520-008) was relocated to the north of new kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ. The statue was gilded in 1826 CE (NS 946).

Object image caption:
Naḥ Bāhāḥ Nani, statue of a Donor, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-28

LAL0520-007
object short description: This donor is called Vajradhara. Both hands of the statue are broken.

Object image caption: Manakāmanā Mandira at Mū Nani, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from E (October 2019)
object short description: This caitya was made by Aṣṭādeva and his wife in 1709 CE.

Object image caption: Manakāmanā Mandira at Mū Nani, statues of Lundekunde Bhairava and Ajimā (December 2019)
object short description: The statues are placed inside the āgama of the temple. On the 9th day of the Dashain, these deities are taken to the Hayagrīva Bhairava temple. Over the following two days a procession takes place within which the deities are carried on cots.

Object image caption: Pilāchẽ Taḥdhaṃ Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-04
object short description: Like other standard dharmadhātus, this structure has an octagonal form and contains eight bodhisattva statues. There is a vajra above this Dharmadhātu. It has been covered with iron rods for its protection.

Object image caption: Pilāchẽ Taḥdhaṃ Bāhāḥ,Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-04
object short description: The plinth above the platform of the Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya contains four Bodhisattvas facing in each of the four directions and has guardian lions on the edges. Four Dhyanī Buddhas have been placed above the lotus throne (padmāsana). Akṣhobya’s statue is flanked by two elephants with Viḍārāja in the middle facing east. Mayura and Caityarāja also flank Amitābha’s statue and face west. The Amoghasiddhi statue shows Garuḍa and Dhvajarāja facing north, while Ratnasambhava’s statue also includes horses and Khaḍgarāja facing south. Above the ground level and the two layers of lotus throne one can find the primary trio of a drum, a dome and a finial with ilã.

Object image caption: Mahādyaḥ Degaḥ, main Śivaliṅga in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-13
Mahādyaḥ Degaḥ, Nandī in front of the Temple, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-13
Mahādyaḥ Degaḥ, additional Śivaliṅga installed on the southeast corner of the sanctum, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-13
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Gaṇeśa shrine, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-27
Gaṇeśa Mandira, a pair of lions, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-27
Gaṇeśa Phalcā, horns of a buffalo, view from E (September 2019)
object short description: A pair of buffalo horns are attached to the Phalcā wall. Horns of sacrificed buffalo can be seen in many temples, especially in the shrines of Nāsaḥdyaḥ, and Śākta temples.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Phalcā, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from E (September 2019)
object short description: This statue of a four-handed Gaṇeśa is sitting in the ardhaparyaṅka posture (a half cross-legged position) and wearing a snake as jewelry. He is holding an axe in his upper left hand. His lower left hand is broken and the weapons held in his remaining hands are not identifiable.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Phalcā, statue of Mahākāla, view from E (September 2019)
object short description: This is a statue of a four-handed Mahākāla. The deity is shown standing in the pratyālīḍha posture (with his left foot forward and his right foot behind), and holding kartikā and a skull in his lower hands. The deity's upper left arm is holding khaṭvāṅga, while the weapon of the upper right hand is not clear.

Object image caption: Hāṭa Gāũ, western structure, view from north; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-08
object short description: The walls of the structure are built with various medieval architectural elements, such as a carved frieze with circles and losanges. On the foreground is the base of a pillar that must have been part of a pavilion.

Object image caption: Hāṭa Gāũ, stone Nandi 005, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-08
object short description: The head of the statue is missing and the back is damaged. The head was broken a certain time ago, as indicated by the advanced erosion of the neck.

Object image caption: Hāṭa Gāũ, stone lion 003, view from north-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-08
object short description:
The statue is damaged in multiple parts.

The statue must date from circa 14th century.

Object image caption: Hāṭa Gāũ, eastern structure, view from north-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-08
Hāṭa Gāũ, stone lion 004, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-08
object short description: The legs of the statue are missing and the face is damaged. These damages are old.

Object image caption: Karuṇāmaya Mandira, stone pillar (A), view from SE (November 2019)
object short description: This stone pillar is one of three pillars located in front of the temple. According to local elders, statues of King Narendradeva, Ācārya Bandhudatta and a Jyāpu used to be displayed on top of the lotus pedestals on the first day of every solar month. However, the tradition ended about three decades ago.

Object image caption: Karuṇāmaya Mandira, Buṅgadyaḥ, view from N (October 2019)
object short description:
The photo was taken in the temporary shrine (BUN0003), where Buṅgadyaḥ has been housed since the collapse of the Karuṇāmaya Temple.

Buṅgadyaḥ is kept in Buṅgamatī for six months a year; during the other six months he dwells in the esoteric shrine of Taḥ Bāhāḥ (LAL0050). Patan’s greatest festival occurs when this god is brought out in a chariot on the full moon day of Vaiśākha. The procession ends up in Jawalakhel.

The chariot procession was started to celebrate the arrival of Buṅga Dyaḥ in Nepal and the end of a devastating drought. Ā. Vajrācārya (1985, 84) mentions that Śubhaśrī Mitra of Karuṇācuka Bahī (LAL1560) made the statue, which is why the monastic building is named after the deity. A Tibetan monk called Dharmasvāmin who stayed in the monastery of Svayambhū (Phags-pa Sin-kun) of the Valley around 1226-34 mentions a miraculous image of Avalokiteśvara which was made of sandalwood painted in a red colour (Regmī 1965, 559-560). The present statue of the deity is made of two different elements; the head is made from clay while the rest of the body is made from metal. The terracotta is painted every year before the deity is placed on the chariot.

Object image caption: Karuṇāmaya Mandira, Patĩgāḥ, view from N (November 2019)
object short description: This 3 ft deep pit is called Patĩgāḥ and contains many aniconic stone images. Local lore suggests that 33 koṭi (330 million) gods dwell inside the pit. Locals believe that women should not go down to the pit.

Object image caption: Karuṇāmaya Mandira, stone pillar (B), view from S (November 2019)
object short description: This stone pillar is one of three pillars located in front of the temple. According to local elders, statues of King Narendradeva, Ācārya Bandhudatta and a Jyāpu used to be displayed on top of the lotus pedestals on the first day of every solar month. However, the tradition ended about three decades ago.

Object image caption: Karuṇāmaya Mandira, stone pillar (C), view from S (November 2019)
object short description: This stone pillar is one of three pillars located in front of the temple. According to local elders, statues of King Narendradeva, Ācārya Bandhudatta and a Jyāpu used to be displayed on top of the lotus pedestals on the first day of every solar month. However, the tradition ended about three decades ago.

Object image caption: Karuṇāmaya Mandira, Vajrasattva pillar, view from S (November 2019)
Karuṇāmaya Mandira, Dharmastambha, view from S (November 2019)
object short description: This stone pillar was erected in 1951 (VS 2008) by Guru Kavi Prasada after a one-week long religious event (saptāha bhajana) in Bungmati. He erected a similar pillar in the same year in Sunaguṭhī in front of Mahākāla Mandira (SUN0200).

Object image caption: Jāhārkoṭa stone memorial pillars, pillar 001, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-27
object short description: The right side of the pillar, less eroded, is the base, which was originally buried in the ground.

Object image caption: Jāhārkoṭa stone memorial pillars, pillar 002, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-27
object short description: This pillar seems to be very damaged. It is completely buried in the rubbles resulting from the road construction. Only the top part of the pillar can be seen.

Object image caption: Khaḍgayoginī Mandira, Licchavi Caitya, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-02
object short description: This Licchavi Caitya (see upper part of the Caitya painted in golden colour) is kept above the dome of a recently built caitya.

Object image caption: Khaḍgayoginī Mandira, Maitreyagarbha Caitya, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-02
object short description: This Caitya is named Maitreyagarbha by Śākya  (1995,75) and was renovated in NS 998 (1878 CE).

Object image caption: Khaḍgayoginī Mandira, statue of Khaḍgayoginī, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-02
object short description: This mud made statue is recently enshrined after the original one got stolen in VS 2036 (1979 CE). If it needs to be repaired or rebuilt, one may do so only using mud brought from Mhaypi, Kathmandu.

Object image caption: Khaḍgayoginī Mandira, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-02
Khaḍgayoginī Mandira, statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-02
object short description: Vajrapāṇi Lokeśvara is standing in the samapāda position with a lotus stalk on his left hand.

Object image caption: Khaḍgayoginī Mandira, Caitya, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-02
Khaḍgayoginī Mandira, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-02
Ārīthāy Dhvākhā Phalcā, lion (B) at the eastern side of the entrance, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-10
Ārīthāy Dhvākhā Phalcā, lion (A) at the western side of the entrance, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-10
Dvārikā Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from NW  (August 2019)
object short description: This caitya is located to the west of the monastic building and contains images of Bodhisattva and Buddha. Above these image are two layers of lotus petals, garbha, harmikā, and 13 bhuvanas. This caitya is slightly damaged and the images of Buddha have deteriorated. Cement plaster has been used to attach the garbha, the harmikā and many other parts.

Object image caption: Bhurtī Duidevala, southern śikhara, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
object short description: A small stone block is missing from the pediment.

Object image caption: Bhurtī Duidevala, northern śikhara, view from south-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
Digichẽ at Ī Bahī; stone statue of Chvāsakaminī (January 2019)
object short description: The statue is installed in a small room on the west side of the ground floor. The caretaker does not allow entry to the building.

Object image caption: Devajyoti Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from NW (October 2019)
object short description: This Maṇḍala was established at the same time as the Bāhāḥ. The usual Bodhisattva images are missing from its eight faces.

Object image caption: Devajyoti Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from E (October 2019)
object short description: This Caitya was established in 1889 alongside the Bāhāḥ. It shows four Bodhisattvas sitting on top of a lotus flower in each of the four directions.

Object image caption: Ghāṭa Pillars, western side of pillar 006, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description: The artefact is located in front of the school. Two meters north of it is MUG0050-006.

Object image caption: Ghāṭa Pillars, pillar 003, view from top; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description:
The pillar is broken in two parts. It presents an unfinished look, unless it is merely the effect of erosion.

The upper section contains a circle with a star shape inside (viśvajra?).

The artefact is laying on the ground in front of a house.

Object image caption: Ghāṭa Pillars, eastern side of pillar 007, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
Ghāṭa Pillars, pillar 002, view from top; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description:
This was the base of a large memorial pillar.

The artefact is laying on the ground in front of a house.

Object image caption: Ghāṭa Pillars, eastern side of pillar 009, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description: The pillar is broken. The upper part is missing.

Object image caption: Ghāṭa Pillars, eastern side of pillar 010, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description:
The upper part of the pillar contains a star shape motif inside of a circle. Below is one horizontal wavy pattern.

The central part seems to contain 3 lines of inscription.

Object image caption: Ghāṭa Pillars, eastern side of pillar 012, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description:
The upper part of the pillar contains a star shape motif inside of a circle. Below is one horizontal wavy pattern.

The central part seems to contain 4 lines of inscription.

The base of the pillar has carvings of a pyramidal shape and wavy pattern

Object image caption: Ghāṭa Pillars, eastern side of pillar 013, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description:
The upper part of the pillar contains a star shape motif inside of a circle. 

The central part contains 6 lines of inscription.

Object image caption: Ghāṭa Pillars, eastern side of pillar 008, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
Ghāṭa Pillars, eastern side of pillar 011, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description:
The upper part of the pillar contains a star shape motif inside of a circle. Below are two horizontal wavy pattern.

The central part seems to contain 4 lines of inscription.

Object image caption: Ghāṭa Pillars, pillar 001, view from top; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description:
This is most likely the back face of the pillar.

The artefact is laying on the ground in front of a house.

Object image caption: Ghāṭa Pillars, eastern side of pillar 005, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description:
The upper register is occupied by carved motifs. On top is a star inside a circle, below it is a quatrefoil. The latter could be a double vajra (viśvavajra), which would thus indicate the Buddhist affiliation of the person for whom the pillar was erected.

The central part of the pillar contains a inscription of nine lines in Devanāgarī script.

The artefact is located in front of the school. Two meters north of it is MUG0050-006.

Object image caption: Ghāṭa Pillars, pillar 004, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description: The pillar had fallen from its original position during a landslide. Since 2014 the whereabouts of this artefact are unknown.

Object image caption: Hitiphusa Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from N (June 2019)
object short description: The upper part of the Caitya above the vedī appears slightly different from other vajradhātu caityas; here, one can see a vajra motif flanked by two elephants, the vehicles of Akṣobhya. On the southern side, there is a jewel motif flanked by horses, which are the vehicles of Ratnasambhava. The western side displays a lotus flower motif flanked by peacocks, the vehicles of Amitābha, whilst the northern face has a sculpted viṣvavajra flanked by Garuḍa, the vehicle of Amoghasiddhi. An oil lamp balustrade surrounds the caitya and an ilā̃, supported by four iron rods, hangs above it.

Object image caption: Hitiphusa Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from E (June 2019)
Hitiphusa Bāhāḥ, Bimba Caitya, view from E (June 2019)
object short description: The plinths of this Caitya have been plastered in cement. The kumbha stands above the two-layered lotus petals, and the trayodaśabhuvana section seems a bit smaller than the kumbha. Cement has been used to join different parts together, and the upper part is slightly slanted.

Object image caption: Hitiphusa Bāhāḥ, image of Mahākāla together with the toraṇa, view from W (June 2019)
object short description: A statue of a four-headed and four-handed Mahākāla has been attached to the wall to the east of the main entrance of the bāhāḥ. He is holding khaḍga and kartṛ in his two right hands and khaṭvāṅga and kapālapātra in his two left hands.

Object image caption: Śiva Mandira, Nandī statue, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śiva Mandira, Śivaliṅga in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Puncali Phalcā, Umāmaheśvara, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-05-12
object short description: Unlike the ancient and medieval statues of Umā-Maheśvara, Gaṅgā and attendants of Shiva are not present in it. There are no inscriptions on the statue. Statues of a donor couple are sculpted at the bottom. Relying upon its structure it can be dated to the Rana period or even later.

Object image caption: Kumārī Pāṭī, statue of the donors, view from SE; photo by Matthias Arnold; 2019-10-13
object short description: Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara is located on top. Figurines of Gomatī, as well as her three sons and her husband, are depicted in seated positions on the lower row.

Object image caption: Kumārī Pāṭī, ritual stone, view from SW; photo by Matthias Arnold; 2019-10-13
object short description: When Buṅgadyaḥ is taken to Patan for his chariot procession, his cot makes a brief stop here. The chariot procession of Buṅgadyaḥ starts from Bungamati once every 12 years. When this happens, the procession ends here.

Object image caption: Kumārī Pāṭī, shrine of Kṛṣṇa, view from SW; photo by Matthias Arnold; 2019-10-13
Kumārī Pāṭī, aniconic stones, view from SE; photo by Matthias Arnold; 2019-10-13
Bāghabhairava Mandira, statue of lion (A), view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-06
Bāghabhairava Mandira, Nāsaḥdyaḥ Shrine, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-06
Bāghabhairava Mandira, painting of the statue of Bāghabhairava, view from E; paint by Candra Maharjana; 2012-00-00
object short description:
There is a popular folk tale about the statue of Bāghabhairava in Kirtipur. 

According to the tale, while some shepherd children were grazing their sheeps in the jungle on the northern slope of Kirtipur, they were sculpting a figure of a tiger out of clay. When the figure was finished, the children went in search of a suitable leaf to use for the tiger's tongue.  However, surprisingly, when they returned with the leaf, their sheeps were missing. They wept and wailed and asked the people in the vicinity if they had seen their sheeps but no one could locate them. They guessed that the sheeps must have been eaten by the clay tiger, so they questioned him. In reply, he wide opened his mouth and the children saw that it was covered with blood. The children were angry with the tiger and decided not to fix the leaf-tongue in his mouth. Therefore, the statue of Bāghabhairava has no tongue and its mouth is wide open.

Inside the sanctum, there is a big safe box in which a small statue of Bāghabhairava (made of clay) is concealed. Locals strongly believe that this little statue of clay was sculpted by the shepherd children.

The front part of the statue is wrapped with silver, while its lower part is sculpted out of clay. In order to restore or resculpt the statue, clays from eight different places must be mixed. Seven out of eight places are in and around Kirtipur and one is Mhaipi (Kathmandu). The most recent resculpting of the statue was in 2013 CE.

Object image caption: Bāghabhairava Mandira, bell (B), view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-06
Bāghabhairava Mandira, statue of Hanumān (B), view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-06
Bāghabhairava Mandira, various weapons hanging on the upper part of the façade, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-06
object short description: Helmets and various metal weapons are displayed on the upper storey of the temple. It is believed that these weapons were seized by the Gorkhali army during their first attack in Kirtipur. It is said that one of these helmets was used by Kālu Pā̃ḍe, a renowned commander of the Gorkhali army.

Object image caption: Bāghabhairava Mandira, traditional wall painting on the lower wall, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-06
object short description: The historic frescos cover the walls of the temple. Amātya (1974, 41) suggests that these frescos are from the late Malla period. They do not only depict individual deities such as Aṣṭabhairava, Candra, Sūrya, Gaṇeśa, Śiva, Aṣṭamātṛkās, and so forth, but also the battle-scenes between the gods and the demons (cf. Ś. Śṛeṣṭha, 1994, 191).

Object image caption: Bāghabhairava Mandira, statue of lion (B), view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-06
Bāghabhairava Mandira, bell (A), view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-06
Bāghabhairava Mandira, Hiphaḥdyaḥ Shrine, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-06
object short description: This sacrificial shrine is locally known as Hiphaḥdyaḥ. The animal sacrifices offered to Bāghabhairava take place in front of this shrine. Two historic toraṇas (one made out of wood and another crafted on stone) are preserved in this shrine. The wooden toraṇa kept above the shrine is an exceptionally fine example of the Newar craftsmanship. It was installed by a local guṭhī in 1662 CE and it depicts the images of various deities such as Aṣṭamātṛkās, Aṣṭabhairava, Viṣṇu sitting on the Garuḍa, Nāgakanyās, Gaṇeśa, Kumāra, and so forth.

Object image caption: Bāghabhairava Mandira, statue of Hanumān (A), view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-06

Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa Sataḥ, two representations of Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa in stone in the sanctum; photo by Stanislaw Klimek; 2006-03; courtesy of Niels Gutschow; free access – no reuse; source: Niels Gutschow, Architecture of the Newars, 2011, vol. 2, p. 649
object short description: A stone statue of Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa is enshrined in the sanctum. The deities sit on a two-layered lotus pedestal. A four-handed Nārāyaṇa sits in an āliḍha posture whilst holding a wheel and a lotus in his right hands and a club in one of his left hands. His other left hand holds a conch and is embracing Lakṣmī. She is depicted sitting in Nārāyaṇa’s lap, with one foot over a tortoise and one hand performing the gesture of vitarka.

Object image caption: Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa Sataḥ, Bālakumāri shrine, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-02-14
object short description: An aniconic stone placed in the pit in front of the Satah is worshipped as Bālakumārī. It is thought that when Bālakumārī of Cākhā Bāhāḥ Ṭola was brought here), she took rest for a while at this place, and so a shrine was established at this site. Bālakumārī is worshipped every day after Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa. A special worship of Bālakumārī is performed here on the day of Gũlā Pāru (1st day of the bright fortnight of Bhādra).

Object image caption: Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa Sataḥ, statue of Kṛṣṇa with Menakā and Rukmiṇī, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-02-14
object short description: A bronze statue of Kṛṣṇa has been placed on a cot in a corner outside the sanctum. Menukā sits to his right and Rukniṇī to his left. There is no record of when the Kṛṣṇa statue was enshrined. However, the Sataḥ is now also referred to as Kṛṣṇa Sataḥ. A Kṛṣṇa procession starts from the Sataḥ and travels around Lalitpur every year on the 9th day of the dark fortnight of Bhādra (the day immediately after Kṛṣṇa Aṣṭamī).

Object image caption: Baṭuka Bhairava, statue of Sarasvatī, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-22
Baṭuka Bhairava, Lion pillar, view from NW; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-11-23
Baṭuka Bhairava, aniconic statue of Gaṇeśa (located to the south of the main stone worshipped as Baṭuka Bhairava), view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-22
Baṭuka Bhairava, aniconic stones (the middle stone is worshipped as Baṭuka Bhairava), view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-22
Baṭuka Bhairava, statue of Gaṇeśa (A), view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-22
Baṭuka Bhairava, aniconic statue of Kumāra (located to the north of the main stone worshipped as Baṭuka Bhairava), view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-22
Baṭuka Bhairava, statue of Gaṇeśa (B), view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-22
Bhujā Phalcā, large portable tray (photograph by Thomas Schrom, July 2020)
object short description: Ritual food (rice) is prepared at this Phalcā on the day before the procession of Matsyendranātha, The food is then carried to Javalakhel on this large tray and presented to Buṅgadyaḥ there.

Object image caption: Ārīthāy Jaḥdhuṃhiṭi, Bhagīratha, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-29
Ārīthāy Jaḥdhuṃhiṭi, hydrant with kaladhārā in front of the Hiṭi, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-29
Ī Bahī Vãtā Vihāra, first caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-10
object short description: This is the southernmost caitya among the three caityas of the courtyard. Images of the two doners are engraved into a stone that is attached to the eastern side of the caitya's plinth.

Object image caption: Ī Bahī Vãtā Vihāra, second caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-10
object short description: This caitya is situated in the middle of the two other caitya. Below its dome one can find images of the Dhyānī Buddha at each of the four directions. On the ground level, there are images of Akṣobhya in the east, Ratnasambhava in the south, Amitābha in the west and Amoghasiddhi in the west. In the lower plinth of the caitya one can find images of lions in four corners, whilst its four sides are home to images of vehicles of the Four Lokeśvaras, namely an elephant, a horse, a peacock and Garuḍa.

Object image caption: Ī Bahī Vãtā Vihāra, third caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-10
object short description: This caitya is situated to the north of the middle caitya. An inscription reading ‘792' can be found on the northern face of the caitya. Images of Buddha and the four Lokeśvaras are placed in each of the four directions.

Object image caption: Mahākāla Phalcā at Oku Bāhāḥ, statue of Guhyasaṃvara, a tantric deity that may not be photographed, view from NE (May 2019)
object short description: Niche #1 on the left houses Guhyasaṃvara, a tantric deity that people are not allowed to take photographs of. The documentation team were able to view the deity but were requested not to take photographs. This deity has nine heads and sixteen hands and stands on a pedestal engraved with images of Brahmā, Viṣṇu, Maheśvara and Indra.

Object image caption: Mahākāla Phalcā at Oku Bāhāḥ, niche #3 with Mañjuśrī, view from E (May 2019)
object short description: A four-handed Mañjuśrī holds a sword and an arrow in his right hands and the Prajñāpāramitā scripture and a bow in his left hands.

Object image caption: Mahākāla Phalcā at Oku Bāhāḥ, niche #4 with Mahākāla, view from E (May 2019)
object short description: A two-handed Mahākāla is shown standing on a corpse holding a ritual knife (kartṛ) and a begging bowl (kapāla pātra).

Object image caption: Mahākāla Phalcā at Oku Bāhāḥ, niche #2 with Gaṇeśa, view from E (May 2019)
object short description: A seated Gaṇeśa with four arms holds a garland and radish in his right hands and an axe and a vessel of sweet balls in his left hands.

Object image caption: Mahākāla Phalcā at Oku Bāhāḥ, niche #5 with Sarasvatī holding a vīṇā on her left hand, view from E (May 2019)
object short description: Sarasvatī can be seen in the fifth niche. She is shown holding a vīṇā in her left hand

Object image caption: Jog Dhusa Bāhā, Triratna temple, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-04
Jog Dhusa Bāhā, view of yagye spot from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-04
Jog Dhusa Bāhā, view of well from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-04
Joga Dhusa Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-04
object short description: In the courtyard towards the east from the main shrine is a śikharakūṭa caitya with images of Lokeśvaras on each of its four sides. An inscription attached to the wall on the left-hand side of the main shrine informs readers about the construction of this śikharakūṭa caitya. Images of Triratna can be found at the top of the inscription.

Object image caption: Joga Dhusa Bāhāḥ, Triratna Mandira, close view of Mahākāla image from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-04
Joga Dhusa Bāhāḥ, eastern-facing Nāmasañgati image attached to the wall at the bottom of the main door; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-04
Joga Dhusa Bāhāḥ, Triratna Mandira, close view of Gaṇeśa image from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-04
Rārā pillars (west), pillar 001, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-05
object short description: A tree has absorbed the upper left part of the pillar. The left side shows traces of intentional damages, unless it is the poor quality of the stone that did not allow the artisans to properly hew the material.

Object image caption: Rārā pillars (west), pillar 002, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-05
object short description: The pillar is broken, only the upper part remains. The original size of the object was probably close to that of pillar 001.

Object image caption: Jagatmaṅgala Vihāra, Gaṇeśa statue, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: This four-handed Gaṇeśa is holding a rosary and a radish in his right hands and an axe and a sweet ball in his left hands.

Object image caption: Jagatmaṅgala Vihāra, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from S (September 2019)
object short description: This Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya was established at the same time as the Bāhāḥ in 1945.

Object image caption: Jagatmaṅgala Vihāra, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S (September 2019)
object short description: This Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala was established alongside the Bāhāḥ in 1945.

Object image caption: Jagatmaṅgala Vihāra, caitya, view from E (September 2019)
object short description: Bodhisattva images have been placed on the four faces of the caitya. This caitya was made by a Vajrācārya of Bu Bāhāḥ (LAL0440). The pipal tree that has grown up around the caitya has damaged it. A smaller caitya was recently established on the south-eastern plinth and a small stone Nandī has been placed at its north-eastern corner. According to locals, this caitya was established before the vihāra.

Object image caption: Jagatmaṅgala Vihāra, Mahākāla statue, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: This statue of Mahākāla is attached to the southern wall of the bāhāḥ shrine. Mahākāla is standing on top of a corpse and holds katṛ in his right hand and a skull in his left hand.

Object image caption: Jagatmaṅgala Vihāra, Vasundharā shrine, view from SW (September 2019)
object short description: Siddhirāja’s family established this temple. An image of Vasundharā fixed in a glass frame, is enshrined in the sanctum. A bronze caitya-shaped pinnacle tops the shrine. The decoration and structure of the shrine clearly exhibits elements of a Tibetan style. Local residents say that Siddhirāja’s family were devotees of a Tibetan monk.

Object image caption: Jagatmaṅgala Vihāra, Sarasvatī statue, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: A statue of Sarasvatī is attached to the back wall of the Vasundharā Temple. She is holding vīṇā with two of her hands and a rosary and a book in her other two hands.

Object image caption: Jagatmaṅgala Vihāra, Kumāra statue, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: Kumāra is standing on top of a peacock, performing an abhaya gesture with one right hand and holding a rosary with the other. He is also holding a trident and a water vessel in his two left hands.

Object image caption: Jagatmaṅgala Vihāra, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: Images related to key events in the life of Buddha have been sculpted on the vedikā of the caitya. The southern side has an inscription. Images of events described in the Viśvantara Jātaka, Maṇicūḍa Jātaka, and Mahāsattva Jātaka have been sculpted on to the western side, whilst the northern side displays Buddha’s birth and attainment of Buddhahood. The eastern side depicts events related to the inauguration of Dharmacakra in Sāranātha and the attainment of Nirvāṇa in Kuśīnagara.

Object image caption: Kuti Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue at the right side of the entrance, view from N (December 2018)
Kuti Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue at the right side of the entrance, view from N (December 2018)
object short description: Image of Gaṇeśa with four arms. He is holding a garland and a radish in his right hands, and an axe and a bowl of sweets in his left hands.

Object image caption: Kuti Bāhāḥ, śikharakūṭa caitya, view from E (December 2018)
Cīdhã Guji Bāhāḥ, base of the old pinnacle of the kvāḥpāḥchẽ, view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-05
object short description: This is the lower part of the Caitya which was erected above the roof of the kvāḥpāḥchẽ as its pinnacle. After the kvāḥpāḥchẽ collapsed, this pinnacle was buried under the rubbles. During the restoration of the damaged kvāḥpāḥchẽ, a new metal Caitya was erected as the pinnacle. The vedikā of the older Caitya (pinnacle) was then placed in the Bāhāḥ’s courtyard.

Object image caption: Cīdhã Guji Bāhāḥ, well built on the plinth of a private house in the Bāhāḥ premises, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-05
object short description: Previously, the water necessary for the daily worship of the kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ used to be collected from this well. However, it has dried out.

Object image caption: Cīdhã Guji Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla shrine, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-05
Cīdhã Guji Bāhāḥ, Aṣṭakoṇoparipadma Caitya, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-05
object short description: Four Bodhisattva and Tārā statues are placed in the four cardinal directions of the Caitya, and it is covered by a metal canopy (ilā̃).

Object image caption: Cīdhã Guji Bāhāḥ, Aṣṭakoṇoparipadma Caitya, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-05
Cīdhã Guji Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-05
Cīdhã Guji Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya in the sanctum, view from N ; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-05
object short description: This statue of Akṣobhya is made out of black stone, and a metal crown adorns his head. Similarly, he is dressed in a metal lhegā.

Object image caption: Gaḥchĕ Hiti, water spout, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-02
Gaḥchĕ Hiti, Bhagīratha statue above the water spout, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-02
Gaḥchĕ Hiti, jaḥdhuṃhiti, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-02
Gaḥchĕ Hiti, statue of Viṣṇu, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-02
Triratnavihāra Phalcā at Cyāsal, Lakṣmī, Sarasvatī and Gaṇeśa, view from W; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2018-12-04
object short description: This stone statue is attached to the eastern wall of the Phalcā. Sarasvatī is flanked by Gaṇeśa and Lakṣmī. The four-handed Sarasvatī sits in the sukhāsana posture and holds akṣamālā and a book with her two hands and a vīṇā with her other two hands. Gaṇeśa manifests in a sukhāsana posture and holds both axe and laḍḍu with his left hands, a radish in one of the right hands and akṣamālā in the other. Lakṣmī, too, is seated in the sukhāsana position, showing abhaya and varada gestures with her left and right hands.

Object image caption: Kvāchẽ Phalcā, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-11-06
object short description: This Caitya has a rectangular plinth with statues of nine patrons above it. There are images of four Bodhisattvas facing in the four cardinal directions as well as a lotus flower. On top of this frieze one can find another set of four Buddha statues facing in the main directions of the building.

Object image caption: Ibāḥ Bahī Dune, Pañcāvaliyukta Caitya, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-24
object short description: Five layered motifs of padma (lotus), jala (water), ratna (jewel), agni (fire) and vajra are carved on the upper part of the Caitya. The part containing the 13 bhuvanas was lost, and so a new section has been fixed upon it.

Object image caption: Ibāḥ Bahī Dune, Hanumān statue, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-24
object short description: The image of Hanumān is placed in a niche on a eastern wall from the Bāhāḥ.

Object image caption: Ibāḥ Bahī Dune, Mahākāla statue, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-24
object short description: This image of Mahākāla is placed in a niche on a eastern wall from the Bāhāḥ.

Object image caption: Sarasvatī Mandira, main statue of Sarasvatī in the sanctum, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-04
Sarasvatī Mandira, an additional statue of Sarasvatī (C) beside the main Sarasvatī statue in the sanctum, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-04
Sarasvatī Mandira, statue of Kṛṣṇa with Rukmiṇī and Satyabhāmā at the western side of the main Sarasvatī statue in the sanctum, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-04
Sarasvatī Mandira, an additional statue of Sarasvatī (B) beside the main Sarasvatī statue in the sanctum, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-04
Sarasvatī Mandira, an additional statue of Sarasvatī (A) beside the main Sarasvatī statue in the sanctum, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-04
Cikã Bahī, statues of the donors, view from W (January 2019)
object short description: This is a statue of the donor couple facing the main deity of the Bahī. An inscription informs the reader of the date and the name of the donors can be found on the back of the same stone. Their names are Bhānucandra and Machamatī. Locke (1985, 212) misreads the first name as Manucandra.

Object image caption: Cikã Bahī, Pañcāvaliyukta Caitya, view from S (January 2019)
object short description: This caitya is similar to the previous Jālāvali caitya. The part above the kumbha was recently (writing in 2019) repaired using cement.

Object image caption: Cikã Bahī, statue of Mahākāla, view from S (January 2019)
object short description: This Mahākāla statue stands in a niche attached to the wall near the outer entrance of the Bahī. The statue is newly installed and replaces one that was allegedly worn out (or stolen?). Mahākāla is standing on a pedestal holding a katṛ in his right hand and kapāla with his left. He is pressing khaṭvāṅga with his left hand.

Object image caption: Cikã Bahī, statues of devotees, view from W (January 2019)
object short description: This statue of one male figure flanked by two woman figures seems to be an image of devotees, and is likely a husband together with his two wives. However, no inscription could be found to provide further information. They are probably donors.

Object image caption: Cikã Bahī, Śikharakūṭa caitya, view from S, and unknown statue on the base of the eastern side of the caitya, view from E (January 2019)
object short description: This caitya stands on a rectangular stone base. Images of lions can be found on the four corners of the vedi, whilst the four sides of nemi contain images of Lokeśvaras. The statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara in the western niche has been very worn down. Above these statues, Buddha icons can be found. The western plinth contains an inscription that informs the reader about the construction of this caitya, which is also less well kept. The eastern plinth of the Śikharakūṭa caitya contains a stone statue of Buddha flanked by Prajñāpāramitā and Ṣaḍakṣarī Lokeśvara. According to local residents, this statue was found somewhere else but was then brought and established here.

Object image caption: Cikã Bahī, Dharmadhātu Manḍala with a vajra on top, view from E (January 2019)
object short description: This octagonal Dharmadhātu has statues of eight Lokeśvaras in eight directions. A metal vajra was added recently (writing in early 2019).

Object image caption: Cikã Bahī, Pañcāvaliyukta Caitya, view from S (January 2019)
object short description: This caitya stands on a square-shaped stone platform. The caitya's vedi contains icons of Lokeśvaras, one in each of the four cardinal directions, and lion statues can be found at the corners. On top of the vedi, a statue of a nāga in an octagonal shape faces north and holds on to the upper construction. Above the nāga, one can find lines symbolising water. A blooming lotus can be found above these, and this sits underneath a rows of flames, a mantra in Rañjanā script, a vajra, and another nāga. Further lotus petals sit atop this second nāga, with one row turning down and another up. Small niches above this contain icons of Dhyānī Buddha, and there is one in each of the cardinal direction. Alongside the Buddha, images of his śakti can be found in each of the four corners. Above these icons, kumbha, harmikā, and trayodaśabhuvana have been installed. The part above the kumbha is slightly bent as it is levered up from the main body.

Object image caption: Cikã Bahī, Cyāsaḥ, statues of the donors, view from W (January 2019)
object short description: These statues have been installed next to the jvālāvali caitya and face the main deity of the Bahī. No inscription could be found to provide further information about the donors.

Object image caption: Bare Nani, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S (June 2020)
Bare Nani, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from NE (June 2020)
Bare Nani, Akṣobhya shrine with statue, view from W (June 2020)
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Śivaliṅga, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Sarasvatī, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Gaṇeṣa (B), view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Nandī (C), view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Unidentified Object (A), view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Śivaliṅga known as Rameśvara Mahādeva or Gvārā Māhādyaḥ, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
object short description: Local residents refer to the Liṅga as Gvārā Māhādyaḥ.

Object image caption:
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Gaṇeṣa (A) inside the sanctum, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04

Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Lakṣmī (Gaurī), view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Nandī (B), view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Unidentified Object (B), view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Unidentified Object (C), view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Unidentified Object (D), view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Nandī (D), view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Nandī (E), view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-11
Santāneśvara Mahādeva, Bell (B), view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-11
Dhvākhāpine Maṇḍapa, Vṛtākāra Caitya, view from SW; photo by Matthias Arnold; 2019-10-13
Dhvākhāpine Maṇḍapa, Nāmasaṅgīti shrine, view from W, photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-02-08
object short description: A Nāmasaṅgīti shrine is located to the west of the Maṇḍapa and contains a stone statue of Nāmasaṅgīti. The deity has one head and twelve arms and is shown sitting in the dhyāna posture. His uppermost arms are raised above his head and performing uttarabodhi mudrā (meaning two hands are folded to indicate prostration). Two hands at his breast level are shown performing the gesture of dharmacakra mudrā, while the two hands below these are in the process of tarpaṇa mudrā (i.e. about to offer water from the alms bowl). A further pair of hands hold an alms bowl in his lap, whilst his two shoulder-level hands are shown holding a sword as well as scripture and a lotus. The statue's last pair of hands hold a bow and arrow. The roof of the temple is covered with tiles and a metal pinnacle is fixed atop it. Amararāja Tulādhara facilitated the construction of this temple in 2013.

Object image caption: Dhvākhāpine Maṇḍapa, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from SE; photo by Matthias Arnold; 2019-10-13
Dhvākhāpine Maṇḍapa, new gate, view form E; photo by Matthias Arnold; 2019-10-13
Guitaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of Nandī (bull) front of Gaṇeśa, view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-26
Guitaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of Gaṇeśa in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-26
