Guitaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of Śiva attached to the wall, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-26
Guitaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of lion flanking the entrance to the sanctum (placed to the northern side of  the staircase), view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-26
Guitaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of lion flanking the entrance (placed on the southern side of the staircase), view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-26
Guitaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, bell and its stand (pillar), view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-26
Guitaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, frog, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-26
Guitaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of Gaṇeśa attached to the wall, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-26
Guitaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of Bhīmasena attached to the wall, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-26
Guitaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of Umāmaheśvara attached to the wall, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-26
Umāmaheśvara Degaḥ, main statue, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-02-18
object short description: Stone statue of Umāmaheśvara is placed in the sanctum of the temple. Umā sits on the left lap of Śiva. Four-handed Śiva sits in āliḍha posture, holds a rosary in one of his right hands and shows varada gesture with the other. One of his left-hand holds trident and with his next hand, he embraces Umā and holds a water-vessel. Umā is in pratyāliḍha posture. Her left-hand shows varada gesture. The part of the statue consisting of her right hand is broken. Both deities sit on their vehicles, bull and lion. Gaṇeśa is on the side of Śiva and Kumāra is standing to the left of Umā. A big lotus flower is the base for all gods and their vehicles while a stone pedestal supports the flower.

Object image caption: Naka Bahī Phalcā 1, Umāmaheśvara statue, view from N (September 2019)
object short description: A stone image of Umāmaheśvara is embedded in the southern wall of Naḥbahī Phalcā. Śiva sits on his vehicle Nandī while Umā reclines on her husband's thigh, leaning gently against him. Śiva holds a rosary (akṣamālā) in his upper right hand, whilst his second right-hand performs a gesture of abhayamudrā. His second left-hand embraces Umā.

Object image caption: Lāchi Phalcā, statues of  statue of Gaṇeśa and Māhākal, view from S; photo by Christiane Brosius; 2019-02-26
Indrāyaṇī Pīṭha, Lion (B), view from SE; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2021-07-22
Indrāyaṇī Pīṭha, Lion (A), view from NE; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2021-07-22
Indrāyaṇī Pīṭha, Śivaliṅga, view from E; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2021-07-22
Indrāyaṇī Pīṭha, Indrāyaṇī shrine, view from E; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2021-07-22
Ikhāchẽ Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from N (May 2019)
Ikhāchẽ Bāhāḥ, Aśoka caitya, view from N (May 2019)
object short description: This caitya was constructed in the late medieval period and exhibits elements of a Licchavi caitya, especially in its upper part where images of deities have been placed. Its niche has been clad in copper plate. Images of Lokeśvaras have been placed at each of the four cardinal directions. Similarly, images of the Four Buddhas have been placed on top of the Lokeśvaras. Small metal statues of the donors have been placed on the western plinth, and four metal lions stand on two feet at each of the four corners.

Object image caption: Ikhāchẽ Bāhāḥ, vajra, view from E (May 2019)
object short description: This Vajra is placed above two rows of lotus petals, which in turn have been placed on top of a stone pillar. An iron grill-work has been fixed in place to protect it from theft. There is a fire altar in front of the Vajra.

Object image caption: Cāra Nārāyaṇa Mandira, statue of guardian Vijaya, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-07-04
Cāra Nārāyaṇa Mandira, statue of guardian Jaya, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-07-04
Umāmaheśvara Mandira, Nhāgaleśvara, view from N (December 2018)
object short description: The southern area of Mahāpāla is called Nhāgala, after which this liṅga is named.

Object image caption: Pilāchẽ Gaṇeśa, gilt copper statue of Gaṇeśa (B), view from S (June 2019)
object short description: This is the second gild copper statue of Gaṇeśa. It is in the possession of another Jyāpu family of Pilāchẽ. Like the first image, this statue is also placed inside the temple's sanctum on Kuśe Aũsī and Indrajātrā. An inscription on the pedestal of the statue mentions that Cinasiṃ Bhāva ordered that this statue be made because the previous one was too old. This occurred in NS 1002.

Object image caption: Pilāchẽ Gaṇeśa, gild copper statue of Gaṇeśa, view from S (June 2019)
object short description: A Jyāpu family of Pilāchẽ is in possession of this metal image of Gaṇeśa. It is similar to the Gaṇeśa image of the sanctum. This gild copper statue is placed inside the sanctum in the occasion of Kuśe Aũsī and Indrajātrā. One of the metal garlands on the statue shows the date NS 874, which suggests that this statue was made at that time or even before. We were not allowed to take a photo of this inscription.

Object image caption: Pilāchẽ Gaṇeśa, Nandī, view from S (June 2019)
object short description: Nandiī faces the main deity of the sanctum and is usually located in front of the temple. Due to the renovation, the statue is currently placed at the plinth of the temple.

Object image caption: Yaḥsi Beam, Lukumahādyaḥ, view from S (October 2019)
Thati Phalcā 2, stone statue of Tārā (B), view from S (August 2019)
object short description: In this second image, Tārā is sitting in sukhāsana on top of a lotus pedestal. Her right hand is performing varada whilst her left hand performs abhaya. She is holding a lotus pedestal with both hands.

Object image caption: Thati Phalcā 2, stone statue of Padmapāṇilokeśvara, view from S (August 2019)
object short description: The image of Padmapāṇilokeśvara is in the middle niche. He is standing in tribaṅga and holding a lotus pedestal in both of his hands.

Object image caption: Thati Phalcā 2, stone statue of Tārā (A), view from S (August 2019)
object short description: There are three niches in the western wall of the Phalcā. This image of Tārā is installed in one of these niches. Tārā is sitting in sukhāsana on top of a lotus pedestal. Her right hand is performing varada whilst her left hand performs abhaya and holds the pedestal of a lotus.

Object image caption: Lvahã Hiti and Bhaṇḍārakhāla Tank, the pavilion principale façade, view from S (February 2020)
object short description: This pavilion stands to the north of the pond. Underneath it, one can find a stone chamber which was used as a changing room for the royal family when taking baths. The chamber’s entrance is topped with a stone toraṇa and flanked by statues of Yamunā and Sarasvatī. The façade of the pavilion is sculpted with various incarnations of Viṣṇu. It has ten wooden carved columns. The roof is covered with jhĩgaṭī tiles and is topped with a metal finial. The chronicle (Nepālko Itihāsa Rājabhogamāla 1969, 24) states that this pavilion and the pond were built together and a wooden canopy (cãduvā) was once fixed over the pavilion.

Object image caption: Tandukar Capaḥ, painting of Bhairava, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-11-03
object short description: On the first floor of the Capāḥ, one can find an image of Bhairava which has been painted on paper and hung on the east wall. The image features an eight-armed Bhairava with flame-like hair standing on top of a male corpse. Bhairava holds a sword and shield along with an elephant hide in his upper pair of hands, a rattle drum and a khatvāṅga in his second pair of hands, and a kartṛ (chopper) and the severed head (of Brahmā) in his third pair of hands. His lower (front) right hand holds a skull cup (kapālapātra) whilst the lower left hand displays the bindumudrā. The painting also shows dogs and devotees. Pictures of Siṅghinī and Vyāghrinī along with devotees have been pasted on either side of the Bhairava's image. A niche considered to represent Nāsaḥdyaḥ (the god of dance and music) can be found to the north side of Bhairava.

Object image caption: Pinchẽ Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from W (June 2019)
object short description: The statue stands behind the outer entrance of the Bāhāḥ on its eastern side.

Object image caption: Pinchẽ Bāhāḥ, damaged Gaṇeśa statue, view from E (June 2019)
object short description: This highly deteriorated and barely recognisable stone statue stands behind the outer entrance of the Bāhāḥ on its western side.

Object image caption: Pinchẽ Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from SE (June 2019)
Pinchẽ Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhatu Maṇḍala, view from S (June 2019)
Pinchẽ Bāhāḥ, Hanumān statue, view from E (June 2019)
object short description: This stone statue stands behind the outer entrance of the Bāhāḥ on its western side. This statue is also deteriorated; the weapons it holds in its hand are not identifiable.

Object image caption: Mūla Coka, Bhidhyāpīṭa Shrine, view from E
object short description: The Vidyāpīṭha (tantric shrine) is located on the first floor of the west wing, directly above the main entrance to the palace courtyard. A similar shrine exists in the Bhaktapur palace. The shrine is made of three timber-carved cabinets containing niches. Three toraṇas are installed above the three cabinets. The altar room also contains wooden statues of Mahiṣāsuramardinī and Gaṇeśa and metal statues of the Eight Mātṛkās. A Brahmin from Tuilā ṭola used to perform the ritual worships at this temple, however, this tradition came to an end more than 40 years ago. It is likely that in historic times members of the Malla Royal family recieved tantric teachings in this room. Today, Vidyāpīṭha serves as a special exhibition gallery of the Patan Museum.

Object image caption: Mūla Coka, sacrificial area, view from N (June 2019)
object short description: A sacrificial altar and a sacrificial post (yūpa) are located in the northern half of the courtyard.

Object image caption: Mūla Coka, Yantāju shrine, view from N (June 2019)
object short description: This small gilt shikhara-style temple to Yantāju stands in the middle of the courtyard. During its establishment, Taleju was first placed at the centre of the Mūla Coka where the shrine now stands. A fire altar at the north-eastern corner of the courtyard infused Śrīyantra with the life of the deity. The gilt copper inscription mentions that Śrīnivāsa Malla made this shrine in 1666 CE.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Cāmuṇḍā and other deities in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: A stone statue of Cāmuṇḍā has been installed inside the sanctum sanctorum of the temple. Earlier, there was only an aniconic stone image here. An eight-armed stone statue joined this stone image some time later. This statue of the goddess holds a sword, aṅkuśa, kartṛ and kapālapātra in her right hands and a shield, noose and a chopped head in her left hands. Her last hand is performing the gesture of pṛthvī. A brass toraṇa tops the statue and two brass flags flank it. Aniconic stone images representing other mother goddesses and Bhairavas have been placed in the sanctum.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, Licchavi Caitya, view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: This Licchavi Caitya is located to the south of the temple. The presence of this Caitya confirms that in earlier times there was once a Bahī in this place. There are four Bodhisattvas at each of the four cardinal directions of the Caitya. This part appears to have been added later. The section above the vedī dates back to the Licchavi period, and the Buddha statues in the upper niches appear to have been added at a later date. The section above the garbha also appears to have been added later.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Chinnamastā in the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Standing on top of a corpse and wearing a garland of heads, Chinnamastā holds her own severed head in one hand and a scimitar in another. The three jets of blood that spurt out of her bleeding neck are drunk by her severed head and two attendants. This statue does not appear to be very old.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, lion statue, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: This lion statue can be found to the west of the temple. It was donated by Mādhavalāla Pātravaṃśa Rāvata from Tumbāhāḥ.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, lion statue, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Located to the south of the temple, this lion statue was donated by Mādhavalāla Pātravaṃśa Rāvata from Tumbāhāḥ.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Manakāmanā on the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Manakāmanā is shown sitting in padmāsana and holds a sword and an arrow in her two right hands and a shield and a bow in her left hands. Kājilāla Maharjana, Kailāsa Maharjana and Kṛsa Daṅgola donated this statue.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Vajrayoginī in the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Vajrayogini is shown standing on a corpse in the pratyālīḍha posture. The statue is holding a kartṛ in her right hand and clasping a khaṭvāṅga with her left arm.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Gaṇeśa in the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, Śivaliṅgas, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Three śivaliṅga have been installed on the east side of the temple.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, stone statue of Umāmaheśvara and ox, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Bangdel (1995, 262) has dated this statue to the 2nd-3rd century. Nandī is visible besides Śiva's head. There seems a small figure sitting on Pārvatī's right thigh; presumably, this is Kumāra. Śiva has two arms. The weapons of the deities are not visible. A śivaliṅga has been erected in front of the statue.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, lion statue, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Located to the north of the temple, this statue was donated by Mādhavalāla Pātravaṃśa Rāvata from Tumbāhāḥ.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of monkeys in the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Hanumān on the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, Śveta Gaṇeśa with toraṇa, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Bangdel (1995, 264) dates this statue to the 18th century. Rāju Deulā and other family members fixed a brass toraṇa above the statue of Gaṇeśa in memory of Mīnā Deulā. The inscription reads "Śrī Śveta Gaṇeśāya namaḥ".

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Viṣṇu in the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Nṛṭyeśvara in the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Nṛṭyeśvara Śiva and Pārvatī are both shown dancing. The eighteen handed Śiva holds a vīṇā with two of his hands. Nandī can be found to Śiva's right, and a lion stands to the left of Pārvatī.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Lakṣmī in the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Lakṣmī’s right hand is broken and the left hand is in varada gesture.  A tortoise is placed to her right.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Gaṇeśa in the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Bhagavatī in the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Gaṇeśa on the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Ganesha's head is installed on the east wall of the temple. Ganesh has a crown on his head.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Bhagavatī in the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, Licchavi Caitya, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: This Caitya is located to the south of the temple. This Caitya also stands testament to the fact that there was once a Bahī in this place. Four Bodhisattvas have been placed at each of the four cardinal directions of the Caitya, though these do not appear to have been part of the original structure. The section above the altar can be dated back to the Licchavi period, as can the part above the vedī. Buddha statues placed in the upper niches also appear to have been added later. The upper part above the garbha also appears to have been a more recent addition.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, kuṇḍa, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: An inscription dated NS 939 mentions that there was once a pond where the Cāmuṇḍā temple now stands. Milamha from Dhumbāhāḥ, Lalitpur funded the construction of this kuṇḍa to the south-west corner of the temple in order to record the works of his ancestors. The inscription also mentions that his predecessors made a pond in the Sika Bahī premises. The pond was filled and the temple was constructed on the land. In the past, the daily worship of Cāmuṇḍā used the water in this kuṇḍa.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, lion statue, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: This lion statue is located to the east of the temple. It was donated by Mādhavalāla Pātravaṃśa Rāvata from Tumbāhāḥ.

Object image caption: Sika Bahī Cāmuṇḍā Mandira, statue of Gaṇeśa in the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05

Object name: Dehīmāṇḍau pillars and archaeological remains, stone lion
Object image caption: Dehīmāṇḍau pillars and archaeological remains, stone lion, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description:
The lion was either placed above the pediment (Skt. śukanāsikā) of a large śikhara temple or paired with another lion and placed at the entrance of a monument.

The object can be dated from the 14th-15th century.

Object name: Dehīmāṇḍau pillars and archaeological remains, pillar 003
Object image caption: Dehīmāṇḍau pillars and archaeological remains, pillar 003, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description:
The pillar contains, on the western side, a niche with the carving of a foot warrior. The warrior, for whom the pillar is dedicated, is turned to the right. He holds a sword in the right hand and a circular shield in the left one.

On the southern side is an eroded inscription.

Object name: Dehīmāṇḍau pillars and archaeological remains, pillar 005
Object image caption: Dehīmāṇḍau pillars and archaeological remains, pillar 005, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description:
The pillar contains, on the western side, a niche with the carving of a warrior. He is represented turned to the right, in a dynamic stance evoking martial postures. The right arm is raised with a sword while the left arm holds a circular shield.

On the northern side is a floral motif and on the southern side is an inscription.

The crowning part of the pillar is broken. It consisted in a bulbous shape similar to that of BTD0020-003.

Object name: Dehīmāṇḍau pillars and archaeological remains, elements of śikhara temple
Object image caption: Dehīmāṇḍau pillars and archaeological remains, elements of śikhara temple, view from south-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description:
Two architectural elements are stacked on top of each other. On top is an amālaka disc that used to crown a śikhara temple. Below it is the śikhara element that was originally placed just below an amālaka disc, on top of the śikhara.

These elements attest the presence, around the 14th-15th century, of at least one śikhara temple.

Object name: Dehīmāṇḍau pillars and archaeological remains, pillar 004
Object image caption: Dehīmāṇḍau pillars and archaeological remains, pillar 004, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description:
The pillar contains, on the western side, a niche with the carving of a horse rider.

On the southern side is an eroded inscription that contains the date of ŚS 1309 (1387 CE).

The eastern and northern sides of the pillar are decorated with floral motifs.

Object image caption: Campakanāga Phalcā, Campaka Nāga, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-04-29
Yatā Bāhāḥ, Maitreya Buddha; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-23
Yatā Bāhāḥ, small Maitreya Buddha; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-23
Yatā Bāhāḥ, bell suspended from a stone frame, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-23
object short description: The bell bears an inscription dated NS 995

Object image caption: Yatā Bāhāḥ, stone lion, south; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-02
Aśoka Caitya, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-02
object short description: The white colored Aśoka caitya rests on a rectangular brick plinth and is situated to the east of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala and the cube of a Licchavi caitya forms part of the upper section

Object image caption: Yatā Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa shrine; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-23
object short description: This aniconic stone is worshipped by local people as Gaṇeśa. It is attached to the left wall of the courtyard's entrance.

Object image caption: Yatā Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla shrine attached to the right wall at the courtyard's entrance; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-23
Yatā Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-02
object short description: Lokeśvara reliefs adorn the 8 sides of the Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala. A brass vajra is installed on top of the octagonal stone maṇḍala (see the additional image below)

Object image caption: Bhīmsena Temple, sacrificial pit in front of the main entrance, view from E (May 2019)
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Statue of Tārā (A), view from SE; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Statue of Mañjuśrī; view from N; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-20
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Statue of Padmapāṇi Lokśvara, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-20
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Statue of Vajrapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from S; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-20
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Stone Bell Pillar, view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Stone Oil Lamp, view from above; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Statue of Amoghasiddhi Buddha, view from N; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Statue of Amitābha Buddha, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Statue of Ratnasambhava, view from S; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Statue of Maitreya Buddha, view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-20
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Statue of Tārā (B), view from SW; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Statue of Tārā (C), view from NW; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Statue of Tārā (D), view from NE; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Vajradhātu Caitya (Khāsti Caitya), Statue of Akṣobhya Buddha, view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-19
Talium Kartika Swami Śivanātha, pillar 001, view from south; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-15
object short description:
The southern side of the stone memorial pillar contains an inscription of 10 lines.

The pillar can be dated between the second half of the 14th century and the early 16th century (Andolfatto 2019: 116).

This is probably the back side of the pillar in its original setting.

Object image caption: Haugaḥ Bāhāḥ, aśoka caitya, view from N (August 2019)
object short description: The caitya is set on a rectangular plinth. Buddha images have been placed in the niches of four sides. In front of the caitya is a yajñakuṇda and a maṇḍapa. A stone lying between the yajñakuṇda and maṇḍapa is worshipped as kṣetrapāla.

Object image caption: Haugaḥ Bāhāḥ, image of Lokeśvara with Vasundharā, view from W (August 2019)
object short description: On the eastern wall of the Bāhāḥ one can find images of Lokeśvara and Vasundharā. Both images are sculpted on the same stone. Lokeśvara's right hand is in the varada posture and their left hand holds a stem of a blossoming lotus flower. Vasundharā has three faces and six arms and is seated in lalita posture. She is holding a rosary and jewels in her right two hands and performing a varada gesture with the third one. Her left hands hold a vase, a rice stalk and scripture. The statue has been covered with a glass slide for its protection.

Object image caption: Haugaḥ Bāhāḥ, statue of Sūryanārāyaṇa with Lakṣmī, view from W (August 2019)
object short description: This statue is attached to the eastern wall of the Bāhāḥ. Both Sūryanārāyaṇa and Lakṣmī are sculpted on the same stone slate. Sūryanārāyaṇa is holding a stem of a blossoming lotus flower and performing abhaya with his right hand and embracing Lakṣmī with his left arm. Lakṣmī is performing abhaya with her left hand and varada with her right. The statue is covered with a glass slide for its protection.

Object image caption: Haugaḥ Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala with a vajra, view from W (August 2019)
object short description: Eight Bodhisattva images have been placed on the eight faces of the dharmadhātu. A vajra donated in VS 2064 has been fixed on top of it. The dharmadhātu is slightly broken in some places.

Object image caption: Buinā Gaṇeśa, aniconic stone shrine, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-01-06
object short description: Local residents worship these aniconic stones as Mahādeva, Pārvatī and Gaṇeśa.

Object image caption: Buinā Gaṇeśa, aniconic Gaṇeśa, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-01-06
Duīkambhā, north pillar, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-25; courtesy of David C. Andolfatto; free access - no reuse
object short description: The east side of the pillar contains an eroded inscription.

Object image caption: Duīkambhā, south pillar, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-25; courtesy of David C. Andolfatto; free access - no reuse
object short description: The west side of the pillar contains an eroded inscription.

Object name: Dullu Vijaya Bhagavatī Temples, south-western temple
Object image caption: Dullu Vijaya Bhagavatī Temples, south-western Temple, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-29

Object name: Dullu Vijaya Bhagavatī Temples, north-eastern temple
Object image caption: Dullu Vijaya Bhagavatī Temples, north-eastern Temple, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-29
object short description: The pediment is free standing.

Object name: Dullu Vijaya Bhagavatī Temples, stone lion
Object image caption: Dullu Vijaya Bhagavatī Temples, stone lion, view from NE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-29
object short description: Also known as the "lion of Sinja".

Object image caption: Kva Hiti, water spout (B), view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-09-10
Kva Hiti, Licchavi Caitya inside the Hiti, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-09-10
Kva Hiti, Śivaliṅga (B) at the northeast corner of the Hiti, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-09-10
Kva Hiti, jaḥdhuṃhiṭi at the northern side of the Hiti, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-09-10
Kva Hiti, Śivaliṅga (A) at the northeast corner of the Hiti, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-09-10
Kva Hiti, Śivaliṅga © at the southeast corner of the Hiti, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-09-10
Kva Hiti, Śivaliṅga (D) at the southeast corner of the Hiti, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-09-10
Kva Hiti, statue of Nāgarājā above the water spout (A), view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-09-10
Kva Hiti, unidentified statue at the western wall niche of the Hiti, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-09-10
Kva Hiti, water spout (A), view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-09-10
Kva Hiti, statue of Yakṣa bellow the water spout (A), view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-09-10

Kva Hiti, statue of Gaṇeśa at the southeast wall niche of the Hiti, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-09-10
Umāmaheśvara Mandira, Umāmaheśvara statue, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-08
object short description: Stone statue of Umāmaheśvara is placed in the sanctum of the temple. Umā sits on the left lap of Śiva. The four-handed Śiva sits in ardhaparyaṅka posture, holding a rosary in one of his right hands and holding varada gesture with the other. One of his left-hand holds trident and with his next hand, he embraces Umā. Umā is also sitting in ardhaparyaṅka posture. Her left-hand shows abhaya gesture and the right hand is in varada gesture. Both deities sit on their respective vehicles, a bull, and a lion.

Nārāṃhiṭī Phalcā, statue of Indra, view from S (photo by Nutan Dhar Sharma, June 2018)
object short description: Indra is seated on an elephant. This icon is embedded in the back wall of the smaller phalcā.

Object image caption: Nārāṃhiṭi Phalcā, statue of Padmapāni, view from W (March 2019)
Nārāṃhiṭī Phalcā, statue of Amitābha Buddha, view from S (photo by Christiane Brosius, March 2015)
Nārāṃhiṭī Phalcā, Gajalakṣmī statue, at the well to the east of the Phalcā, view from NE (photo by Christiane Brosius, February 2019)
object short description: Though this statue is in the close vicinity of the Nārāṃhiṭī Phalcā it is not directly connected, yet, part of the architectural assemblage of sites around the hiti.

Object image caption: Kumārī Pāṭī, Kumārī 's throne, view from NE (June 2019)
object short description: Sitting on her throne, the Kumārī watches the chariot as it is pulled from Thati to Jawahakhel during the annual Buṅgadyaḥ jātrā . This throne is kept in the Phalcā and was constructed some time around 2005 CE.

Object image caption:
Mūchẽ Āgama, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from E (July 2019)

This statue of a four-armed Gaṇeśa is located at the north-western corner of the monument. Gaṇeśa is holding a japamālā in his upper right hand and his lower right hand is broken. He is holding an axe and a sweet ball in his two left hands.
Keku Bāhāḥ at Dau Bāhāḥ, Bhairava statue, view from E (October 2018)
Keku Bāhāḥ at Dau Bāhāḥ, Vasundharā Devī, view from S (October 2018)
object short description: The stone statue of Vasundharā Devī can be found at the northern wall of the courtyard. It was constructed in NS 1122. The deity has three heads, six arms, and is sitting in the ardhaparyaṅka (lalita) posture.

Object image caption: Keku Bāhāḥ at Dau Bāhāḥ, Hiding Mahādeva (Lukumahādeva) facing N (October 2018)
object short description: The Hiding Mahādeva (Lukumahādeva) is an aniconic stone that is worshipped once a year as Śiva in a special ritual (see, Michaels 1992 for a deeper discussion of this anconic stone).

Object image caption: Keku Bāhāḥ at Dau Bāhāḥ, Jvālāvali Caitya in front of the āgãchẽ, view from S (October 2018)
object short description:
The Caitya stands on a vedī which has images of lions in each of its four corners. The lions share heads at the corners. The main body of the Caitya has been constructed in the shape of a lotus flower. At the bottom, one can see an image of a nāga facing towards the north; this supports the upper section. Above the nāga, there is a layer of lotus patels, and above this one can find a circle of a motif representing fire (jvālā). Next come two layers of lotus petals, one turned to face upward and the other downward. These petals sit beneath four images of Akṣobhya Buddha facing in four directions. Above them, one can find the kumbha, harmikā, and circles symbolising bhuvanas. 

The inscription incarved on the vedī informs the reader that the Caitya was established in NS 1003. Locke (1985: 227) misreads this date as NS 1002.

Object image caption: Keku Bāhāḥ at Dau Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from E (October 2018)
Ko Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-13
Ko Bāhāḥ, Kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ statue, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-08
Ko Bāhāḥ, stone pedestal, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-13
object short description: This stone pedestal (jalahari) dates to the Śaka era year 411 (489 CE). It was found while digging a drain on the road just in front of this Bāhāḥ. At present, this artifact is preserved in the courtyard of the Bāhāḥ.

Object image caption: Ko Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-13
Ko Bāhāḥ, Tārā statue, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-13
Ko Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from NE; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-13
Ko Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-13
Caṇḍeśvarī Mandira, statue of lion, view from NE (photo by Yogesh Budathoki, March 2019)
object short description: This statue of a lion (the vehicle of Caṇḍeśvarī) is placed in front of the temple.

Object image caption: Caṇḍeśvarī Mandira, Degudyaḥ shrine, view from N (photo by Yogesh Budathoki, March 2019)
object short description: The Jyāpu communities of Patan organise their devālī pūjā (worship of lineage deities) in this shrine. Three niches contain a Kīrtimukha toraṇa with aniconic stone idols, while one has an an image of Gaṇeśa with a similar but smaller toraṇa.

Object image caption: Caṇḍeśvarī Mandira, jaḥrũhiti, view from N (photo by Yogesh Budathoki, March 2019)
object short description: Water from this jaḥrũhiti was once used to worship the gods of this temple. Nowadays, some cement-plastered shrines have been constructed in front of the structure.

Object image caption: Caṇḍeśvarī Mandira, Viṣṇu shrine, view from NE (photo by Yogesh Budathoki, March 2019)
object short description: Inside this śikhara-style small shrine, one can find an image of Viṣṇu sitting on Garuḍa. The image is topped with five serpents.

Object name: Aniconic stones of Śiva and Pārvatī with Nandī
Object image caption: Caṇḍeśvarī Mandira, aniconic stones of Śiva and Pārvatī with Nandī, view from N (photo by Yogesh Budathoki, March 2019)
Cābāhāḥ Phalcā, statue of Umāmaheśvara, view from SE; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2019-02-04
object short description: An inscription dated 800 NS (1680 CE) on the caitya in front of the Phalcā mentions the installation of a statue of Umāmaheśvara. However, the reconstruction report by KVPT states that all niches were empty prior to the 2002 CE reconstruction, and that the statues were stolen 20 years earlier.

Object image caption: Cābāhāḥ Phalcā, statue of Kumāra, view from SE; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2019-02-04
object short description: Kumāra has four arms and sits on a peacock. He is carrying a rosary in his upper right hand and performing a gesture of varada with his lower right hand. His upper left hand carries a spear and his lower left hand is holding a water vessel.

Object image caption: Cābāhāḥ Phalcā, statue of Mahākāla, view from SE; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2019-02-04
object short description: This two-handed Mahākāla statue is standing on a corpse holding a kartṛ (knife) and a kapāpāpātra (skull bowl) and clasping a khatvāṅga.

Object image caption: Cābāhāḥ Phalcā, statue of Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa, view from SE; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2019-02-04
Cābāhāḥ Phalcā, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from SE; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2019-02-04
object short description: This statue of Gaṇeśa has four arms. The elephant god is holding a garland and a radish in his two right hands and an axe and a sweet ball in his two left hands.
