Gaṇeśa Mandira, an aniconic stone worshipped as Gaṇeśa with toraṇa in the sanctum, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki, Rishi Amatya; 2020-07-03
object short description: The aniconic statue of Gaṇeaśa is below the toraṇa which contains images of Garuḍa in the middle.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, well, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki, Rishi Amatya; 2020-07-03
Gaṇeśa Mandira, stone statue of Nandī in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki, Rishi Amatya; 2020-07-03
Gaṇeśa Mandira, stone statues of donors, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki, Rishi Amatya; 2020-07-03
object short description: According to the inscription from NS 1021 (1701 CE), the donors are Maṇirāja Thakālī and his wife Pratimā.

Object image caption: Buddha Mandira, Lion statue on the northern side of the staircase, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-02-01
Buddha Mandira, Śākyamuni Buddha in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-02-01
object short description: This contemporary Śākyamuni statue, consecrated in the sanctum (garbhagṛha), was established by Kānchī Vajrācārya, a local community member, after the old one was stolen in 1984 CE (cf. Ś. Śreṣṭha VS 2057, 58).

Object image caption: Buddha Mandira, Lion on the southern side of the staircase, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-02-01
Dau Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from N (November 2018)
object short description: This caitya stands on a rectangular plinth and has a vedikā over it. In each of the four directions one can find images of lokeśvaras together with toraṇas. Above the images is a bhaṅgī, and above this are images of Dhyānī Buddha with toraṇas to each of the four directions. Above these images are two layers of lotus petals, a garbhagṛha, a harmikā, 13 bhuvanas, the pinnacle and a chatra.

Object image caption: Dau Bāhāḥ, Svayambhū Caitya, view from W (November 2018)
object short description: This caitya is the lineage deity of the Sarvasaṃgha of the Dau Bāhāḥ. Some kind of red-coloured structure has been constructed over and around it for its preservation and, as one can see, this almost covers the entire caitya. Images of the Dhyānī Buddha are located on each side of the caitya in the four cardinal directions. Above the images are two layers of lotus petals, garbhagṛha, harmikā, and 13 bhuvanas

Object image caption: Dau Bāhāḥ, Navagraha Maṇḍala in front of the main god house, view from N (November 2018)
Dau Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya, view from N (November 2018)
object short description: This caitya, situated towards the west of the Vajradhātu Caitya, stands on a rectangular plinth. Above the vedikā of the caitya are images of four lokeśvaras in each of the four directions, and each of the four corners harbour images of lions. Above this level, there is one layer of lotus petals, and above that one can find images of Dhyānī Buddha facing in four directions. Above these images are two layers of lotus petals, and on top of the petals are are a garbhagṛha and harmikā, 13 bhuvanas, the pinnacle, and the chatra.

Object image caption: Dau Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Manḍala, view from N (November 2018)
Dau Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Manḍala, view from N (November 2018)
Dau Bāhāḥ, Manjuśrī statue, view from E (November 2018)
object short description: A stone image of Mañjuśrī facing east is attached to the wall at the main entrance of the Bāhāḥ. Mañjuśrī has four arms and is shown holding a sword and an arrow in his right hands and a bow and a book in his left.

Object image caption: Dau Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from N (November 2018)
object short description: This white caitya is situated in front of the main shrine and stands on a rectangular plinth. Above the plinth are four small niches in each of the four directions, within which images of Buddha sit on a vedikā. Above the vedikā is one layer of lotas petals. Above the petals are a garbhagṛha, a harmikā, 13 bhuvanas, the pinnacle and the chatra.

Object image caption: Dau Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya, view from E (November 2018)
object short description: This caitya stands on a rectangular plinth, and the vedikā has images of Lokeśvaras together with toraṇas at each of the four directions. There is an image a of lion in each of the four corners. Lotus petals form the next layer, and above these are images of smaller lions in each of the four corners. Above them, in turn, are images of the Dhyānī Buddha facing in each of the four directions. The top of the caitya consists of three layers of lotus petals and garbhagṛha, harmikā, as well as 13 bhuvanas, a pinnacle and chatra.

Object image caption: Dau Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from E (November 2018)
object short description: This stone image of an eastern-facing seated Gaṇeśa with eight arms can be found attached to the wall to the left of the main entrance of the Bāhāḥ.

Object image caption: Sarasvatī Mandira, fragment of an old trident, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
Sarasvatī Mandira, statue of Umāmaheśvara, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
Sarasvatī Mandira, statue of Sarasvatī, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
Sarasvatī Mandira, dalūpāḥ, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
Sarasvatī Mandira, fragment of a Śivaliṅga (with a stone slab bearing an inscription on the background), view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
Sarasvatī Mandira, Degudyaḥ Shrine (A), view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
Sarasvatī Mandira, Degudyaḥ Shrine (B), view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
Buṅga Bahī, statue of Akṣobhya Buddha with toraṇa, view from E (October 2018)
object short description: The statue is made of black stone and has been covered with a lhẽgā made of an embroidered red cloth. The deity has a crown and a silver kikiṃpā on his head. An aura has been made for the god out of carved wood. Wooden toraṇas with various images and motifs have been fixed on the back of the statue.

Object image caption: Buṅga Bahī, statue of Mahākāla, view from S (October 2019)
Buṅga Bahī, Aśoka caitya, view from NW (October 2019)
object short description: This caitya differs from other aśoka caityas because it has a śivaliṅga shape. The liṅga is plastered with mud mortar and is standing on top of a north-facing yonī. There are four small empty niches in the four cardinal directions of the liṅga. Locals assume that there is a caitya inside the śivaliṅga, and that this was covered for its protection during the expedition of philosopher Ādi Saṅkarācārya. The philosopher got rid of other heterodox religious traditions for the expansion of his own religious doctrine.

Object image caption: Buṅga Bahī, statue of the donors, view from E (October 2019)
object short description: Statues of the two donors have been placed to the south of the sanctum entrance. The inscription mentions that they represent Kranajoti (Karṇajyoti) and his wife.

Object image caption: Buṅga Bahī, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from W (October 2019)
Buṅga Bahī, statue of Hanumān, view from N (October 2019)
Buṅga Bahī, statue of Buddha-Tārā, view from W (October 2019)
Buṅga Bahī, dharmadhātujinālaya caitya, view from W (October 2019)
Buṅga Bahī, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from W (October 2019)
Buṅga Bahī, dharmadhātujinālaya caitya, view from W (October 2019)
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Yak tail (camara) in the niche in the outer wall on the northern side of the temple, view from N (October 2019)
object short description: On the northern wall of the temple, a pair of yak tail has been made on the stone. This artwork is considered to be from the 17th century (Department of Archaeology 2059, 25).

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira Gaṇeśa Mandira, an aniconic stone of Gaṇeśa and other unidentified deities with a toraṇa above it in the sanctum, view from S (October 2019)
object short description: The aniconic stone image in the sanctum represents Gaṇeśa. The statue in the left hand corner represents Umā-Maheśvara.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, toraṇa in the sanctum, view from S (December 2019)
object short description: Inside the sanctum sanctorum, a wooden toraṇa has been fixed on top of the idol of Gaṇeśa. After the installation of the new toraṇa in VS 2033, the old one has been preserved inside the temple.

Object image caption: Cīdhã Bahī, Hanumān, view from S (June 2019)
object short description: A niche in the southern wall of the vihāra contains an aniconic stone. It is worshipped by locals as Hanumān. Above the niche, one can find a wall painting showing Hanumān flying over the sky.

Object image caption: Cīdhã Bahī, statue of devotees, view from W  (June 2019)
object short description: Two statues of devotees are located to the west of the caitya. A small stone pillar used for lighting oil lamps stands next to the statues.

Object image caption: Cīdhã Bahī, Lokeśvara, view from W  (June 2019)
object short description: A statue of Lokeśvara has been installed on the northern side of the main entrance to the vihāra. He is holding a lotus flower in his left hand and performing the gesture of varada with his right hand.

Object image caption: Cīdhã Bahī, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from  NE (June 2019)
object short description: This Caitya looks slightly different from other śikharakūṭa caityas. Two lion statues can be found on the western plinth, and its base shows eight Bodhisattvas in seated positions on the upper register and eight on the lower register. These Bodhisattvas remain unidentified; they are very worn and any distinguishing attributes cannot be made out (Gutschow 1997, 50).

Object image caption: Cīdhã Bahī, Mahākāla, view from N  (June 2019)
object short description: A gilded mask of Mahākāla is located on the inner northen wall of the monastic building.

Object image caption: Cīdhã Bahī, Bālakumārī, view from N (June 2019)
object short description: There is a small stone in front of the Lokeśvara statue which locals worship as Bālakumārī. There is also a stone vedī which is worshipped as the Aṣṭapāla deities.

Object image caption: Cīdhã Bahī, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from SE (June 2019)
Lũ Hiti, statue of Viṣṇu, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
object short description: Viṣṇu is standing on a Garuḍa. He is holding a conch and wheel on his two right hands and a club and lotus on his two left hands.

Object image caption: Lũ Hiti, Byā̃cā Hiti, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
object short description: It is called Byā̃cā Hiti because a frog is placed on its top. Water falls down from the mouth of a cow which is joined to the mouth of a crocodile. The hitiphusā of the conduit holds a śivaliṅga and an image of a frog. The eight auspicious symbols are drawn on the wall and a statue of Bhagīratha is fixed below the conduit. In NS 821, the grandsons of King Siddhinarasiṃha Malla, Pratāpasiṃha Bābu, Vīranarasiṃha Bābu, Jayabhadrasiṃha Bābu and Ānandasiṃha Bābu had renovated Lũ Hiti, added this Byā̃cā Hiti and also established a golden statue of Lakṣmī. The golden statue is already lost. Hanumān stands on top of the eastern stone pillar and Narasiṃha on top of the western one.

Object image caption: Lũ Hiti, statue of Viṣṇu, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
object short description: Standing Viṣṇu is holding a wheel and lotus on his two right hands and a club and conch on his two left hands. The lotus and conch are not clearly visible. He is surrounded by seven serpent kings (nāga). Garuḍa is praying to him.

Object image caption: Lũ Hiti, Śivaliṅga, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
Lũ Hiti, statue of Brahmā on the top of the third spout (LAL1860-005 ), view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
object short description: This idol differs from the common idols of Brahmā.  He is commonly found with four faces, however, in this statue, he has only one. He has moustache and is sitting on a duck. Four-armed Brahmā holds an akṣamālā on his upper right hand and displays vitarka gesture with the lower one. He is holding a book and a alms vessel (kamaṇḍalu) on his left hands.

Object image caption: Lũ Hiti, statue of Viṣṇu on the top of the middle spout (LAL1860-003), view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
object short description: Viṣṇu is holding a wheel and lotus with his two right hands and a club and conch with his two left hands. He is surmounted by seven serpent kings (nāga).

Object image caption: Lũ Hiti, middle spout, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
object short description: The hitipusā (lid of the conduit) has lotus motifs. Two Bhagīratha statues have been established below the spout.

Object image caption: Lũ Hiti, statue of Umāmaheśvara on the top of the spout (LAL1860-001), view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
object short description: Śiva is shown here with four hands. One of his right hands holds a rosary whilst the other displays the varada gesture. He holds a trident with one of his left hands. Their vehicles (vāhana), a bull, and a lion, are at their sides.

Object image caption: Lũ Hiti, first spout, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
object short description: The stone water-conduit is cladded with copper and is gilded too. The hitiphusā (lid of the conduit) has lotus motifs. In around 2007, the gilded plate of the conduit was stolen. Below the spout has a statue of Bhagīratha.

Object image caption: Lũ Hiti, third spout, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
object short description: The stone water-conduit is cladded with copper and is gilded. The hitipusā (lid of the conduit) has lotus motifs. Below the spout has a statue of Bhagīratha.

Object image caption: Lũ Hiti, statue of Viṣṇu, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
object short description: Siting Viṣṇu is holding a conch and wheel on his two right hands and a club and lotus on his two left hands.

Object image caption: Lũ Hiti, statue of Varuṇa, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
object short description: Varuṇa is sitting on a crocodile. Generally, he holds a conch on his right hand, however, it is not clear what is holding in this statue. He is holding a serpent on his left hand and the seven serpents are capping him.

Object image caption: Lũ Hiti, statue of Viṣṇu, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-08-11
object short description: Siting Viṣṇu is holding a lotus and conch on his two right hands and a wheel and club on his two left hands.

Object image caption: Ganeśa Phalcā at Cvachẽ, Mahākāla statue, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-02-01
Ganeśa Phalcā at Cvachẽ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-02-01
object short description: Gaṇeśa Phalcā contains a statue of a four-handed Ganeśa. The statue shows Ganeśa holding a garland in his upper right hand, a radish in his lower right hand, an axe in his upper left hand and a sweetball (laddu) in his lower left hand. Above him is a tympanum, and to his west is a small bell hanging on the wall on a chain. The statue is located at the northern wall of the Phalcā, to the west of the inscription.

Object image caption: Balabhadra, Aśoka Caitya, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-02-25
object short description: In front of the temple, to the north-east, there is a cemented half damaged caitya. Locals consider it an aśoka caitya which was damaged during the attack of Śaṅkarācārya. Originally the caitya was made of stone but a thick layer of cement has covered it.

Object image caption: Balabhadra, Gaṇeśa, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-02-25
object short description: A small Gaṇeśa shrine is built attached to the south wall of the Balabhadra temple. Four-handed standing Gaṇeśa is called Kāryavināyaka. Locals consider him as the representation of Bungmati’s Kāryavināyaka. Every year on the day of Indrajātrā, samaybaji is offered to him.

Object image caption: Balabhadra, statue, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-02-25
object short description: The standing stone statue of Balabhadra placed on a lotus pedestal above the stone jalaharī is backed by a brick masonry wall forming a trefoil arch at the top. Bangdel (1989, 139-140), Slusser (1982 vol. 2 plate 469) and Giuliano (2001) identify him as Vajrapuruṣa. His arms are folded across his chest, the gesture of submission or a humble position known as vinayaka-hasta. The vajra (thunderbolt) emerging from his head is his principal attribute. He wears earrings, a necklace, armlets, bracelets and a dhotī. See also. Pruscha (1975, 131) wrongly describes that he is carrying a plough.

Object image caption: Jalavināyaka Mandira, stone vase, view from W (June 2020)
object short description: The stone vase (named kvaṃdyaḥ cā by the local residents) is one of the oldest items of this temple. Gutschow  (2011, 458) dates it to the 12th century.

Object image caption: Jalavināyaka Mandira, Gaṇeśa mask placed on the aniconic stone, view from S (photograph by Bāburājā Maharjan, November 2019)
Jalavināyaka Mandira, one of three aniconic stones, view from W (April 2020)
Jalavināyaka Mandira, Umāmaheśvara, view from W (June 2020)
Jalavināyaka Mandira, aniconic stone, view from S (April 2020)
object short description: The fragment (CHO0100-005) seen to the left is a large aniconic stone worshipped as Kvaynā Gaṇeśa. It has been enshrined in the sanctum of the temple and covered with brass plates. The temple of Chobhar is considered to be the seat (pīṭha) of the Patan’s Kvaynā Gaṇeśa and both the deities in Patan and in Chobhar are considered to be the same.

Object image caption: Jalavināyaka Mandira, Śivalinga, view from above (June 2020)
Jalavināyaka Mandira, Gaṇeśa mask worshipped in its chariot (Photograph by Bāburājā Maharjan, November 2019)
Jalavināyaka Mandira, the Gaṇeśa mask in its original temple (June 2020)
Jalavināyaka Mandira, Viṣṇu Shrine, view from W (April 2020)
Jalavināyaka Mandira, temporary shrine, view from N (April 2020)
Jalavināyaka Mandira, Nāga shrine (Vāsuki Nāga), view from N (April 2020)
Jalavināyaka Mandira, rock representing Bhairava, view from W (June 2020)
Jalavināyaka Mandira, rock and two Śivalingas, view from N (June 2020)
object short description: A Śivalinga has been placed in the cavity of the rock. A separate Śivalinga is located on the temple's plinth to the right.

Object image caption: Jalavināyaka Mandira, shrew, view from N (April 2020)
Jalavināyaka Mandira, stone fragment, view from SE (April 2020)
Thapāḥ Bahī, Aśoka Caitya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-20
object short description:
This Caitya is the only historical object in the courtyard. It exhibits a mixture of Licchavi and medieval architecture. The section from the plinth to the bhagiṃ dates back to the medieval period, whereas the part extending from the lotus petals to the garbha is from the Licchavi period. The structure of the niche suggests that it must have been constructed in the Licchavi period, while the images of the Buddha appear to have been added later. The upper part of the Caitya (meaning the section above the harmikā) also appears to have been added at a later date. There is no inscription to refer to, but Pruscha (1975, 196) claims that this Caitya dates back to some time between the 11th to 14th century.

The Caitya has been covered in cement in many places. The ūṣṇīṣacūḍāmaṇi that is generally found on top of a Caitya also seems to have been lost.

Object image caption: Thapāḥ Bahī, Mahākāla statue, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-20
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Nandī statue, view from E (October 2019)
Gaṇeśa Mandira, lion statue placed on a pillar, view from NW (October 2019)
Gaṇeśa Mandira, trident (triśūla), view from N (October 2019)
object short description: The trident is fixed on top of a wooden pole. It is offered to Mahādeva in the sanctum.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Gaṇeśa statue in the sanctum, view from S (October 2019)
object short description: The previous Gaṇeśa statue was stolen in 2009. This new one was enshrined in 2012.

Object image caption: Dune Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-20
object short description: This Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala is located to the east of the Buddha temple. Previously, this structure was located between the fire alter and the temple, but it was later moved to its present position.

Object image caption: Dune Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-20
object short description: This Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya was established in VS 2066. The name of this Vihāra has been mistakenly inscribed on this Caitya as Candrasūrya Vihāra. To the east of this Caitya, one can find a vedikā of another Caitya. The main body of this other Caitya is at the home of the family who established it. The portable Caitya is placed here for a day every year on the 2nd day of the dark half of the Bhādra (on the day of matayāḥ).

Object image caption: Dune Bāhāḥ, Buddha shrine, view from SW; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-20
object short description: This three-roofed temple of Buddha made of terracotta bricks is located in the monastic building's courtyard. The entrance to this temple is made of iron railings and topped with a wooden toraṇa with an image of Akṣobhya. The entrance is flanked by statues of two monks and images of the Sun and the Moon. Two lions sit in front of the entrance and guard the temple. In front of the temple (i.e. to its south), one can find statues of a couple sitting and praying. A stone inscription dated NS 851 and 861 has been placed to the south of the couple and informs readers of their role in establishing the temple (Śākya 1994: 111). The northern wall of the temple has images of Amoghasiddhi (at the top) and Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara (at the bottom) attached to it. Images of Amitābha and Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara can also be found on the eastern wall, at the top and bottom respectively. The southern wall displays images of Ratnasambhava (on the top) and Mañjuśrī (on the bottom). Some of the niches contain images of Amitābha Buddha, though most have been left empty. A jvālānhāyakaṃ acts as the pinnacle for the temple. The temple is surrounded by an oil lamp balustrade.

Object image caption: Bhagavān Coka Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from W (October 2019)
object short description: Vajrarāja Śākya made this Caitya using eight different metals. Locke (1985, 166) says that it was made of copper, but locals claim that this Caitya is gilded with an alloy of copper and zinc. A few years ago, one could find metal Buddha statues in the niches. However, the statues placed there are now made of cement. The pinnacle of the Caitya was replaced after the loss of the original one. There was a metal vajra on the western vedī, but this has now been removed due to fear of theft.

Object image caption: Svaṃ Chapu Gaṇeśa, Lion (A), view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-23
Svaṃ Chapu Gaṇeśa, statue of Gaṇeśa inside the sanctum, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-21
Svaṃ Chapu Gaṇeśa, statue of Mahālakṣmī, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-21
Svaṃ Chapu Gaṇeśa, statue of Mahākāla, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-21
Svaṃ Chapu Gaṇeśa, Lion (B), view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-23
Gorakhanātha Pīṭha, detail view of Gorakhanātha Shrine from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-02
object short description:
A pair of feet (pādukā) have been placed inside the unroofed brick enclosure, representing Gorakhanātha. Inside the Mañjuśrī Shrine of Svayambhūnātha, there is also a footprint of Mañjuśrī which exactly looks the same as this one. Thus, some locals believe that the footprint of this Pīṭha should be the feet of Mañjuśrī.

Those who cannot go to Svambhū to worship Mañjuśrī on the day of Śrīpañcamī come to this Pīṭha and worship Gorakhanātha’s footprint. Shokoohy (2014, 94) and others have also erroneously described these feet as MañjuŚrī but the inscription from 1667 CE (NS 787) clearly mentions that Gorakhanātha and statue of Bhairava were installed and initial construction of this temple was done.

Not just in Kirtipur, but Kapālī community of Kathmandu, Bhaktapur, and Patan also worship their lineage deity Gorakhanātha as a footprint instead of the concrete human form.

Object image caption: Gorakhanātha Pīṭha, statue of Devotees (B) with inscription, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-02
Gorakhanātha Pīṭha, statue of a Devotee, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-02
Gorakhanātha Pīṭha, statue of Bhairava (A), view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-02
Gorakhanātha Pīṭha, statue of Devotees (A) with inscription, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-02
Gorakhanātha Pīṭha, statue of Devotees (C) with inscription, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-02
Gorakhanātha Pīṭha, Bhairava Shrine (B), view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-02
Gorakhanātha Pīṭha, stone khaḍga, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-02
Gorakhanātha Pīṭha, Bhariva Shrine (C), view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-02
Gorakhanātha Pīṭha, stone trident, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-02
Bhuyū Cībhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from SE (June 2020)
object short description: A Jyāpu family living in front of the Caitya established this Dharmadhātu in 1962.

Object image caption: Bhuyū Cībhāḥ, Buṅgadyaḥ (Karuṇāmaya), view from NE (June 2020)
object short description: The statue of Buṅgadyaḥ has been placed on the northern plinth of the Caitya. It was added by Gopi Maharjan, a guṭhī member, in the 1970s.

Object image caption: Bhuyū Cībhāḥ, Umāmaheśvara, view from NW (March 2020)
Bhuyū Cībhāḥ, Amoghasiddhi, view from NE (June 2020)
Bhuyū Cībhāḥ, Amitābha, view from NW (June 2020)
Bhuyū Cībhāḥ, Ratnasambhava, view from SW (June 2020)
Bhuyū Cībhāḥ, Akṣobhya, view from SE (June 2020)
Dathu Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-11-08
Dathu Bāhāḥ, Svayambhū Caitya, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-11-08
object short description: The statues of Buddha placed on the four cardinal directions of this Caitya are decaying. The part above its dome (garbha) must be a later addition.”

Object image caption: Dathu Bāhāḥ, Well, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-11-08
object short description: This well was initially constructed in square shape. After it was renovated, it was given the present-day rectangular shape. Previously, those carrying out the daily rituals in the Bāhāḥ were responsible to collect water from the well. However, this is not the case in the present-day.

Object image caption: Sundarī Cok, stone bed, view from W (May 2019)
object short description: This huge stone bed placed to the south of Tusāhiti is said to be the bed of King Siddhinarsiṃha Malla, and the place where he used to meditate. King Siddhinarasiṃha Malla was a great practitioner of yoga meditation. During winter, everyone else was shivering but the King used to rest on this bed wearing only a loin-cloth. During summer when the sun got very hot he wore many warm clothes and set the wood placed before him on fire. The stone bed of the king can still be found in the courtyard with these legends as its legacy. A statue of a monkey can be found to its north. The monkey is squatting down and holding a butter lamp in his hands, which rest on its lap. The figure may have once been used as a night lamp.

Object image caption: Sundarī Coka, Tusāhiti, panoramic view (from Kathmandu Valley Preservation Trust, 2010)
object short description:
Tusāhiṭī is located at the centre of the Sundarī Coka. Tu is a Newari word meaning sugarcane, while sā means tasty. The name Tusāhiṭī therefore literally means 'the spout which gives water as tasty as the juice of sugarcane' (Shrestha 1996, 3). A couple of nāgas encircle the structure, and it is believed that they allow the outflow of the water from the hiṭī. The entrance to the hiṭī is further guarded by a pair of lions. The raised heads of the nāgas are particularly beautiful. The spout is embellished with figures of Lakṣmī Nārāyaṇa seated on Garuḍa. The images of Lakṣmī Nārāyaṇa and Garuḍa, as well as those of other aquatic animals on the spout are all gilded. A statue of Bhagīratha holding the spout in two hands is installed beneath the spout. On top of the spout, one can find a small stone temple believed to be a miniature version of the famous Krishna Temple of Patan Darbar Square (LAL1340). It is carved out of a single block of stone and contains no cella. The hiṭī is filled with Hindu images of Śaiva, Vaiśnava, Tantric and other astral divinities. Shrestha (1996, 4-5) suggests that this spout was constructed by Siddhinarasiṃha Malla and was not intended for bathing but rather to offer holy water to the gods. It is therefore better described as a libation spout rather than a royal bath. The hiṭī was renovated between 2017-18. 

The names of the gods whose images are placed in the hiṭī are listed below (in a clockwise direction):

Images on top surface

1. Bagalāmukhī

2. Kalkī

3. Not recognized

4. Ananta Nāga

5. Vāsukī Nāga

6. Takṣaka Nāga

7. Candra

8. Karkoṭaka Nāga

9. Umāmaheśvara

10. Kṛṣṇa Hari

11. Agni

12. Image lost

13. Not recognized

14. Lakṣmī Narasiṃha

15. Unmatta Bhairava

16. Not recognized

17. Padma Nāga

18. Sūrya

19. Mahāpadma Nāga

20. Śaṅkhapāla Nāga

21. Kulika Nāga

22. Ratna Pañca Kumārī

23. Canḍa Bhairava

24. Bhīmasena

On the west side of step down - Vīrabhadra

On the east side of step down - Dvāradeva

Top west wall

First chamber:

1. Sammukha Bhairava

2. Tāṇdaveśvara

3. Krodha Bhairava with his śakti Vaiśṇavī

Second chamber:

4. Caṇḍa Bhairava with his consort Kumārī

5. Ruru Bhairava with his consort Māheśvarī

6. Asitāṅga Bhairava with his consort Brahmāyaṇī

Third chamber:

7. Bhairavordhvavaktra Saptasvara Ṛddhināyaka

8. Ardhanārīśvara Aṣṭamūrti Śiva (Hariśaṅkarī/Jhaṅkeśvarī according to Bühnemann, 2008, 90)

9. Sarvamaṅgaladevī

Top east wall

First chamber:

10. Gaṅgādhara Hari

11. Pañcamukha Hayagrīva

12. Pañcavaktra Ramāpati

13. Saṃhāra Bhairava with his consort Mahālakṣmī

14. Bhīṣaṇa Bhairava with his consort Cāmuṇḍā

Second chamber:

15. Karāla (Krodha) Bhairava with his consort Indrāyaṇī

16. Unmatta Bhairava with his consort Vārāhī

17. Durgāgaṇapariveṣṭhita Caṇḍī

18. Candra

19. Ekasya Bhairava with his consort Kumārī

Third chamber:

20. Pavanadeva with his consort

21. Not recognized yet

22. Umā-Maheśvara

23. Lakṣmī-Nārāyaṇa

24. Trijata Nāga (?)

Bottom west wall

First chamber:

1. Six empty niches

2. Nṛteśvara Saṅgīteśvara

3. Six empty niches

Second chamber:

4. Vīrabhadra

5. Mahākāla (reinstalled during the renovation of 1960/61)

6. Mātṛkāgaṇamadhyasthitā Mahiṣāsuramardinī

7. Vaṭuka Bhairava

8. Kṣetrapāla

Third chamber:

9. Trimātṛkā (Caṇḍikā, Cāmuṇḍā, Śivadūti)

10. Kārtikeya in tantric surrounded by 10 other gods

11. Śmaśāneśvarī

Bottom east wall

First chamber:

12. Bhūteśvarī

13. Trimātṛkā (Harisiddhi, Svetāmaha Bhairavī and Bālakumārī)

14. Śmaśāna Bhairava

15. Vātsalyayukta Pañcamukhahara

16. Siddhi Vināyaka

Second chamber:

17. Śaḍvaktra Bhairava

18. Pañcamukha Gaṇeśa

19. Ekādaśāsya Śmaśāna Bhairava with his consort

20. Dasavaktra Bhairava

21. Ekāsya Bhairava

Third chamber:

22. Gaurī-Lakṣmī

23. Caṇḍikādevī followed by Cāmuṇḍā and Śivadūti

24. Śrīkaṇṭhanāthayukta Śaḍvaktra Narasiṃha Bhairava

(Shrestha 1996, 8-10; Deva 1984, 40-57)

Object image caption: Āratī Chẽ, stone statue of Dhyānī Buddha, view from S (December 2019)
object short description: The statue is placed in a niche on the ground floor wall which faces south.

Object image caption: Bhaiṣajyarāja Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: The Caitya is tied up with iron rods that are meant to secure it against theft. Jīvanṛsiṃha, the consecrator of this Bāhāḥ, installed this Caitya in 1878 (NS 998).

Object image caption: Bhaiṣajyarāja Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: Mahākāla is located on the eastern wall. He stands on a corpse, holding a kartṛ (cutter) and a kapālā (skull bowl) and clasping a khaṭvāṅga.

Object image caption: Bhaiṣajyarāja Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: This four-handed Gaṇeśa can be found on the eastern wall. He is standing on a rat, holding a garland and a radish with his right hands, and an axe and a sweet ball with his left hands.

Object image caption: Bhaiṣajyarāja Bāhāḥ, Garuḍa statue, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: This small statue of Garuḍa is placed to the north of Bhīmasena's statue. The left hand and both feet of the image are missing.

Object image caption: Bhaiṣajyarāja Bāhāḥ, Bhīmasena statue, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: Bhīmasena is located to the north of the entrance. He is holding a club (gadā) in his right hand, while performing a gesture of protection (abhayamudrā) with his left.

Object image caption: Bhaiṣajyarāja Bāhāḥ, Mañjuśrī statue, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: The four-handed Mañjuśrī is placed towards the south from the entrance of the bāhāḥ. He is seated on a lotus pedestal. His upper left hand raises a sword (a weapon to cut down ignorance) whilst his upper right hand holds a book (with Buddha's teachings). His lower left hand holds  an arrow and his lower right hand is holding a bow. These are both symbols of penetrating wisdom.

Object image caption: Rāvatakoṭa Pañcadevala, temple 003, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
Rāvatakoṭa Pañcadevala, temple 002, view from NE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
Rāvatakoṭa Pañcadevala, temple 001, view from SW; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
Rāvatakoṭa Pañcadevala, temple 005, view from NW; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
object short description: View of the north-western corner of temple 005.

Object image caption: Rāvatakoṭa Pañcadevala, temple 004, view from SW; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
object short description: View of the south-western corner of temple 004.

Object image caption: Rārā pillars (east), pillar 003, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-06
Rārā pillars (east), pillar 002, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-06
object short description:
The upper part of the pillar contains two motifs, On top is the sun and moon and below is a stylised double vajra (viśvavajra). The latter symbol indicates the Buddhist affiliation of the person for which the monument was erected.

Below is an eroded inscription.

Object image caption: Rārā pillars (east), upper part of the pillar 001, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-06
object short description: The lower section of the pillar is lying on the ground, with its carved side facing the ground.

Object image caption: Nāpīcandra Mahāvihāra, Mahākāla, view from S (January 2019)
object short description: A statue of a standing Mahākāla holding kartṛ (chopper) and kapāla (skull bowl) is placed on the right side of the main entrance.

Object image caption: Nāpīcandra Mahāvihāra, Aśoka Caitya, view from E (January 2019)
object short description: This caitya stands on a rectangular plinth. Images of Buddha are placed inside the niches of four directions of the nemī. Above that there are round shaped niches in four directions and images of Buddha inside them. The images enshrined in the eastern and western sides of the niches were stolen and replaced by newly made images. The caitya is in good condition.

Object image caption: Statue of Buddha, view from NE (February 2019)
object short description: This statue of Buddha shows him sitting in bhūsparśa. Parts of the right hand and leg have broken off, most of the nimbus is missing and the damaged head has been patched up with cement mortar (probably some time around 1994 CE).

Object image caption: Licchavi Caitya fragment, view from N (February 2019)
object short description: A fragment of a Licchavi Caitya dome sits to the right of the Buddha statue.

Object image caption: Jyo Bāhāḥ, Licchavi Caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: The lower part of the caitya is subterranean; only the upper part is visible. Generally, Licchavi caityas are found without images in the niches, however, images of Buddha have been placed in this caitya. It is possible that these images were added at a later date, though they are now worn down.

Object image caption: Jyo Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: This octagonal maṇḍala does not contain images of Lokeśvaras.

Object image caption: Jyo Bāhāḥ, Caitya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: The four small niches on the four sides of the caitya remain empty. To the south of the caitya is a small hole. Local inhabitants maintain that Nāgarāja (king of serpents) resides there and that he sometimes emerges from the hole. To the north of the caitya, one can find a fire alter.

Object image caption: Jyo Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: Mahākāla is standing on a corpse. He holds a kartṛ (cutter) and a Kapāpā (skull bowl) and clasps a khatvāṅga.

Object image caption: Jyo Bāhāḥ, Hanumān statue, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: Hanumān is holding a club (gadā) with his right hand and resting his left hand on his thigh.

Object image caption: Jyo Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: This ten-handed Gaṇeśa is standing in ālīḍha posture together with his Śakti. His weapons could not be identified, as the image has been worn away.

Object image caption: Jyo Bāhāḥ, digichẽ, view from SE; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: This digichẽ is located to the north of the bāhāḥ. When functions are organised in the bāhāḥ, this place is used to hold feasts. This house was demolished in the 2015 earthquake. It was reconstructed in 2018 with the financial support of Lalitpur Sub-Metropolitan.

Object image caption: Jyo Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: There are no images of gods in the upper niches of the caitya.

Object image caption: Jyo Bāhjāḥ, Mañjuśrī, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: This image of Mañjuśrī is attached to the wall of a house located to the west of the bāhāḥ. He holds a sword and an arrow in his right hands and a book and a bow with his left hands.

Object image caption: Mākaḥ Bāhāḥ, śikharakūṭa caitya, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-03-03
object short description: Bodhisattvas are placed in the niches of the four cardinal directions of the caitya. Four Buddha statues are placed on the upper part. An oil-lamp balustrade surrounds the caitya and a metal canopy hangs above it.

Object image caption: Mākaḥ Bāhāḥ, statue of donor, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-03-03
object short description: This statue of a donor has been placed to the east of the śkharakūṭa caitya. There is no inscription. Oil lamps are lit on top of the statue.

Object image caption: Mākaḥ Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-03-03
object short description: The niche made on a wall right to the sanctum door houses a statue of Mahākāla. He is holding a kartṛ in his right hand and kapālapātra in his left hand. His left hand also clasps a khaṭvāṅga. A grillwork has been fixed in place for the protection of the statue. A wooden toraṇa with an image of Mahākāla is fixed above the niche.

Object image caption: Mākaḥ Bāhāḥ, Bhīmasena, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-03-03
object short description: This stone statue of Bhīmasena is located to the south of the outer entrance of the Bāhāḥ. Bhīmasena is shown killing Duḥśāsana. A wooden toraṇa is fixed above the statue.

Object image caption: Mākaḥ Bāhāḥ, Vasundharā, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-03-03
object short description: This stone statue of Vasundharā is placed to the west of the śikharakūṭa caitya. This statue was established a few years back.

Object image caption: Mākaḥ Bāhāḥ, Ganeśa, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-03-03
object short description: This statue of a standing Gaṇeśa has been placed in a niche made on the left wall of the Bāhāḥ. The four-handed Gaṇeśa holds a rosary and a radish in his right hands and an axe and sweet ball in his left hands. A grillwork has been fixed in place for the protection of the statue. A wooden toraṇa showing Gaṇeśa tops the niche.

Object image caption: Mākaḥ Bāhāḥ, Hanumān, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-03-03
object short description: This statue of Hanumān has been placed in a niche made on the left wall of the Bāhāḥ. A grillwork has been fixed around it to protect it from theft. A wooden toraṇa showing Gaṇeśa tops the niche.

Object image caption: Akṣobhya
object short description: Akṣobhya, the main deity of the Bāhāḥ, sits in bhūmisparśa in the sanctum.

Object image caption: Bhṛṅgāreśvara Mandira, statues of Buddha and Bhagīratha at the bottom of the coral tree, view from SW (October 2019)
Bhṛṅgāreśvara Mandira, Kīrtimukha Bhairava on the southern courtyard, view from E (October 2019)
object short description: This small plot to the south of the Umāmaheśvara shrine is protected with iron chains. Local residents believe that a statue of Kīrtimukha Bhairava can be found underneath the stone slab. It has been hidden because it may cast an evil eye upon them.

Object image caption: Bhṛṅgāreśvara Mandira, trident (triśūla) in front of the western entrance, view from SW (October 2019)
object short description: The stone trident (triśūla) is made from a single stone and stands on a lotus pedestal. A Brahmin by the name of Nārāyaṇa offered it to Bhṛṅgāreśvara in 1614 (NS 734). Local residents decorate it on the 14th of the bright fortnight of Caitra (which is the day before the Pyakhaḥ Jātrā), coating its tip with copper and anointing its lower part with oil.

Object image caption: Bhṛṅgāreśvara Mandira, statue of Nandī in front of the western entrance, view from S (October 2019)
object short description: The Nandī statue is anointed with oil and decorated with various colours during the Pyakhaḥ Jātrā (organised on the full moon day of Caitra).

Object image caption: Bhṛṅgāreśvara Mandira, a statue of Umāmaheśvara in the southern courtyard, view from N (October 2019)
object short description: This statue, dated to the 18th century (L.S. Bangdel 1995, 476), is kept inside an iron cage and is located to the south of the main temple. Two rounded liṅgas (probably from the Licchavi period) with octagonal bottoms and rectangular bases (yonī) flank the statue.

Object image caption: Bhṛṅgāreśvara Mandira, Jagannātha shrine in the south-west courtyard, view from E (October 2019)
object short description: The pinnacle and upper roof of the temple are gilded, but the lower roof is tiled. A Jagannātha statue is enshrined in the sanctum. The metal toraṇa is fixed on top of the entrance, with a lotus in the middle. The daily worship is performed at the shrine by the priest of the Bhṛṅgāreśvara temple.

Object image caption: Bhṛṅgāreśvara Mandira, a statue of Hanumān in the south-west courtyard, view from N (October 2019)
object short description: This statue of Hanumān performs varada and abhaya gestures with its right and left hands respectively. It has been placed on a jalaharī, and was established by the local residents in 2015.

Object name: A small shrine with various deities
Object image caption: Bhṛṅgāreśvara Mandira, a small shrine in the southern courtyard, view from E (October 2019)
Bhṛṅgāreśvara Mandira, main śivaliṅga in the sanctum, view from W (October 2019)
object short description: This liṅga used to be worshipped by the Brāhma community (S. Jośī 2069, 26). It is placed on a lotus pedestal, though the east-western part of this is broken. Local residents believe that a priest of the temple once worshipped the liṅga whilst wearing a ring made out of kuśa grass. He had such a pure heart that it later turned into a golden ring. However, greed overcame him. He tried to produce more gold by wearing ten kuśa rings, and when this did not work, the enraged priest attacked the liṅga with an axe. This is why the liṅga is now deformed (S. Jośī 2069, 29). Another legend tells that Bhṛṅgāreśvara Māhādeva will bring the monsoon rain when he is showered with milk or if a fire ritual is performed in the temple for him (S. Jośī 2069, 28).

Object image caption: Bhṛṅgāreśvara Mandira, a statue of Jalaśayana Nārāyaṇa at the northeast courtyard, view from S (October 2019)
object short description: The residents of Sunaguthi helped to make the statue of Jalaśayana Nārāyaṇa in Buḍhānīlakaṇṭha during the Licchavi period. The present inhabitants of Sunāguthi created the statue (named Bhṛṅgu Nārāyaṇa and a replica of the one in Buḍhānīlakanṭha) to connect themselves to this historical event.

Object image caption: Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 006, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 001, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
object short description:
The pillar was damaged in its upper part (to the right on the picture).

The pillar presents carvings of a triangular shape (a mountain?) and a flower pattern.

Object image caption: Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 012, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
object short description: The upper part of the pillar has a carved niche that contained either a religious image or an inscribed metal plate.

Object image caption: Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 011, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 010, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
object short description: The nature of the carved motif is unclear. It evokes a stylised anthropomorphic figure. Giuseppe Tucci published a similar pillar, of finer details, that he locates on the road from Dullu to Surkhet (Tucci 1956: 39, fig. 46).

Object image caption: Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 003, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 002, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 013, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
object short description:
A stūpa is represented in the upper part, together with two star motifs.

This pillar was first published in Tucci 1956: 39, fig. 47.

Object image caption: Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 009, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
object short description: The pillar contains carvings of spirals and a triangular shape.

Object image caption: Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 007, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 004, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
object short description: The upper part of the pillar has a carved niche that contained either a religious image or an inscribed metal plate.

Object image caption: Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 005, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
object short description: The upper part of the pillar has a carved niche that contained either a religious image or an inscribed metal plate.

Object image caption: Ḍāḍimāḍī Pillars, pillar 008, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
Kvay Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya in the courtyard, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-29
Kvay Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla inside a wall niche of a private house through which the Bāhāḥ can be accessed, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-29
Kvay Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-29
Kvay Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa inside a wall niche of a private house through which the Bāhāḥ can be accessed, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-29
Chvāsakāminī, maṇḍala, view from W (February 2020)
Bhagavān Degaḥ, Śākyamuni Buddha, view from E (December 2019)
object short description: This statue was enshrined around four decades ago.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, well at the Northwest corner of the temple, view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-01
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Nārāyaṇa shrine, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-01
object short description: An aniconic stone worshipped as Nārāyaṇa is kept inside the shrine.

Object name: Unidentified stone statue (believed to be Sitalā or Hāratī by the locals))(
Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, unidentified stone statue in the niche, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-01
object short description: This statue is kept near to the enshrined Ganesha in the sanctum. Due to its heavily damaged condition, the identity of this statue is not clear. As per Local's strong belief, the statue belongs to Sitalā (Hāratī). The iconographic features of this statue match up with the female statues from the 2nd-3rd century found in the valley.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, fragmented stone statues in the niche, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-01
object short description: Three small stone statues are kept inside this niche. Among these, two statues depict Bhīmasena and the other one depicts Lokeśvara.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of Gaṇeśa in the sanctum, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-01
object short description: This stone statue of Gaṇeśa is enshrined in the sanctum sanctorum of the temple. The iconographic features of the statue suggest that this is one of the oldest Gaṇeśa statues of the Valley. The Gaṇeśa statues of the Valley made between the 5th and 7th centuries have certain distinctive features, such as having only two arms and a large belly, wearing no ornaments, sitting in the ardhaparyaṅka posture, the trunk slightly bent to the left, touching the sweet ball and are shown sitting alone even without the deity's vehicle  (Khanāla VS 2074, 163). The statue within this temple exactly matches these features. With this in mind, one can assume that the present pagoda-style temple was built in the Malla period, thus encompassing the Licchavi period Gaṇeśa shrine into its sanctum.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of Nandī, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-01
object short description: This Nandī faces the main deity of the sanctum and is usually located in front of the temple. Exceptionally, this statue is currently placed in the south-east corner of the temple.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of Viṣṇu on the wall niche of the private house, eastern side from the temple, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-01
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-01
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Licchavi Caitya, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-01
object short description: A post Licchavi caitya has been placed on a newer caitya structure of unknown date.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-01
object short description: A Jyāpu family living in Tyāgaḥ Ṭola established this Dharmadhātu in 1977.

Object image caption: Pim Bāhāḥ Caitya, pillar, view from W (March 2019)
Pim Bāhāḥ Caitya, Vajradhātu Caitya  2, view from E (March 2019)
Pim Bāhāḥ Caitya, Vajradhātu Caitya  1, view from N (March 2019)
Pim Bāhāḥ Caitya, bell with inscription, view from E (March 2019)
object short description: This bell is placed to the south of Akṣobhya, the main deity of the Caitya. Khaḍgamāna Siṃha donated this bell in VS 1987.

Object image caption: Pim Bāhāḥ Caitya, Vajradhātu Caitya 4, view from W (March 2019)
Pim Bāhāḥ Caitya, Akṣhobya statue, view from E (March 2019)
Pim Bāhāḥ Caitya, Vajradhātu Caitya 3, view from S (March 2019)
Pim Bāhāḥ, caitya, view from S (March 2019)
object short description: This caitya stands to the west of the main Caitya. Somebody was cleaning the nearby pond some time before 2002 and discovered part of a caitya (containing bhagiṃ). This was found to date back to the 12th century and was used to establish this smaller caitya.

Object image caption: Pim Bāhāḥ Caitya, Mañjuśrī shrine, view from W (March 2019)
object short description: Previously, a mandaḥpāḥ symbolising Mañjuśrī was worshipped here by the members of Mū Bāhāḥ as their family deity. In 2006, the image of Mañjuśrī was enshrined and this caitya was constructed. The deity is shown holding a sword in his right hand and a lotus stalk in his left hand.

Object image caption: Pim Bāhāḥ Caitya, dharmadhātu manḍala, view from SW (March 2019)
object short description: This dharmadhātu manḍala is large in size. None of its eight faces display images of Bodhisattvas. Below the lotus petals are 24 small niches, some of which contain statues of Buddhas. Many of these statues are heavily worn down, and some are missing. There is a mandaḥpāḥ and a fire altar to the east of the dharmadhātu manḍala.

Object image caption: Dyaḥ Sataḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from W (April 2017)
object short description: This five-headed sandalwood statue of Gaṇeśa made out of sandalwood is kept on the first floor of the Sataḥ. It is mounted on a chariot alongside Bālakumārī to be taken out for the procession on the full moon day of Caitra.

Object image caption: Dyaḥ Sataḥ, statue of Kumāra, view from W (April 2017)
object short description: This sandalwood statue of Kumāra is kept on the first floor of the Sataḥ. This, too, is mounted on a chariot on the full moon day of Caitra to be taken out for the procession.

Object image caption: Dyaḥ Sataḥ, an aniconic image of Hanumān, view from W (November 2019)
object short description: This triangular hole on the Satah's wall is located to the west of the main entrance of Bhṛṅgāreśvara Mandira and is worshipped as an aniconic image of Hanumān by local residents. Locals believe that offerings of kã̄sa (stalk of the grass Saccharum spontaneum) and varieties of limes or wild limes (jyāmira/bimiro) will entice the aniconic Hnumān to cure children from stomach ailments and keep evil spirits away from them.

Object image caption: Dyaḥ Sataḥ, statue of Mahādeva, view from W (April 2017)
object short description: This sandalwood statue of Mahādeva is kept on the first floor of the Sataḥ. It is mounted on a chariot alongside Bālakumārī to be taken out for the procession on the full moon day of Caitra.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, an unidentified stone statue in the sanctum, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-05
object short description: Inside the sanctum sanctorum, a statue of a couple is placed to the west of Gaṇeśa. The statue is severely eroded therefore they cannot be recognized. According to locals, the statue was lying outside the temple before some months and they recently placed it in the sanctum.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of Gaṇeśa in the sanctum, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-05
object short description: A stone statue of Gaṇeśa has been installed inside the sanctum sanctorum of the temple. The four-armed Gaṇeśa holds an akṣamālā in his upper right hand and an ax in the upper left hand. Both lower hands are eroded. A toraṇa covered with metal sheet has been fixed on the upper background.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, stone statue of Nandī, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-05
Yanamugaḥ Kṛṣṇadyaḥ Phalcā 1, stone statue of Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa in the wall niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-05
Yanamugaḥ Kṛṣṇadyaḥ Phalcā 1, Kṛṣṇa shrine with toraṇa above, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-05
Yanamugaḥ Kṛṣṇadyaḥ Phalcā 1, stone statue of Karuṇāmaya in the wall niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-05
Yanamugaḥ Kṛṣṇadyaḥ Phalcā 1, stone statue of Nārāyaṇa in the wall niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-05
Yanamugaḥ Kṛṣṇadyaḥ Phalcā 1, stone statue of Hanumān on the south west corner of the wall, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-05
Yanamugaḥ Kṛṣṇadyaḥ Phalcā 1, stone statue of Nāmasaṅgīti in the wall niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-05
Yanamugaḥ Kṛṣṇadyaḥ Phalcā 1, stone statue of Bhairava in the wall niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-05
Yanamugaḥ Kṛṣṇadyaḥ Phalcā 1, stone statue of Mahākāla in the wall niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-05

Object name: Bhīmasena Dyaḥchẽ, Cyāsal, bell in upper storey
Object image caption: Bhīmasena Dyaḥchẽ, Cyāsal, niche of Sūrya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-08
object short description: There is a damaged statue of Sūrya on the southern wall of the ground floor. The figure of Sūrya is missing from the statue. However, one can identify his chariot, with seven horses driven by Aruṇa, and an image of Daṇḍī and Piṅgala to his right and left-hand side respectively. Eight planets are shown to be circling the image. There is no inscription.

Object name: Bhīmasena Dyaḥchẽ, Cyāsal, bell in upper storey
Object image caption: Bhīmasena Dyaḥchẽ, a bell on the first floor; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-08
object short description: There is a bell in front of the Bhīmasena statue on the first floor. It was donated by Gaumi Siṃha and his friends and has an inscription which refers to Bhīmasena as Mahāhindu Bhīmarājeśvara.

Object name: Bhīmasena Dyaḥchẽ, Cyāsal, bell in upper storey
Object image caption: Bhīmasena Dyaḥchẽ, statue of Nārāyaṇa, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-25
object short description: The statue of Nārāyaṇa is placed in the wall behind the sanctum. The statue faces west, and there are further statues of two devotees to its right and left. The statue has been corroded due to the continued use of vermillion powder; it is in a very bad state.

Object image caption: Ārīthāy Jaḥdhuṃhiṭi, Bhagīratha, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-29
Ārīthāy Jaḥdhuṃhiṭi, hydrant with kaladhārā in front of the Hiṭi, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-29

Haribhajana Phalcā, Lokeśvara, view from N (November 2019) 

This statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara is located in a niche on the southern wall of the Phalcā. His right hand is performing varada mudrā whilst his left hand holds the stem of a blossoming lotus flower.
Vãlā Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālya Caitya, view from SW (September 2019)
object short description: Images of Caturmahārājas, namely Vīṇārāja (east), Khaḍgarāja (south), Caityarāja (west) and Dhvarāja (north), can be found above the plinth. Four lions and images of the Four Dhyānī Buddhas face in each of the four cardinal directions and are seated on top of lotus petals with their vehicles. One can find further images of the Four Buddhas and of Tārā above another three lotus petals.

Object image caption: Ganedyaḥ, an aniconic stone worshipped as Nāsaḥdyaḥ, view from S (October 2019)
object short description: The Nāsaḥdyaḥ shrine is attached to the southern wall of the temple. Its group of three triangular holes is said to be an aniconic representation of the deity. Nāsaḥdyaḥ is the deity of the traditional kā̃bājā (music played during the funeral procession and also during other religious activities); new learners of music come to worship him.

Object image caption: Ganedyaḥ, Sarasvatī shrine (statues of Mahākāla, Sarasvatī and Rādhākṛṣṇa), view from W (October 2019)
object short description: These shrines are attached to the back wall of the Ganedyaḥ temple. The left shrine belongs to Mahākāla. His statue was established by Suvarṇarāma Jośī and Suvarṇalakṣmī Jośī in 2014. A four-handed Sarasvatī statue is placed in the middle shrine. She is holding a rosary in her upper right hand and performing a gesture of varada with her lower right hand. She holds a book in her upper left hand and performs abhaya with the lower one. To the left of this Sarasvatī statue and in the third shrine stands Lakṣmī, who is holding a lotus bud.  Bangdel (1995, 475) dates this statue to the 15th century. A statue of Rādhākṛṣṇa has been placed to the right of the Sarasvatī shrine.

Object image caption: Ganedyaḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from E (October 2019)
object short description: This Caitya lies to the north of the Ganedyaḥ temple.

Object image caption: Ganedyaḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa in the sanctum, view from E (October 2019)
object short description: The four-handed Gaṇeśa statue holds a rosary and a radish in his right hands, and an axe and a sweet ball in his left hands. Bangdel (1995, 476) has dated this statue as being from the 18th century. A highly deteriorated stone statue can be found to the left of the main statue, and is said to be the original statue of the sanctum. A legend tells that a man named Hākucā replaced the old Gaṇeśa statue with a new one. The deity was furious. Blisters broke out across Hākucā's body, and after a period of intense suffering, he ultimately passed away.

Object image caption: Taḥdhãlibi Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07
object short description: The Caitya is surrounded by an oil-lamp balustrade. Brass-clad images of Buddha have been placed in the niches at each of the four cardinal directions. Stone lions sit at each of the caitya's four corners.

Object image caption: Taḥdhãlibi Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07

Umāmaheśvara Mandira, statue of Sarasvatī, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-05

Umāmaheśvara Mandira, statue of Umāmaheśvara in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-05
Umāmaheśvara Mandira, statue of Umāmaheśvara at the Southern side of the main statue in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-05
Umāmaheśvara Mandira, statue of Bhīmasena flanking the staircase in the southern side, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-05
Umāmaheśvara Mandira, elephant (A) flanking in the southern side of the staircase, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-05
Umāmaheśvara Mandira, elephant (B) flanking in the northern side of the staircase, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-05
Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa Mandira, tulasī-maṭha, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-16
Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa Mandira, dabū, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-16
object short description: The elevated platform (dabū) is located at the crossroads between the roads to Mvaḥmadugallī, Dhaugala and Mahāpāla. A dance performance from Ṭheco called gathupyākhã is performed at this platform on the 10th day of the Daśaĩ festival.

Object image caption: Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa Mandira, stone statue of Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-16
object short description: This statue is a replica of the original one, which was stolen in 1984 (Bangdel 1989, 246) and smuggled to the United States of America (cp. Thompson 2020).

Object image caption: Matū Ajimā Mandira, Trident (triśūla), view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-01-07
object short description: If anyone wishes to sacrifice in this temple it is offered to this trident, not directly to the Matū Ajimā,

Object image caption: Matū Ajimā Mandira, stone sword, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-01-07
Matū Ajimā Mandira, Lion (east), view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-01-07
Matū Ajimā Mandira, bell supported from a stone stand, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-01-07
Matū Ajimā Mandira, Lukumahādyaḥ (Hidden Śiva), view from above; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-01-07
Matū Ajimā Mandira, wall with a display of stone pillars, toraṇa (tympanum) and an inscription, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-01-07
object short description: Previously it was an open door. The door was blocked with a wall as Matū Ajimā could be seen from the road outside.

Object image caption: Matū Ajimā Mandira, Lion, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-01-07

Object name: Group of small statues and fragments
Object image caption: Matū Ajimā Mandira, group of small statues and fragments, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-01-07
Bhurtī Pañcadevala 3, central śikhara, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
Bhurtī Pañcadevala 3, southern śikhara, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
object short description:
The śikhara is oriented to the north, and to the central temple.

There are gaps between some of the stones of the tower.

Object image caption: Bhurtī Pañcadevala 3, northern śikhara, view from south; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24

Bhurtī Pañcadevala 5, eastern śikhara, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24

Viśvakarmā Devala, statue of Viśvakarmā in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-24
Mahākāla shrine, stone pillar, view from W (November 2019)
object short description: This stone pillar is six feet high and was erected in 1951 CE (VS 2008) by Guru Kavi Prasada after he organised saptāha bhajana (a one-week long religious event) in Sunaguthi. This square pillar has a lotus pedestal on top of it and bears inscriptions on two sides.

Object image caption: Mahākāla shrine, wooden post with a bell (VS 2031), view from SW (October 2019)
Mahākāla shrine, stone statue of Mahākāla, view from S (October 2019)
object short description: The statue of Mahākāla is standing on top of a corpse and holding kartikā, kapāla and khaṭvāṅga.

Object image caption: Chāya Bāhāḥ, statue of Kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ, view from N (March 2020)
Chāya Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from N (March 2020)
Chāya Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from N (March 2020)
Chāya Bāhāḥ, Vasundharā shrine, view from N (March 2020)
Chāya Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu, view from N (March 2020)
Chāya Bāhāḥ, śikharakūṭa caitya, view from NE (March 2020)
object short description: This caitya was made by Ratnamuni Vajrācārya in 1667. He also established a guṭhī for the management of the Bāhāḥ and this caitya.

Object image caption: Rāmacandra Mandira, statue of Hanumān attached to the southern wall of the sanctum, view from NW ; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-11
Rāmacandra Mandira, statue of Rāma-Sitā-Lakṣmaṇa in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-11

Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa Mandira, statue of Gaṇeśa in the sanctum (next to the Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa statue), view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-16
Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa Mandira, statue of Hanumān, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-16
