Jagannātha Mandira, Nṛsiṃha shrine, view from E (October 2019)
Jagannātha Mandira, shrine with statues of Umāmaheśvara, Bhagavatī and Hanumān, view from N (October 2019)
Jagannātha Mandira, bell, view from S (October 2019)
object short description: The bell is supported by a frame made of stone. The inscription on the bell is no longer legible as it has been covered with thick layers of oil.

Object image caption: Jagannātha Mandira, shrine with Garuḍa, view from W (October 2019)
object short description: An inscription and two statues of devotees are located on the west side of the plinth. The inscription is obliterated by thick layers of ghee and oil.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira at Cyāsaḥ, an iconic stone of Nandī, view from W (March 2019)
Yatkhā Phalcā, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-04-05
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Palāncoka Bhagavatī, view from NE; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Bhairavī, view from NW; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, aniconic statue of Manakāmanā, view from SW; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, Śivaliṅga, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
object short description: This four-faced Śivaliṅga is worshipped as Paśupati.

Object image caption: Bālakumārī Mandira, Peacock Pillar, view from SE; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Mahālakṣmī, view from SW; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Dakṣiṇakālī , view from SE; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Vaiṣṇavī, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Vārāhī, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Kumārī, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Brahmāyaṇī, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of the Simbāli couple, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
object short description: This statue is believed to be of the Jośī couple from the Simbāli clan who established a guṭhī in the temple.

Object image caption: Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Mahālakṣmī, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Rudrāyaṇī, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Cāmuṇḍā, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Indrāyaṇī, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, Guhyeśvarī, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, aniconic statue of Kumārī, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
object short description: The local women who have mensuration problems worship this aniconic statue of Kumārī to get better.

Object image caption: Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Bhairava, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Bālakumārī Mandira, statue of Bālakumārī, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-22
Tāpā Hiti East, Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: Both Lakṣmī and Nārāyaṇa are shown standing. Nārāyaṇa holds a conch and a club in his two right hands and wheel and lotus in his left hands. Their vehicles, Garuḍa and a tortoise, are at their sides.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti East, Viṣṇu, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: Viṣṇu is standing in the samabhaṅga posture. This idol once had four hands, but the rear two have since worn away. His lower right hand was previously shown performing a varada gesture whilst his left hand was holding a conch (Bangdel 1982, 64). The statue was dilapidated, and locals sought to repair it, though this means that it is no longer in its original form. Bangdel (1982, 64) dates back this statue to the 4th century.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti East, Umāmaheśvara, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-03-29
object short description: Śiva is shown here with four hands. One of his right hands holds a rosary and the other is shown performing the gesture of varada. Similarly, he holds a trident with one of his left hands whilst the other rests on Umā's shoulder. Attendants of Śiva, including Gaṇeśa, can be seen below the idol. Bangdel (1995, 287) dates this statue to the 15th century.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti East, Viṣṇu, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: Two statues of Viṣṇu are erected on the same stone on the east wall of the Hiti alongside the Umāmaheśvara statue (LAL0841-008). Both statues of Viṣṇu have the same features. They are both depicted holding a conch and a lotus in their right hands and a wheel and a mace in their left hands.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti East, Śivaliṅga, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-03-29
object short description: Locals have sought to protect this śivaliṅga by fixing an iron fence around it after several attempts were made to steal it. Four Nandī statues have been installed to the west of the śivaliṅga.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti East, Umāmaheśvara, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: Śiva is shown here with four hands. One of his right hands holds a rosary whilst the other performs a varada gesture. He is holding a trident with one of his left hands whilst the other rests on Umā's shoulder. Umā's head looks unusual and might have been added later.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti East, the central water spout, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: Water flows mainly from the middle spout, which is called Taḥdhāḥ Hiti. The entire Hiti is also sometimes referred to as Taḥdhāḥ Hiti. The spout does not have a lid (hitipusā). A statue of Bhagiratha had been installed under the spout but has since gone missing.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti East, eastern water spout, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: The eastern spout has been built in the shape of a buffalo head. It often runs dry; very little water flows from it even during the rainy season. People do not use this spout even when it does produce water.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti East, western water spout, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: The western spout is also made in the shape of a buffalo head. It too often runs dry, even in the rainy season, and is rarely used.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti East, Sage Agastya Shrine, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: A statue of Agastya has been erected above the middle spout (LAL0841-001). The statue of sage Agastya sits atop a water pot holding a trident and water pot in his left hands and some beads in his right hand. His other right hand is shown in the process of performing a blessing.

Object image caption: Nārāyana Mandira, statue of Nārāyaṇa, view from S; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-06-17
Nārāyana Mandira, Śrīdhara Viṣṇu, view from S; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-06-17
Gutpau Caitya, statue of Amitābha inside a niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-20
Gutpau Caitya, statue of Amoghasiddhi inside a niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-20
Gutpau Caitya, statue of Lokeśvara with an inscription on its base inside a niche, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-20
Gutpau Caitya, statue of Ratnasambhava inside a niche, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-20
Gutpau Caitya, statue of Akṣobhya placed inside a niche, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-20
Jyāthā Bāhāḥ, Masks of Aṣṭamātṛkā Dance, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Jyāthā Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Jyāthā Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Jyāthā Bāhāḥ, Bhairava, view from N; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Jyāthā Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa, view from N; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Jyāthā Bāhāḥ, Statue of Padmarāja Śākya, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Bekhārāja Bāhāḥ, statue of a sitting Gaṇeśa, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-07
Bekhārāja Bāhāḥ, standing Mahākāla holding kartṛ and kapāla, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-07
Bekhārāja Bāhāḥ, śikharakūṭa caitya in front of the main shrine, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-07
object short description: This caitya stands on a rectangular plinth. Images of lions and jvalānhāykã can be found on each of the four sides of its vedikā. There are toraṇas in each of the four cardinal directions, each of which display images of the Bodhisattva at their centre. There is a bhagiṃ above the toranas, and four images of Buddha above this. Above these images, in turn, one can see two layers of lotus petals. These are topped by a kumbha, then harmikā and 13 bhuvanas, and finally crowned by the pinnacle.

Object image caption: Bekhārāja Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala in front of the main shrine and unfinished carving, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-07
object short description: Eight Lokeśvaras have been placed in each of the eight compass directions within the octagonal dharmadhātu maṇḍala. However, the western face is the only one engraved with a sketch of Padmapāṇi Bodhisattva. There are no images of Bodhisattvas on the other seven sides. This is unusual for a dharmadhātu maṇḍala and might indicate that this object's construction was never finished.

Object image caption: Viśvakarmā Mandira, Lion Pillar, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-09
Viśvakarmā Mandira, aniconic stone worshipped as Bhīmasena, view of the from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-09
object short description: This aniconic Bhīmasena statue is established inside the sanctum and is worshiped on the day of Bhīmasenapūjā. The wooden toraṇa which was placed above it was stolen.

Object image caption: Viśvakarmā Mandira, aniconic statue of Gaṇeśa, view of the from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-09
object short description: If one wishes to sacrifice an animal to Viśvakarmā, it is not offered directly to him, but to this aniconic stone worshipped as Gaṇeśa which is crowned with a brass toraṇa.

Object image caption: Viśvakarmā Mandira, aniconic stone worshipped as Viśvakarmā, view of the from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-09
object short description: Viśvakarmā is established as three circular niches. It is crowned with a wooden toraṇa. The icon of Viśvakarmā attached to the toraṇa was stolen.

Object image caption: Hayagrīva Mandira, statue of Hayagrīva Bhairava, view from N; photo by Christiane Brosius; 2019-11-18
object short description:
Hayagrīva is shown holding a bowl in his left hand and performing karaṇa with his right hand.

Currently (March 2020), due to the ongoing restoration work, the Hayagrīva statue is kept in storage in the building adjacent to the north-east of the temple.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti West, Amoghasiddhi Shrine, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: The statue of Amoghasiddhi is placed in a stone made structure, above the spout called Cīdhāḥ (LAL0842-001). Bangdel (1995, 287) dates this statue to the 12th century.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti West, water spout west, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: This east-facing spout too can be seen dripping during the rainy season, but no one collects water from it anymore. Until a few decades back, the spot had a full flow of water coming through the place where one can see a recently built Bhairava Shrine (LAL0840-005) in front of the Gaṇeśa temple (LAL0840) next to the Hiti.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti West, central water spout, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: This spout is called Cīḍhāḥ and has no cover (hitipusā).

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti West, Umāmaheśvara, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: Since this statue is deteriorated sharply, the faces of Umā and Maheśvara and objects on their hands cannot be identified.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti West, Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: In this statue, Lakṣmī and Nārāyaṇa are in standing position. The later is holding a gadā on his one of the left hands. The objects he is holding on rest of his hands are not clear. Nārayaṇa and Lakṣmī are flanked by a Garuḍa and tortoise.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti West, an unidentified statue of a female deity view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-03-29
object short description: This female deity has four arms and has worn a skull garland. She is holding an akṣamālā and flower on her right hands, whereas the object she is holding on her left hands cannot identified.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti West, Garudnārāyaṇa, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: In this statue, Nārāyaṇa is sitting on a garuḍa figure and holding a conch and wheel on his right hands, and a gadā and padma on his left hands.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti West, smalll water spout, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: This east-facing spout is called Byā̃cā and it can be seen slightly dripping during the rainy season.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti West, Caturvyūha Caitya, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: Four Bodhisattvas are placed on the niches of the four directions of this Caitya. Excepting Maitreya kept in the west niche, other three Bodhisattvas cannot be identified. According to Gutschow (1997, 113), Vajrapāṇi and Padmapāṇi are kept on the east and west niches, respectively, whereas the one kept on the north niche cannot be accurately identified. Bangdel (1995, 287) dates this Caitya around 7th-8th century.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti West, Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-02
object short description: In this statue, Narāyaṇa can been seen holding a conch and padma on his right hands, and a gadā and cakra on his left hands. Lakṣmī is sitting on the lap of Nārāyaṇa and placing her left foot on a tortoise.

Object image caption: Tāpā Hiti West, Licchavi Caitya, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-03-29
object short description: This Caitya stands on a tall stone plinth. The eight niches above the garbha (dome) are empty. The parts made of cement above the adytum were recently added. According to the local residents, the Caitya was built by the Śreṣṭha caste members living in Tāpā Hiti. The decedents of those Śreṣṭhas still collect the sacrificial fee (bheṭī) offered to the Caitya on every 2nd dark fortnight of Bhādra.

Object image caption: Jaḥrũhiti, statue of Bhagīratha, view from W (November 2019)
Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, statue of Gaṇeśa, Mañjuśrī and Mahākāla, view from W (February 2020)
object short description: Statues of Gaṇeśa, Mañjuśrī and Mahākāla are placed to the west of the Caitya. Gaṇeśa holds an akṣamālā in his upper right hand and radish in his lower right hand. His upper left hand is performing the gesture of abhaya whilst his lower hand holds an axe. Mañjuśrī holds a bow and book in his left hands and a sword and arrow in his right hands. Mahākāla is shown standing on a corpse holding a kartṛ (a knife) in his right hand whilst his left-hand holds a kapāpāpātra (a skull bowl) and clasps a khaṭvāṅga (a club).

Object image caption: Śikharakūṭa Caitya, stone oil lamp, view from W (October 2019)

Silkhu Phalcā, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from SE (Mar 2020)
Silkhu Phalcā, small shrine with stone stele, view from NE (May 2020)
Silkhu Phalcā, Shrine with a statue of Śākyamuni Buddha, view from E (May 2020)
object short description: The shrine is located at the bank of the river. It has been damaged by floods.

Object image caption: Silkhu Phalcā, cremation shed, view from SE (May 2020)
Silkhu Phalcā, modern Phalcā, view from E (May 2020)
object short description: This Phalcā is located to the south of the Sikhu Phalcā. The inscription attached to its wall mentions that it was commissioned by Baccurāma and his three sons in VS 1981 (1924 CE). The Phalcā was maintained by Baccurāma’s grandson Śivapradāsa. Around VS 2058 (2001 CE) Surajanātha, another grandson of Baccurāma, reconstructed the Phalcā as a crudely built one-storey brick and concrete structure. It is further mentioned that the land, located to the west from this Phalcā has been secured to support religious functions and the upkeep of the Phalcā. The cremation ground situated in front of the Phalcā is used by the Mālī community of Bhājaṅgala. During the funeral nāyakhiṃ and kāhā music is played nearby the Phalcā.

Object image caption: Naka Bahī Phalcā 4, Nāsaḥdyaḥ shrine, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: The shrine of Nāsaḥdyaḥ (Nṛtyeśvara) is located in the north-eastern corner of the first floor. The room is used for classical music classes. Various musical instruments played by the Jyāpu community are assembled in the room.

Object image caption: Naka Bahī Phalcā 4, statue of Viṣṇu (B), view from E (September 2019)
object short description: A four-handed Viṣṇu is sitting in a paryaṅka posture.

Object image caption: Naka Bahī  Phalcā 4, statue of Viṣṇu (A), view from E (September 2019)
object short description: This statue shows a four-handed Viṣṇu wearing a long garland and standing on top of Garuḍa in a samapāda posture. His weapons could not be identified.

Object image caption: Taḥdhã Bahī, Aśoka Caitya, view from E; photo by Ashma Adhikari; 2019-06-14
object short description: This Licchavi styled Caitya stands on top of a brick plinth. There are four niches on the upper part and twelve on the lower half. Images of Buddha, Bodhisattva and others have been placed in these niches. According to local inhabitants, these niches have always remained empty, and the images were placed there recently. Stone lions sit at the four corners of the caitya. Statues of devotees can be found sitting on the southern plinth. The pedestal of the statue is inscribed with the date NS 873.

Object image caption: Taḥdhã Bahī, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Ashma Adhikari; 2019-06-14
object short description: There are images of Bodhisattvas at each of the four directions of the Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala. The other four corners are left blank. A metal vajra has been fixed on top of it. A sacrificial altar lies towards south of the Maṇḍala. Two stone pillars have been erected at the south east and south west.

Object image caption: Taḥdhã Bahī, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Ashma Adhikari; 2019-06-14
object short description: Images of Bodhisattva have been engraved on the four faces of the Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, and vajras are placed in the four corners. Statues of Jogadhana and his family (the donors) have been engraved on the plinth. The Dharmadhātu is in good condition.

Object image caption: Taḥdhã Bahī, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Ashma Adhikari; 2019-06-14
Taḥdhã Bahī, Vajra, view from N; photo by Ashma Adhikari; 2019-06-14
object short description: The stone vajra has been fixed on top of a small stone pillar. Images of 12 devotees and their names have been engraved upon it. There is an inscription on the back side of the pillar. The object is in good condition.

Object image caption: Taḥdhã Bahī, Mahākāla statue, view from N; photo by Ashma Adhikari; 2019-06-14
object short description: This Mahākāla image is placed to the north of the outer entrance of the monastic building. A two-handed Mahākāla holds kartṛ in his right hand and kapālapātra in his left hand. This object is slightly damaged, and the image has worn away.

Object image caption: Taḥdhã Bahī, Viśvakarmā, view from S; photo by Ashma Adhikari; 2019-06-14
object short description: This shrine of Viśvakarmā lies to the north of the outer entrance of the monastic building. There is no statue of Viśvakarmā, only a niche. Above this niche is a metal toraṇa containing an image of Viśvakarmā. A special worship is performed here annually on the 8th day of the bright half of Āśvina (Mahā Aṣṭamī). This shrine is slightly damaged, The toraṇa offered to Viśvakarmā is eroded.

Object image caption: Taḥdhã Bahī, Salãśālā building, view from N; photo by Ashma Adhikari; 2019-06-14
object short description: The house attached to the esoteric god house is the Salãśālā (var. salaṃśālā). A salaṃśālā is a place where general meetings and exhibitions related to the monastic building are arranged. In the Newari month of Gũlā the archaic objects of the monastery are exhibited on the ground floor of the two-storey house. This event is called Bahīdyaḥ Bvayegu. This building has been newly renovated.

Object image caption: Taḥdhã Bahī, Guitaḥ, Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya, view from N; photo by Ashma Adhikari; 2019-06-14
Kota Pāṭī, Bhīmasena statue, view from N; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2019-02-06
object short description: This Bhīmasena is believed to have been dragged here from Dolakha. There is a gate on the western part of phalcā which leads to the dumāju placed inside Patan Darbar. On the west side of the gate, there is a small room where a small statue of Bhīmasena has been installed. This room is opened only on special occasions. There is a blind window and triangular-shaped hole on the west side of the door. People worship the hole as Bhīmasena. A brass toraṇa with an umbrella over it is offered to the god. Two eyes and a mace are painted here, as they resemble the face of Bhīmasena. This Bhīmasena is patronized by Haḥkhā Ṭola Sudhāra Samiti.

Object image caption: Thabũ Phalcā, Statue of Śivapārvatī, view from S; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-21
Thabũ Phalcā, Statue of Ṛṣi, view from S; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-21
Taṅgaḥ Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from N (August 2019)
object short description: This caitya, like other dharmadhātujinālaya caityas has four Buddhas facing in four directions on top of a lotus pedestal. There is another lotus pedestal on top of it with four Buddhas. There are also statues of Taras in four corners and a harmikā and trayodaśabhuvana on top of it.

Object image caption: Taṅgaḥ Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W (August 2019)
object short description: This octagonal dharmadhātu maṇḍala has Bodhisatva images in its eight faces. There is a vajra on top of it.

Bhurtī Pañcadevala 2, central śikhara, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
Bhurtī Pañcadevala 2, northern śikhara, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24

Object name: Bhurtī Pañcadevala 2, western śikhara, view from north
Object image caption: Bhurtī Pañcadevala 2, western śikhara, view from north; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
Jom Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
object short description: The part above the harkimā of this Caitya is wrapped in metal.

Object image caption: Jom Bāhāḥ, statue of Sūrya, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
Jom Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
Jom Bāhāḥ, statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
object short description: The local residents worship this statue as Buṅgadyaḥ (Red Matsyendranatha).

Object image caption: Jom Bāhāḥ, vajra, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
Jom Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
object short description: Akṣobhya is the main deity (kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ) enshrined in the sanctum of the āgaṃchẽ. He is dressed in a metal lhegā.

Object image caption: Jom Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
Jom Bāhāḥ, statue of Candra, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
Jom Bāhāḥ, aniconic Mañjuśrī, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
object short description: A khaḍga (ritual sword), representing Mañjuśrī, is carved on this niche. A pair of feet (possibly of Mañjuśrī) can be seen on the pedestal.

Object image caption: Jom Bāhāḥ, statue of Jaṭādhārī Lokeśvara (Mīnanātha), view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
Jom Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala (A), view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
Jom Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala (B), view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
Jom Bāhāḥ, Mahādeva-Pārvatī, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-19
object short description: This Śivaliṅga is erected in the north-east part of the Bahāḥ. The local residents worship it as Śivapārvatī. Whenever a feast is organised in the āgaṃchẽ, a portion is offered also to the Śivaliṅga.

Object image caption: Manavināyaka Mandira, statue of Manavināyaka in the sanctum, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-28
Nāmasaṅgīti Phalcā, Nāmasaṅgīti, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-11
object short description: Nāmasaṅgīti is one of the important manifest­ations of Mañjuśrī, the embodiment of the wisdom of all the Buddhas. This statue shows him with one head and twelve arms, seated with two hands in a dhyāna-mudrā posture. He holds two hands above his head are in a gesture of uttarabodhi-mudrā i.e. two hands folded in prostration. The two hands are at his breast level perform the gesture of dharmacakra-mudrā., whilst two further hands are performing tarpaṇa-mudrā i.e. about to offer water from the alms bowl. Another pair of hands holds an alms bowl in his lap, whilst the hands at his shoulder level hold a sword and scripture on a lotus. The last pair are shown holding a bow and arrow.

Object image caption: Nāmasaṅgīti Phalcā, statue of Narasiṃha, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-11
object short description: Someone named Deva Maharjana donated this metal statue in VS 2070.

Object image caption: Nāmasaṅgīti Phalcā, statue of Tārā, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-11
object short description: The right and left hands of this Tārā statue are displaying a boon-giving gesture (varada-mudrā) and abhaya-mudrā, respectively. It was donated by two people named Jujuratna and Āśāmāyā.

Object image caption: Nāmasaṅgīti Phalcā, statue of Buṅgadyaḥ, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-11
object short description: This statue of Buṅgadyaḥ (Lokeśvara) is standing in the samapāda posture. His right hand is performing the boon-giving gesture (varada-mudrā) whilst his left hand holds a lotus.

Object image caption: Nāmasaṅgīti Phalcā, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-11
object short description: This Gaṇeśa statue was established in NS 1105. The deity is known as the Venerable Kṛṣṇakula and has four arms.

Object image caption: Nāmasaṅgīti Phalcā, statue of Umāmaheśvara, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-11
Bāliphaḥ Ganedyaḥ Phalcā, Viṣṇu Shrine, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-05-24
object short description:
Statue of Viṣṇu

Size of Viṣṇu: height: 26 cm, width: 18 cm

Object image caption: Bāliphaḥ Ganedyaḥ Phalcā, Gaṇeśa Shrine, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-03-30
object short description:
Gaṇeśa Shrine 

Size of Gaṇeśa: height: 40 cm, width: 27 cm

Object image caption: Bāliphaḥ Ganedyaḥ Phalcā, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-05-24
object short description: Statue of Garuḍa

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Gaṇeśa Shrine, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
object short description: This stone statue of Gaṇeśa is enshrined in the sanctum sanctorum of the temple. The iconographic features of the statue suggest that this is one of the oldest Gaṇeśa statues of the Valley. Gaṇeśa statues of the Valley made between the 5th and 7th centuries have certain distinctive features, such as having only two arms and a large belly, wearing no ornaments, sitting in the ardhaparyaṅka posture, the trunk slightly bent to the left, touching the sweet ball and are shown sitting alone even without the deity's vehicle  (Khanāla VS 2074, 163). The statue within this temple exactly matches these features. With this in mind, one can assume that the present pagoda-style temple was built in the Malla period, thus encompassing the Licchavi period Gaṇeśa shrine into its its sanctum.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Jaḥdhũhiti, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
object short description: A large concrete water tank was built on top of the base of the traditional water fountain (Jaḥdhũhiti). The marbel inscription lists the names of those who donated funds for the renovation of the new tank. According to Furukawa (2010, 56), the fountain was constructed during the Malla period.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Mākāḥdalū (monkey holding a oil lamp), view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Śivaliṅga, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Viṣṇu, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Dhyānī Buddha, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Kṛṣṇa with inscription, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Jaḥdhũhiti, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Jinālaya Caitya, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
Gaṇeśa Mandira, cot, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
object short description: The cot is used during the Matayāḥ festival and stored under the temple's roof overhang.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Viṣṇu, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Sarasvatī Shrine, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Viṣṇu, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
Gaṇeśa Mandira, well, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-06-13
object short description: This might be a historic well, but it is completely encased in concrete and cement plaster.

Object image caption: Bhindyaḥ Phalcā, stone statue of Bhīmasena (A), view from SE (December 2019)
object short description: A statue of Bhīmasena in ālīḍha posture is placed inside the niche on the western wall of the sataḥ. Bhimasena's right leg is touching the ground and his left leg is on the lion. He is holding a mace with his right arm and his left arm is in abhaya-mudrā. A small statue is carved on the pedestal, and is looking towards Bhīmasena in a namaskāra posture (mudrā). The border of the niche is framed by crafted wood.

Object image caption: Bhindyaḥ Phalcā, stone statue of Vajravīra Mahākāla, view from NE (December 2019)
object short description: This image is installed at the western wall of Bhindyaḥ Phalcā. The deity has two arms, and is standing on Betāḥdyaḥ and holding a Khaṭvāṃka.

Object image caption: Bhindyaḥ Phalcā, statue of Nārāyaṇa (A), view from SE (December 2019)
object short description: A statue of standing Nārāyaṇawith four hands holding his attributes (lotus, wheel, mace and conch) is placed inside a niche on western wall of the sataḥ.

Object image caption: Bhindyaḥ Phalcā, wooden statue of Nārāyaṇa (B), view from NE (February 2020)
object short description: This statue is placed inside a niche on the southern wall of the phalcā, and depicts a standing Nārāyaṇaholding each of his attributes (the lotus, the wheel, mace and a conch) in his four hands. It is believed to be a part of a strut which has been brought to the site from somewhere else.

Object image caption: Bhindyaḥ Phalcā, wooden statue (probably) of Bhīmasena (B), view from NE (February 2020)
object short description: The wooden statue depicts an icon which is probably Bhīmasena, and is located on the southern wall. This wooden statue is also believed to be a part of a strut that was brought to the site from an unknown place.

Object image caption: Cāṅgala Bāhāḥ, Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from W (February 2020)
object short description: Stone statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara is attached to the back wall of the shrine. He is holding lotus stalks in his both hands.

Object image caption: Cāṅgala Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya, view from E (February 2020)
object short description: When the thieves tried to steal the statue of Akṣobhya from the temple, the idol broke down into pieces. Later in 2008 CE, the saṅgha members of the Kvātha Bāhāḥ installed this new statue of the deity. Stone statues of Sāriputra and Maudgalyāyana flank Akṣobhya and a toraṇa is fixed on his top.

Object image caption: Uttaragaṅgā Pillars, pillar 002, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-21
Uttaragaṅgā Pillars, pillar 001, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-21
object short description: The damaged representation of a horse turned to the left is visible on the upper part of the pillar.

Object image caption: Lāhā pillars, pillar 3, south-eastern side, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-06
object short description: The upper part contains a highly eroded inscription, allowing a partial reading of the date '1404' (Śaka era) which corresponds to 1482 CE.

Object image caption: Lāhā pillars, pillar 1, south-eastern side, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-06
object short description: The upper left part of the pillar is broken. The inscription on the upper part is illegible.

Object image caption: Lāhā pillars, pillar 2, south-eastern side, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-06
object short description: The upper part of the pillar is long gone.

Object image caption: Kulle Koṭa, stone goddess, view from south; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description: This image, representing an unidentified four-armed goddess, is similar in style  and material to that of Viṣṇu. It was attributed to the 10th century (Sharma 2012: 286-287), although a later dating (13th-15th century) is most likely.

Object image caption: Kulle Koṭa, stone lintel, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description: This stone lintel (broken on the right) was probably part of a śikhara temple.

Object image caption: Kulle Koṭa, stone Viṣṇu, view from south; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description: Viṣṇu is represented standing and four-armed, with his traditional attributes and gestures. This image was compared to a 6th century sculpture from Kumaon by D. R. Sharma, who tentatively dated the Kulle Koṭa image from "at least 9th century" (Sharma 2012: 286). This is untenable since the sculptures have nothing in common, besides their general iconography. The image is most likely dating from the 13th to 15th century.

Object image caption: Chvāsapāḥ Bāhāḥ, guardian lion (B) at the western side of the entrance of the sanctum, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-07
Chvāsapāḥ Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-07
Chvāsapāḥ Bāhāḥ, guardian lion (D) at the southern side of the outer entrance to the Bāhāḥ, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-07
Chvāsapāḥ Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla at the northwest corner wall niche of a private house, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-07

Tuṃjhvaḥ Phalcā, Kalaśa, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Tuṃjhvaḥ Phalcā, Kalaśa, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Tuṃjhvaḥ Phalcā, Viṣṇu, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Tuṃjhvaḥ Phalcā, Sarasvatī, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Matsyendranātha Mandira, Matsya pillar, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: Padma Jaṅga erected this stone pillar in 1883. This pillar has a fish on top of it.

Object image caption: Padma Jaṅga erected this stone pillar in 1883. This pillar has a Bhagavatī and five deities on top of it.
Matsyendranātha Mandira, Patĩgāḥ, view from E (January 2020)
object short description: This pit is called Patĩgāḥ. There is also a Patĩgāḥ in front of the Karuṇāmaya Mandira of Bungmati. According to the priests, there is a small caitya inside this pit. The remains of the worshipping materials are thrown into this pit. This practice does not take place in the temple of Bungmati.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, Bhairava shrine, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: There is a small chamber beneath the eastern plinth of the temple. Inside this chamber, one can find an aniconic stone worshipped as Bhairava. At end of his term, which lasts for one lunar fortnight, a priest worships this Bhairava. He offers samaybaji to the deity and eats it as the gift of the deity.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, Bandhudatta pillar, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: This stone pillar has an image of Ācārya Bandhudatta on top of it.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, Matsyendranātha statue in the sanctum, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: Buṅgadyaḥ is kept here for six months every year. During the other six months, he dwells in the Karuṇāmaya Mandira (BUN0001) of Bungmati. Patan’s greatest festival takes place when this god is brought out in a chariot on the full moon day of Vaiśākha. The procession leads all the way to Jawalakhel. The chariot procession began as a way to celebrate the arrival of Buṅga Dyaḥ in Nepal and the end of a devastating drought. Ā. Vajrācārya (1985, 84) mentions that Śubhaśrī Mitra of Karuṇācuka Bahī (LAL1560) made the statue, which is why the bahī was named after the deity. A Tibetan monk called Dharmasvāmin who stayed in the monastery of Svayambhū (Phags-pa Sin-kun) of the Valley around 1226-34 CE makes mention of a miraculous image of Avalokiteśvara made of sandalwood and painted red (Regmī 1965, 559-560). The present statue of the deity is made from two different materials. The head is made of clay while the rest of the body is made from metal. The clay section is painted every year before the deity is placed on the chariot.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, Aśva pillar, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: Padma Jaṅga erected this stone pillar in 1883. This pillar has a horse on top of it.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, Garuḍa pillar, view from NE (January 2020)P
object short description: Padma Jaṅga erected this stone pillar in 1883. This pillar has a Garuḍa on top of it.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, King Narendradeva pillar, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: According to Nepalese chronicles, King Narendradeva, Acharya Bandhudatta and Lalita Jyāpu played a vital role in bringing Matsyendranātha from Kamārū Mountain to Nepal. Their statues are placed in the temple courtyard. This stone pillar has an image of King Narendradeva on top of it.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, pillar of Nāga, view from NE  (January 2020)
object short description: Padma Jaṅga erected this stone pillar in 1883. This pillar has a serpent on top of it.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, Nandī pillar, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: Padma Jaṅga erected this stone pillar in 1883. This pillar has a Nandī on top of it.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, Lalita Jyāpu pillar, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: This stone pillar has an image of Lalita Jyāpu on top of it.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, vajra, view from S (January 2020)
object short description: This vajra was offered to the temple in 1996 CE in memory of Oṃkārāsa Maharjan and Rāmadevī.

Object name: Pillar of King Narendradeva, Ācārya Bandhudatta and Lalita Jyapu
Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, King Lalit, Bandhudatta and Lalita Jyāpu pillar, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: This stone pillar has images of King Narendradeva, Acharya Bandhudatta and Lalita Jyāpu on top of it. Kṛṣṇagopāla Khaḍgī and his wife Tulasīmāyā, brother Rājagopāla, son Rājakumāra and grandson Śravaṇa Kumāra erected this pillar in 1998.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, Gaja pillar, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: Padma Jaṅga erected this stone pillar in 1883. This pillar has an elephant on top of it.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, Mayūra pillar, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: Padma Jaṅga erected this stone pillar in 1883. This pillar has a peacock on top of it.

Object image caption: Matsyendranātha Mandira, lion (siṃha) pillar, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: Padma Jaṅga, a son of Jaṅga Bahādura, erected 9 out of the 13 stone pillars of the courtyard in 1883. Similar inscriptions are engraved in all of the other eight pillars. This pillar has a lion on top of it.

Object name: Ugratārā Mandira, pair of stone pillars
Object image caption: Ugratārā Mandira, pair of stone pillars, view from south; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description: The two pillars are placed in a small niche on the outer wall of the temple sanctum.

Object image caption: Ugratārā Mandira, Durgā Devī frieze,view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description: View of the the interior of the vestibule, towards the door to the sanctum.

Object image caption: Ugratārā Mandira, Bhairava Mandira, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description: View of the stone sculptures kept at the small Bhairava Mandira. The sculptures display different iconographies and styles.

Object image caption: Ugratārā Mandira, stone memorial pillar, view from south; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description:
The upper register of the pillar's southern side contains the representation of a horse rider, probably the person for whom the pillar was originally installed. The object is nowadays reused as a sacrificial pole for buffaloes.

The object may date from the 13th-15th century.

Object image caption: Ugratārā Mandira, shrine of Kālī, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description: The shrine contains a recent (plaster?) statue of Kālī. This is the place where sacrifices of goats are performed.

Lāchi Hiti, statue Bhagīratha (B), view from N; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-05
Lāchi Hiti, statue of Bhagīratha (C), view from N; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-13

Lāchi Hiti, statue of Sūrya, view from N; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-05
Lāchi Hiti, statue of Yakṣa, view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-05

Lāchi Hiti, Water Spout (B), view from NW; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-08-05

Cīthū Vajradhātu Caitya, statue of Akṣobhya iniside a niche, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-25

Bhagavatī Asigrāma archaeological remains, śikhara 002, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-15-08
object short description:
The miniature śikhara is constituted of four horizontal registers (base, wall, pediment and tower), each carved in a block of stone, except for the tower, made of two parts.

The tower part is moved towards the north.

Object image caption: Bhagavatī Asigrāma archaeological remains, pillar 003, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-15-08
object short description:
This pillar is half-buried. It was probably part of a pavilion. 

On top is a protruding tenon.

Object image caption: Bhagavatī Asigrāma archaeological remains, pillar 004, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-15-08
object short description:
The four sides of the pillar are ornamented with a simplified vase motif (kalaśa). 

On top of the pillar is a tenon.

Object image caption: Bhagavatī Asigrāma archaeological remains, pillar 005, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-15-08
object short description:
The four sides of the pillar are ornamented with a vase motif (kalaśa) as well as friezes with spiraled foliages and losanges.

On top of the pillar is a tenon.

Object image caption: Bhagavatī Asigrāma archaeological remains, pillar 006, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-15-08
object short description: The four sides of the pillar are decorated with a central motif of losange (ratna).

Object image caption: Bhagavatī Asigrāma archaeological remains, pillar 007, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-15-08
object short description: The four sides of the pillar are ornamented with a naturalist vase motif (kalaśa).

Object name: Bhagavatī Asigrāma archaeological remains, platform and modern temple
Object image caption: Bhagavatī Asigrāma archaeological remains, platform and modern temple, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-15-08
object short description: A Bhagavatī temple stands on top of the stone platform. The temple, oriented to the east, was built in the early 2010's. The platform, preexistent, is constituted of divers medieval architectural remains indicating the importance of the site around the 14th-15th century.

Object image caption: Bhagavatī Asigrāma archaeological remains, śikhara 001, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-15-08
object short description:
The door of the śikhara is partly buried. Above it is an uncomplete pediment. 

The top of the śikhara is occupied by a cruciform capital (up side down). The capital must belong to a pavilion.

Object image caption: Chinnamastā Pīṭha, first part of the traditional wall painting, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-15
object short description: The first part of the wall panting shows the eight mother goddesses (aṣṭamātṛkā) in a vertical row. Below the mother goddesses are Hanumān, Vyāsa, King Bali, Asośyāmā (Aśvatthāmā), Vibhīṣaṇa, Kṛpācārya, Paraśurāma and Mārkaṇḍeya. Bhairava, Sarasvatī, Khyāka, Kaṃkāla and others are at the centre. The lower painting shows Gaṇeśa, Kumāra, a dog, jackal and so forth. In the second part of the painting, a woman who wants to learn the witchcrafts from Chinnamastā is shown bringing her husband towards the pīṭha to sacrifice him as a he-goat. The local residents believe that the pīṭha was a place one could learn magic.

Object image caption: Chinnamastā Pīṭha, Chinnamastā shrine with an aniconic stone representing Goddess Chinnamastā, one of the ten mahāvidyās, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-15
Ālko Sataḥ, Viṣṇu, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-03-30
Ālko Sataḥ, male guardian deity, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-03-30
Ālko Sataḥ, Lakṣṃīnārāyaṇa, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-03-30
Pāhā̃ Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from E (September, 2019)
object short description: This Caitya was errected in NS 780 (1660 CE) together with the monastic building.

Object image caption: Pāhā̃ Bāhāḥ, Mañjuśrī statue, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: Mañjuśrī is holding a sword and an arrow in his right hands and bow and a book in his left hands. An aniconic stone worshipped as Lokeśvara is located in the same niche.

Object image caption: Pāhā̃ Bāhāḥ, Lokeśvara statue, view from W  (September 2019)
Pāhā̃ Bāhāḥ, Hanumān statue, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: Hanumān stands to the south of the bāhāḥ entrance. A devotee from Naḥ Ṭola established this statue in VS 2075. A mask of Hanumān is also located here.

Object image caption: Pāhā̃ Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from S (September 2019)
object short description: This statue is placed in a small niche located on the wall of the private house to the north of the bāhāḥ. The four-handed Gaṇeśa holds a rosary and a radish in his right hands and an axe and a sweet ball in his left hands.

Object image caption: Pāhā̃ Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: Mahākāla is standing to the north of the outer entrance of the bāhāḥ. He is standing on top of a corpse and holding kartṛ and a skull. A wooden statue of Mahākāla was recently installed after the images were stolen twice

Object image caption: Umāmaheśvara Mandira at Kvālkhu, Vajradhātupurī Aśoka caitya, view from S (January 2019)
object short description: The caitya was recently plastered in cement and painted white. The name of the caitya comes from Śākya (1993, 44).

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira at Dau Bāhā, Sarasvatī, view from W (October 2018)
Gaṇeśa Mandira at Dau Bāhā, Nārāyaṇa, view from S (October 2018)
object short description: This image is installed on the northern wall of the phalcā.  Nārāyaṇa is standing in the samapāda posture and has four hands. He is holding śaṅkha, cakra, gadā and padma in each of his four hands.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira at Dau Bāhā, Lakṣmī, view from S (October 2018)
Gaṇeśa Mandira at Dau Bāhā, Bhīmasena, view from E (October 2018)
object short description: This image is installed at the western wall of the phalcā.

Object image caption: Bhinchẽ Bāhāḥ, niche and statue of Mahākāla, view from S (June 2019)
object short description: A niche has been made on the southern wall of the god house, and now contains a five-headed, four-handed statue of Mahākāla. The statue is standing on top of a corpse holding a khadga and kartṛ in his right two hands and khaṭvāṅga and kapāla in his left hands. One can also find an older statue of Mahākāla in the niche as well as a statue of Mañjuśrī with khaḍga. The niche is crowned with a wooden toraṇa showing a further image of Mahākāla.

Object image caption: Bhinchẽ Bāhāḥ, Pillar (A), view from N (June 2019)
object short description: Dharmarāja Śākya and Laxmīmāyā Śākya built a pillar in the memory of their parents Bhimarāja, Lāni Thakũ and their elder son Dharmarāja who passed away in the earthquake of 1934. Statues of Mañjuśrī and Amoghapāśa Lokeśvara can be found to the east of the statue. On top of the pillar, four Buddhas face in the four directions with a caitya above them. Images of the donors, Dharmarāja and his wife Lakṣmīmāyā, are placed on the base of the pillar. There is a sacrificial metal altar to the south.

Object image caption: Bhinchẽ Bāhāḥ, statue of Nāmasaṅgīti , view from S (June 2019)
object short description: A statue of Nāmasaṅgīti is located on the southern wall of the god house. He has one head and twelve arms, and is seated in dhyānamudrā. His uppermost arms are located above his head and are performing the gesture of uttarabodhi mudrā, i.e., two hands folded in prostration. His other two hands are at the level of his chest and are performing dharmacakra mudrā. Two more hands are performing tarpaṇa mudrā, i.e. they appear about to offer water from the alms bowl. He holds this alms bowl in his lap with another two hands. The two hands visible at his shoulder level are holding a sword and scripture on a lotus, whilst his final two hands hold a bow and arrow.

Object image caption: Bhinchẽ Bāhāḥ, statue of Hanumān, view from N (June 2019)
Bhinchẽ Bāhāḥ, vajra, view from SW (June 2019)
Bhinchẽ Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from N (June 2019)
object short description: Cement has been used to attach the harmikā to the garbha.

Object image caption: Bhinchẽ Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from N (June 2019)
object short description: There was once an aśoka caitya at this location. However, this Caitya was so dilapidated that Āsāmadhu Vajrācārya covered it with this new Śikharakūṭa Caitya some time around NS 1066.

Object image caption: Bhinchẽ Bāhāḥ, statue of Vasundharā, view from S (June 2019)
object short description: A statue of Vasundharā is located on the southern wall of the god house. She has three faces and six arms, and is seated in lalitāsana. Her right foot rests on a conch placed on top of a vase with a lotus. Two of her three right hands hold a rosary and jewels, whilst her third right hand performs the gesture of varada mudrā. In her left three hands, she holds a vase, a rice stalk and scripture.

Object image caption: Bhinchẽ Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from SW (June 2019)
object short description: There are no Bodhisatva images on any of the eight faces of this maṇḍala. The upper part of the Maṇḍala has been covered in copper plates.

Object image caption: Bhinchẽ Bāhāḥ, pillar (B), view from W (June 2019)
object short description: A piṇda is offered to deceased ancestors here during the śrāddha ritual.

Object image caption: Bhinchẽ Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭoparipadma Caitya, view from NE (June 2019)
object short description: This Caitya is situated in the courtyard of the Bāhāḥ. The lower part is constructed in a sikharakūṭa style whilst the upper part has five layers of lotus motif. However, the lower layer of the lotus has been covered in cement plaster. On top of the lotus motifs, one can find statues of Dhyani Buddhas in each of the four cardinal directions.

Lokeśvara Mandira, Lion statue (left side) view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 20-02-2021
Lokeśvara Mandira, Lion statue (right side) view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 20-02-2021
Udayadeva Mandira, stone architectural element, view from north; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description:
This is a very unique architectural element that is probably in relation to BTD0010-010. it was most probably part of the original temple's façade.

Two male individuals are represented in very "local" style, with round, elongated proportions. The character to the left is four-armed. The lower left hand shows the varadamudrā. The character to the right is wearing large earrings and a crown-looking headdress. It has two hands. It seems to be breaking a serpent's body in two pieces.

Object image caption: Udayadeva Mandira, stone sculpture, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description: The image is very damaged but it remains possible to identify a mace or a sword in the character's raised right hand. The left hand seems to hold a circular shield (right part broken). It is interesting to note that the character is standing on a throne. It may represent Bhīma or a warrior.

Object image caption: Udayadeva Mandira, carved architectural element, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description:
Judging by its dimensions this artefact was part of a large monument. A central palister divides the composition. On the far left is a vertical register with foliages. to its right is another register, with four superimposed characters (guardians or deities). To the right side are two horses and two characters holding mace-looking attributes.

Dilli Raj Sharma ascribes this element to the 13th century (Sharma 2012: 338).

Object image caption: Udayadeva Mandira, architectural frieze, view from south; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description:
The artefact is an architectural frieze with nine characters, separated by columns. Because there are nine characters represented, the local interpretation of the frieze is that it represents the Navadurgā ("Nau Durgā"). 

There are actually no iconographic attributes allowing this identification and one may rather see five enshrined deities, two devotees and two guardians (lokapāla). Dilli Raj Sharma identified Sūrya in the central niche and dated the frieze from the 14th century (Sharma 2012: 340).

Object name: Udayadeva Mandira, carved architectural element with a soldier
Object image caption: Udayadeva Mandira, carved architectural element with a soldier, view from south; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description:
This is a very unique architectural element that is probably in relation to BTD0010-007. it was most probably part of the original temple's façade.

To the left is a standing character holding a rifle. It is wearing an hourglass-like headdress.

Object name: Udayadeva Mandira, statue of four-armed deity
Object image caption: Udayadeva Mandira, statue of four-armed deity, view from south; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description:
The sculpture is placed in a small niche. It represents a four-armed deity under an arch with two pillars. The style and composition are similar to BTD0010-011.

The carving can be tentatively dated from the 14th-16th century. It was probably placed on the walls of a previous temple.

Object name: Udayadeva Mandira, statue of four-armed Viṣṇu
Object image caption: Udayadeva Mandira, statue of four-armed Viṣṇu, view from north; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description:
The statue is placed in a niche, to the right side of the sanctum's entrance.

Viṣṇu is represented with four arms, holding (in a clockwise order starting from the lower left hand): the lotus flower, the mace, the cakra wheel and the conch. 

The image has been linked to artistic productions of 12th century Kumaon (Sharma 2012: 337). This appears to be a too early dating. A more likely dating, though very approximate, would situate it between the 14th and the 17th century.

Object name: Udayadeva Mandira, kīrtimukha from a temple ceiling
Object image caption: Udayadeva Mandira, kīrtimukha from a temple ceiling, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description:
The triangular shape of the object indicates that it was placed at the corner of the ceiling of a śikhara temple. A kīrtimukha is represented in a style datable from the 14th-16th century.

Another identical element is found near by it (BTD0010-005). There are some stylistic differences between the two objects, indicating that there may have been at least two śikhara temples in the vicinity.

Object name: Udayadeva Mandira, kīrtimukha ​​​​​​​from a temple ceiling
Object image caption: Udayadeva Mandira, kīrtimukha from a temple ceiling, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description:
The triangular shape of the object indicates that it was placed at the corner of the ceiling of a śikhara temple. A kīrtimukha is represented in a style datable from the 14th-16th century.

Another identical element is found near by it (BTD0010-006). There are some stylistic differences between the two objects, indicating that there may have been at least two śikhara temples in the vicinity.

Object image caption: Udayadeva Mandira, carved architectural element, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description: As for BTD0010-002, this element must originate from a large medieval temple, probably the same structure.

Object name: Udayadeva Mandira, group of architectural elements
Object image caption: Udayadeva Mandira, group of architectural elements, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-07
object short description:
This group of artefacts contains:

- a temple's crowning (painted yellow and red),

- two elements of a temple wall (vertical, painted yellow), 

- a carved male (?) character with a pillar to its right

- a śikhara temple's treshold.

Maṅgaḥ Hiti, water spout center, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-27
Cilkhāyā Temples, temple 002, view from SW; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-05
Cilkhāyā Temples, temple 001, view from NE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-05
object short description: View of the the main temple and its door. The priest is standing to the left.

Object image caption: Taḥnani Caitya, statue of Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-24
Taḥnani Caitya, statue of Ratnasambhava, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-24
Taḥnani Caitya, statue of Amitābha, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-24
Taḥnani Caitya, statue of Amoghasiddhi, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-24
Taḥnani Caitya, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-24
Taḥnani Caitya, stone oil lamp stand (dalūpā), view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-24
Bāhālukhā Phalcā 2, statue of Sarasvatī, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-09
object short description: Sarasvatī is holding a vīṇā with two hands, and a rosary and a book with her other two hands. The niche had been empty for many years after the old statue of Sarasvatī was stolen. After the reconstruction of phalcā in VS 2064 (2007 CE), a new statue of Sarasvatī was installed.

Object image caption: Bāhālukhā Phalcā 2, statue of Bhīmasena, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-09
object short description: Bhīmasena is pictured pressing his enemy down with the knee of his left leg. He is depicted as ripping open the enemy’s chest with his left hand and pulling out a long portion of his entrails with his right hand or is raising a club over him. The niche had been empty for many years after the old statue of Bhīmasena was stolen. After the reconstruction of phalcā in VS 2064 (2007 CE), a new statue of Bhīmasena was also installed.

Object image caption: Pānda Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-20
Pānda Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-20
Pānda Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-20
Pānda Bāhāḥ, Pañcāvalīyukta Caitya, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-20
Khvāya Bahī Taḥdhaṅgu, Hanumān, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: There is a statue of Hanumā on the southern wall towards the main entrance.

Object image caption: Khvāya Bahī Taḥdhaṅgu, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from W (January 2020)
object short description: The Caitya has been painted with white lime. Four Buddhas are placed in the four side niches. These statues appear to be quite new, and were probably a more recent addition. The top parts of the caitya (above the 13 tapered rings) have been lost.

Object image caption: Khvāya Bahī Taḥdhaṅgu, Vasundharā, view from E (January 2020)
object short description: The statue of Vasundharā is located to the south of the sanctum. Lakṣmī and Sarasvatī are placed on her right and left sides respectively. Harṣamāyā Śākya and her son Sānukājī Śākya installed these statues.

Object image caption: Khvāya Bahī Taḥdhaṅgu, historical photo of Samantabhadra Bodhisattva, view from E (photo by Hemarāja Śākya, 2000)
object short description: Source: Śākya 2000, 11. Samantabhadra Bodhisattva, the principal deity of the Bahī is painted white and portrayed as sitting down with his right leg raised. Locke (1985, 193) names the deity as Maitreya, whereas Sinclair (2010, 36) calls it Śrīśākyamunigaṇadevatābhaṭṭāraka. Samantabhadra is sitting in an ardhasattvaparyaṅka posture and performing the gesture of dharmacakra with his hands. H. Vajrācārya (2000, 107) mentions that a new statue of the deity was established in 25th April 1998 (12th day of Vaiśākha in the Vikrama year 2055).

Object image caption: Khvāya Bahī Taḥdhaṅgu, Mahākāla, view from S (January 2020)
object short description: On the northen wall of the entrance to the complex one can find a statue of Mahākāla with an inscription from NS 643 on its plinth. The inscription is badly damaged, but the statue is in good condition.

Object image caption: Khvāya Bahī Taḥdhaṅgu, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: This structure resembles a dharmadhātu maṇḍala. However, it is significantly different in several ways. The structure has cement plastered circles on top of it; normally, a dharmadhātu maṇḍala would be surmounted by a vāgīśvara maṇḍala.

Object image caption: Khvāya Bahī Taḥdhaṅgu, Lakṣmī, view from E (January 2020)
object short description: Harṣamāyā Śākya and her son Sānukājī Śākya installed this statue.

Object image caption: Khvāya Bahī Taḥdhaṅgu, Sarasvatī, view from E (January 2020)
object short description: Harṣamāyā Śākya and her son Sānukājī Śākya established this statue.

Object image caption: Aki Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-11-26
object short description: The octagonal dharmadhātu has images of Bodhisattvas in eight directions. To its west is a pādukā of Mañjuśrī.

Object image caption: Aki Bāhāḥ, vajradhātu caitya, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-11-26
object short description: This caitya is located to the west of the aśoka caitya. It was constructed around 1970, and is made of cement.

Object image caption: Aki Bāhāḥ, Aśoka Caitya, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-11-26
object short description: This caitya is located to the north of the Dharmadhātu, and stands on a rectangular plinth. There are images of Dhyānī Buddha at each side. Surrounding the Caitya is an oil-lamp balustrade. There is also a cãduvā supported by iron rods

Hanumāna Pillar, statue of donors at the lower side of the pillar, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-11
Thati Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-03-21
Thati Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-03-21
Bālakumārī Dyaḥchẽ, Wooden Palanquin (B), view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-05
object short description: This palanquin is not used during the Bālakumārī procession since 2009. According to the local residents, it is not used anymore because of its heavy weight. A new palanquin was made in 2009 for this purpose.

Object image caption: Bālakumārī Dyaḥchẽ, Wooden Palanquin (A); photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-05
object short description: As mentioned above (see LAL2140-001), the statue of Bālakumārī with the masks of other gods and goddesses are mounted to one of three palanquins stored on the ground floor of this Dyaḥchẽ and brought to the abode of Bālakumārī on the day of Pāhāṃcaḥhre (Piśāca Caturdaśī) and full moon day of the bright fortnight of Māgha.

Object image caption: Bālakumārī Dyaḥchẽ, brass statue of Bālakumārī in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-14
Bālakumārī Dyaḥchẽ, Wooden Palanquin (C), view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-05
object short description: This is the new palanquin that is being used for the procession since 2010.

Object image caption: Bālakumārī Dyaḥchẽ, stone statue of donor (couple) attached on the wall of the first floor, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-14

Vaṃśī Nārāyaṇa (Kṛṣṇa) Mandira, Garuḍa Pillar, view from S; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2021-07-22
Mati Bāhācā, shrine with Akṣobhya image, view from S (November 2018)
object short description: To the south of the caitya is a small shrine. In the niche of this shrine one can find an image of Akṣobhya Buddha facing north. There is a stone image of a lion on either side of the shrine, an a stone pinnacle at its top.

Object image caption: Mati Bāhācā, Sarasvatī Shrine, view from W (November 2019)
Ibāḥ Bahī, Aśoka Caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-24
object short description: Images of Bodhisattva are placed in the Caitya's niches in each of the four directions. Vajrapāṇi Bodhisattva is normally to be found on the southern side, however, this Caitya contains two statues of Mañjuśrī - one in his normal position and one also in the southern niche.

Object image caption: Ibāḥ Bahī, new Mahākāla statue, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-24
object short description: This stone statue of Mahākāla lies to the north of the outer entrance of the Bahī. A toraṇa can be found above the statue, containing images of Mahākāla flanked by Gaṇeśa and Kumāra. There is a wooden image of Mahākāla to its right. This has been heavily damaged.

Object image caption: Ibāḥ Bahī, Dharmadhātu Manḍala, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-24
object short description: Images of Bodhisattvas are placed in each of the four directions of the Maṇḍala. There is an inscription on the upper part, below the lotus petals. However, it is covered with dust and oil and is too difficult to read in this state.

Object image caption: Ibāḥ Bahī, statue of donor, view from SW; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-24
object short description: This image is to the east of the Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala. The statues of two donors are facing one another.

Object image caption: Ibāḥ Bahī, Hanumān statue, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-24
object short description: A toraṇa with an image of Mañjuśrī can be found above this image of Hanumān.

Pusākoṭa stone memorial pillars, pillar 001, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-27
object short description: The pillar is leaning towards the south.

Object image caption: Pusākoṭa stone memorial pillars, pillar 002, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-27
Lamjī Pañcadevala, central temple, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
Lamjī Pañcadevala, southwestern temple, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-10-02
