Bhakteśvara Mandira, śivaliṅga in the sanctum, view from S; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-30
Bu Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: Four Buddhas are placed in the four cardinal directions of the caitya.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, the Śikharakuṭa caitya enshrined with Manñjuśrī, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This śikhara-style caitya enshrines an image of Mañjuśrī depicted in the dharmacakra posture. The image is flanked with other images of Tārā, Prajñāpāramitā, Gaṇeśa and Mahākāla. An image of Akṣobhya can be found above the Mañjuśrī image. A worn-out image of Āryāvalokiteśvara can be found at the rear of the caitya. The caitya is in good condition.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu caitya and dharmadhātu, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
Bu Bāhāḥ, Dabū, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This platform with Akṣobhya statue was made a few years back by the locals. Some of the religious and cultural activities related to the Bāhāḥ are performed here.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala - 3, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This octagonal maṇḍala has images of eight Bodhisattvas on its eight faces. Muktarāja donated it in memory of his late father Harṣarāja Vajrācārya.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, Nāmasaṃgīti Kuṭāgāra caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This caitya enshrines a twelve-armed stone figure of Nāmasaṅgīti. A caitya-shaped pinnacle has been built above the shrine. A cement tympanum above the entrance to the shrine also depicts an image of the deity Nāmasaṅgīti.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, image of nāga (serpent) to the north of the Aśoka caitya; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This stone image of a serpent has been installed on the ground to the north of the aśoka caitya. The image is secured by a rectangular structure which also serves the purpose of containing water so that the image is submerged. This serpent is worshipped to prevent interruptions caused by rain during major ritual ceremonies.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, dharmadhatu maṇḍala to the north of the aśoka caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: Established in NS 1066 by Jogaratna Vajrācārya, this stone dharmadhātu maṇḍala lies to the north of the aśoka caitya. This object contains an image of a two-armed Tārā on the northern side and is fenced in by a stone structure.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, Lokeśvara Sthita Śikharakuṭa caitya, view from NW; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This caitya is made in the style of the Kṛṣṇa temple of Mangalbazar. A metal statue of Lokeśvara resides in its sanctum. He is holding lotus stalk in his left hand and showing varada gesture with his right hand.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, Amitābha Buddha Sthita Kuṭāgāra caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: The caitya is covered with brass plates. The gilded caitya is called Golden Caitya (Lũcibhāḥ). A golden statue of Amitābha is enshrined here. Devendra and his family covered the original caitya with brass in NS 1008. There is a small dharmadhātu maṇḍala in front of the caitya. Statues of 11 devotees have been placed on top of the Maṇḍala, showing the people who donated funds for the Amitābha statue to be gilded. A small caitya is attached to the backside of the bigger caitya structure.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, well - 2, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: Locals use the well.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhaḥ, stone pillar 2, view from SE; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This pillar to the north of the main shrine was installed above an east-facing stone statue of a tortoise. On top of it is an image of a gilt bodhi-tree. This bodhi-tree, dated NS 997 (1877 CE), was previously installed in the house of the Vajrācārya brothers Devendra, Devarāja and Pañcarāja. Later, in 1930, the pillar was erected and the image was placed above it. The pillar is in good condition.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, digichẽ, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: The digichẽ (the house of the esoteric shrine) is located in the northwest corner of the courtyard. The three-storey house has various spaces for different purposes such as periodic feasts, esoteric rituals, public gatherings and meditation. The ground floor is divided into two parts: one part enshrines an altar containing images of Amoghapāśalokeśvara, Vasundharā, Tārā and so on, while the other part is used for public gathering and singing bhajanas. The middle floor contains the esoteric shrine, and may only be accessed by initiated members. Behind the building in the courtyard, one can find a Nāṭyeśvara shrine and a fig (vara) tree that is believed to have been planted by a brahman from nearby Agniśālā.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhā, Vajra in front of the main shrine, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: The metal vajra is placed above a stone pillar. The object is in good condition.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, Śikharakuṭa caitya to the west of the main caitya, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This is a standard śikharakuṭa caitya made of stone. The lower section depicts four Bodhisattvas facing in each of the four directions, while the upper section has four Buddhas. The object is in good condition.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, the big prayer wheel, view from NW; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This prayer wheel is the newest addition among the objects of this monastery. It was donated by Buddhirāja Vajrācārya in NS 1121. It has a brass roofing, and it is secured with iron bars.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, Bhajana Phalcā, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: Bhajan Phalcā lies to the right side upon entering the main entrance of the Bāhāḥ compound. As the name suggests, this Phalcā is used primarily for bhajana singing. It has a long stone inscription attached to its eastern wall. The Phalcā is the ground floor of a private house, and the attached inscription has four dates referring to different installations: NS 873, 893, 895 and 896. The house itself has been rebuilt with a concrete structure.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, Kuṭāgāra caitya enshrined with Vajratāra, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-29
object short description: An eight-armed image of Vajratārā is enshrined in this caitya. In her right arms, she holds a vajra, an arrow, a conch-shell and performs the varada-posture, while in her left arms one can find a hook, a bow, a noose and a lotus. The caitya is intact.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, stambha to the west of the main caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: The pillar is used to place the piṇḍa offerred while performing śrāddha ritual.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, caitya to the northwest of the main caitya, view from SE; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This plastered caitya has been coloured red. The upper section of the caitya depicts four Buddhas and there are no other decorations. According to one of the elders of the Bāhāḥa, Soma Narasiṃ (age 76), this caitya was erected at a place that used to be a yajñakuṇḍa. It has no inscription.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, large dharmadhātu maṇḍala in front of the main shrine, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This dharmadhātu maṇḍala is located to the north of the main shrine and is of a much bigger size than the ones normally found in a bāhāḥ. The upper part of it is clad in brass sheets with carvings of the dharmadhātuvāgīśvara maṇḍala as described in the 21st chapter of the Niṣpannayogāvali. The current brass sheet was donated by Cetakīdhara and replaced the old one. A large vajra has been installed above the maṇḍala. In front of this object, one can find a fire pit (yajñaśālā), a small maṇḍala and a seat for the priest. The dharmadhātu is in good condition.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhā, Caturvyūha Jinālaṃkṛta caitya; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This uniquely shaped caitya has a representation of the Sumeru Mountain above its plinths. Above this are images of four Buddhas in each of the cardinal directions. A conventional looking caitya containing smaller images of the four Buddhas has been built on top. A metal bar has been placed around the caitya. The object is in good condition.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, Aśoka caitya aka Mū Cibhāḥ, to the north of the main shrine, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This is considered the main caitya of Bu Bāhāḥ. Above its plinth images of four Buddhas face in each of the cardinal directions. Another set of four Buddha statues have been installed in the upper level of the caitya. Above this are the harmikā and the thirteen tapered rings (trayodaśa-bhuvana). The image of Akṣobhya that has been placed on the eastern side of the caitya is larger than all of its other statues. A stone toraṇa depicting the Five Buddhas can be found above this statue. A pair of stone lions lie in front of the Akṣobhya statue. A bell that was donated in NS 1021 has been placed to the left of the statue. The caitya is covered with four metallic serpents and a parasol. This caitya consists of two stone inscriptions dated NS 771 and NS 820. The first one is badly damaged, whilst the second one informs the reader of the reconstruction of the caitya's plinth (H. Vajrācārya et al. 1993: 11). The caitya is in good condition.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, Mūtale Āgama, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-29
object short description: In older times, the main digi of the Bāhāḥ was placed in this house. A wooden toraṇa with the images of Lokeśvara, Akṣobhya and Prajñāpāramitā is fixed on top of the entrance.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, Vaiśṇavī Pīṭha, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: Aniconic stones are placed in the shrine. According to locals, a cremation took place here. Later, this shrine was made.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhā, Phalcā; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This two-storey building adjoining the Kvāpādyuḥ Shrine used to have a phalcā-like structure, but it has now been rebuilt as a closed house-like building. The caretakers of the shrine use this phalcā for lodging purposes. The phalcā contains stone figures of Mañjuśrī, Vajrasattva and Vasundharā on its ground floor, and the upper floor houses a stone figure of Saṅkaṭā. The available inscription is completely damaged and the date of its construction cannot be determined.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, Padma Caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: Five layers of downward and two layers of upward lotus petals can be seen in the caitya. It was donated by Śākyavaṃśa Dānaśiriju and his family in NS 843.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, well west of the Kvāpādyaḥ, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This well lies to the west of the Kvāpādyaḥ Shrine of Bu Bāhāḥ. The caretakers of the shrine use the water from this well for rituals. The upper section of the well is encircled with a couple of serpents (nāga), whose heads are facing north. Between the serpents' heads is a figure of a vase with eight auspicious symbols (aṣṭamaṅgala). The object has no inscription, and it has a jarũhiṭi spout to its west.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, stone pillar 1, view from NE; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: This stone pillar to the north of the main shrine was installed above a north-facing tortoise. On top of it is an image of Śākyamuni Buddha flanked by Sāriputra and Maudgalyāyana. It was established by Dhaṃcāmuni. During the ritual of cūḍākarma, the anoniting of the novice is performed on a small maṇḍala in front of this pillar. This object is in good condition.

Object image caption: Bu Bāhāḥ, Dīpankara Sthita Kuṭāgāra caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-24
object short description: The standing statue of Dīpaṅkara is housed inside the caitya. It was made in NS 1098. Later, in NS 1121, a statue of Lokeśvara was placed on the back side wall of the caitya.

Object image caption: Vagalāmukhī, statue of Bhīmasena on the eastern wall of the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-12-15
object short description: This Bhīmasena is worshiped on the day of Bhīmasenapūjā held in Lalitpur.

Object image caption: Vagalāmukhī, a manḍala representing Ānanda Bhairava inside the sanctum, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-12-15
Vagalāmukhī, statue of Bhīmasena on the western wall of the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-12-15
Vagalāmukhī, pillar, view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-12-15
Vagalāmukhī, Lion pillar, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-12-15
Vagalāmukhī, Vagalāmukhī in the sanctum represented by a small puddle filled with water, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-12-15
object short description: Vagalāmukhī is not represented by a statue in the sanctum. Instead, a small streaming puddle represents her. A silver shrine has been built to host her aniconic representation. The pinnacle, roof, toraṇa, and pillars of the shrine are all covered with silver. Seven serpents are placed over the pinnacle as a canopy.

Object image caption: Umāmaheśvara Mandira, Mahiṣāsuramardinī (left), view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-07
object short description: On the left side of the main entrance, there is an image of Goddess Durgā killing the demon Mahiṣāsura with her spear.

Object image caption: Umāmaheśvara Mandira, Mahiṣāsuramardinī (right), view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-07
object short description: On the right side of the main entrance, there is an image of Goddess Durgā killing the demon Mahiṣāsura with her spear.

Object image caption: Dhaneśvara Mandira, śivaliṅga in the sanctum, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-01-29
Dhaneśvara Mandira, Bhairava, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-01-29
Dāphā Phalcā, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from W (October 2019)
object short description: A canopy (ilā̃) with the images of the Five Buddhas is hanging above the Caitya, and a metal parasol tops the canopy.

Object image caption: Dāphā Phalcā, bell, view from W (October 2019)
object short description: Divalachimi was one of five people to donate this bell in NS 985. The inscription on the bell mentions that it weighs eight dhārnī.

Object image caption: Bayalkāṭiyā Baiṭhak, stone memorial pillar, view from south-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-08-28
object short description: The pillar does not present any inscription or specific engravings. A series of vertical cup marks is visible on the south-western side. These cup marks are locally explained as traces left by children who climb on the pillar.

Object image caption: Kimugāũ Temple and Pillar, view from W; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-26
object short description: The pillar may contain inscriptions on its buried sides.

object short description: This stone water tank used to be filled regularly by the local guṭhī however, after the exprorpriation of the guṭhī‘s land and the installation of water pipeline througout the town, it remained idle.

object short description: Locally, this object is called a satuṃgāḥcā. It was used for mixing lime. According to Śukrasāgara, it was installed in 1815 CE (935 NS), but he doesn't refer to any source (Ś. Śreṣṭha VS 2057, 61).

Nāga Bāhāḥ Hiti, Gaṇeśa statue, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-10-27
object short description: The statue is installed in a niche of the eastern lower plinth.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ Hiti, navagrahamaṇḍala; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-10-27
Nāga Bāhāḥ Hiti, jaruñhiti, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-11-27
object short description: This jarũhiti is located in the lower wall of the northern plinth. There are two small images of lion heads, which are in fact water spouts. Back when the hiti was still functioning, water would flow from the lions' mouths. According to Furukawa (2010, 54), the fountain was constructed during the Licchavi period.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ Hiti, standing Buddha; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-11-27
object short description: About half way down the steps leading to the tap, one finds a large stone image of a standing Buddha. Bangdel (1995, 254) dates it back to the 12th century.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ Hiti, Licchavi caitya, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-10-29
object short description: Located at the north-east corner above the hiti. Installed on a modern brick substructure, this is a fragment of a caitya that may date back to the 8th century. It has been plastered with cement.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ Hiti, Viṣṇu statue, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-10-27
Nāga Bāhāḥ Hiti, stone spouts with makara carvings, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-11-27
Nāga Bāhāḥ Hiti, Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-11-27
Nāga Bāhāḥ Hiti, caturmukha (caturvyūha) caitya, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-10-27
object short description: This structure features images of Vajrapāṇi Bodhisattva (west), Padmapāṇi Boddhisattva (north), and two other Buddhas. Slusser (1982) dates the caitya back to the 8th century. Bangdel (1995), on the other hand, identifies the same image as both Buddha and Viṣṇu, and dates them back to the 7th century. The finial is comparatively very new (installed after 2010).

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ Hiti, Licchavi caitya, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-10-27

Mū Guitaḥ Bahī, pillar, view from W (June 2019)
object short description: This pillar is located to the north of the aśoka caitya. Although at first glance the pillar appears simple, the top part has been given the form of a crown (uṣṇīṣacūḍāmaṇi). There are two large maṇḍapas to the north of the pillar.

Object image caption: Mū Guitaḥ Bahī, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from E and W (June 2019)
Mū Guitaḥ Bahī, Mahākāla, view from S (June 2019)
Mū Guitaḥ Bahī, Aśoka Caitya, view from S (June 2019)
object short description: This Lichhavi period Caitya is located in front of the esoteric god house. It contains images of four Bodhisattvas in four directions. Above the Bodhisattva images, one can find images of Buddhas flanked by Tārās. According to local people, all 16 niches were originally empty; the statues are more recent additions. Gutschow (1997, 218) suggests the caitya was constructed some time between the 9th - 13th century. There are nine planetary maṇḍalas to the south and west of the Caitya.

Object image caption: Mahādyaḥ Gāḥcā, Triliṅgeśvara Mahādeva with oxen in the kuṇḍa, view from E; Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-10-30
Mahādyaḥ Gāḥcā, statue of Gaṇeśa on the northern side of the entrance, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-10-30

Mahādyaḥ Gāḥcā, 64 liṅgas on the top of the wall, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-10-30
object short description: The list displays the names of the 64 jyotirliṅgas from different parts of Nepal with which the liṅgas on the wall are associated.

Object image caption: Mahādyaḥ Gāḥcā, statue of Hanumān at the southwest corner, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-10-30

Yaṅgaḥ Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-15
Yaṅgaḥ Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-15
object short description: This stone statue lost its authenticity, since it has been painted in enamel paint. It was repaired by Jogaratna Śākya and painted by Bhikṣu Vivekānanda (Śākya 2053, 4).

Object image caption: Kvātha Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-04
Kvātha Bāhāḥ, statue of Triratna, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-04
Kvātha Bāhāḥ, statue of Sarasvatī, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-04
Kvātha Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-04
Kvātha Bāhāḥ, statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-08
Kvātha Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-04
Tvāya Bāhāḥ,  Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-08
object short description: This Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala has the Bodhisattvas images in all eight directions, and a metal vajra is kept above it.

Object image caption: Tvāya Bāhāḥ, Aśoka Caitya, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-08
object short description: The Caitya stands on the a rectangular plinth and has two layers of the empty niches, a distinct feature of the Licchavi caityas. The structure above the dome seems to be added later.

Object image caption: Tvāya Bāhāḥ, Navagraha Maṇḍala, topdown view; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-08
object short description: The maṇḍaḥpaḥ at the centre is surrounded by nine stone circles which are representing the nine planets. Some people believe that this Manḍala is the symbol of the nine scriptures (navagrantha) in the Mahāyāna Buddhism.

Object image caption: Tvāya Bāhāḥ, Vimba Caitya, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-08
Tvāya Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-08
object short description: This four-armed Gaṇeśa is affixed to the Bāhāḥ’s northern wall. He is holding a garland and radish on his right hands, and an axe and a sweet ball on the left hands. A small statue of Bhīmasena is placed beside the Ganeśa.

Object image caption: Tvāya Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-08
object short description: This two-armed Mahākāla is standing on a corpse holding a ritual knife (kartṛ) and a begging bowl (kapālapātra). It is affixed to the north wall in the entry way to the courtyard.

Object image caption: Tvāya Bāhāḥ, Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-08
object short description: This stone statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara was enshrined recently after the original one made of sandalwood got stolen around VS 2015-16.

Object image caption: Kvaynā Sataḥ, Gaṇeśa, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-28
Kvaynā Sataḥ, Stone relief with eight Rishis, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-28
Kvaynā Sataḥ, Nāga Shrine, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-28
Kvaynā Sataḥ, Viṣṇu, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-28
Kvaynā Sataḥ, Statue of devotees/doors, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-28
Kvaynā Sataḥ, Kumāra, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-28
Kvaynā Sataḥ, Śivaliṅga and Nandi bull, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-28
Unmatta Bhairava, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-25
object short description: A statue of Unmatta Bhairava is established in the sanctum on the ground floor of the temple. The wooden statue faces west. Most of the wooden statues sculpted in the medieval period were made of pieces of wood, however, this statue of Unmatta Bhairava ​​was sculpted out of a single wooden block. He has ten arms, and wears snake and muṇḍamālā as ornament. He stands naked and his penis is completely erected. A vetāla is placed in front of the Bhairava. Although the statue is made of wood, his feet are covered with copper foil.

Object image caption: Unmatta Bhairava, the statue of Bhagavatī, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-25
Unmatta Bhairava, the statue of Kumāra, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-25
Unmatta Bhairava, the statue of Baṭuka Bhairava, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-25
Unmatta Bhairava, the statue of devotees, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-16
object short description: A woman named Parvatī had donated this statue on the first death anniversary of her parents.

Object image caption: Unmatta Bhairava, Kṣetrapāla, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-25
Unmatta Bhairava, pedestal, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-25
object short description: This is a fragment of the pedestal of a statue. There is no date as the pedestal is broken. According to the inscription, Jitalakṣmī and Ragurāja had set up a golden statue together. The statue mentioned in the inscription is missing.

Object image caption: Unmatta Bhairava, the headless statue of a female devotee, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-16
object short description: The head of this statue is missing. No information is available about the statue as there is no inscription.

Object image caption: Unmatta Bhairava, the statue of Gaṇeśa, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-25
dwadwdwd
object short description: dwawda

Object image caption: Ilāe Bahī, statue of Nāmasaṅgīti, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
object short description: The twelve-armed Nāmasaṅgīti is sitting in a meditation position, dhyānamudrā, and displaying the uttarabodhimudrā through his uppermost left and right arms.

Object image caption: Ilāy Bahī, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
Ilāy Bahī, Licchavi Caitya, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
object short description: Large part of this caitya, is also underneath the ground level. The part above, harmikā, seems to be added later.

Object image caption: Ilāy Bahī, statue of Mahākāla, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
Ilāy Bahī, Vimba Caitya, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
object short description: As it can be seen on the photo, this caitya is randomly plastered.

Object image caption: Ilāy Bahī, Licchavi Caitya, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
object short description: Large part of this caitya is underneath the level ground. The part above the harmikā seems to be added later.

Object image caption: Ilāy Bahī, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
Ilāy Bahī, close view of the Akṣobhya statue in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
Ilāy Bahī, statue of Vasundharā, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
object short description: Vasundharā is believed to be the Goddess of wealth and prosperity. She  is sitting in the lalita posture.

Object image caption: Ilāy Bahī, statue of Vajrasattva, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
object short description: This two-armed Vajrasattva holds respectively a vajra and a bell on his right and left hand.

Object image caption: Ilāy Bahī, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
object short description: This four-armed Gaṇeśa is holding a rosary and radish on his right hands, and an axe and a sweet ball on his left hands.

Object image caption: Ilāy Bahī, statue of a female donor, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
Ilāy Bahī, statue of a male donor, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-07
Pintu Bahī, statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-02-21
object short description: The pillars made to hang a bell were empty after the theft of the bell. In the 1980’s thieves made an unsuccessful attempt to steal the 12th century statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara placed in Ālko Hiti. They had to leave it behind when they were disturbed by local residents (Bangdel 1989, 293). Generally, Amitābha Buddha is found on the crown of Lokeśvara, but in the present case, Akṣobhya sits on his crown.

Object image caption: Pintu Bahī, statues of donors, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-02-21
object short description: Statues of three donors are attached to the western plinth of the Aśoka Caitya. These are the statues of Kīrtirāja and his two wives who donated a moharamālā which weights 12 tolā to the main deity of the Bahī.

Object image caption: Pintu Bahī, Aśoka Caitya, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-02-21
object short description: Older Aśoka Caitya was covered with a new structure. Four Buddhas are placed in the niches of four cardinal directions. The statues are bronze-clad. The metal ilā̃, hanging over the Caitya was offered in 1928. Every year on the full moon day of Āśvina, a parasol is placed on top of the Caitya.

Object image caption: Pintu Bahī, aniconic niche of Hanumān, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-02-21
object short description: Aniconic symbol, worshipped as Hanumān, is attached to the northern wall of the main entrance of the Bahī.

Object image caption: Pintu Bahī, Mahākāla shrine, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-02-21
object short description: Mahākāla is standing on a lotus petal and holding a kartṛ (cutter) in his right hand and a kapāpāpātra (skull bowl) in his left hand. His left hand also claspses a khaṭvāṅga. The saṅgha members of the Bahī worship him as their lineage deity (digudaḥ).

Object image caption: Pintu Bahī, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-02-21
object short description: The feature of this Caitya is similar to other Dharmadhātujinālaya Caityas.

Object image caption: Pintu Bahī, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-02-21
object short description: Images of eight Bodhisattvas are placed on the faces of the octagonal Maṇḍala. Nhucherāja Brahmacarjyā and his family made this Maṇḍala.

Object image caption: Pintu Bahī, statue of Akṣobhya in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-02-21
object short description: Stone statue of Akṣobhya is placed in the sanctum as the main deity (gandhurī devatā) of the Bahī.

Object image caption: Sejuvalgāũ Devala, āmalaka ring, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-07
object short description: This āmalaka ring was either placed on top of the nearby śikhara temple or on top of another, now gone, śikhara temple.

Object image caption: Kuladeva Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-11-19
Kuladeva Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-11-19
object short description: The Vajradhātu Caitya had been established at this place even before it became Bāhāḥ. This is confirmed by a bell offered for the Caitya by two brothers, Kuladeva and Caityarāja in NS 1040 (CE 1920) at the southwest of the Caitya. After the upper part of the caitya was stolen from the garbha, a local Aśṭarāja Śākya made the stolen part with cement and covered it with brass sheets. Stone lions are placed at the four corners of the caitya. A metal ilā̃ is offered to the caitya.

Object image caption: Kuladeva Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-11-19
object short description:
The upper portion of the Dharmadhātu is brass plated. It starts from the nāga motif and continues upwards. This Dharmadhātu was installed when this Bāhāḥ was founded.   

धर्मधातु मण्डलको नागदेखि माथिको भागमा पित्तलको पाताले मोडिएको छ । बाहा: स्थापना गर्दा यो धर्मधातु मण्डल पनि स्थापना गरिएको थियो ।

Object image caption: Kuladeva Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-11-19
Kuladeva Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-11-19
object short description: When the Bāhāḥ was established in 1928 CE (NS 1048), the stone statue of Akṣobhya was installed in the sanctum, facing east as the Bāhā'sḥ Kvāḥpāḥdya. Following the theft of the statue, an idol of Dhalot was installed in its place by an individual named Jñānadeva Śākya.”

Object image caption: Athaḥ Bāhāḥ, stone statue of Tārā, view from W (March 2020)
object short description: A statue of Tārā is located on the western plinth of the vajradhātu caitya. The right hand is broken. She is holding lotus stalks in both of her hands.

Object image caption: Athaḥ Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from E (March 2020)
object short description: Four of the faces of this octagonal maṇḍala contain four Bodhisattvas, whilst the other four display flower motifs. A fire alter has been built on the side of the maṇḍala.

Object image caption: Athaḥ Bāhāḥ, Mañjuśrī Pādukā, view from E (March 2020)
object short description: An impression of the feet of Mañjuśrī has been made beside the maṇḍala (LAL0870-009). Two small stone lions guard the feet.

Object image caption: Athaḥ Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from S (March 2020)
object short description: Eight Bodhisattvas are placed on the eight faces of the maṇḍala. Siddhirāja and his family commissioned this maṇḍala.

Object image caption: Athaḥ Bāhāḥ, vajradhātu caitya, view from S (March 2020)
object short description: Four Buddhas have been placed at the four cardinal directions of the vajradhātu caitya. Metal serpents rise from the four corners and an ilā̃ is fixed on top of the structure.

Object image caption: Athaḥ Bāhāḥ, Sarasvatī shrine, view from E (March 2020)
object short description: A two-storey structure is attached to the god house of the Bāhāḥ. Statues of Sarasvtī and Nāmasaṅgīti are enshrined on the ground floor.

Object image caption: Athaḥ Bāhāḥ, Buddha in Bhaviṣyavyākaraṇa Mudrā (Maitreya), view from E (March 2020)
object short description: This statue of Maitreya Buddha in bhaviṣyavyākaraṇa posture is enshrined in the sanctum. His right hand is performing a gesture of blessing whilst his left hand holds a cloth. An aura surrounds him and a metal ilā̃ is fixed above him. In 1990, thapāḥju Lakṣmījyoti Śākya established this wooden statue after the loss of the previous one.

Object image caption: Athaḥ Bāhāḥ, stone statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara in a niche, view from E (March 2020)
object short description: A toraṇa with an image of Amitābha Buddha is fixed above the statue.

Object image caption: Athaḥ Bāhāḥ, stone statue of Gaṇeśa attached to the wall of the god house, view from E (March 2020)
Athaḥ Bāhāḥ, stone statue of Hanumān attached to the wall of the god house, view from E (March 2020)
Indrāyaṇī Dyaḥchẽ, statue of lion (B), view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-30
Indrāyaṇī Dyaḥchẽ, statue of lion (A), view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-30
Indrāyaṇī Dyaḥchẽ, wooden palanquin (B), view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-30
Indrāyaṇī Dyaḥchẽ, wooden palanquin (A), view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-30
Indrāyaṇī Dyaḥchẽ, statue of Indrāyaṇī in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-30
Indrāyaṇī Dyaḥchẽ, statue of Gaṇeśa in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-05-30
Dhum Bāhāḥ Caitya, statue of Amitābha in the niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-15
Dhum Bāhāḥ Caitya, statue of Maudagalyāyana, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-15
Dhum Bāhāḥ Caitya, statue of Amoghasiddhi in the niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-15
Dhum Bāhāḥ Caitya, statue of Akṣobhya in the niche, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-15
Dhum Bāhāḥ Caitya, statue of Sāriputra, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-15
Dhum Bāhāḥ Caitya, statue of Ratnasambhava in the niche, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-15
Konti Bahī, aniconic niche of Hanumān, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-07
object short description: There is an empty niche at the northeast corner of the Bahī. The locals worship it as Hanumān.

Object image caption: Konti Bahī, stone statue of Amitābha Buddha, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-07
object short description: The statue of Amitābha Buddha is attached to the Aśoka Caitya. Statues of five devotees ahave been placed at the bottom of the statue. Dharmarāja and Aindrarāja established the Buddha statue in memory of Monk Dhanadeva during the reign of King Mahendra Siṃha and minister Jhagala Thākura in NS 838.

Object image caption: Konti Bahī, Buddha in Bhaviṣyavyākaraṇa mudrā in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-07
object short description: A statue of Buddha in bhaviṣyavyākaraṇa posture is enshrined in the sanctum. The earlier statue was made from clay and gold and was stolen in 2001. Sanukaji Shakya made a new clay idol and established it in 2002. A wooden aura is fixed behind the statue.

Object image caption: Konti Bahī, Dharmacakra, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-07
object short description: There is a stone Dharmacakra at the bottom of the Mahākāla statue. Sculptures of lotus flower and a vajra can be seen to the right and left of the Dharmachakra respectively. Art historians consider this to be from the Licchavi period. Pal (1974, plates 162, 163) dates them to the 8th century and Bangdel (1995, 247) to the 10th century.

Object image caption: Konti Bahī, Mahākāla and Lokeśvara, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-07
object short description: These eroded wooden statues of Mahākāla and Lokeśvara have been placed in a niche. The deities cannot be recognized from the figure. Mahākāla was worshipped here once, but this is no longer the case.

Object image caption: Konti Bahī, Aśoka Caitya, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-07
object short description: An Aśoka Caitya of the Lichhavi period has been established in the Bahī courtyard. The lower floor of the Caitya is octagonal and the niches have been left empty. The upper part of the Caitya has four niches in four directions. Buddha statues were later added in the empty niches. Those statues are eroded. Cement plaster has been used to join the garbha and harmikā. Some decades ago, the anniversary ritual worship of the Caitya used to be celebrated on the 2nd day of the dark fortnight of Bhādra. However, the tradition is discontinued.

Object image caption: Konti Bahī, Caitya, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-07
object short description: This Caitya is built on a five-tiered plinth. Buddha statues are placed in the four cardinal directions. Cement plaster has been applied to connect the garbha to the harmikā. Bekhāratna Khaḍgī established this Caitya.

Object image caption: Konti Bahī, Mañjuśrī Pādukā, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-07
object short description: The Mañjuśrī Pādukā (feet of Mañjuśrī) is located to the north of the Bahī's entrance. The Pādukās are placed on a cemented plinth. Bekhāratna Khaḍgī funded its construction.

Object image caption: Cilancva Bāhāḥ, lion (B), view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-10
Cilancva Bāhāḥ, lion (A), view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-10
Cilancva Bāhāḥ, Maudagalyāyana, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-10
Cilancva Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya Buddha in the sanctum, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-10
Cilancva Bāhāḥ, Sāriputra, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-10-10

Jagamaru Pukhū Phalcā, shrine of Kṛṣṇa, view from SW (February 2020)

The shrine is small and made of bricks. It has a cement roof and a dome-like structure on top of it. The main deity faces west.
Dabū (dance platform) and temporary shrine, statue of Buṅgadyaḥ, view from N (December 2019)
object short description: Buṅgadyaḥ was moved to this temporary shrine after the collapse of the Karuṇāmaya Temple

Object image caption: Dabū (dance platform) and temporary shrine, bell with inscription suspended from a stone frame (December 2019).
object short description: This bell was moved from the Karuṇāmaya Temple following the 2015 earthquakes.

Object image caption: Dabū (dance platform) and temporary shrine, one of a pair of large stone lions. (December 2019)
object short description: The statues were moved from the Karuṇāmaya Temple after the 2015 earthquakes.

Object image caption: Dabū (dance platform) and temporary shrine, one of a pair of small stone lions. (December 2019)
object short description: The statues were moved from the Karuṇāmaya Temple after the 2015 earthquakes.

Object image caption: Bhajana Phalcā, statue of the donor family, view from SW (August 2019)
object short description: The statues of the donors, Chatrasiṃ (in the middle) and his two wife Dhanamāĩ (to the right) and Bhīmalakṣmi (to the left), have been sculpted on a single stone slab and are attached to the wall of the Phalcā.

Object image caption: Bhajana Phalcā, an aniconic stone, view from SW (August 2019)
object short description: This aniconic stone placed below the middle bay of the Phalcā is worshipped as Nārāyaṇa.

Object image caption: Bhajana Phalcā, statue of Padmapāṇilokeśvara, view from S (August 2019)
object short description: The statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara is attached to the northern wall of the Phalcā. He is standing on a lotus pedestal in abhaṅga posture and wearing a long garland. He is holding lotus flowers in both hands and performing varada with his right hand.

Object image caption: Taḥdhaṃnani Caitya, Licchavi Caitya 4, view from S (June 2020)
Taḥdhaṃnani Caitya, Licchavi Caitya 3, view from SE (June 2020)
Taḥdhaṃnani Caitya, Licchavi Caitya 1, view from NW (June 2020)
Taḥdhaṃnani Caitya, Licchavi Caitya 2, view from NE (June 2020)
Siṃhadvapāḥ Phalcā, statue of Mañjuśrī attached on the wall, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-06
Ubāhāḥ Gathicā at Oku Bāhāḥ, Buddha statue; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07
object short description: This image is so worn that his hand posture cannot be determined.

Object image caption: Ubāhāḥ Gathicā at Oku Bāhāḥ, Bhīmasena fighting with animals; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07
object short description: This image is badly damaged.

Object image caption: Ubāhāḥ Gathicā at Oku Bāhāḥ, three faced and six armed Mañjuvajra with consort; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07
Ubāhāḥ Gathicā at Oku Bāhāḥ, two armed Mañjuśrī with consort in sukhāsana posture; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07
Ubāhāḥ Gathicā at Oku Bāhāḥ, Lokanātha Degaḥ, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07
object short description: This temple to Lokeśvara is probably amongst the first miniature temples to be built in stone with a bell-shaped top (Gutschow 2011, 560). The stone toraṇa depicts a Pañcabuddha and there are statues of Lokeśvaras on the southern, western and northern sides of the temple.

Object image caption: Ubāhāḥ Gathicā at Oku Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07
Ubāhāḥ Gathicā at Oku Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa and Kumāra statues; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07
object short description: This image is so worn that the attributes of the figures are almost indistinguishable.

Object image caption: Pūcva Kvaya Bahī, Mahākāla shrine, view from S (February 2020)
object short description: Mahākāla stands on a lotus seat. He is holding a kartṛ (cutter) in his right hand and his left hand holds a kapāpāpātra (skull bowl) and claspses a khaṭvāṅga. There is a maṇḍala of nine planets on the floor in front of Mahākāla.

Object image caption: Pūcva Kvaya Bahī, Hanumān shrine, view from N (February 2020)
object short description: There is no statute of Hanumān. The niche of the wall is the symbolic representation of the deity.

Object image caption: Pūcva Kvaya Bahī, Vajra, view from E (February 2020)
object short description: Ratna Śākya and Kamalā Śākya offered this Vajra in the memory of their mother Pūrṇamāyā Śākya.

Object image caption: Pūcva Kvaya Bahī, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N (February 2020)
object short description: The Maṇḍala places eight Bodhisattvas on its eight faces.

Object image caption: Pūcva Kvaya Bahī, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from NE (February 2020)
object short description: Cement plaster joins the garbha and harmikā parts of the Caitya.

Object image caption: Pūcva Kvaya Bahī, Maitreya Buddha, view from E (February 2020)
object short description: Maitreya sits showing bhaviṣyavyākaraṇa gesture with his hand. His body is covered with metal cloth. The wooden statue of the deity was covered with gilded metal.

Object image caption: Nhū Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from SW (January 2019)
object short description: This octagonal maṇḍala has images of eight Lokeśvaras in eight directions. It was established by Harṣa Bir, Rāj Bir, Nhukṣhe Bir, Dharma Bir, Hela Thakũ and their family members in memory of the Dhirja Bir Company.

Object image caption: Nhū Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, views from E (January 2019)
Svãgaḥ Cibhāḥ, Sarasvatī, view from E (January 2020)
Svãgaḥ Cibhāḥ, Acala, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: The image of Acala has been placed on the south of main entrance to caitya courtyard.  Acala is depicted holding a sword for subduing demons in his right hand and a rope in his left hand. The repeated application of vermilion powder has destroyed the face of the deity.

Object image caption: Svãgaḥ Cibhāḥ, Kumāra, view from W (January 2020)
object short description: The statue of Kumāra was also installed together with Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara. Four-handed Kumāra, sitting over a peacock holds a rosary in his upper right hand. He holds a spear and a water vessel in his two left hands. His fourth hand is broken.

Object image caption: Svãgaḥ Cibhāḥ, Gaṇeśa, view from W (January 2020)
object short description: Stone statue of Gaṇeśa was installed together with the statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara. Four-handed Gaṇeśa holds a rosary and radish on his right hands and an axe and sweet ball in his left hands.

Object image caption: Svãgaḥ Cibahāḥ, various small statues of deities
object short description:
At the southern side of the courtyard, small metal statues of various gods are placed inside the tiny rooms. The gods are as follows:

Eastern Section: 1. Mañjuśrī, 2. Ṣaḍakṣarī Lokeśvara, 3. Akṣobhya, 4. Āryatārā, 5. Vajradhara

Middle Section: 1. Ratnasambhava, 2. Akṣobhya, 3. Vairocana, 4. Amitābha, 5. Amoghasiddhi

Western Section: 1. Vajrasattva, 2. Bhaiṣajya Buddha, 3. Aparimitā, 4. Ṣaḍakṣarī Lokeśvara, 5. Saptalocanī Tārā, 6. Āryatārā

Object image caption: Svãgaḥ Cibhāḥ, Padmapaṇi Lokeśvara, view from W (January 2020)
object short description: The shrine of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara stands in front of the central caitya. The deity stands on a lotus pedestal holding a lotus stalk in his left hand and showing varada gesture with the right hand. His crown displays an Akṣobhya image. The historical statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, dated to the 13th century, was stolen (Śākya and Vaidya 1970, 96). This new statue was installed in 2006.

Object image caption: Yoku Bāhāḥ, Lotus-shaped stones in the ground for special rituals, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-27
Yoku Bāhāḥ, pillar, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-10-22
Yoku Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla image, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-27
Yoku Bāhāḥ, Aṣṭakoṇavedikoparipadma Caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-27
object short description: Above the octagonal base are images of eight bodhisattvas and above them are four images of Buddha.

Object image caption: Jyābā Bahī, Śikharakūṭa caitya, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-28
object short description: This caitya lies to the north of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala. It was installed by Dhanajyoti and his wife Āśāmāyā in NS 1095. Images of the donors can be found on the eastern plinth of the caitya, which also contains statues of Buddha at each cardinal direction.

Object image caption: Jyābā Bahī, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-28
object short description: An octagonal dharmadhātu maṇḍala with eight Bodhisattvas at each of its eight directions stands to the north of the aśoka caitya.

Object image caption: Jyābā Bahī, Aśoka Caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-28
object short description: This aśoka caitya is located in front of the door of the main shrine. A vajra covers the caitya for protection. Four niches containing kīrtimukha toraṇas can be found at the four sides of the caitya. Inside the eastern niche is an image of Akṣobhya. The southern and western niches do not contain any images. On the toraṇa of the western niche, one can see statues of five Buddhas. Inside the northern niche, one can find an image of Amitābha Buddha. An oil lamp balustrade and a metal ilā̃ supported by iron angular rods surround the caitya. To the west, one can find a mandaḥpā and a yajñavedī.

Object image caption: Jyābā Bahī, Caturvyūha caitya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-28
object short description: This caitya is located outside the Bahī. It was established in NS 800. One can find images of Bodhisattvas standing on lotus pedestals at each of the four cardinal directions - these are: Maitreya (E), Vajrapāṇi (S), Padmapāṇi (W) and Mañjuśrī (N). Above the Bodhisattva images, one can find seven circles of petals from a blooming lotus flower (padmāvalī). Six are turned downward and one upward. This structure of successive rings with lotus petals occured for the first time on the design of the Caturvyūha caitya (Gutschow 1997, 272). There are small images of Buddha on four sides above the padmāvalī.

Object image caption: Jyābā Bahī, Mahākāla shrine, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-28
object short description: One can find a carved wooden statue of Māhākāla inside a niche to the western side of the main entrance of the Bahī. Māhākāla is standing and holding a katṛ in his right hand and a kapālapātra in his left. He is holding a khaṭvāṅga with his left hand. A toraṇa above the statue contains an image of Akṣobhya Buddha at its centre.

Object image caption: Subāhāḥ Hiti Phalcā, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from SE; photo by Niels Gutschow; 1993; courtesy of Niels Gutschow; free access – no reuse
object short description: Gaṇeśa is the lineage deity of the Shakyas of Subāhāḥ. They celebrate the Diwali pūjā of Gaṇeśa on the 10th and 12-14th of the dark half of Jyeṣṭha.

Object image caption: Subāhāḥ Hiti Phalcā, statue of Hāratī Ajimā, view from S; photo by Niels Gutschow; 1993; courtesy of Niels Gutschow; free access – no reuse
object short description:
This stone statue of a four-handed Hāratī Ajimā is estimated to date back to the 3rd century CE. In a small (unpublished) fieldwork report from 1992, Nutan Sharma observes the following: "according to the Shakyas of Subāhāḥ, this is an icon of Hāratī Ajimā. whereas Mr Lainsingh Bangdel says in his book about old icons that this is an icon of Baisnavī, one of the mother goddesses from the 4th century BCE".

The goddess Hāratī is worshipped when people suffer from smallpox. Nowadays, this worship is no longer as common.

Object image caption: Śiva Mandira, śivaliṅga, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-19
Duru Bāhāḥ Nani, vajradhātu caitya, view from N (March 2019)
Duru Bāhāḥ Nani, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from N (March 2019)
object short description: A metal vajra is erected on an iron stand to the east of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala. This is dated NS 1123.

Object image caption: Duru Bāhāḥ Nani, Hanumān statue, view from E (March 2019)
object short description: Hanumān is kneeling; his left leg touches the ground while the right is slightly raised. His right hand is in varada mudrā and his left hand is in abhaya mudrā.

Object image caption: Duru Bāhāḥ Nani, dharmadhātu maṇḍala (b), view from N (March 2019)
object short description: A metal vajra was added to the top of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala.

Object image caption: Duru Bāhāḥ Nani, Bhīmasena statue, view from E (March 2019)
object short description: Bhīmasena is pictured pressing his enemy down with the knee of his left leg. He rips open the enemy’s chest with his left hand and pulls out a long portion of his entrails with his right hand or else raises a club over him. Individuals are often unable to identify the enemy in such representations, while others are not sure whether he is Duryodhana, Duḥśāsana or Kīcaka.

Object image caption: Mīnanātha Mandira, Kṣetrapāla, view from W (August 2019)
object short description: This small platform is located to the east of the caitya and surrounded by two serpents. It is worshipped as the place of Kṣetrapāla. Both of the serpents' heads are joined together and turned to face the eastern side. The flowers and materials from the pūja of the khaḍgajātrā on the 10th day of the bright fortnight of Aśvina are put away here when it ends.

Object image caption: Mīnanātha Mandira, Ghaṭakūṭa Caitya, view from E (August 2019)
object short description: There are two caityas attached to the Kṣetrapāla on the eastern side. Although they look simple, they contain rectangular trayodaśabhuvanas. A mandaḥpā is located between these two caityas.

Object image caption: Mīnanātha Mandira, Aṣṭakoṇākāra Caitya, view from N (August 2019)
object short description: This caitya is situated on the eastern side of the temple and has eight Bodhisattvas on its eight faces. There are five layers of lotus petals on top of it.

Object image caption: Mīnanātha Mandira, Yamadvāra shrine, view from S (August 2019)
object short description: There is a Yamadvāra or Narakdvāra ('doorway to hell') on the north-eastern side of the bāḥāḥ with lots of small stones on its walls. A stone with a toraṇa on the northern wall takes the form of Yamarāja and has a stone serpent on top of it. Another stone in the southern wall represents Hanumān. On the first day of the bright fortnight of Bhādra, devotees light 108 oil lamps in the memory of late family members.

Object image caption: Mīnanātha Mandira, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from W (August 2019)
object short description: Octagonal dharmadhātu maṇḍala with Bodhisattvas in eight directions. There is a metal vajra on top of it.

Object image caption: Mīnanātha Mandira,dharmadhātu jinālaya caitya, view from W (August 2019)
object short description: Like other dharmadhātu jinālaya caityas, this caitya has a lotus pedestal with four Buddhas facing in four directions and another lotus motif on top of it. There are Buddha statues facing in four directions with garbhagṛiha and a harmikā and trayodaśabhuvana on top of them.

Object image caption: Mīnanātha Mandira, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from W (August 2019)
object short description: The images of Buddha are eroded. Cement plaster has been used to attach the garbha and harmikā.

Object image caption: Mīnanātha Mandira, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from E (August 2019)
object short description: There are Bodhisattvas in eight directions of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala. There is a metal vajra on top of the maṇḍala. On the eastern side of the maṇḍala are two stone manḍaḥpās, one metal manḍaḥpā and one metal yajñakuṇḍa.

Object image caption: Mīnanātha Mandira, Nhavã Dabū (bathing platform), view from W (August 2019)
object short description: There is a nhavã dabū (a platform for the bathing ritual of Mīnanātha) on the northern side of Mīnanātha Mandira. Stairs on the eastern side lead to the dabalī. It is unclear when the dabalī was constructed, however it was restored in NS 793 and 1022.

Object image caption: Mīnanātha Mandira, Bimba Caitya, view from W (August 2019)
object short description: This caitya is situated on the northern side of the temple and has a small dome in proportion to its plinth. There are no decorations on the caitya. A rectangular structure sits on the top of the garbha and appears to be a harmikā. There is a round stone figure on top of it which might be an uṣṇīṣacūdāmaṇi.

Object image caption: Mīnanātha Mandira, Aśoka Caitya, view from W (August 2019)
object short description: This is the oldest caitya in the Bahāḥ. Although the makers of the caitya are unknown, it appears to have been reconstructed in NS 793 and 993. There is an image of Amogasiddhi on the eastern vedikā of the caitya, though the other three sides are empty. There are three niches in each of the four directions on top of the vedikā. The middle niches house a statue of Buddha while the other two remain empty. A further niche has also been made with a Buddha statue in it. Prayer wheels and vajra can be found to the eastern side of the caitya.

Object image caption: Vachẽ Nani Bāhāḥcā, Hanumān statue, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: This statue is placed in a small niche on a wall south of the temple.

Object image caption: Vachẽ Nani Bāhāḥcā, Śikharakūṭotpannaparipadma Caitya, view from E (September 2019)
object short description: This Caitya was established at an earlier date than the bāhāḥ. It is located at the centre of the courtyard. Images of four Bodhisattvas have been placed on it in each of the four directions. Pruscha (1975, 208) mentions that it was constructed by Dhanavantasiṃha Vajrācārya.

Object image caption: Vachẽ Nani Bāhāḥcā, Gaṇeśa statue, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: This statue is placed in a small niche made on a wall to the north of the temple.

Garuḍanārāyaṇa Mandira, image of guardian deity Vijaya, view from W (July 2019)

Bodhikha Gaṇeśa, statue of Viṣṇu (B), view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-11
Bodhikha Gaṇeśa, lineage shrine, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-11
Bodhikha Gaṇeśa, Śivaliṅga, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-11
Āvaḥ Capāḥ, water spout from jahrũhiti, view from W (March 2019)
object short description: A stone jahrũhiti stands next to the south-eastern door of the monument. It is decorated with a Bhairava painted on paper that displays songs of worship.

Object image caption: Avāḥ Capāḥ, a round pole
object short description: A round pole (ākāśadīpa) hangs under the roof of the phalcā as part of the Capāḥ. It is erected at Indrajātrā and a light is placed on top of it - the pole then stands in the open square to the south-southwest of the monument for the duration of 1 month.

Object image caption: Avāḥ Capāḥ, a painting of Bhairava is enshrined on the first floor of the Capāḥ.
object short description: A dhakiṃ (screen) depicting Nāsaḥdyaḥ covers the Bhairava.

Object image caption: Avāḥ Capāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from S (February 2019)
object short description: This worn-down stone statue of Gaṇeśa is in a small niche with a pitched stone roof and a pinnacle. There is a small carved blind window made of wood above it.

Object image caption: Svĩsvĩdyaḥ Shrine, view from W (February 2019)
object short description: The Svĩsvĩdyaḥ Shrine is embedded into the western side of the plinth and consists of uniconic stones and possibly the remnants of a stone sculpture. All of the stones are heavily eroded. Respiritary problems are called svĩsvĩ in the Newari language. When someone suffers from such an ailment their relatives come to worship this deity.

Object image caption: Jalahari, view from top (February 2019)
Halĩpatāḥ Phalcā, statue of Umāmaheśvara (October 2019)
object short description: The Umāmaheśvara statue is attached to the wall of the Phalcā.

Object image caption: Siddhimukteśvara Mandira, śivaliṅga (brought from India) inside the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-16
Yachu Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-01-28
Yachhu Baha, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-01-28
Siddhilakṣmī Mandira, statue of Nandī on the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-02
Siddhilakṣmī Mandira, statue of Lakṣmī in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-02
object short description: This Lakṣmī statue (also known as Siddhilakṣmī) is enshrined in the sanctum sanctorum. She is standing in the samapāda posture and holding a lotus on her left hand.  She is flanked by the images of two Sevikās who are whisking her with the cāmara (New. cvāmola).

Object image caption: Siddhilakṣmī Mandira, stone kalaśa with a statue on the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-02
object short description: The kalaśa (ritual water vessel) has a four-armed statue on its top. Since the statue is heavily damaged, it cannot be identified. The local residents worship it as Gorakhanātha.

Object image caption: Siddhilakṣmī Mandira, statue of Lakṣmī on the wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-02
object short description: The iconographic features of this statue are exactly similar to the one in the sanctum.

Object image caption: Siddhilakṣmī Mandira, well, view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-02
Siddhilakṣmī Mandira, jaḥdhuṃhiti, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-02
object short description: This jaḥdhũhiti is at the northeast corner of the temple. It faces north and bears two inscriptions from the Licchavi period.

Object image caption: Mahālakṣmī Dyaḥchẽ, a statue of Dvārapāla (B), view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-31
Mahālakṣmī Dyaḥchẽ, a statue of Dvārapāla (A), view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-05-31
Saĩthu Gaṇeśa Mandira, mouse statue, view from E (December 2018)
Saĩthu Gaṇeśa Mandira, shrine of Gorakhnātha, view from E (December 2018)
object short description: This shrine stands on a single plinth. Three steps lead up to its entrance, which is flanked by images of lions. An oil-lamp balustrade surrounds the temple. The upper part of the shrine is bell shaped, with a pinnacle at it's top. Inside the shrine are images of Gorakhanātha, Jālandhara (?), Bhairava, Gaṇeśa and some other deities. The Kapalī community of Patan worship Gorakhanātha as their family deity and once a year they perform their devālī pūjā.

Object image caption: Saĩthu Gaṇeśa Mandira, Ākāśabhairava shrine, view from N (December 2018)
object short description: Inside this small shrine is an image of Bhairava. Some parts of the image are broken. Above the niche is a kīrtimukha toraṇa. Two lion statues were established on the both sides of the gate in front of the shrine, however the statue of the right-hand side is broken and only a remnant of it is existing there. On the top of the shrine is a pinnacle and on the both sides of it are jvālānhāyakaṃs. At the bottom of the pinnacle is a small image of Bhairava.

Object image caption: Saĩthu Gaṇeśa Mandira, Kuladevatā shrine, view from W (December 2018)
object short description: Once a year, the Vyañjanakāras of Cyāsal Ṭola perform their devālī pūjā also in this temple. There are five kīrtimukha toraṇas, below which are empty niches that are worshipped by the people as their family deities. On the both sides of the toraṇa there are aniconic stone images.

Object image caption: Saĩthu Gaṇeśa Mandira, Sarasvatī, view from E (December 2018)
object short description: To the west of the main temple is an image of Sarasvatī attached to the wall. Decorating with nāga and daliṃkhvāla the part of the wall ihas developed to a small shrine. It has been newly made during the time of reconstruction of the main temple.

Object image caption: Saĩthu Gaṇeśa Mandira, unidentified image (Viṣṇu?), view from E (December 2018)
object short description: Most of the parts of the image is broken. Only the upper part of the body of the image is visible while lower parts of the body below the chest are buried in the earth.

Object image caption: Saĩthu Gaṇeśa Mandira, Sūryavināyaka shrine, view from E (December 2018)
object short description: This is one of the east-facing Gaṇeśa temples of the Kathmandu Valley. The aniconic Gaṇeśa image and the toraṇa were lying in open ground but have recently been established in the temple.

Object image caption: Saĩthu Gaṇeśa Mandira, Kuladevatā shrine, view from W (December 2018)
object short description: The Jyāpu community of Kontī Ṭola worship the deity inside the shrine as their family deity and perform their devālī pūjā once a year. There is one kīrtimukha toraṇa and four other toraṇa like stone structures in front of which aniconic stones are placed. There are newly installed two bronze oil lamps

Object image caption: Saĩthu Gaṇeśa Mandira, Kuladevatā shrine, view from W  (December 2018)
object short description: The Vyañjanakāras of Cyāsala Ṭola perform their devālī pūjā in this temple every year. There are four kīrtimukha toraṇas, and below the toraṇas are empty niches which are worshipped by the people as their family deities.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, ox (Nandi), view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: Most Ganeśa temples have a statue of a mouse, the vehicle of Gaṇeśa, in front of them. However, this temple has a statue of a bull, the vehicle of Śiva.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, stone statue with toraṇa above, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: A stone statue of Gaṇeśa with three faces and four arms has been installed inside the sanctum sanctorum of the temple. He is sitting on two tieres of lotus petals and is shown holding a rosary and radish in his right hands and an axe and a sweet ball in his left hands. A brass-clad toraṇa has been installed above the niche.

Object image caption: Sikālī Mandira, Degudyaḥ Shrine, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-14
object short description: The Jyāpu community of Khokanā worship this shrine as their lineage deity.

Object image caption: Sikālī Mandira, Kot; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-29
object short description: The statues of Rudrāyaṇī, Bālakumārī and Bhairava along with the faces of other gods and goddesses are kept in this kot and brought to this temple from the temple of Khokanā.

Object image caption: Sikālī Mandira, Gaṇeśa Shrine, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-04-05
Sikālī Mandira, aniconic stone, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-14
Sikālī Mandira, aniconic stone, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-14
Sikālī Mandira, brass statue of Bhairava; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-29
object short description: This statue is enshrined inside the three-storey temple of Khokanā. On the day of Gāijātrā and the 5th day of the bright fortnight of Asoja, the idols of Rudrāyaṇī and Bālakumārī along with this Bhairava are brought from the temple of Khokanā to this temple. However, the main statues of Rudrāyaṇī and Bālakumārī were stolen in 2018. They have not been replaced, and so now only Bhairava is brought here.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Shrine, Caitya, view from E (November 2019)
object short description: This rounded caitya is located in the courtyard. It has been painted white and sits on a vedī. Four Bodhisattva statues have been placed at each of the four cardinal directions A stone statue of Tārā can be found on the north-eastern corner. Above the two layers of lotus petals one can find four small niches containing Buddha statues. There is no inscription. The structure of this caitya is similar to those from the Malla period.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Shrine, Pulā̃ Cibhāḥ, view from W (November 2019)
object short description: The Pulā̃ Cibhā (lit. an old caitya) is located on the western side of the nani. Locals claim that this caitya is the oldest of the courtyard's three caityas. However, there seems to be no hard evidence to support their claim. The caitya has been painted with white lime. Four Buddha statues are placed in the niches at each of the four cardinal directions. Before the 2015 earthquake the caitya stood alone in an open space. However, after the earthquake people constructed a hut in its vicinity. This has caged the caitya in.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Shrine, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from E (November 2019)
object short description: The Śikharakūṭa Caitya is located at the northern corner of the courtyard. A stone inscription states that it was constructed by Śākyas in 1691. A Buddha statue has been placed inside the eastern niche, while the other three niches remain empty. Some of the stones have become dislocated and many others have gaps between them. Cement plaster has been used to join some of the parts together. The harmikā is slightly bent.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Shrine, Gaṇeśa statue inside the shrine, view from S (November 2019)
object short description: A stone statue of four-handed Gaṇeśa, surmounted by a stone toraṇa. The statue is weathered.

Object image caption: Jati Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07
object short description: The oil-lamp balustrade surrounding the caitya was donated in NS 1117 and the prayer wheels to the west of it were donated in NS 1112.

Object image caption: Jati Bāhāḥ, statue of the donor, view from NE; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07
object short description: The inscription on the back of the statue mentions that the figure is Devasiṃha, the consecrator of the bāhāḥ. There is also another inscription on the pedestal of the statue, however this is illegible. Śākya (VS 2036, 33) writes that the prosperous Devasiṃha also organised a Samyak Mahādāna in NS 767.

Object image caption: Jati Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07
object short description: This image of a four-handed Mahākāla is attached to the northern wall of the main entrance of the bāhāḥ. He is holding khaḍga and kartṛ in his two right hands, and khaṭvāṅga and kapālapātra in his two left hands.

Object image caption: Jati Bāhāḥ, Statue of Acala (Saṅkaṭa), view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-07
object short description: A statue of Acala (Saṅkaṭa) is attached to the northern wall of the entrance. He is holding a sword and a rope.

Object image caption: Bhavānīśaṅkara Mandira, statue of Bhavānīśaṅkara (Umāmaheśvara) in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-07-10

Object name: Bhurtī śikhara temples with pavilion, northern śikhara
Object image caption: Bhurtī śikhara temples with pavilion, northern śikhara, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24

Object name: Bhurtī śikhara temples with pavilion, southern śikhara
Object image caption: Bhurtī śikhara temples with pavilion, southern śikhara, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
Śāntipura Phalcā 2, fire wheel and bull, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-05
Śāntipura Phalcā 2, stone lion, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-05
Śāntipura Phalcā 2, Lokeśvara, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-05
Mahābuddha Mandira, statue of Mahākāla, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-19
object short description: This image of Mahākāla is located on the northern wall of the vihāra. The four-handed Mahākāla holds a khaḍga and kartṛ in his right hands and khaṭvāṅga and kapāla in his left hands. The toraṇa also shows an image of Mahākāla.

Object image caption: Mahābuddha Mandira, Māyādevī Mandira, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-19
object short description: After the earthquake of VS 1990, the remains of the temple were used to make a Śikara-styled terracotta temple to Māyādevī. There is an image of Buddha's mother Māyādevī performing sālabhañjikā inside the sanctum, and a statue of Siddhartha Gautama in front of her. The eastern side contains an image of Akṣobhaya, the southern side contains Achal (Yamari) and the western side has an image of Saraswatī. A dharmadhatu maṇḍala has been established in front of this temple. The temple itself is in good condition.

Object image caption: Mahābuddha Mandira, Hāritī niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-19
object short description: The empty opening/niche is located on the southern wall of the Vihāra. Locals worship it as Hāritī.

Object image caption: Mahābuddha Mandira, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-19
object short description: This Gaṇeśa image is attached to the northern wall of the temple. The six-handed statue is holding a japamālā and a turnip in his right hands, and his third right hand is performing varada mudrā. His left hands hold an axe and a sweet ball whilst one performs abhaya mudrā. The statue is flanked by seven nāgas. The toraṇa also has an image of Gaṇeśa with seven nāgas.

Object image caption: Mahābuddha Mandira, Dharmadhātu with a vajra above, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-19
object short description: The Dharmadhātu is in good condition.

Object image caption: Sunanda Vihāra, statue of Akṣobhya (middle) in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Sunanda Vihāra, statue of Gaṇeśa (inside a wall niche, next to the door to the sanctum), view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Sunanda Vihāra, statue of Mahākāla (inside a wall niche, next to the door to the sanctum), view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Sunanda Vihāra, Nāga (A), view from N; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Sunanda Vihāra, Nāga (B), view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Sunanda Vihāra, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from S; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Sunanda Vihāra, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Sunanda Vihāra, Mañjuśrī Pādukā, view from above; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-20
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Gaṇeśa statue, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-08
object short description: Inside the sanctum, there is a Gaṇeśa statue at the centre and two niches on both sides of the statue. Kīritimukha toraṇa has been added on the outer surface of both niches. Gaṇeśa is sitting in sukhāsana on a stone pedestal, holding an axe and sweet ball with his left hands. One of the right hands is in abhaya posture, and another one is holding a rosary.

Object image caption: Svathanārāyaṇa Mandira, Garuḍa, view from E (December 2018)
object short description: Stone statue of a kneeing Garuḍa in a greeting gesture facing the Svathanārāyaṇa temple, located by two flags donated in VS 1952.

Object image caption: Svathanārāyaṇa Mandira, stone snake, view from S (December 2018)
Svathanārāyaṇa Mandira, shrine, view from S (December 2018)
object short description: Ensemble of five small statues measuring between 13 and 34 cm in height: Viṣṇu, Gopinī, Kṛṣṇa, Gopinī, Viṣṇutrivikrama.At the eastern side, a statue of Gaṇeśa (h 60, w 64) is set in a brick enclosure.

Object image caption: Licchavi caitya, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from S (November 2019)
object short description: Gaṇeśamāna Pāneju from Bungmati and his wives Aṣṭamāyā and Mohanamāyā made this caitya in 1956.

Object image caption: Pilāchẽ Cidhaṃ Bāhāḥ, Pilāchẽ, Mahākāla shrine, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-13
object short description: A south-facing image of Mahākāla has been installed in the northern wall of the Bāhāḥ. Mahākāla stands on top of a corpse, holding kartṛ in his right hand and kapāla in his left hand. Above Mahākāla, one can find a stone toraṇa with an image of a sword in the middle and kartṛ and kapāla on its right and left respectively. An iron fence has been installed to protect the image.

Object image caption: Pilāchẽ Cidhaṃ Bāhāḥ, Pilāchẽ, Viśvakarmā Shrine, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-13
object short description: A small shrine for Viśvakarmā has been constructed on top of a plinth. An uniconic east-facing stone image has been placed in the shrine. The shrine also contains a stone toraṇa displaying an image of Kṣepu. In the middle of the toraṇa, the auspicious syllable oṃ has been engraved in Ranjanā script. Images of the Sun and Moon have been carved to its right and left respectively. The stone pinnacle contains images of bees and is placed on top of the shrine. Viśvakarmā is worshipped here when an auspicious event takes place in the local or neighbouring city quarters.

Object image caption: Pilāchẽ Cidhaṃ Bāhāḥ, Pilāchẽ, Saṅkaṭā Shrine, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-13
object short description: A shrine for Saṅkaṭā can be found in a niche in the northern wall of the Bāhāḥ. Saṅkaṭā is also called Caṇḍamahāroṣaṇa or Acalā. The statue faces south, holding a sword in her right hand and a noose in her left hand. These objects have been worn down and are no longer easily identifiable. A stone toraṇa above Saṅkaṭā contains an image of Kṣepu.

Object image caption: Pilāchẽ Cidhaṃ Bāhāḥ, Caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-13
object short description: There is no inscription on this Caitya. Iron rods have been installed for its protection.

Object image caption: Bhelakhu Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from N (November 2018)
Bhelakhu Bāhāḥ, caitya, view from N (November 2018)
object short description: This caitya has a double lotus no images of Buddhas in its niches.

Object image caption: Bhelakhu Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from W (November 2018)
Bhelakhu Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from E (November 2018)
object short description: The other Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala (# 005) is seen in the background.

Object image caption: Bhelakhu Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from S (November 2018)
object short description: This caitya in śikhara style has 4 Bodhisattvas in the 4 directions, above which are images of 4 Buddhas.

Object image caption: Bhelakhu Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W (November 2018)
Bhelakhu Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya, view from W (November 2018)
Rādhākṛṣṇa Mandira, Brahmanāla, view from NW (July 2019)
object short description: When a person is nearing death, he or she is taken to brahmanāla and his feet are made to touch the water of a river until his last breath. When a person dies, he is taken to ghāṭa for funeral procession.

Object image caption: Rādhākṛṣṇa Mandira, Śeṣaśāyī Viṣṇu, view from SE (July 2019)
object short description: Viṣṇu is depicted in reclining posture on a serpents' bed. He holds cakra in his upper right, gadā in his upper left, padma in his lower right and śaṅkha in his lower hands. His legs are in a crossed legged position and his eyes are half-open in a meditative state.

Object image caption: Rādhākṛṣṇa Mandira, Śivaliṅga C, view from NE ( July 2019)
object short description: A third Śivaliṅga and a Nandī are located at the south-west corner of the temple. The śivaliṅga rests on a stone pedestal. "Buddheśvara'' has been inscribed on its base

Object image caption: Rādhākṛṣṇa Mandira, Garuḍa Stambha, view from S (July 2017)
object short description: Traditionally Garuḍa pillars are erected in front of Vaiṣṇava temples. Usually a stone turtle forms the base of the pillar. The original large stone statue of Garuḍa (as seen in the 1973 photograph in Pruscha's inventory) was stolen in 1983 and later replaced with a much smaller statue of poor quality. Garuḍa greets the temple with the namaskāra gesture.

Object image caption: Rādhākṛṣṇa Mandira, Śivaliṅga B, view from NE (July 2019)
object short description: Two śivaliṅgas are flanking the main axis of the temple in the east. Śivaliṅga B is placed on the left side of the axis towards the south. The supporting pedestal made of brick and cement plaster was built after 2007.

Object image caption: Rādhākṛṣṇa Mandira, Śivaliṅga A, view from NE (July 2019)
object short description: Two śivaliṅgas are flanking the main axis of the temple in the east. Śivaliṅga is placed on the right side of the axis towards the north. The supporting pedestal made of brick and cement plaster was built after 2007.

Object image caption: Yatkhā Bāhāḥ Caitya, Ratnasambhava, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ Caitya, Amitābha, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ Caitya, Amoghasiddhi, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
Yatkhā Bāhāḥ Caitya, Akṣobhya, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12

Yatkhā Bāhāḥ Caitya, Jalamanuṣya, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
