Cīthū Bahī, Statue of Lion (A), view from NE; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-02-23

Cīthū Bahī, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from SW; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-02-20
Cīthū Bahī, statue of Kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ, view from NE; photo by Bharat Maharjan; 2021-03-13
Cīthū Bahī, Statue of Lion (B), view from NE; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-02-23
Cīthū Bahī, Statue of Mahākāla, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-02-23
Cīthū Bahī, statue of Tārā, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-02-20
Cīthū Bahī, statue of Triratna, view from SW; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-02-23
Pacalī Bhairava, Nāsaḥdyaḥ, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-10
Pacalī Bhairava, Bhagavatī, view from S; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-10
Pacalī Bhairava, Pīṭha (South), view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-19
Pacalī Bhairava, Lokeśvara, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-02-13
Pacalī Bhairava, Gaṇeśa, view from S; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
Pacalī Bhairava, statue of Pacalī Bhairava, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
object short description: The circular stone inside the pit is the real Pacalī Bhairava. This stone is believed to be his buttocks. The gilded copper statue ​was established later. He is standing on the Vetāla, holding a sword, a trident, and a bowl in his right hand, and a shield, muṇḍamālā, and vindu mudrā in his left hand.

Object image caption: Pacalī Bhairava, Rudrāyaṇī (right), view from S; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
Pacalī Bhairava, Nāgarājā, view from S; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-10
object short description: Earlier, a twelfth century statue of Nāgarājā, sitting on nāgas, was established here (cf. Bangdel 1995, 173). The present statue is newly installed since the old one was stolen.

Object image caption: Pacalī Bhairava, Vetāla, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
object short description: The stone statue of Vetāla is covered with brass repousse. Vetāla should be worshipped before worshipping Pacalī Bhairava. There is a belief that Pacalī Bhairava ​​can only be pleased if one can please Vetāla.

Object image caption: Pacalī Bhairava, Vārāhī, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
Pacalī Bhairava, Mahālakṣmī, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
Pacalī Bhairava, Dhumbā (Vyāghriṇī), view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
Pacalī Bhairava, Pīṭha (South-east), view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
Pacalī Bhairava, Yajñakuṇḍa (sacrificial pit), view from S; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-25
Pacalī Bhairava, Pīṭha (south-west), view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-19
Pacalī Bhairava, Sarasvatī, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-10
Pacalī Bhairava, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-10
Pacalī Bhairava, Pīṭha (west), view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-19
Pacalī Bhairava, Pīṭha (near the entrance), view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-19
Pacalī Bhairava, Viṣṇu, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-18
Pacalī Bhairava, Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-18

Pacalī Bhairava, Brahmāyaṇī (middle), view from S; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
Pacalī Bhairava, Donors, view from S; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-10
Pacalī Bhairava, Pīṭha (north-east), view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
Pacalī Bhairava, Ajimā, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
object short description: The statue, which is worshiped by the locals as Ajimā, is identified by Bangdel (1995, 172) as a sixth century Yakṣa statue.

Object image caption: Pacalī Bhairava, Nārāyaṇī, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-10
Pacalī Bhairava, Kumāra, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
Pacalī Bhairava, Kumārī, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-11
Pacalī Bhairava, Agnimaṭha, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-01-10
Gvaṅgaḥ Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-13
Gvaṅgaḥ Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 202-10
object short description: Unlike the Dharmadhātu Maṇḍalas found in the Kathmandu Valley, this particular one bears inscriptions on its north-west, south-west, and south-east façades, while the north-east façade left empty. The images of Four Bodhisattvas are carved on its four cardinal directions.

Object image caption: Gvaṅgaḥ Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-13
Gvaṅgaḥ Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-13
Gvaṅgaḥ Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭoparipadma Caitya, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-13
Karuṇācuka Bahī, jaladroṇī, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-16
object short description: The jaladroṇī lies to the west of the śikharakūṭa caitya. There are some letters in Licchavi script on it: the name 'sujātaprabha vihāra' is inscribed on its western face. However, the inscription is not dated

Object image caption: Karuṇācuka Bahī, śikharakūṭa caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-12-16
object short description: The caitya is situated in front of the image of the kvapādyaḥ. There are images of Lokeśvaras on the four sides of the caitya. Below the kumbha one can see images of Buddha on each of the four sides.

Object image caption: Koligāũ Pañcadevala, south-eastern side of the western temple, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-03
object short description: Access to the sanctum is blocked by a stone slab.

Object image caption: Koligāũ Pañcadevala, southern side of the northern temple, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-03
object short description: This temple was probably dismantled and reassembled. The āmalaka ring on top may come from another monument.

Object image caption: Koligāũ Pañcadevala, northern side of the southern temple, view from N; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-03
object short description: This temple is constituted of architectural elements originating from another, larger, śikhara.

Object image caption: Koligāũ Pañcadevala, western side of the central temple, view from SW; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-03
Koligāũ Pañcadevala, south-western side of the eastern temple, view from SW; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-03
object short description: Access to the sanctum is blocked by a stone slab.

Bhavānīśaṅkara Mandira, statue of Bhavānīśaṅkara in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-11
object short description: This statue was installed in 1984 CE after the previous one consecrated during the initial construction of the temple in 1718 CE got stolen (cf. Ś. Śreṣṭha VS 2057,43).

Object image caption: Bhavānīśaṅkara Mandira, nāga, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-11
Bhavānīśaṅkara Mandira, statue of the founders of the Temple, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-11
Bhavānīśaṅkara Mandira, unidentified deity, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-11
Devala Hāṭa Temples, temple 003, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description: View of temple 003 (on the right) and 002 (on the left). The two monuments are almost identical and are built on the same platform.

Object image caption: Devala Hāṭa Temples, temple 002, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17

Object name: Devala Hāṭa Temples, inscribed base of sculpture
Object image caption: Devala Hāṭa Temples, inscribed base of sculpture; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description:
This is the base of a stone sculpture. The upper part is lost.

The inscribed part (in devanāgarī) is framed by two sitted characters, probably the donors.

A tenon is visible in the inferior part, indicating that the image was inserted on a larger pedestal.

Object image caption: Devala Hāṭa Temples, stone Nandi; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description: The image was severely damaged. Very few details are left visible.

Object image caption: Devala Hāṭa Temples, stone Brahmā; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description:
The Hindu god is represented on his swan, with what appears to be six heads.

The image was probably part of a larger composition or of a monument. It remains complicated to provide any dating for this sculpture.

Object name: Devala Hāṭa Temples, stone Durgā Mahiṣāsuramardini
Object image caption: Devala Hāṭa Temples, stone Durgā Mahiṣāsuramardini; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description: The image can be roughly from the 12th-15th century.

Object image caption: Devala Hāṭa Temples, temple 004, view from north-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description: The interior of the temple could not be surveyed at the time of visit.

Object image caption: Devala Hāṭa Temples, stone Gaṇeśa; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description:
The image bears no inscription. It may be roughly dated to the 13th-15th century.

The object is not attached to any particular monument.

Object image caption: Devala Hāṭa Temples, interior of storeroom, view from south-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description:
The storeroom was used to keep the numerous artefacts discovered within the towers of the śikhara temples. The building was dismantled after 2015. 

On the image can be seen swords and metal vessels.

Object image caption: Devala Hāṭa Temples, temple 007, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description: The tower of the temple is missing.

Object image caption: Devala Hāṭa Temples, temple 006, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
Devala Hāṭa Temples, stone Umā Maheśvara; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description: The image is very damaged. It can be roughly dated from the 12th (Sharma 2012: 346) to 15th century.

Object image caption: Devala Hāṭa Temples, temple 001, view from north-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
object short description: The śikhara tower is partially dismantled and the monument's western section is encased in the masonry of the modern storeroom.

Object image caption: Devala Hāṭa Temples, temple 005, view from north-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-17
Dhaugāḥ Bahī, Vajradhātuparī Aśoka Caitya, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-06
object short description: There are the images of the Buddha in the four cardinal directions of the lower part of the caitya. Its upper part is from the Licchvi Period. The caitya is capped with a metal ilā̃.

Object image caption: Dhaugāḥ Bahī, wooden statue of Mahākāla on a niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-06
object short description: The local residents worship this wooden statue as Mahākāla. Since it is badly deteriorated, what he is holding on his hands cannot be identified.

Object image caption: Dhaugāḥ Bahī, statue of Akṣobhya in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-06
object short description: A stone statue of Akṣobhya is enshrined in the sanctum of the bāhī. He faces east and is dressed in metal lhegā. His face is covered with a metal mask. There is a wooden toraṇa behind the statute.

Object image caption: Dhaugāḥ Bahī, statue of Mahākāla on a niche, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-06
Dhaugāḥ Bahī, statue of Hanumān on a niche, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-06
Dhaugāḥ Bahī, Vajra, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-06
Dhaugāḥ Bahī, statue of Tārā on a niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-06
Om Bāhāḥ Nani, mañjuśrī-pādukā, topdown view; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
object short description: An impression of the feet of Mañjuśrī (mañjuśrī-pādukā) has been made besides the Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala.

Object image caption: Om Bāhāḥ Nani, Caitya, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
object short description: This Caitya is located at the centre of the Nani. It stands on a rectangular plinth. One can see the images of standing Bodhisattvas (Maitreya in east, Vajrapāṇi in south, Padmapāni in west and Mañjuśrī in north) in the four cardinal directions. Above the images is a bhaṅgī, and above this are images of Dhyānī Buddhas with toraṇas to each of the four directions. Above these images are two layers of lotus petals, a garbhagṛha, 13 bhuvanas, and the pinnacle. A metal canopy is offered over the Caitya. The caitya is surrounded by oil-balustrade.

Object image caption: Om Bāhāḥ Nani, Dharmadhātu, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
object short description: This octagonal Maṇḍala has images of eight Lokeśvaras in eight directions. It was constructed by Śivadhana Bhāvo together with his wife and sons. There are three prayers wheels on the east and a bell on the south of Maṇḍala.

Object image caption: Kutisaugaḥ Phalcā, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from E (August 2019)
object short description: Gaṇeśa is sitting in the sukhāsana position on top of a lotus pedestal. His upper left hand holds an axe and his second left hand is holding a laḍḍu. One of his right hands is performing abhaya whilst holding a radish and his other right hand is holding akṣamālā.

Object image caption: Kutisaugaḥ Phalcā, statue of Sarasvatī, view from E (August 2019)
object short description: Sarasvatī is sitting in the sukhāsana position on top of lotus pedestal. Her upper right hand holds an akṣamālā whilst her lower left hand holds a book. Her other two hands are holding a vīṇā.

Object image caption: Kutisaugaḥ Phalcā, statue of Bhīmasena, view from E (August 2019)
object short description: This statue is attached to the western wall of the Phalcā.

Object image caption: Taḥgaḥcībhāḥ (caitya), stone statue of Amitābha, located in the caitya's middle register, view from W (December 2019)
Taḥgaḥcībhāḥ (caitya), stone statue of Ratnasambhava, located in the caitya's middle register, view from S (December 2019)
Taḥgaḥcībhāḥ (caitya), stone statue of Akṣobhya (B), located in the caitya's middle register, view from E (December 2019)
Taḥgaḥcībhāḥ (caitya), stone statue of Akṣobhya (A), located in the caitya's lower register, view from E (December 2019)
Taḥgaḥcībhāḥ (caitya), stone statue of Amoghasiddhi, located in the caitya's middle register, view from N (December 2019)
Nhū Bāhāḥ, Nārāyaṇa shrine and Nārāyaṇa statue, view from SE (November 2018)
Nhū Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭoparipadma Caitya, view from N (November 2018)
object short description: This caitya is located in the courtyard behind the Nhū Bāhāḥ. It stands on a one stepped plinth and there are images of various animals at the four corners of the plinth. There are two elephants at the eastern side, and an image of Vajra in the middle. To the south are images of horses, and in the middle is a ratna. To the west, meanwhile, are images of two peacocks with an image of a lotus between them. Above these, and on each of the the four sides of the caitya, there are images of Bodhisatva. Above them are five layers of lotus petals, and there are images of four Tārās in four corners. Above these are two layers of lotus petals, and four images of Buddha in each of the cardinal directions. Above this, in turn, is a harmikā, thirteen bhuvanas, and a pinnacle.

Object image caption: Nhū Bāhāḥ, vajradhātu caitya, view from N (November 2018)
object short description: This caitya is located in the courtyard behind the Nhū Bāhāḥ. It stands on a two-tier plinth. There are four niches at each of the four sides of the caitya, within which images of Buddha can be found. Above these are harmikā, 13 bhuvanas and a pinnacle.

Object image caption: Kularatna Vihāra, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-08
object short description: This octagonal Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala has no images of the Eight Lokeśvaras on any of its eight sides.

Object image caption: Kularatna Vihāra, Khaḍgarāja statue, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-08
object short description: Khaḍgarāja is one of four guardian kings (caturmahārājas). Generally, his images are placed at the four corners of a temple-roof and also in the entrance of a monastery. Here, this image of Khaḍgarāja is placed at the southern side of the sanctum. He is holding a sword in his right hand and a book in his left hand. He kneels with his left leg, so that his left knee is touching the ground whilst the right is slightly raised.

Object image caption: Kularatna Vihāra, Gaṇeśa statue, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-08
object short description: An image of Gaṇeśa is placed at the north side of the sanctum. The four-armed figure is holding a garland and a radish in his two right hands, and an axe and a sweet ball in two left hands. This image also looks as though it is relatively new.

Object image caption: Kularatna Vihāra, Bhīmasena statue, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-08
object short description: A small statue of Bhīmasena is attached to the eastern wall of the main entrance. This statue appears to be relatively new. The figure is holding a club (gadā) in his right hand while performing a gesture of protection (abhayamudrā) with his left.

Object image caption: Nhū Bāhāḥ at Nugaḥ, vajradhātu caitya, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-02-16
object short description: There is no inscription regarding the construction date of this object.

Object image caption: Nhū Bāhāḥ at Nugaḥ, Mahāṅkāla, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-02-16
object short description: The images of Mahākāla, Gaṇeśa and three other small images are attached to the wall to the left of the outer entrance.

Object image caption: Nhū Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-02-16
object short description: There is no inscription regarding the construction date of this object. However, in the photos published by Pruscha (1975, 180) and Locke (1985, 107) this Dharmadhātu is absent, which suggests that it was installed some time after 1985.

Object image caption: Śobhābhagavatī, Caitya, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, statue of Mahākāla, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, bunch of Śivaliṅgas, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, statue of Siṃha (C), view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, bell (C), view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, bell (B), view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, bell (A), view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, stone khaḍga, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, statue of brass Siṃha (B), view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, statue of Śivakāmadeva, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, statue of Sūrya, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, statue of Viṣṇu, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, bell (H), view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, bell (G), view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, bell (F), view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, statue of brass Siṃha (A), view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, main statue (of Mahiṣāsuramardinī) in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, stone statue of Siṃha (A), view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, stone statue of Siṃha (B), view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03

Śobhābhagavatī, bell (E), view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, Śivaliṅga, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, statue of Siṃha (A), view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Śobhābhagavatī, statue of Siṃha (B), view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-03
Gaṇeśa Mandira, bell at the eastern side of the temple, view from E (October 2018)
Gaṇeśa Mandira, aniconic Śivaliṅga stone besides the Gaṇeśa, view from S (October 2018)
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Gaṇeśa stone statue with two toraṇas, view from S (October 2018)
Kṛṣṇa Degaḥ, Garuḍa pillar, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-05-26
object short description: Cp. LAL1341

Object image caption: Maṇikumāra Gaṇeśa, Gaṇeśa image in the sanctum, view from S (May 2019)
Maṇikumāra Gaṇeśa, statues of Viṣṇu and Nṛtyeśvara, view from S (May 2019)
Maṇikumāra Gaṇeśa, statue of Nṛtyeśvara, view from S (May 2019)
Iku Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N (March 2019)
object short description: The octagonal Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala has Bodhisattva statues on each of its eight faces. It has been fenced off with iron rods for protection.

Object image caption: Iku Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from S (March 2019)
object short description: Four Bodhisattva images are kept at the four cardinal directions of the base storey of the caitya, while four Buddhas sit on its upper part. Statues of the donors have been established on the eastern side. A metal canopy (ilā̃) hangs above the caitya.

Object name: Amargaḍhi Śiva Mandira sculptures, statue of a Mother Goddess
Object image caption: Amargaḍhi Śiva Mandira sculptures, statue of a Mother Goddess, view from north; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-29
object short description:
The goddess is sitted on a simplified double lotus base. With the right hand she presents a circular attribute. A child is resting on the deity's folded left leg. The head is broken.

The statue may represent de Buddhist goddess Hārītī.

Object name: Amargaḍhi Śiva Mandira sculptures, statue of Durgā
Object image caption: Amargaḍhi Śiva Mandira sculptures, statue of Durgā, view from north; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-29
object short description:
The upper part of the statue is missing. 

The remaining part shows a standing character standing next to a quadruped. This is most likely a statue of Durgā with a lion or a tiger.

Object name: Amargaḍhi Śiva Mandira sculptures, statue of a four-armed deity
Object image caption: Amargaḍhi Śiva Mandira sculptures, statue of a four-armed deity, view from north; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-29
object short description: Only the two left arms of the deity are left. They are holding a mace or small sword and an unidentified object.

Object image caption: Kvaynā Phalcā, Halāhala Lokeśvara, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Kvaynā Phalcā, Sūrya, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Kvaynā Phalcā, Śrīdhara Viṣṇu, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Kvaynā Phalcā, Varuṇa, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Kvaynā Phalcā, Halāhala Lokeśvara, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Kvaynā Phalcā, group of donors, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Kvaynā Phalcā, Viṣṇu, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Kvaynā Phalcā, Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa, view from S, photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Kvaynā Phalcā, Umāmaheśvara, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-02-07
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Sarasvatī shrine with inscription from NS 1001, view from W (December 2019)
object short description: The statue has deteriorated and the inscription is damaged.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Viśvakarmā, view from W (October 2019)
object short description: This statue of Viśvakarmā has been placed in a small niche of the back wall of the Gaṇeśa temple. This image was brought from the Himal Cement Factory, Chobhar after it closed down.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Lukumahādyaḥ, view from E (December 2019)
object short description: An aniconic stone idol called Lukumahādyaḥ (hiding Mahādeva) is placed in this pit. An iron fence is fixed to its opening. On the 14th day of the dark fortnight of Caitra (Piśāca Caturdaśī), the deity is worshipped with an offering of cooked rice. Michaels (1992, 193) states that ‘on this day, Śiva is supposed to become a demon, ghost or goblin (piśāca), depicted in a small stone, which is kept hidden in ‘unclean’ places such as the neighbourhood garbage dump or the courtyards.'

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, stone statue of Gaṇeśa in the sanctum, view from S (December 2019)
object short description: This four-handed Gaṇeśa is holding a rosary and a radish in his two right hands and an axe and a sweet ball in his left hands. An ilā̃ made from cloth hangs above the statue.

Object image caption: Khaḍācakra Koṭa Durbar, stone pillar, view from N; photo by David Andolfatto; 2014-09-14
object short description:
Stone pillar placed on a small stone platform on the southern side of the durbar. It shows (from bottom to top) images of a trident, an four-footed animal, a person in praying gesture and the sun.

It remains complicated to date this object. The sun on the top seems to be more recently carved than the rest.

Object image caption: Basantapur architectural remains, memorial pillar, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-02
object short description:
The stone memorial pillar is vertically broken. It seems that the southern and northern face of the pillar was covered with inscriptions in Devanāgarī script. The inscriptions are too damaged to allow any reading.

The right side is missing.

Object image caption: Basantapur architectural remains, architectural element, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-02
Basantapur architectural remains, architectural element, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-02
object short description: This element was probably part of a stone fountain.

Object image caption: Basantapur architectural remains, architectural element, view from NE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-02
object short description: This element was probably part of a pavilion or another large monument.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ Phalcā, snake painting (stiched from several images), view from W (July 2019)
Nāga Bāhāḥ Phalcā, Gaṇeśa shrine, attached to Southern side, view from S
Gaṇeśa shrine, attached to the Southern side of Nāga Bāhāḥ Phalcā
object short description: It is unclear whether the shrine has been conceptualised as part of the Nāga Bāhāḥ Phalcā from the beginning or whether they exist independently from each other.

Object image caption: Sum Bāhāḥ, statue of Mañjuśrī, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
Sum Bāhāḥ, statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
Sum Bāhāḥ, statue of Nāmasaṅgīti, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
Sum Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaṅkṛta Caitya, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
object short description: The images of four Bodhisattvas have been kept in the four cardinal directions of this Caitya which is standing on a brick-made platform. This Caitya was built to replace an older caitya inside of which a golden Buddha statue was enshrined.

Object image caption: Sum Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
Sum Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
Sum Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
Sum Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
object short description: The stone statue of Akṣobhya dressed in a metal lhegā is enshrined in the sanctum sanctorum as the Bāhaḥ’s primary deity (kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ). He is flanked by the statues of Sun and a Svayambhū Caitya is installed to his left.

Object image caption: Sum Bāhāḥ, statue of Hanumān, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
Indrāyaṇī Pīṭha Hiti, Waterspout view from NW; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2021-07-22
Indrāyaṇī Pīṭha Hiti, Śivaliṅga, view from W; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2021-07-22
Indrāyaṇī Pīṭha, Viṣṇu srine atop the water spout, view from W; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2021-07-22
Hariśaṅkara Mandira, image of Sūrya, view from N (September 2019)
Hariśaṅkara Mandira, main statue of Hariśaṅkara, view from W (September 2019)
Hariśaṅkara Mandira, mock entrance with image of Gaṇeśa, view from S (September 2019)
Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Sarasvatī on the southeast corner of the courtyard, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: The statue is placed at the southern gate of the garden. Sarasvatī has four arms. She is holding an akṣamālā and a manuscript in two hands and showing varada and abhaya gestures with her other two hands.  L. Bangdel (1995, 213) dates the statue to the 19th century.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Tārā on the Northeast corner of the courtyard, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: The statue is placed at the northern gate of the garden. Tārā is holding a lotus stalk in her left hand and her right hand is in varada gesture.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Aśoka Caitya, view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: Buddha statues are placed in the four directions of this Licchavi Caitya. Akṣobhya is placed in the east and Amitābha is placed in the remaining three directions. The Caitya has only 11 layers in its trio. L. Bangdel (1995, 211) dates the Akṣobhya statue to the 10th century.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Sūrya on the wall, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: Sūrya (the Sun god) is riding in a chariot driven by Aruṇa and drawn by seven horses. Daṇḍī and Piṅgala are at his side. The faces of all the gods have been broken.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Viṣṇu on the wall, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: The statue is damaged. Visnu holds weapons in his four hands, but only the wheel (cakra) in his right hand and the mace (gadā) in the left hand are visible. The other two hands have been broken. L. Bangdel (1995, 213) dates the statue to the 18th century.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statues of donors on the wall, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: As there is no inscription in this statue, the names of the donor couple is unknown.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Umāmaheśvara on the wall, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: The damaged statue has a Śivaliṅga above it. L. Bangdel (1995, 212) dates it to the 17th century.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Sūrya on the wall, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: Sūrya (the Sun god), his driver Aruṇa and attendants Daṇḍī and Piṅgala can be seen in the statue.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Viṣṇu on the wall, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: Viṣṇu is holding a wheel and a lotus in his right hand and a mace and a conch in his left hand. L. Bangdel  (1995, 212) dates the statue to the 10th century.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Nārā̃ Hiti (spout 3), view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: As it is near the temple of Nārāyaṇa in the Hiti precinct, the name of this spout is Nārāṃ Hiti (Nārāyaṇa Hiti). The water of this spout is considered to be the purest.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Amitābha and Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: This statue of Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa is placed on the northern wall of the Hiti. Nārāyaṇa is holding a conch and a lotus in his right hands and a mace and a wheel in his left hands. A statue of Amitābha is placed in front of Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Aśoka Caitya, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: The Caitya rises above the rectangular plinth. The parts above the āmalaka are lost.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Aśoka Caitya, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: Like a Licchavi style caitya, this Caitya has empty niches. The parts above the āmalaka are lost.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Hanumān on the wall, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
Ālko Hiti, Śivaliṅga, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: A Śivaliṅga has been erected at the north-eastern side of the Hiti. The jalahari of the  liṅga faces to the north.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Buddha, Yoginī and Lokeśvara shrine on the wall, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: Stone statues of Akṣobhya, Yoginī and Lokeśvara have been erected to the east of the Hiti. These statues look modern. A cement Caitya has been built over the statue of Buddha.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Vā̃khāḥ Hiti (spout 4), view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: Instead of a crocodile’s mouth shape, this spout has a tiger mouth. As water flows from the mouth of the tiger locals call it Vā̃khāhiti. A jaḥrunhiti has been placed at the bottom of this spout.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Akṣobhya shrine, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: This broken statue was abandoned in Sika Bahī (P-153) and was erected here by Vaidya Dharmadeva in NS 898 BS in the witness of Vishnu Malla (V. Vajrācārya 1980, 9-10). This date does not match with the reign of King Vishnu Malla of Lalitpur (regn. NS 849-865).

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Akṣobhya, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: A statue of Akṣobhya lies to the west of the Aśoka Caitya (LAL0990-016). L. Bangdel (1995, 211) dates this severely damaged object to the 5th century.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Cīdhāḥ Hiti (spout 5), view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: This spout is called Cīdhāḥ Hiti because it is the smallest of the five spouts in Ālko Hiti. A pipe has been fixed on the mouth of the spout.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Nārāyaṇa Mandira, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: A temple of Nārāyaṇa has been erected on top of the conduit basin (hitigāḥ) of the Hiti. As there is no inscription, it is not known when and who made this temple. Korn (2014, 39) calls this temple the Padmapāṇi Temple, built in the 16th century. However, according to the locals, this temple is not of Padmapāṇi but Nārāyaṇa. The new statue of Nārāyaṇa was installed after the theft of the old one. A statue of Nārāyaṇa is attached to the southern wall and Umāmaheśvara is placed on the northern wall.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Aśoka Caitya, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: This Caitya is different from other common caityas. The niches of this Caitya contain a statue of Amitābha to the north, Amoghasiddhi to the east, and two statues of Akṣobhya, one in the southern niche and one in the western one. The parts above the āmalaka are lost.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Aśoka Caitya, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: Two layers of empty niches have been made in the Caitya. The parts above the āmalaka are lost.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Aśoka Caitya, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: This Caitya is different from other common caityas. Maitreya is situated to the north, Amitābha to the east, Akṣobhya to the south and another Akṣobhya has been placed to the west. The upper part of the Caitya is in good condition. Śākya (1097, 92) dates the statue of Maitreya to the 8th century.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Amoghasiddhi and Nārāyaṇa-Lakṣmī, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: This statue of Nārāyaṇal-Lakṣmī has been placed on the northern wall of the Hiti, and is also called Vāsudeva Kamalāja. The eight-armed statue holds a wheel, a conch, a mace, and a lotus in its right hands, and a book, a lotus, a mirror, and a lotus seed in its left hands. 12 statues of Viṣṇu have been placed around it. A statue of Amoghasiddhi covered by seven serpents has been placed in front of the statue.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Ratnasambhava, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: This statue of Ratnasambhava is placed on the northern wall of the Hiti. An artistic toraṇa tops the statue, which also has an artistic pylon. Earlier, a 12th-century statue of Vairocana in Dharmacakra posture that was kept at this niche (Śākya 1097, 63). The new statue was placed here after the loss of the old one.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Dathu Hiti (spout 2), view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: This spout is called Dathuhiti because it is in the middle of two other spouts. A statue of Bhagīratha is placed under the spout. Only some parts of the statue remain.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Taḥdhāḥ Hiti (spout 1), view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: This is called Taḥdhāḥ Hiti as it produces the most water out of the five spouts in Ālko Hiti. A lizard is sculpted on the lid (hitipusā).

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, Śivaliṅga, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: Earlier, the Śivaliṅga was placed in a garden east of Ālko Hiti.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Sūrya on the wall, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: This statue does not show Sūrya being drawn by seven horses. Sūrya and his both attendants are wearing boots on their feet. L. Bangdel  (1995, 212) dates the statue to the 15th century.

Object image caption: Ālko Hiti, stone statue of Viṣṇu on the wall, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-14
object short description: Lord Viṣṇu is covered with seven serpents. His face and hands are broken. He is holding a conch and a lotus in his two right hands and a wheel and a mace in his left hands.

Object image caption: Mahālakṣmī Phalcā, Gaṇeśa, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-20
Mahālakṣmī Phalcā, Sarasvatī, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-20
Mahālakṣmī Phalcā, Viṣṇu, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-20
Mahālakṣmī Phalcā, Hanumāna, view from NW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-20
Mahālakṣmī Phalcā, Jaḥdhuṃhiti, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-20
Mahālakṣmī Phalcā, well and jaḥdhuṃhiti, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-20
Mahālakṣmī Phalcā, shrine with uniconic stones, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-20
object short description: Probably also to prevent the building over the sacred uniconic stones, and to mark the site as a ritual site, a 'modern' frame/shrine has been build from brick/cement and white tiles. It allows for worship to take place, which, as the photograph indicates, still happens.

Object image caption: Patukvā Sataḥ 2, jaḥrũhiti, view from S; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2019-06-21
object short description: A stone jaḥrũhiti is attached to the eastern wall of the Sataḥ. It is no longer in use and contains no inscription.

Object image caption: Kimugāũ Temples, temple 002, view from north-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-26
Kimugāũ Temples, temple 003, view from south-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-26
Kimugāũ Temples, temple 005, view from north-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-26
Kimugāũ Temples, temple 006, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-26
Kimugāũ Temples, temple 007, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-26
Kimugāũ Temples, temple 001, view from south-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-26
Kimugāũ Temples, temple 004, view from south-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-26
Nāsaḥ Capāḥ, Dharmadhātu, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-30
Nāsaḥ Capāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-30
Nāsaḥ Capāḥ, statue of Rādhākṛṣṇa, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-22
Nāsaḥ Capāḥ, statue of Viṣṇu, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-22

Bhailaḥsĩ Bāhāḥ, an aniconic stone worshipped as Gaṇeśa, view from S (September 2019)
object short description: This aniconic stone image of Gaṇeśa is attached to the wall of a private house at the north-eastern corner of the bāhāḥ.

Object image caption: Bhailaḥsĩ Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from W (September 2019)
object short description: Vajrācārya (1993,132) assumes that this Caitya was established before the Bāhāḥ itself.

Object image caption: Bhailaḥsĩ Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from E (September 2019)
object short description: Eight Bodhisattvas have been placed on the eight faces of the maṇḍala. It was established in NS 1026 together with the bāhāḥ.

Object image caption: Viśvakarmā Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya in the sanctum, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-17
Viśvakarmā Bāhāḥ, lion (A) at the eastern side of the staircase, view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-17
Viśvakarmā Bāhāḥ, lion (B) at the western side of the staircase, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-17
Viśvakarmā Bāhāḥ, caitya at the middle of the courtyard, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-17
Viśvakarmā Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla at the wall niche of the private house, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-17
Viśvakarmā Bāhāḥ, statue of Hanumān at the southwest wall, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-17
Dathu Bāhāḥ at Pilāchẽ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-04
object short description: There is a Dharmadhātu Maṇdala in the courtyard of the Bāhāḥ. It was installed in NS 1003.

Object image caption: Dathu Bāhāḥ at Pilāchẽ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-04
object short description: There is a Śikharakūṭa Caitya inside the Bāhāḥ's courtyard. Images of the Four Bodhisattvas have been installed on the Caitya's four faces. The Bodhisattva at the western side is in association of his śakti. According to local inhabitants, the images of the Bodhisattvas were installed much later than the Caitya. There is no inscription to provide information about the installation of the caitya. However, Homarāja Vajrācārya, the priest of the Bāhāḥ, informed us that Nandarāja Vajrācārya established this Caitya some decades ago.

Object image caption: Phaṭṭeśvara Mahādeva Mandira, Śiva Liṇga, view from SW; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-09-02
Phaṭṭeśvara Mahādeva Mandira, Nandi, view from SW; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-09-02
Tashi Gomang Stupa, Vaiśravaṇa/Kubera in the central niche, view from N; photo by David Andolfatto; 2013
Tashi Gomang Stupa, Virūpākṣa in the central niche, view from W; photo by David Andolfatto; 2013
Tashi Gomang Stupa, Virūdhaka in the central niche, view from S; photo by David Andolfatto; 2013
Tashi Gomang Stupa, charred wooden beams; photo by David Andolfatto; 2016-09-16
object short description:
The central square of the mandala at level A was marked by five charred beams made of the tropical hardwood shorea robusta. The beams were found parallel to each other in an east–west direction, sandwiched between tsha-tshas  and covered by sand and charcoal. All beams were severely burnt and beam no. 2 exhibited traces of carvings evoking volute patterns of a pillar’s base. Due to the extreme deterioration of the objects it is difficult to ascertain if the beams were cut. The fact that the beams were severely burnt suggests that they were part of a cremation ritual (homa). 

Beam No. 1: 160 x Ø 8 cm

Beam No. 2: 160 x 10,5 x 10 cm

Beam No. 3: 70 x 10 x 8 cm

Beam No. 4: 140 x 10 x 8 cm

Beam No. 5: 48 x Ø 2 cm

Beam No. 6: 145 x 12 x 10 cm

Object image caption: Tashi Gomang Stupa, inscribed copper reliquary; photo by David Andolfatto; 2016-09-18
Tashi Gomang Stupa, Dhṛtarāṣṭa in the central niche, view from E; photo by David Andolfatto; 2013
Kisi Cuka Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya, view from E (January 2020)
object short description: A new metal statue of Akṣobhya was enshrined in the sanctum after the previous one was stolen.

Object image caption: Kisi Cuka Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S (January 2020)
object short description: Eight Bodhisattva images are placed in the eight faces of this octagonal Dharmadhātu.

Object image caption: Kisi Cuka Bāhāḥ, Khadiravatī Tārā view from N (January 2020)
object short description: This statue of Khadiravatī Tārā can be found to the north of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala (LAL0490-009). The statue's right hand performs varada (blessing) gesture whilst her left hand holds a lotus stalk. Lokapati and Hirāmāyā Vajrācārya installed this statue in memory of their daughter Someśvarī.

Object image caption: Kisi Cuka Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S (January 2020)
object short description: This Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala has vajras (thunderbolts) on each of its eight corners.

Object image caption: Kisi Cuka Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla, view from E (January 2020)
Kisi Cuka Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa, view from E (January 2020)
Kisi Cuka Bāhāḥ, Hanumān, view from E (January 2020)
Kisi Cuka Bāhāḥ, Āryatārā, view from E (January 2020)
object short description: This statue of Āryatārā is located to the east of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala (LAL0490-011). The four-headed Tārā has eight hands. She holds an arrow and a vajra in her two right hands. Her third right-hand is performing a varada (blessing) gesture, whilst the weapon she holds in her fourth hand could not be identified. In her left hands, she holds a lotus flower, a bow and a noose, but the weapon in her fourth hand could also not be identified.

Object image caption: Kisi Cuka Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from SE (January 2020)
object short description: Four Bodhisattva images have been placed on a throne which sits upon the opening lotus blossoms and two layers of petals. Four Buddhas are placed on the upper part of the caitya. The harmikā and garbha parts are disjointed. A fire altar can be found to the south of the caitya.

Object image caption: Kisi Cuka Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: Eight Bodhisattva images are placed on its eight faces.

Object image caption: Kisi Cuka Bāhāḥ, Hanumān, view from S (January 2020)
Kisi Cuka Bāhāḥ, Sarasvatī, view from E (January 2020)
object short description: A four-armed Sarasvatī holds a rosary in her upper right hand, a book in her lower left hand, and a vīṇā with her remaining two hands.

Object image caption: Nārāyaṇa Mandira, two Nārāyaṇa statues in the sanctum; photo by Manik Bajracharya; ca. 2005; courtesy of Manik Bajracharya; free access - no reuse
Nārāyaṇa Mandira, Garuḍa statue in the eastern turret, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-10-12
Nārāyaṇa Mandira, Garuḍa statue in western turret, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-10-12
Pinchẽ Gaṇeśa Mandira, bell at the southwest corner of the Temple, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-26
Pinchẽ Gaṇeśa Mandira, shrew at the top of the pillar, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-26
Pinchẽ Gaṇeśa Mandira, guardian lion (B) at the southern side of the entrance, view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-26
Pinchẽ Gaṇeśa Mandira, guardian lion (A) at the northern side of the entrance, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-06-26

Nārāyaṇa Mandira at Cāka Bāhāḥ, full view of Garuḍa pillar from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-02-05
object short description: This pillar was built in 2012. Garuḍa sits on top of the pillar and is praying to Śrīdhara Viṣṇu, the main deity inside the temple.

Object image caption: Mū Bāhāḥ, digichẽ, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-14
object short description: The three-storey digichẽ.is located to the south of the Bāhāḥ's main shrine. Its carved door is flanked by two small windows. An image of Dīpaṅkara is stored in the ground floor of the house and is exhibited on the day of Ilhane Samyak. The first floor of the house contains a pāsukā jhyāla which is flanked by two small windows. Zinc sheets act as the roof. After the 2015 earthquake, the house was damaged and has since been supported by extra wooden pillars. Generally, the thapāḥāḥju lives in the digichẽ of a bāhāḥ. However, this house is currently too dilapidated for anybody to live in it.

Object image caption: Mū Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu caitya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-14
object short description: This cement-plastered caitya is located to the east of the vajradhātu caitya and was constructed in VS 2031 (CE 1974). It does not follow the classical structure of a caitya. Inside the niches of the upper stories are images of Buddha in the four cardinal directions. Instead of Ratnasaṃbhava, Akṣobhya has been placed in the southern niche.

Object image caption: Mū Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-14
object short description: This cement-plastered caitya stands on a rectangular plinth made of bricks. Images of Buddha have been placed on its four faces. In front of the caitya one can find a fire altar and a mandaḥpā.

Object image caption: Triliṅgeśvara Temple, shrine of Viṣṇu, view from W (November 2018)
object short description: This shrine is located to the north east of the main temple. In the niche is an image of a four-armed Viṣṇu and a toraṇa.

Object image caption: Triliṅgeśvara Temple, sacrificial platform (yajñavedi), view from S (November 2018)
object short description: The yajñavedi is located between the Bhairava and Bhairavī shrine.

Object image caption: Triliṅgeśvara Temple, Bhairavī shrine, view from S (November 2018)
object short description: A Bhairavī Pīṭha is located to the south of the Bhairava shrine. A chatramukha has been carved on the upper parts of the stones. Some of their lower parts are submerged in the ground.

Object image caption: Triliṅgeśvara Temple, well, view from E (November 2018)
object short description: This well (183 cm in diameter) is located to the north of the main temple. The upper part of the well is made of stone. In the capstone of the eastern side of the well one can find an image of Viṣṇu sleeping on a bed of Nāgas with Laksmī sitting below at his feet.

Object image caption: Triliṅgeśvara Temple, Nandī, view from E (November 2018)
object short description: According to local information, the statue facing the temple was installed fairly recently (writing in 2018) after the first one was stolen.

Object image caption: Triliṅgeśvara Temple, shrine with Bhairava, view from S (November 2018)
object short description: This shrine is attached to the southern plinth of the temple. There are three stones, parts of which are underground. The upper parts of the stones display a carved chatramukha. There were once two stone images of lions, one on either side of the shrine. Now, only one is to be seen there, though another has been placed inside the sanctum of the main temple.

Object image caption: Triliṅgeśvara Temple, Śivalinga, view from S (November 2018)
object short description: Some decades earlier (writing in 2018), this śivaliṅga was found in the field to the south of Bāhālukhā during the construction of a private house. This śivaliṅga is not preserved in its complete form as the original liṅga has been lost. It has been placed at the northern side of the temple near the well.

Object image caption: Triliṅgeśvara Temple, stome pit, view from S (November 2018)
object short description: This stone pot was perhaps used as a yajñaśāla or to feed cows. Now, it has been placed so that it is attached the northern plinth of the main temple.

Object image caption: Puncali Sataḥ, statue of donor couple, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-17
Puncali Sataḥ, aniconic Bhairava shrine, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-17
Ṭīkā Bhairava at Bhelachẽ, Ajimā, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-12-23
object short description: Towards the north of the temple is an aniconic stone which is worshipped as Ajimā.

Object image caption: Ṭīkā Bhairava at Bhelachẽ, Nandī, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-12-23
object short description: There is a small stone statue of Basāhā in front of the temple just below the the bell. The image has worn away.

Object image caption: Ṭīkā Bhairava at Bhelachẽ, Jahrũhiṭi, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-12-23
Ṭīkā Bhairava at Bhelachẽ, bell, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-12-23
object short description: According to an inscription, the bell in front of the temple was donated by Lāla, Dayālakṣmī and their family. Previously, a bell installed by Ayana Siṃha hung in the same place.

Object image caption: Jhatāpvaḥ Lalitāpurī Sataḥ, painting of a human face, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-02
Jhatāpvaḥ Lalitāpurī Sataḥ, Lalita stambha (stone slab), view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-02

Ratneśvara Mahādeva, a Brahmin priest worships the liṅga, view from W; photo by Niels Gutschow; 2009-11-05; courtesy of Niels Gutschow; free access – no reuse; source: Niels Gutschow, Architecture of the Newars, 2011, vol. 1, p. 256
Lekhagāũ Pillars, pillar 001, view from north; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-22
object short description: Detail of the base of the pillar, showing a motif with a triangular topping (a religious monument?)

Object image caption: Lekhagāũ Pillars, pillar 002, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-22
Bhām Bāḍā Devaldhārā, śikhara temple, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description: The temple is oriented to the south-east. It is set on a platform directly on top of the fountain.

Object image caption: Bhām Bāḍā Devaldhārā, memorial pillar, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description:
The upper part of the pillar is broken. The shape of the pillar is unique for the region.

Potentially much higher at the origin, it evokes some pillars found in the Jumla district.

Object image caption: Bhām Bāḍā Devaldhārā, fountain, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-07
object short description: The side platforms of the fountain have been dismantled.

object short description:
This miniature śikhara-style temple used to stand to the north of Chusyā Bāhāḥ. In 1970 CE, probably due to the widening of the road, the temple was relocated to the Bāhāḥ courtyard .

Sources:

Gutschow, Niels. Architecture of the Newars: A History of Building Typologies and Details in Nepal. 3 vols. Chicago: Serindia Publications, 2011, p. 738.

Gutschow, Niels. The Nepalese Caitya. Stuttgart/London: Edition Axel Menges, 1997, p. 317.

Bhājudhana Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya, view from E (May 2019)
Bhājudhana Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from S (May 2019)
object short description: The Nāga (snake) surrounding the Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala and the upper part is clad in brass. There is no inscription here but an inscription dated NS 1029 mentions that the temple of Akṣobhya and this Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala were built at the same time.

Object image caption: Bhājudhana Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from N (May 2019)
object short description:
These statues are attached to a wall to the south of the god house. Three prayer wheels have also been fixed on top of the sculptures.

1. Mahākāla is standing on a corpse holding a kartṛ and kapāla, and clasping a khatvāṅga.

2. A four-handed Mañjuśrī is sitting on two lions. He is holding a sword, the Prajñāpāramitā scripture, a bow, and an arrow in his hands.

3. A seated Gaṇeśa is holding a garland and a radish in his hands.

Object image caption: Yatālibi Caitya, Oku Bāhāḥ, Vasukī Nāga, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
Yatālibi Caitya, Oku Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala with vajra, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-04-16
Chāya Bāhāḥ Bhindyaḥ, Draupadī, view from W; photo by Nahib Kafle; 2020-03-14
object short description: There are three holes inside the sanctum. The middle one is called Draupadī and is topped with a wooden toraṇa.

Object image caption: Chāya Bāhāḥ Bhindyaḥ, Bhīmasena, view from W; photo by Nahib Kafle; 2020-03-14
object short description: There are three holes inside the sanctum. The southernmost hole is called Bhīmasena and is topped with a wooden toraṇa.

Object image caption: Chāya Bāhāḥ Bhindyaḥ, Gaṇeśa, view from S; photo by Nahib Kafle; 2020-03-14
object short description: A four-armed statue of Gaṇeśa has been erected on the northern wall of the temple. Nānīmayā Maharjana's family installed the statue in memory of Āśālāla.

Object image caption: Chāya Bāhāḥ Bhindyaḥ, Cāmuṇḍā, view from S; photo by Nahib Kafle; 2020-03-14
object short description: A statue of Cāmuṇḍā has been erected on the northern wall of the temple. Cāmuṇḍā has eight arms and she is sitting on two corpses. She carries a sword and noose are visible in two of her right hands and a shield in one of her left hands. It is not clear what the weapons in her other hands are.

Object image caption: Chāya Bāhāḥ Bhindyaḥ, Vārāhī, view from S; photo by Nahib Kafle; 2020-03-14
object short description: This statue of Vārāhī is located on the northern wall of the temple. Vārāhī has four arms and is resting her right foot on the bull. She holds a sword and a kapālapātra (skull bowl) in her right hands and a shield in her left hand. Her last hand is performing a gesture of vitarka. Nhuchelāla and Manamāyā Maharjana commissioned this statue.

Object image caption: Chāya Bāhāḥ Bhindyaḥ, Bhairava, view from S; photo by Nahib Kafle; 2020-03-14
object short description: A four-armed statue of Bhairava has been erected on the northern wall of the temple. Bhairava is holding a sword and a kapālapātra (skull bowl) in his right hands, while his left hand is holding a shield. His last hand is performing abhaya. The statue was commissioned by Nandalāla and his wife Maiyā Maharjana.

Object image caption: Chāya Bāhāḥ Bhindyaḥ, Hiḍimbā, view from W; photo by Nahib Kafle; 2020-03-14
object short description: There are three holes inside the sanctum. The northern one is called Hiḍimbā and is topped with a wooden toraṇa.

Object image caption: Chāya Bāhāḥ Bhindyaḥ, Kṣetrapāla, view from S; photo by Nahib Kafle; 2020-03-14
object short description: An aniconic stone in front of the temple is worshipped by locals as Kṣetrapāla (the protector of the area). A few years ago, local people built a small tiled temple for the deity.

Object image caption: Chāya Bāhāḥ Bhindyaḥ, Vasundharā, view from S; photo by Nahib Kafle; 2020-03-14
object short description: Chirikājī Maharjana and his family commissioned a statue of Vasundharā to be erected on the northern wall of the temple.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Gaṇeśa statue located in the turret above the main entrance, view from S (October 2018)
object short description: This is a recent image of Gaṇeśa. The central stone of the toraṇa above is missing but the makaras of the two sides are intact.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, four-armed Gaṇeśa in the sanctum, view from S (October 2018)
Yanamugaḥ Capāḥ 2, stone statue of Gaṇeśa, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-06
Yanamugaḥ Capāḥ 2, Nāsaḥdyaḥ shrine in the first floor, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-06
object short description: There is a shrine of Nāsaḥdyaḥ on the northern wall of the building’s upper floor. Three holes are covered with a cloth decorated with images of two eyes and a trident. Whenever an art performance or training takes place in the locality, the essence of the Nāsaḥdyaḥ is taken to the location and worshipped before the event begins.

Object image caption: Yanamugaḥ Capāḥ 2, yaḥsĩ, view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-06
object short description: Pālisa Guṭhī erects a yaḥsĩ in front of the Capāḥ from Katipunhī (full moon day of Asoja) to Sakimanāpunhī (full moon day of Kārttika). An oil lamp is lit on the yaḥsĩ every evening. The oil-lamp is called ālaḥmata cyākegu.

Yanamugaḥ Capāḥ 2, aniconic stone worshiped as Gaṇeśa, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-06

Pañcadevala Pañcadevala, northern śikhara, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-26
Pañcadevala Pañcadevala, central śikhara, view from south-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-26
object short description: A large tree and ferns are growing through the masonry.

Object image caption: Pañcadevala Pañcadevala, southern śikhara, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-26
object short description: The top slab was moved and a stone block is missing from the western façade.

Object image caption: Pañcadevala Pañcadevala, eastern śikhara, view from north; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-26
Tāha Phalcā, yaḥsĩ (ceremonial wooden pole), view from NW (November 2019)
object short description: The yaḥsĩ (a ceremonial flag pole) is stored on the Phalcā wall above a door. The pole is erected on the full moon day of Āśvina so that it may be worshipped for a month. It is taken down on the next full moon day of Kārttika (Sakimanā Punhi).

Sarasvatī Nani, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-01-06
Sarasvatī Nani, Manjuśrī, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-01-06
Sarasvatī Nani, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-01-06
Hona Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-09
object short description: Image of Mahākāla standing on a corpse holding karṭri (chopper) and Kapāpā (skull bowl). The statue is located on the west side of the sanctum.

Object image caption: Hona Bāhāḥ, Mañjuvajra statue, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-09
object short description: The statue of Mañjuvajra is attached to the western wall of the phalcā. Mañjuvajra, a form of Mañjuśrī, has six arms. One of his right hand is in varada gesture and the two others are holding a sword and an arrow. His left three hands hold a Prajñāpāramitā book, a lotus and a bow.

Object image caption: Hona Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-09
object short description: Statue of Gaṇeśa standing on a rat with four arms, holding a garland and a radish in his right hands and an axe and sweet ball in his left hands. This statue is located on the east side of the sanctum.

Object image caption: Hona Bāhāḥ, Pañcāvaliyukta Caitya, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-03-09
object short description: This caitya has five layers of lotus, water, gem, fire and vajra. There are two inscriptions on the vedi of the caitya. The inscription on the western side mentions that this caitya was established in NS 1015 on Jestha 10. Names of the deceased are carved into the southern side: Kisna Suṃdha, Subhalakṣmi, Kisnabira and Lami. The following names are carved into the eastern side: Jagabira, Saptalakṣmi, Ludrabira and Camerakṣmi. On the northern side, one can read these names: Lal, Bhagatabi, Kisnalala, Pūchimi, Sobhāthakū and Vīsnumāyā.

Object image caption: Keśavanārāyaṇa Coka, the courtyard with Keśavanārāyaṇa temple, view from NE (photo by Tuomo Manninen, 1995)
object short description:
West-facomg dome-style Keśavanārāyaṇa temple stands in the middle of the square-shaped courtyard. The name of the courtyard is given after the name of the temple. Gutschow (2011, 207) assumes that the temple was made by the Mahāpātras of Lalitpur incorporating two Licchavi columns. Statues of Nārāyaṇa, Lakṣmī and Garuḍa are standing in the sanctum of the temple. Similar statue of other temples of the valley are called Śrīdhara Viṣṇu. Beside these, there are images of Kṛṣṇa and his two wives.

The Narayan Temple is in a poor state of repair with edge stones and terracotta features missing.

Object image caption: Ilachen Phalcā 2, statue of Mahākāla, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-29
Ilachen Phalcā 2, aniconic statue of Gaṇeśa, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-12-29
Cvalcā Phalcā, inscription from NS 785; photo by Christiane Brosius; 2019-02-18
object short description: This inscription from NS 785 is attached on the eastern wall of the Phalcā. According to the inscription, the Phalcā was constructed with three bays. The mentioning of three bays indicates that there probably was an earlier Phalcā with two bays which made the expansion to a third one possible. On top of the inscription is a statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara. She stands in the tribhaṅga āsana with two hands, holding a flower of lotus in her left hand and keeping the right hand in the varad posture. On right and left sides of Lokeśvara are shapes of candra (moon) and sūrya (sun).

object short description: Although it is called Jalaharī Lokeśvara, he does not stand on a jalaharī. The jalaharī may have been removed during a renovation.

object short description: The pillar is half-buried.

object short description: This statue was erected to the north of the sanctum's entrance. A four-handed Narasiṃha is shown killing Hiraṇyakaśipu and holding a wheel and mace in his two hands.

Object image caption: Kṛṣṇa Mandira, statue of Kṛṣṇa with Rukmiṇī and Satyabhāmā, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Statues of Kṛṣṇa, Satyabhāmā and Rukmiṇī have been installed inside the sanctum sanctorum of the temple. Kṛṣṇa is covered with five metal snakes. The original statue of the temple was stolen around 1986. Afterward, locals installed these new statues.

Object image caption: Kṛṣṇa Mandira, stone statue of Garuḍa, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
Kṛṣṇa Mandira, stone statue of Jagannātha, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Jagannātha is shown holding a flower in his right hand and a conch in his left hand. Subhadra stands in a praying posture in the middle and Balarāma stands to the right of Subhadrā, holding a club in his right hand and a plough in his left hand.

Object image caption: Kṛṣṇa Mandira, stone statue of Bhagavatī, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Standing atop two lions, Bhagavatī is shown holding a sword and a trident in her upper hands and performing gestures of varada and abhaya with her lower hands.

Object image caption: Kṛṣṇa Mandira, stone statue of Śiva, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Śiva is wearing a garland of heads and holding a trident and mātuluṅga in his left hands and an akṣamālā in one of his right hands. He is also performing a gesture of vitarka.

Object image caption: Kṛṣṇa Mandira, śivaliṅga, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-07-05
object short description: Earlier, this śivaliṅga was established on the side of the road. It was relocated to its present location as it was inconvenient for passers-by.

object short description: Sūrya (the Sun god) is shown riding in a chariot driven by Aruṇa and drawn by seven horses. Daṇḍī and Piṅgala are at his side.

Object image caption: Jhatāpvaḥ Phalcā, four aniconic stones worshiped by locals as Pīgaṃdyaḥ, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-05-31
object short description: The local residents worship these four aniconic stones placed in the north-east corner of the Phalcā as their mother goddesses. They worship the goddesses before beginning any ritual performance.
