Iche Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇdala, view from W (May 2019)
object short description: A vajra donated in VS 2075 has been placed on top of the dharmadhātu maṇdala. In front (and to the south), one can find a maṇḍala showing nine planets.

Object image caption: Iche Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa caitya, view from S (May 2019)
Subāhāḥ Phalcā 3, well, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-09-16
Vana Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Manḍala, view from S (January 2019)
object short description: This octagonal Maṇḍala has images of eight Lokeśvaras in eight directions. It is also surounded by an oil lamp balustrade. It has no inscription.

Object image caption: Vana Bāhāḥ, Bāhāḥcā (small monastery), view from S (January 2019)
object short description: To the east of the Vihāra one can find a residential house whose ground floor houses a sanctum (kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ). It is called a small bāhāḥ by local inhabitants. In NS 748, Dau Jittapāla established this Bāhāḥ and enshrined a golden image of Śākyamuni Buddha within it. However, this image was stolen and so in NS 884 another image, this time made of stone, was enshrined. Above the entrance of the temple one can see a wooden toraṇa with an image of Mahāvairocana in its centre. This was donated in NS 858. This old monument was heavily damaged by the 2015 earthquake. The southern part of the temple has collapsed, and the frontal facade is supported by wood.

Object image caption: Vana Bāhāḥ, Śikharokūṭotpannajinālaya Caitya, view from SW (January 2019)
object short description: On top of this Caitya one can find an image of Buddha. Because of this, it was named Śikharokūṭotpannajinālaya Caitya. On the lower part of the Caitya one can find images of four Bodhisattvas. Above them are images of four Buddhas. An iron fence has been fixed around it for its protection.

Object image caption: Vana Bāhāḥ, Pañcāvaliyukta Caitya, view from N (January 2019)
object short description: This Caitya is located behind a small temple which stands in the middle of the Bāhāḥ. There are five layers of lotus, water, gems, vajra, and fire and above the layers is the garbha of the Caitya. An iron fence has been installed for its protection.

Object image caption: Vana Bāhāḥ, Degaḥcā (small temple), view from SW (January 2019)
object short description: At the centre of the Bāhāḥ courtyard is a single-tiered temple with a Caitya inside it. Attached to the entrance of the temple one can find a phalcā that is generally used to recite Nāmasaṅgīti . A bell-shaped pinnacle is fixed on the top of its roof. Before the 1934 earthquake, the temple was two-tiered. Later, it was reconscructed in its present shape. The 16 struts containing images of Bodhisattva are fixed, with 8 supporting the northern roof and 8 supporting the southern roof of the temple. The shrine is slightly damaged and the walls are cracked.

Object image caption: Vana Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from N (January 2019)
object short description: This Caitya is situated behind the Vana Bāhāḥ. It stands on a rectangular plinth. Above this are four small niches in the four cardinal directions in which Bodhisattva images have been established on a vedikā. Above the vedikā are two layers of lotus petals, the garbhagṛha, harmikā 13 bhuvanas, a pinnacle and the chatra.

Object image caption: Vana Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from W (January 2019)
object short description: This Caitya is located to the south of the Bāhāḥ. The Caitya stands on a vedi and images of Four Lokeśvaras have been placed on the four faces of the Caitya. Above the images is a bhagiṃ and images of Four Dhyānī Buddhas have been placed on it alongside toraṇas. Above these images are two layers of lotus petals, garbhagṛha, harmikā, 13 bhuvanas, a pinnacle and a parasol. An iron fence surrounds the Caitya for its protection.

Object image caption: Vana Bāhāḥ, well, view from S (January 2019)
object short description: Due to a long-standing custom, the water of this well has to be used for the ritual worship of the main deity of this Bāhāḥ.

Object image caption: Naudvã Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya, view from NW; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-04
object short description: Akṣobhya carries a metal crown. There is a metal prabhamaṇḍala behind him. There are also small  statues of Akṣobhya, Prajñāpāramitā, and Lokeśvara right in front of the main Akṣobhya statue.

Object image caption: Naudvã Bāhāḥ, Hanumān, view from SE; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-04
Naudvã Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla, view from SE; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-04
Naudvã Bāhāḥ, Sarasvatī, view from SW; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-04
Naudvã Bāhāḥ, the statue of Akṣobhya on the wall of a private house, view from NE; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-04
Naudvã Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-04
object short description: Kājīmāna, Āśāmāyā, and others jointly constructed the Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala at the Bāhāḥ courtyard. Metal monkeys, holding jackfruits on their both hands, are placed to the south-east and north-east of the Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala.

Object image caption: Naudvã Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from NW; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-04
object short description: Traditionally, images of the Buddhas or Bodhisattvas are placed in four cardinal directions on the base of a caitya. However,  all four directions are left empty in this Caitya. Further, it is capped with a metal umbrella.

Object image caption: Baku Nani, Caitya, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-04-04
object short description: The residents of Baku Nani also call this caitya Aśoka Caitya and Dhaval Caitya.

Object image caption: Buĩcā Hiti, water conduit, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-03-21
Buĩcā Hiti, Jaḥrũhiti, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-03-21
Buĩcā Hiti, Varuṇa, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-03-21
Buĩcā Hiti, Bhagīratha, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-03-21
Gaṇeśa Mandira, Bhairava statue, view from N (September 2019)
object short description: There are two doors to enter the temple. The stone statue of Bhairava can be seen directly from the rear door of the temple. This six-handed Bhairava is standing in a pratyālīḍha posture. His upper right hand holds a khaḍga whilst the other two hands hold a ḍamaru and kartikā. He holds kheṭaka in his upper left hand and khaṭvāṅga in his upper right hand. The lower left hand is performing a sūrya gesture. The statue is 33 cm in width and 44 cm in height.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Bāgaḥtũ (half circled well), view from E (September 2019)

Śrīdhara Mandira, the additional statue of Viṣṇu (see object number KIR0064-001 above) enshrined to the left of the main Śrīdharaviṣṇu statue in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-02
Śrīdhara Mandira, statue of Śrīdharaviṣṇu in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-11-02
Aśoka Stūpa North, vajradhātu caitya with Buddha statues in the niches, view from E (December 2018)
object short description: As is typical of such caitya, images of four Buddhas are placed inside the niches and garbha is made. No eyes or urṇā have been drawn in the harmikā. Only 9 bhuvanas have been made above the harmikā, which provides evidence for the argument that this caitya is more archaic. On the northern plinth of the caitya is an image of a standing Buddha which is severely worn down. Bangdel (1995, 288) has dated this image back to the 5th century. Next to the image to the south there is a stone which appears to be a faded stone inscription. On the western plinth of the caitya is an image of Vairocana and at the northern plinth is an image of Amitābha, both severly eroded. At the northeast corner of the caitya is a bell that was donated in NS 1119.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, Sarasvatī shrine, view from E (December 2018)
object short description: This shrine seems quite new. The statue inside the shrine is in a standing posture and has four hands. The right hand holds a rosary of beeds, while the left hand holds a book. The remaining two hands hold vīnā.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, Buddha Statue in vajradhātu caitya, view from W (December 2018)
object short description: There is an empty niche at the eastern plinth. Similarly, there is a small hole at the southern plinth and an image of Vairocana at the western plinth. This is severely worn down.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, vajradhātu caitya, view from E (December 2018)
object short description: As is typical of vajradhātu caitya, images of four Buddhas are placed inside the niches, and garbha, harmikā and 13 bhuvanas are present. A metal ilā̃ is placed on top of the caitya.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, Tārā shrine, view from SW (December 2018)
object short description: Inside the south-western niche of the stūpa is a stone image of Tārā sitting in the vajrāsana.  She is holding a gem with her right arm and lotus stalk with her left arm.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, Amitābha statue, view from W (December 2018)
Aśoka Stūpa North, Tārā shrine, view from NE (December 2018)
object short description: Inside the north-eastern niche of the stūpa is a stone image of Tārā sitting in the vajrāsana. She is holding a gem with her right arm and lotus stalk with her left arm.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from E (December 2018)
object short description: To the north of the stūpa is a dharmadhātu maṇḍala with images of Eight Bodhisattvas in eight faces and a vajra on top. In NS 1059, Vajrācārya Siddhivajra established this dharmadhātu. To the east of the dharmadhātu are three mandaḥpāḥs and one fire altar.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, vajradhātu caitya, view from N (December 2018)
object short description: As is typical to vajradhātu caitya, images of four Buddhas are placed inside the niches, and garbha, harmikā and 13 bhuvanas are present. On top of the caitya is a metal ilā̃. This caitya seens to be older than the other two caitya in its vicinity. An inscription dated NS 961 mentions that a caitya of the northwest corner of the courtyard was renovated. It is likely that the inscription is referring to this caitya.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, vajradhātu caitya with a standing Buddha in a niche, view from S (December 2018)
object short description: At the southern plinth of the caitya there is a broken image of a standing Buddha. Bangdel (1995, 288) has dated this image back to the 5th century. Inside the niche of the northern side of the caitya is an image of the upper half of Buddha's body. At the western plinth of the caitya is another broken image of a standing Buddha. A mandaḥpaḥ can be found in front of the image.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, vajradhātu caitya, view from the N (December 2018)
Aśoka Stūpa North, Tārā shrine, view from the NW (December 2018)
object short description: Inside the north-western niche of the stūpa is a stone image of Tārā sitting in the vajrāsana.  She is holding a gem with her right arm and a lotus stalk with her left arm.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, Amitābha shrine, view from N (December 2018)
object short description: Generally, Amoghasiddhi is placed in the northern side of a stūpa; however, in this stūpa Amitābha is placed here instead.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, view from SE (December 2018)
object short description: Every year on the 2nd day of the dark half of Bhādra, the light procession (matayāḥ) is organised. Custom dictates that the devotees go to Bāḍe village to worship Lokeśvara on the first Wednesday after the procession. If a devotee is not able go to the Bāḍe village, they may worship this Budhavāra deity instead.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, Tārā Shrine, view from S (December 2018)
object short description: Inside the south-eastern niche of the stūpa is a stone image of Tārā sitting in the vajrāsana.  She is holding a gem with her right arm and lotus stalk with her left arm. Bangdel (1995, 289) estimates this statue to date back to the 12th century.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, Akṣobhya shrine, view from S (December 2018)
object short description: Inside the southern niche of the Aśoka Stūpa is an image of the Akṣobhya Buddha performing a bhūmisparśa gesture.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, stone oil lamp pillar, view from S (December 2018)
object short description: To the north of the stūpa is a pillar erected to light the oil-lamps. There are three mandaḥpāḥs in front of the pillar.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, vajradhātu caitya, view from E (December 2018)
Aśoka Stūpa North, Akṣobhya Shrine, view from SE (December 2018)
object short description: Akṣobhya Buddha, the main deity of this stūpa, is enshrined in the east-facing niche. To his right is Prajñāpāramitā and to his left is Lokeśvara. The bodies of all three deities are covered by clothes.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, Śikharakuṭa caitya with Licchavi fragment, view from E (December 2018)
object short description: A Licchavi caitya is attached to the śikhara style caitya above the bhagiṃ. The garbha and the harmikā of the caitya have been attached with cement.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, Mahākāla shrine, view from S (December 2018)
object short description: To the right of the stūpa's entrance is an image of a standing Mahākāla holding kartṛ in his right hand and kapāla in his left.

Object image caption: Aśoka Stūpa North, Stone nāga, view from N (December 2018)
Aśoka Stūpa North, śikharakuṭa caitya with Licchavi fragment, view from N (December 2018)
object short description: A Licchavi caitya is attached to the śikhara style caitya above the bhagiṃ. The garbha and the harmikā of the caitya have been attached using cement.

Object image caption: Kapileśvara Mahādeva Mandira, Gaṇeśa, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-23
Kapileśvara Mahādeva Mandira, Śivaliṅga, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-23
Kapileśvara Mahādeva Mandira, Śivaliṅga, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-23
Kapileśvara Mahādeva Mandira, Nandī, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2021-03-23
Seto Gaṇeśa Guṭhī Capāḥchẽ, stone statue of Sarasvatī, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-12
object short description: This statue is attached to the eastern wall of the Kṛṣṇa shrine. Sarasvatī is sitting in an ardhaparyaṅka posture. She is holding a rosary in her upper right hand and performing the gesture of varada with her lower right hand. Her left hands are also holding a book and performing abhaya respectively.

Object image caption: Seto Gaṇeśa Guṭhī Capāḥchẽ, stone statue of Sarasvatī, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-12
object short description: A stone statue of Sarasvatī has been placed below Kṛṣṇa. The four-handed statue is holding a rosary and a book in her upper hands and performing a gesture of varada with her lower right hand. Her last hand is empty.

Object image caption: Seto Gaṇeśa Guṭhī Capāḥchẽ, stone statue of Mahākāla, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-12
object short description: Statues of various deities are attached to the wall of the eastern phalcā. Here, a four-handed Mahākāla is shown standing over a corpse. He is holding a kartṛ (knife) and a sword in his right hands. His left hand holds a kapālapātra (skull bowl) and clasps a khaṭvāṅga whilst his lowest left hand holds a trident.

Object image caption: Seto Gaṇeśa Guṭhī Capāḥchẽ, stone statue of Nārāyaṇa, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-12
object short description: Nārāyaṇa is holding a wheel and a conch in his right hands, and a club and a lotus in his left hands. Garuḍa is sitting to his left.

Object image caption: Seto Gaṇeśa Guṭhī Capāḥchẽ, stone statue of Kṛṣṇa, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-12
object short description: There is a small Kṛṣṇa shrine to the north of the entrance of the eastern phalcā. A stone statue of Kṛṣṇa alongside Rukminī and Satyabhāmā has been placed on the upper part of the shrine.

Object image caption: Seto Gaṇeśa Guṭhī Capāḥchẽ, stone statue of Lakṣmī-Nārāyaṇa, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-12
object short description: This second statue of Lakṣmī-Nārāyaṇa is located inside a wooden frame in the eastern phalcā. Nārāyaṇa is shown holding a lotus flower and a conch in his left hands and a wheel and a club in his right hands. Lakṣmī stands near to Nārāyaṇa performing the gestures of abhaya and varada gestures with her right and left hands respectively. Garuḍa is sitting and praying to her left.

Object image caption: Seto Gaṇeśa Guṭhī Capāḥchẽ, stone statue of Lakṣmī-Nārāyaṇa, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-12
object short description: A statue of Lakṣmī-Nārāyaṇa has been placed in the eastern phalcā of the building. Nārāyaṇa is shown holding a lotus flower and a conch in his right hands and a wheel and club in his left hands. Lakṣmī stands near to Nārāyaṇa and is performing the gestures of abhaya and varada with her right and left hands respectively. Garuḍa is sitting in a praying pose to her left.

Object image caption: Seto Gaṇeśa Guṭhī Capāḥchẽ, stone statue of Jagannātha with Balarāma and Subhadrā, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-12
object short description: Statues of Balarāma, Subhadrā and Jagannātha have been placed in the western phalcā of the building. Jagannātha is shown holding a wheel in his right hand and a conch in his left hand. Subhadrā stands in a praying posture in the middle and Balarāma stands to the right of Subhadrā, holding a club in his right hand and a plough in his left hand.

Object image caption: Seto Gaṇeśa Guṭhī Capāḥchẽ, stone statue of Buddha, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-12
object short description: The Amitābha Buddha is shown sitting above some serpents. The statue is severely damaged; the head and hands are broken.

Object image caption: Seto Gaṇeśa Guṭhī Capāḥchẽ, stone statue of Sūrya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-12
object short description: Sūrya’s chariot driver Aruṇa is barely distinguishable. Daṇḍī and Piṅgala appear at his sides. The seven horses that one commonly finds in such Sūrya statues are missing here.

Mehalmuḍī Pañcadevala, northern temple, view from SW; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-03
object short description: The pediment is adorned with friezes of geometric patterns. Above the pediment is a small stone sculpture with the representation of an unknown figure.

Object image caption: Mehalmuḍī Pañcadevala, stone lion, view from NW; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-03
object short description:
The face and legs are broken. The sculpture was either placed on one of the śikharas' pediments or was paired with another lion and set on each side of a temple door.

The sculpture is now placed on the contemporary wall surrounding the pañcadevala complex.

Object image caption: Mehalmuḍī Pañcadevala, eastern temple, view from SW; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-03
object short description: The monument is leaning to the northwest.

Object image caption: Mehalmuḍī Pañcadevala, southern temple, view from NE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-03
Mehalmuḍī Pañcadevala, western temple, view from NE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-03
object short description: The monument is slightly leaning to the southeast.

Object image caption: Mehalmuḍī Pañcadevala, central temple, view from NE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-03
object short description:
The pediment is adorned with two registers of  eroded carvings. The carvings include the representations of lions (?) and unidentified figures.

Above the pediment is a little stone slab with the representation of an unknown figure holding staffs.

Object image caption: Bhajana Maṇḍala Phalcā, statue of Hastamāyā, view from S (October 2019)
object short description: A stone statue of the donor Hastamāyā, who facilitated the renovation of Bhajana Maṇḍala Phalcā in 1981. The statue is attached to the façade of the upper storey.

Object image caption: Gaḥdhvākhā, statue of Bhairava above the entrance, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-29
Gaḥdhvākhā, Jaḥdhuṃhiti, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-29
object short description: This object (Jaḥdhuṃhiti) is attached to the Gaḥdhvākhā. It has a modern waterspout with a statue of Bhagīratha just below it.

Object image caption: Gaḥdhvākhā, statue of Bhagīratha below the waterspout of the Jaḥdhuṃhiti, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-29

Harṣa Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-09
Pūcvathūra Phalcā, Bhagavatī, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-11
object short description: This cement statue is relatively new. The local residents worship her as Mother Goddess Santoṣī. The figure is holding a sword, a trident and a sacrificial vase (pātra) in three of her hands whilst performing the abhaya gesture with the fourth.

Object image caption: Pūcvathūra Phalcā, Rādhākṛṣṇa statue, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-11
object short description: Kṛṣṇa is shown playing the flute whilst Rādhā performs gestures of varada and abhaya with her right and left hands respectively.

Object image caption: Pūcvathūra Phalcā, Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-11
object short description: Lakṣmī and Viṣṇu are both standing in the samapāda posture. Lakṣmī is shown performing gestures of boon-giving (varada) and abhaya with her right and left hands respectively, whilst the four-armed Viṣṇu is shown holding his four weapons (śaṅkha, cakra, gadā and padma).

Object image caption: Pūcvathūra Phalcā, Vasundharā, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-07-11
object short description: This stone statue of Vasundharā is embedded in the western niche of the Phalcā. The deity has three heads, six arms, and is sitting in the ardhaparyaṅka (lalita) posture.

Object image caption: Lihī stūpa and pillar, stūpa 002, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-02
object short description: The different horizontal levels of the re-assembled stūpa are constituted of plinths from one or more dismantled stūpas.

Object image caption: Lihī stūpa and pillar, pillar 001, view from north-east: photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-02
Konti Hiti, stone statue of Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: Both Lakṣmī and Nārāyaṇa are standing on a lotus pedestal. Their vehicles Garuḍa and tortoise are at their sides.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, water spout 6, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: A lizard has been sculpted on the stone lid (hitipusā) of the conduit. Below the conduit one can find a statue of Bhagīratha.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, stone statue of Kālīyadamana, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: Based on the story of Lord Krishna's subjugation of the Kālīya Nāga, the idol is dated to the eighth century by Bangdel (1995, 245) and to the seventh by Deva (1984, VII).

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, water spout 5, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: This is the middle spout of the three that face south. The statues of Bhagīratha and an elephant can be found below it.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, stone statue of Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: The faces of both deities are damaged. Nārāyaṇa holds a conch and a lotus in his two right hands and club and wheel in his left hands. Their vehicles (Garuḍa and a tortoise) are at their sides. Bangdel (1995, 247) dates this statue to the 19th century.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, stone statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: The statue holds a lotus stalk in its left hand and is performing a varada gesture with its right hand. It has been dated to the 17th century by Bangdel (1995, 246).

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, water spout 1, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: Two lizards are sculpted on the stone lid (hitipusā) placed on top of the conduit. Beneath is a statue of Bhagīratha.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, Pañcāvaliyukta Caitya, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: This Caitya is located nearby the southern steps that lead to the water conduits of the Hiti. The Caitya has five layers resembling lotuses, water, jewels, fire and thunderbolts. The garbha and the harmikā are connected with cement plaster. Cement is has been applied on top of the trayodaśabhuvana.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, stone statue of Bhagīratha, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: This statue is attached to the western wall of the Hiti. A four-handed Bhagīratha is shown praying with two hands whilst holding a stick in his right hand and a gourd in his left hand. Bangdel (1995, 245) dates the statue to the 18th century.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, Caturvyūha Nārāyaṇa, view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: The statue of Caturvyūha Nārāyaṇa has been established on a north-facing jalahari at the middle of the Konti Hiti. Images of Śrīdhara Viṣṇu have been sculpted from the four sides of the idol. Lakṣmī and Garuḍa are standing on the sides of Viṣṇu. Bangdel (1995, 245) dates the statue to the 10th century.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, stone statue of Śiva-Pārvatī, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: This small Gaṇeśa statue has been placed between Śiva and Pārvatī. Śivaliṅgas can be seen on the outer circle of the statue. Bangdel (1995, 246) dates this statue to the 17th century.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, water spout 2, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: The stone lid (hitipusā) of the conduit is missing.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, stone statue of Umāmaheśvara, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: Both Śiva and Pārvatī are holding water vessels in their hands. Gaṇeśa and other attendants of Śiva are dancing below of the statue. Bangdel (1995, 246) has dated the statue to the 14th century while Deva (1984, VI) has dated it to the 12th century.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, stone statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: Lokeśvara is holding a lotus stalk in his left hand and performing the varada gesture with his right hand.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, stone statue of Harihara, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: Harihara, a deity combining the two major gods Vishnu (Hari) and Śiva (Hara) is depicted. The right half emerges from Shiva whilst the left resembles Vishnu. Lakṣmī and Pārvatī are standing beside their consorts. Bangdel (1995, 245) dates this statue to the 9-10th century.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, stone statue of Umāmaheśvara, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: Śiva is shown here with four hands. One of his right hands holds a rosary whilst the other performs a varada gesture. He holds a trident with one of his left hands whilst the other rests on Umā's shoulder. Gaṅgā is pouring water over Shiva's head. Attendants of Śiva, including Gaṇeśa, are seen below the idol. Deva (1984, 33-34) dates this statue to the 9th century.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, water spout 4, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
Konti Hiti, Śiva-Bhāṣkara, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: Sūrya stands holding two lotus flowers in his hands. Seven horses are pulling his chariot. Śiva is on top of Sūrya, and Brahmā, Viṣṇu and other gods surround him. Bangdel (1995, 246) dates this statue to the 12th century.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, stone statue of Sūrya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: This statue is severely eroded.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, water spout 3, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: Of all the water conduits of the Hiti, this water conduit dries up last in the dry season. When the rainy season starts, it is the first one to produce water again.

Object image caption: Konti Hiti, stone statue of Skanda Kārtikeya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-06-10
object short description: This statue has been installed between two spouts. Kārttikeya stands holding a stick whilst two women pray to him. The statue is dated to the seventh century by Deva (1984, VII) and to the eighth by Bangdel (1995, 245).

Object image caption: Rādhākṛṣṇa Mandira, Jahrūhiti, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-12-08
Rādhākṛṣṇa Mandira, well, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-12-08
object short description: A Licchavi caitya placed on a newer caitya structure of unknown date. The lower caitya was recently (writing in 2018) plastered in cement .

Object image caption: Rādhākṛṣṇa Mandira, Vajradhātu Caitya (also called Aśoka Caitya), view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-12-08
object short description: A Licchavi caitya placed on a newer caitya structure of unknown date. The lower caitya was recently (writing in 2018) plastered in cement .

Object image caption: Bekhārāja Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-24
Bekhārāja Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-24
Bekhārāja Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-24
Bekhārāja Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-07-24
Bhurtī Pañcadevala 1, southern śikhara, view from north-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
object short description: This temple is oriented to the north, towards the central temple (001).

Object image caption: Bhurtī Pañcadevala 1, central śikhara, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
object short description: Note the disproportionate āmalaka ring on top.

Object image caption: Bhurtī Pañcadevala 1, northern śikhara, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-24
object short description:
The monument is oriented to the south, and to the central temple.

Note the disproportionate āmalaka ring and its supporting drum on top.

Object image caption: Ārīthāy Phalcā, statue of Umāmaheśvara attached on the wall, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-09
Nāya Hiṭī at Cyāsaḥ, statue of Balarāma, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: A broken image of Balarāma is located between the two main water spouts of the Hiṭī. This broken image is dated to the 15-16th century by Paudel (2062, 91). It is heavily damaged.

Object image caption: Nāya Hiṭī at Cyāsaḥ, Śivaliṅga, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: This Śivaliṅga, placed in front of the Gajalakṣmī image is plain on top, but made octagonal in lower part. The layers of plastering of the upper part is delaminating. The Liṅga placed on a simple jalahari is slightly bended. This Liṅga is roughly dated to the Licchavi period (Khanal 2068, 183).

Object image caption: Nāya Hiṭī at Cyāsaḥ, statue of Gajalakṣmī, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: Lakṣmī stands in a samapāda posture. She holds something unidentifiable in her right hand and performs abhaya with her left hand. Two elephants stand on a lotus pedestal on either side of the goddess with uplifted trunks; they hold an inverted jar from which they pour water over her head. Bangdel (1982, 26 and 95) has dated this image to the second century. The object it is heavily damaged.

Object image caption: Nāya Hiṭī at Cyāsaḥ, well, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
Nāya Hiṭī at Cyāsaḥ, Jahrũhiti, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: This Jahrũhiti is attached to the eastern plinth of the Hiṭī and is in an unused condition. It is heavily damaged. Water damage poses a direct threat.

Object image caption: Dhārākholā stone memorial pillars, pillar 005, view from west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-27
Dhārākholā stone memorial pillars, pillar 006, view from south-west; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-27
object short description: The pillar contains a very eroded inscription below the top section.

Object image caption: Dhārākholā stone memorial pillars, pillar 001, view from south-east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-27
Dhārākholā stone memorial pillars, pillar 002, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-27
Dhārākholā stone memorial pillars, pillar 003, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-27
Dhārākholā stone memorial pillars, pillar 004, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-27
Thakuṃ Bāhāḥ, Śikharokūtopari Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-13
object short description: The Caitya was established in NS 787. It has a circular maṇḍala with two layers of lotus petals on top of its śikharakūṭa structure. On top of the Maṇḍala is a dharmadhātu jinālaya caitya-esque structure. Images of Tārā have been fixed on lotus petals in the four cardinal directions. On top of these images, one can find images of four Buddhas in four directions. Above the images, there are garbhagṛha, harmikā, 13 bhuvanas, āmalaka, yaḥsĩ, uṣṇīṣa, cūḍāmaṇi and a parasol. A fire alter stands to the north of this Caitya. The object is slightly damaged.

Object image caption: Thakuṃ Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-13
object short description: Mahākāla, standing in samapāḍa posture, is holding kartṛ in his right hand and a pātra in his left. He presses a khaṭvāṅga with his left arm.

Object image caption: Thakuṃ Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-02-13
object short description: Gaṇeśa stands on a mole. He holds a japamālā (rosary for counting prayers) and a carrot in his right hands and an axe and a sweet ball with his two left hands.

Object image caption: Sataḥ at Purohitaghāṭa, stone pillar, view from SW (February 2020)
object short description:
The stone stele rests on the back of a tortoise and supports a massive lotus pedestal. A statue of Garuḍa was once placed upon this pedestal, but this was stolen some time around 1985.

The stone pillar is 201 cm tall (including the tortoise and the lotus pedestal) and its cross-section measures 39 x 38 cm.

Object name: Shrine with a stone statue of Viṣṇu
Object image caption: Sataḥ at Purohitaghāṭa, shrine with a statue of Viṣṇu (photo by Niels Gutschow, January, 1983)
object short description:
Source: Gutschow 2011, 918

Before the 2015 earthquake, this Viṣṇu shrine was located on the upper floor. In it stood a four-handed Viṣṇu, holding śaṅkha, cakra, gadā and padma and standing in the sthānaka posture. Following the demolition of the upper storey, the Viṣṇu statue was placed in the sanctum of the Viṣṇu Mandira located behind the Sataḥ.

Object name: Stone pillar with a statue of Hanumān
Object image caption: Sataḥ at Purohitaghāṭa, stone pillars in front, view from S (photo by Thomas Schrom, April 2017)
object short description: The stone pillar stands on the back of a tortoise and supports a statue of Hanumān, who has been placed upon on a lotus pedestal. The Hanumān statue was stolen around 1985 but recovered a few days later at the banks of the Bagmati, near Kālamocana.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, Bhañsā Gaṇeśa shrine, view from SE (November 2018)
object short description: A small open shrine of Gaṇeśa attached to the wall and flanked by two lions.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, Kuṭi Bāhāḥ well, view from SE (November 2018)
object short description: The well is encircled by a green iron grid and was recently renovated with new materials.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, Buddha Ratnasambhava, view from SE (November 2018)
object short description: A stone statue of Ratnasambhava Buddha facing south in an artistic toraṇa. At the corner of the lower part are horses, Ratnasambhava’a vāhana.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu, view from SE (November 2018)
object short description: A dharmadhātu with eight Lokeśvaras in the niches.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu jinātmaja caitya, view from SE (November 2018)
object short description: A Licchavi caitya placed on a newer caitya structure of an unknown date. The lower caitya has recently been plastered in cement, but the material below could not be identified – possibly brick and/or stone. The stone inscription has been heavily damaged and is placed at the eastern side.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, khataśailī caitya (A), view from SE (November 2018)
object short description: A rectangular caitya with a statue of Akṣobhaya and a small caitya on top.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, khataśailī caitya, view from SE (November 2018)
object short description: A rectangular caitya with a statue of Akṣobhaya and a small caitya on top, as well as an oil lamp balustrade that surrounds the monument.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, Buddhasthita aśoka caitya and dharmadhātu, view from SE (November 2018)
object short description: A Licchavi caitya placed on a newer caitya substructure with a dharmadhātu in the foreground.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, Nīla Vṛṣaratna, view from NE (November 2018)
object short description: A roofed shrine with a golden statue of Nandī, Śiva’s vehicle. This forms the centre of the Dīpaṅkhā procession.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, sanctum with Buddha Śākyamuni, view from E (November 2018)
Nāga Bāhāḥ, Padma Caitya, view from N (November 2018)
object short description: A three-stepped caitya on a rectangular plinth with rows of lotus petals. There are four Buddhas facing in four directions below the harmikā (cp. Śākya 1993, 43).

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, śikharakūṭa caitya, view from NE (November 2018)
object short description: A three-stepped caitya with four Lokeśvara statues in the upper part, dated NS 1047.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, Mahaṅkāla, view from E (November 2018)
Nāga Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu at Kuṭi Bāhāḥ, view from NE (November 2018)
object short description: A dharmadhātu with an octagonal base and statues of Lokeśvaras in the niches, dated VS 2050.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, vimba caitya, view from NW (November 2018)
object short description: The vimba or bimba caitya was built by Śākyas (Śākya 1993: 43). It looks similar to a octagonal dharmadhātu caitya and has eight Lokeśvaras in the lower part and four Buddha statues in the upper section. It is surrounded by an oil lamp balustrade.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, vajradhātu caitya (A), view from SE (November 2018)
object short description: The white-painted caitya is covered with cement, but the other building material is unknown (most likely to be brick and/or stone).

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, vajradhātu caitya (B), view from S (November 2018)
object short description: This caitya has been painted in white, and is surrounded by an oil lamp balustrade. It is covered in cement, but the other building material is unknown (most likely to be brick and/or stone).

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from SE (November 2018)
object short description: This dharmadhātu has a metal vajra on top with an inscription that refers to the Matayā festivaldated VS 2054. The stone inscription is dated VS 2055 and refers to its construction.

Object image caption: Nāga Bāhāḥ, aṣṭakoṇoparīvṛtākāra caitya, view from NW (November 2018)
object short description: This caitya has an octagonal base with eight Dhyāni Lokeśvaras in the four niches of the middle part, and statues of Buddha in the upper part.

Object image caption: Taḥ Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala (B), view from N (July 2019)
object short description: Eight Bodhisatva images have been placed on each of its eight faces. A metal vajra has been fixed on top of the object.

Object image caption: Taḥ Bāhāḥ, śikharakūṭa caitya, view from NE (July 2019)
object short description: This caitya stands to the north of the esoteric shrine. There are no inscriptions on the caitya. Four Bodhisatva and four Buddha images have been painted at each of the four directions. Two stone pillars have been erected at the south-east and north-west corners.

Object image caption: Taḥ Bāhāḥ, vajradhātu caitya, view from E (July 2019)
object short description: Images of the Four Buddhas have been placed in the four niches above the caitya's rectangular plinth. These images have been ordered in a manner that subverts the conventional structure; Akṣobhya and Amithābha have changed places. A small caitya can be found above every niche, however there is no statue in the caitya's uppermost niche. Above the structure, one can find further statues of the Four Buddhas in each of the four directions. A harmikā, a trayodaśabhuvana and a finial have been placed above these statues. A dharmadhātu maṇḍala has been established to the west of the caitya.. There is a stone vajrā on top of the maṇḍala.

Object image caption: Taḥ Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala (A), view from SE (July 2019)
object short description: Eight Bodhisatvas have been placed on each of the eight faces of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala. A vajra tied to an iron rod has been fixed on top of the dharmadhātu. A golden nāga surrounds the object.

Object image caption: Cīthū Stone Caitya, statue of Akṣobhya on the eastern face of the Caitya, view from E; photo by Bharat Maharjan; 2021-05-30
Cīthū Stone Caitya, statue of Amoghasiddhi on the northern face of the Caitya, view from N; photo by Bharat Maharjan; 2021-05-30
Cīthū Stone Caitya, statue of Amitābha on the western face of the Caitya, view from W; photo by Bharat Maharjan; 2021-05-30
Cīthū Stone Caitya, statue of Ratnasambhava on the southern face of the Caitya, view from S; photo by Bharat Maharjan; 2021-05-30
Tulasī Devala, stone pillar erected on the eastern side of the Devala, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-17
Tulasī Devala, statue of Umāmaheśvara attached to a wall niche, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-17
Tulasī Devala, statue of Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa attached to a wall niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-17
Tulasī Devala, statue of Garuḍaṇārāyaṇa attached to a wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-17
Tulasī Devala, statue of Rādhākṛṣṇa attached to a wall niche, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-17
Tulasī Devala, statue of Sarasvatī attached to a wall niche, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-17
Tulasī Devala, statue of Viṣṇu attached to a wall niche view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-04-17
Cvaḥpvaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, Kaṅgaḥdyaḥ̣ Shrine under construction, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-08
Cvaḥpvaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, Gaṇeśa Shrine, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-27
Cvaḥpvaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, Stone lion east, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-27
Cvaḥpvaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, Bell on a stone stand, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-27
Cvaḥpvaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, Nandī statue, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-27
Cvaḥpvaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, Hāratī Shrine, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-27
Cvaḥpvaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, Umāmaheśvara Shrine, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-27
Cvaḥpvaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, Well, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-27
Cvaḥpvaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, Gaṇeśa Shrine attached to the north-side of the temple, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-27
Cvaḥpvaḥ Gaṇeśa Mandira, Stone lion west, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-11-27
Ikhālakhu Phalcā, stone statue of Viṣṇu Lakṣmī, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-01-25
object short description: Viṣṇu holds a wheel and a club in his two right hands. He is holding a conch in his upper left hand and performing a gesture of fearlessness with his lower left hand, whilst Lakṣmī holds an oblong water pot in her right hand and performs the gesture of fearlessness with her left hand. Viṣṇu sits Garuḍa sits to the right of Viṣṇu in a praying posture. Vinoda Kṛṣṇa Śreṣṭha and his wife installed this statue in memory of their nephew Savina Kṛṣṇa Śreṣṭha and his wife.

Object image caption: Ikhālakhu Phalcā, stone statue of Viṣṇu Lakṣmī, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-01-25
object short description: This statue was installed in memory of Nārāyaṇakṛṣṇa Śreṣṭha (VS 1978-2071) and Kadamalatā Śreṣṭha (VS 1982-2071).

Ikhālakhu Phalcā, stone statue of Viṣṇu, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-01-25

Object image caption: Ikhālakhu Phalcā, stone statue of Viṣṇu, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-01-25
Naḥ Bāhāḥcā, Mahākāla, view from E (January 2020)
object short description: To the right of the sanctum door is a small niche made from a carved wooden frame. A stone statue of Mahākāla is placed in the niche. He is standing on a corpse holding a kartṛ (cutter) in his right hand whilst his left-hand holds a kapāpāpātra (skull bowl) and clasps a khaṭvāṅga.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥcā, donor's statue and Caitya, view from W (January 2020)
object short description: A stone statue of a donor has been erected on the plinth of the bāhāḥcā courtyard, to the east of the caitya. There is a lamp post above it.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥcā, Hanumān, view from S (January 2020)
object short description: A stone statue of Hanumān is attached to the wall of a neighbouring house. His right hand is performing a varada gesture whilst left hand is displayed in an abhaya gesture. His hands have been partially broken and his face has been worn away by vermilion powder.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥcā, Gaṇeśa, view from E (January 2020)
object short description: To the left of the sanctum door is a small niche made from a carved wooden frame. A stone statue of Gaṇeśa has been placed in the niche. This four-handed Gaṇeśa sits on a rat and holds an akṣamālā and a radish in his two right hands. His two left hands hold an axe and a sweet ball.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥcā, Akṣobhya, view from E (January 2020)
object short description: A stone statue of an east-facing Akṣobhya is enshrined in the sanctum. Only the lower parts of the wooden frame on the back of the statue remain.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥcā, Aṣṭakoṇoparipadma Caitya, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: Aṣṭakoṇoparipadma Caitya stands in the middle of the square-shaped sunken courtyard. In earlier times, rainwater collected in the courtyard due to the lack of a drainage system. As a result, the bottom of the caitya was often submerged. Locals therefore named it Pukhū Cibhā (meaning 'a caitya in a pond'). The caitya stands on the base of an octagonal plinth. Eight Bodhisattva images are placed on its eight faces. Ten layers of lotus petals can be seen on the upper part, and four Buddha statues have been placed at the bottom of the dome. The dome and harmikā have been joined together with cement plaster. The āmalaka (myrobalan) part is covered by a metal sheet. There is a fire altar to the east of the caitya.

Olā Nani at Dau Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātumaṇḍala, view from E (October 2018)
Olā Nani at Dau Bāhāḥ, view from N (October 2018)
object short description: The well represents a traditional design with custom-made, wedge-shaped bricks forming the round corpus. The deeply worn stone ring attests to its antiquity even though it is difficult to determine the well's age. The well is framed by a brick apron and partly covered by an iron grill.

Object image caption: Olā Nani at Dau Bāhāḥ, small shrine on tulasīmaṭha, view from W (October 2018)
object short description: The brick base of the tulasīmaṭha supports a small śikhara-style shrine, which houses a Rādhā-Kṛṣṇa statue and is flanked by stone istatues of Bhairava and Umāmaheśvara.

Object name: Aniconic stone statue identified as Bhairava and bell
Object image caption: Olā Nani, shrine and aniconic image, view from W (October 2018)
object short description: This small shrine is located near the main (eastern) entrance to Olā Nani. The aniconic object represents Bhairava and is worshipped regularly. A small brass bell is installed next to it.

Object image caption: Olā Nani at Dau Bāhāḥ, platform (dabū), view from W (October 2018)
object short description: The raised platform is currently completely covered with building materials from two demolished houses next to it.

Object image caption: Su Bāhāḥ, Aṣṭakoṇakṛti Caitya, view from N (June 2019)
object short description: This octagonal Caitya contains images of the Four Buddhas, namely Akṣobhya, Ratnasambhava, Amitābha and Amoghasiddhi. These are located on the eastern, southern, western and northern faces respectively. Meanwhile, Māmakī, Pāṇḍarā, Āryatārā and Locanā sit on the south-east, south-west, north-west and north-east corners respectively. The upper part of the caitya is clad in brass; this includes the kumbha. Images of the Four Busshas have also been fixed at the four faces of the kumbha. There are three holes­­—which do not seem to be niches—in the middle part of the vedī on its southern, eastern and northern faces.

Object image caption: Su Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla Cheli, view from N (June 2019)
object short description:
Mahākāla Cheli, a corridor to the north of the monastery, contains images of Hanumān, Viṣvakarmā, Mahākāla and Nāsaḥdyaḥ (Nṛtyeśvara).

  1. Hanumān: This small image of Hanumān does not seem to be very old. Hanumān commonly serves as the protector of monastic buildings.
  2. Viśvakarmā: Viśvakarmā, the god of crafts, is enshrined inside this niche without any image.
  3. Mahākāla: Some people worship this Mahākāla as Bhairava. No statue of Mahākāla is established; instead, one can find a curtain with three furious eyes. The curtain also contains images of kartṛ, kapālapātra, khaṭvāṅga, dogs and jackals. Only men from the monastery are allowed to open the curtain. It is believed that this Mahākāla, god of the cremation ground, used to live here before this monastery was established. To appease him, incense of human flesh is offered to him every year on the 9th day of the bright half of Āśvina. This ritual is called Lā Khāyegu.
  4. Nāsaḥdyaḥ: The god of music, dance and acting has no image here. A curtain showing images of three eyes, a sword, and a trident etc. serves as the symbol of the the god. People come to worship this god when they start to learn the arts.

Object image caption: Su Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W (June 2019)
object short description: This octagonal Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala has no images on any of its faces. A metal vajra has been fixed on top of it.

Object image caption: Su Bāhāḥ, cremation ground, view from S (June 2019)
object short description: This altar symbolises the fact that this land was once a cremation ground.

Object image caption: Su Bāhāḥ, Aśoka Caitya, view from W (June 2019)
object short description: This Aśoka Caitya is attached to the aṣṭakoṇākṛti caitya and is raised over the brick vedikā. Three niches with Buddha images can be found to the west, south and north. It is clear that the Buddha images in the niche below the kumbha were added later. The images in the southern and western niches have already been lost. A deteriorated stone inscription is attached to the western plinth of the caitya. Another caitya stands to the south west corner of this Caitya. The Buddha images that were placed in its niches have eroded over time, and the outer layers of the garbha stone have already started to fall down. The garbha and the harmikā are joined together with cement plaster. The yaḥsĩ and the cūḍāmaṇi are broken.

Object image caption: I Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from NE; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-03
object short description: This octagonal Maṇḍala has images of Lokeśvaras on its eight sides.

Object image caption: I Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya with nāgas; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-03
object short description: This Caitya stands  on a single plinth and has niches containing images of Bodhisattvas in its four directions. Smaller niches containing statues of Buddha can be found above these. Iron rods rise from the four corners of the Caitya and curve in towards the top of the object. Metal images of four nāgas are fixed upon these rods, implying that they are protecting the Caitya.

Object image caption: Nhugu Phalcā at Cyāsal, shrine of Vasundharā, view from E; photo by Charlotte von Waitz; 2019-02-16
object short description: Brick shrine with pointed roof attached to the eastern outer wall of the Phalcā.

Object image caption: Nhugu Phalcā at Cyāsal, stone icon of Lakṣmīnārāyaṇa, view from E; photo by Christiane Brosius; 2018-10-05
Ituṃ Bāhāḥ, paubhā; photo by Chiniya Tamrakar; 1978; courtesy of the Ituṃ Bāhāḥ Saṅgha
object short description:
The photograph was taken when the paubhā was exhibited in the Ituṃ Bāhāḥ courtyard during the Guṃlā festival in June/August 1978 CE.

Today, the paubhā is part of a private collection in the USA. It was exhibited at "Himalayas: An Aesthetic Adventure" organized by The Art Institute of Chicago from April 5 to August 17, 2003 CE.

It is published in: 

Pal, Pratapaditya. Himalayas, An Aesthetic Adventure. Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 2003, p. 69

Ituṃ Bāhāḥ, Caturvyūhacaitya, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2020-12-12
object short description: Caturvyūhacaitya (elevation west, height 172 cm) was established in 1551 CE. It is placed on top of a drain (jalaharī), indicating the place where the sacrificial balls (piṇḍa) are discarded by members of the Bāhāḥ after the performance of death rituals. Four unidentified Buddhas in standing position are worked in relief from a slender shaft. The western Buddha displays the gesture of turning the wheel of the law (dharmacakramudrā). The four Tathāgatas are found on the niches that are attached to the drum and dome of the primary trio, the stūpa proper. Amidst the lotus scrollwork of the base are seen the guardians of the four directions, flanked by mythic aquatic creatures (makara) and wisdom bearers (vidyādhara). The Caitya represents the modified copy of a sixth century Licchavicaitya on the Svayambhūnātha hill. There, the Buddhas display identical gestures, which are otherwise only found at Lagan Bāhā and Jyā Bāhāḥ, both in Kathmandu.

Yākaḥ Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view N  (January 2019)
object short description: This dharmadhātu maṇḍala stands in front of the sanctum. The inscription inscribed on the maṇḍala informs the reader that Thapāju Dhīrjamuni established it in VS 2043 Vaiśākha 29.

Object image caption: Yākaḥ Bāhāḥ, Bimba caitya, view N  (January 2019)
object short description: This caitya is located between the dharmadhātu maṇḍala and the jinālaya caitya. Śākya (1993, 41) has named this caitya based on its structure. Above the plinth, there are two layers of lotus petals, and above this one can find garbha, harmikā and 13 bhuvanas

Object image caption: Yākaḥ Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātujinālaya caitya, view from N (January 2019)
object short description: This Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya is located behind the bimba caitya (LAL0680_002). Images of the donors have been placed on the eastern vedi; their names are also inscribed at the bottom of the images. Sundarī Vajrācārya, wife of the late Uṣṇisa Vajrācārya donated this caitya in VS 2043 Vaiśākha 29.

Object image caption: Hakha Bāhāḥ, vajra, view from SW; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-01-26
object short description: This bronze vajra lies on a bronze lotus pedestal that has been placed on top of a stone pillar of ca. 3 feet.

Object image caption: Hakha Bāhāḥ, Padmāvali Caitya, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-01-26
object short description: An inscription (cp. Vajrācārya 1996, 7) in the western vedi provides information about the construction of this Caitya. In the eastern vedi one can also find images of the donors. The stone image of Maitreya that has been placed in the eastern niche was damaged and has been replaced with a metal image. An oil lamp balustrade is fixed on top of the stone fence surrounding the Caitya.

Object image caption: Hakha Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-01-26
object short description: This Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala is different from other dharmadhātus. It is larger in size, there are no images of Lokeśvaras, and its top is covered with a metal sheet.

Object image caption: Hakha Bāhāḥ, stone sculpture of two devotees, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-01-26
object short description: These stone images of a couple face towards the main deity of the Bāhāḥ. There is no inscription to provide information about the name or date of these persons.

Object image caption: Hakha Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla shrine, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-02-01
object short description: An image of Mahākāla can be found on the right-hand side when one enters the courtyard of the Bāhāḥ through its main entrance. The statue is standing in a samapāda posture and holding kartṛ with his right hand and kapāla and a khaṭvāṅga with his left.

Object image caption: Hakha Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-01-26
Hakha Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-01-26
Hakha Bāhāḥ, Licchavi Caitya, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-01-26
object short description: This Caitya is located in front of the kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ shrine. It has been painted white, and the bell installed to the west of it was donated in NS 774.

Object image caption: Hakha Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from NE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-01-26
object short description: This Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala is located to the west of Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya (LAL0390-011).

Object image caption: Hakha Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-01-26
object short description: This Caitya is located at the southeast corner of the Bāhāḥ-courtyard. Images of donors are inscribed at the eastern vedi of the Caitya.

Object image caption: Hakha Bāhāḥ, Amoghapāśa Lokeśvara shrine, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-01-26
object short description: There is a small door on the ground floor of the western facade of the monastic building. Phalcā-shaped plinths flank the corridor, and an image of Amoghapāśa Lokeśvara facing south has been attached to the left-hand side wall. This eight handed Lokeśvara, standing in tribhaṅga posture, is flanked by two standing Tārās.

Object image caption: Kṛṣṇa Mandira at Vala Ṭol, Umāmaheśvara Shrine, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-21
object short description: This was originally constructed from bricks and cement, so as to support the tap and its pipe. However, the tap no longer functions, and some of the bricks have fallen down from the upper section. There is a small niche above the bent pipe, within which one can find a stone image of Umāmaheśvara.

Object image caption: Kṛṣṇa Mandira at Vala Ṭol, Bhairava shrine; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-21
Kṛṣṇa Mandira at Vala Ṭol, Gaṇeśa Shrine, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-21
object short description: This shrine is attached to the Sarasvatī shrine, and it faces southwards. Compared to the Sarasvatī shrine, this one is a little bigger in size, but the structure of both shrines is very similar. The entrance of the shrine is made of stone. A small image of Gaṇeśa has been carved in the middle of the upper stone of the entrance. Inside the sanctum, one can find another image of Gaṇeśa. An engraved inscription on the lintel of the entrance provides information about the shrine's reconstruction. On top of the shrine is a metal pinnacle, flanked by sinhaḥmhū and jvālānhāyekaṁ to its right and left respectively.

Object image caption: Kṛṣṇa Mandira at Vala Ṭol, well, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-21
object short description: There was once an old well in this area, the material of which has been used to construct this new one, 7m west of the temple.

Object image caption: Kṛṣṇa Mandira at Vala Ṭol, Sarasvatī Shrine, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2018-11-21
object short description: This shrine is constructed on top of the historical Jahrũhiti. On the surface of the hiti one can still see an inscription, although most of it is broken.

Mikhā Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N (June 2020)
object short description: The octagonal Dharmadhātumaṇḍala has images of Bodhisattva in its eight faces.

Object image caption: Mikhā Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from S (June 2020)
object short description: The Caitya is built on an octagonal plinth. Images related to the life of Buddha are engraved on its sides. Four statues of Tārā have been placed at its four corners.

Object image caption: Mikhā Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from NE (June 2020)
object short description: The octagonal Dharmadhātumaṇḍala has images of Bodhisattva in its eight faces. A metal vajra has been fixed on its top.

Object image caption: Mikhā Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from NE (June 2020)
object short description: The plinth above the platform of the Caitya contains four Bodhisattvas and it has guardian lions on the edges. Four Dhyanī Buddhas have been placed above the lotus throne (padmāsana). Statues of Akṣobhya, Ratnasambhava, Amitābha and Amoghasiddhi are placed on the eastern, southern, western and northern faces of the caitya respectively. Akṣobhya’s seat is decorated with images of two elephants and Vīṇārāja. Similarly, the southern side shows two horses and Vajrapāṇi, the western side displays peacocks and Padmapāṇi, and the northern side exhibits images of Garuḍas and Mañjuśrī. Above the ground level and the three layers of lotus throne one can find the primary trio, drum, dome and finial with ilã.

Object image caption: Mikhā Bāhāḥ, statue of Akṣobhya in the sanctum, view from E (June 2020)
object short description: Stone statue of Akṣobhya has been enshrined in the sanctum of the Bāhāḥ. The deity wears a metal cloth called lhegā and a metal crown.

Object image caption: Om Bāhāḥ, Svayambhū Caitya, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
object short description:
This Caitya is built atop a viṃśatikoṇa shaped plinth. Four Buddhas, each facing one cardinal direction, are placed on top of two layers of a lotus leaf base. Caitya’s sanctum, garbha, and harmikā are cemented together. 

विंशतिकोण आकारको पेटीमाथि यो चैत्य बनाइएको छ । दुई तहको कमलपत्रमाथि चार दिशामा चार बुद्ध राखिएका छन् । चैत्यको गर्भ र हर्मिकालाई सिमेन्ट प्रयोग गरेर जोडिएको छ ।

Object image caption: Om Bāhāḥ, Lokeśvara, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
Om Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
object short description:
A statue of Akṣobhya, facing north, has been established as the bāhāḥ’s kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ. The older statue of Akṣobhya was stone-made, folded by a metal sheet. In NS 778 (1658 CE), it was gilded in gold. In NS 977 (1857 CE) a gold gilded copper statue was installed in the bāhāḥ. According to the local community, the older stone statue was covered with copper to make the new one.

बाहा:को गर्भगृहभित्र उत्तराभिमुख गरी अक्षोभ्यलाई क्वा:पा:द्य:को रूपमा स्थापना गरिएको छ । अक्षोभ्यको पुरानो मूर्ति धातुको पाताले मोडिएको ढुंगाले बनाइएको थियो । पछि नेसं 778 (सन् 1658) मा क्वा:पा:द्य:को मूर्तिमा सुनको जलप लगाइएको थियो । फेरि नेसं 977 (सन् 1857) मा तामाको अर्कै मूर्ति बनाएर सुनको मोलम्बा लगाएर चढाइएको थियो । स्थानीयहरूका अनुसार पुरानो ढुंगाको मूर्तिलाई छोपेर तामाको मूर्ति बनाइएको थियो ।

Object image caption: Om Bāhāḥ, Hanumān, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
Om Bāhāḥ, Mañjuśrī, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
Om Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
Om Bāhāḥ, Licchavi Caitya, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
object short description:
The plinth of this Lichchhavi Caitya was probably added later. There are three niches, gavākṣa, in each cardinal direction of the bottom part. Statues of four Buddhas are installed inside the central four niches, while the other niches are empty. Statues of Vairocana are kept in all four directions of the upper part of the caitya. Usually, the Lichchhavi Era caityas feature empty niches, and the Buddha statues are probably a later addition. The part above the caitya’s sanctum was also added later. Slusser (1982, 172) compares this caitya with another one in the Dhākhwā Bāhāḥ and dates it to the seventh century. 

यो लिच्छविकालीन चैत्य भएपनि पेटी भने पछि मात्र थपेको देखिन्छ । चैत्यको तल्लो भागमा प्रत्येक दिशामा तीन-तीनवटा गवाक्ष बनाइएका छन् र बीचको गवाक्षमा चार दिशामा चार बुद्ध राखिएका छन् । बीचको गवाक्ष बाहेक दायाँबायाँका गवाक्षहरू खाली नै राखिएका छन् । माथिल्लो तलाको गवाक्षमा चारै दिशामा वैरोचन राखिएका छन् । लिच्छवि चैत्यमा गवाक्ष खाली नै राखिने हुनाले यी बुद्धमूर्तिहरू पछि मात्र थपिएका देखिन्छन् । चैत्यको गर्भभन्दा माथिको भाग पनि पछि मात्र थपेको देखिन्छ । Slusser (1982, 172) ले यस चैत्यलाई काठमाडौं ध्वाखा बाहा:को चैत्यसँग तुलना गरी सातौं शताब्दीको मानेका छन् ।

Object image caption: Om Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūtoparipadma Caitya, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
object short description:
This is called a Śikharakūtoparipadma Caitya since the padma is placed atop the Śikharakūta Caitya. Statues of four Boddhisattvas are placed in the four cardinal directions. A seven-layered is placed on the top over which statues of four Buddhas are placed inside a sanctum. The sanctum and harmikā are cemented together. The part above its pinnacle, rayodaśabhuvana, has been lost.

शिखरकूट चैत्यमाथि पद्म राखी निर्माण गरिएकोले यसलाई Śikharakūtoparipadma Caitya भनिएको हो । यस चैत्यमा चार दिशामा चार बोधिसत्व राखी त्यसमाथि सात तहको पद्म राखिएको छ । त्यसमाथि चार दिशामा चार बुद्ध राखी गर्भ बनाइएको छ । गर्भ र हर्मिका जोड्न सिमेन्टको प्रयोग गरिएको छ । चैत्यको त्रयोदशभुवन भन्दा माथिको भाग हराइसकेको छ ।

Object image caption: Om Bāhāḥ, Pañcāvaliyukta Caitya, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
object short description: This caitya has five layers, symbolizing lotus, water, gem, fire, and vajra. The inscription on its western side mentions that this caitya was established by Cakrapāṇi.

Object image caption: Om Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
Om Bāhāḥ, Tārā, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-13
Om Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
object short description:
The eight faces of the Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala are without any carving and empty. There is a metal Vajra, which was installed in NS 1010 (1890 CE), on its top.

यस धर्मधातु मण्डलको आठ दिशामा कुनै देवता नराखी खाली नै छोडिएको छ । धर्मधातु मण्डलमाथि NS 1010 (CE 1890) मा चढाइएको धातुको वज्र राखिएको छ ।

Object image caption: Om Bāhāḥ, Pillar, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-14
object short description:
The statue of Amṛtajoti and his wife is placed on this pillar. The couple paved the bāhāḥ’s digi, installed a caitya (LAL1740-005), a Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, and a pillar. On top of the pillar, they installed their statue. 

यो शिलास्तम्भमा Amṛtajoti र उनकी श्रीमतीको प्रतिमा राखिएको छ । उनीहरूले बाहा:को दिगिमा तेलिया इँटाले छापी बाहा: प्राङ्गनमा चैत्य (LAL1740-005)  र धर्मधातु मण्डल स्थापना गरी आफ्नो प्रतिमा सहितको स्तम्भ पनि ठड्याएका थिए ।

object short description:
This is the base of a pillar identical in shape and dimensions to those of the nearby pavilion, to which it must be contemporary.

As seen on the pavilion, the artefact is carved with the diamond, or jewel motif (ratna).
