Mati Bāhāḥ, Śikharopari Bimba Caitya, view from E (November 2018)
object short description: This Caitya is located in front of the main door of the Bāhāḥ. The base of the Caitya is in a viṃśatikoṇa plan and raised by a stone plinth. A nāga winds across the lower story in a mountain-like design, with its head and tail facing north. These mountains represent the four mountains Jāmāco, Sipuco, Phūco and Dhināco, all of which surround the Kathmandu Valley. On top of the mountains in each of the four directions are images of Buddha. There are images of Tārā in the four corners. Some parts of these images are broken, though it seems that they were installed later.  Above the images are two layers of lotus petals. Above this, in turn, are kumbha, harmikā, trayodaśabhuvana and a pinnacle. A metal cãduvā supported by four iron angular rods in four corners can be found above the entire Caitya. These rods also support an oil-lamp balustrade. There is no inscription to provide information about the history of the object. However, Gutschow (1997, 257) dates it back to the 18th century.

Object image caption: Mati Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from S (November 2018)
object short description: Mahākāla, a guardian of the shrine, stands on the left side of main buildingto the south of the main door. He is holding kartṛ and khaṭvāṅga.

Object image caption: Nārāyaṇa Mandira, Garuḍa statue, view from E (September 2019)
object short description: Small figures of devotees can be seen on the front side of the statue's plinth and an inscription has been placed on the rear side. The statue is 32 cm in width and 60 cm in height.

Object image caption: Patāṅginī Gaṇeśa, aniconic stone representing Gaṇeśa in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-03-19
Patāṅginī Gaṇeśa, Vajradhātu Caitya, view from S; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-03-19
Patāṅginī Gaṇeśa, Bell, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-03-19
Patāṅginī Gaṇeśa Mandira, Namobuddha Caitya, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2021-03-19
Tripurasundarī Mandirā, stone Varāha image, view from south; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-18
object short description: In the centre of the sculpture is Varāha, standing under a finely carved arch and turned to the right, where the central image of Vaikuṇṭha (now gone) must have stood originally. The sculpture may be dated from ca. 12th century. It is executed in the same bluish stone used for later sculptures in Kulle Koṭa (BTD0050).

Object image caption: Tripurasundarī Mandirā, temple pinnacle, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-18
Tripurasundarī Mandirā, temple pinnacles, view from east; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2015-04-18
object short description:
The temple pinnacle is painted in pink. It consists of two āmalaka discs on top of each others, with a stūpi on top. The whole is placed on a pedestal that is now covered by plaster shaped in the continuity of the āmalakas.

The āmalakas and the stūpi may date from the original temple, which is believed to be erected in 1688.

Object image caption: Jora Gaṇeśa Mandira, statue of mouse (vehicle of Gaṇeśa), view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-04
Sohraśrāddha Phalcā, Aṣṭakoṇākṛtipadma Caitya in front of the Phalcā, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-21
Sohraśrāddha Phalcā, statue of Sarasvatī on a wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-21
Sohraśrāddha Phalcā, statue of Nāgakanyā on a wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-21
Sohraśrāddha Phalcā, statue of Mahākāla on a wall niche, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-21
Sohraśrāddha Phalcā, statue of Gaṇeśa on a wall niche, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-21
Sohraśrāddha Phalcā, statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, probably complemented by donot figurines on a wall niche, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-21
Sohraśrāddha Phalcā, statue of donors on a wall niche, view from SW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-21
Sohraśrāddha Phalcā, statue of Sūrya on a wall niche, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-21
Sohraśrāddha Phalcā, statue of Sūrya with three smaller figurines in a wall niche, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-21
Sohraśrāddha Phalcā, statue of Garuḍa inside a wall niche, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-21
Sohraśrāddha Phalcā, remains of a jaḥdhuṃhiti, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-08-21
object short description: There used to be a ritual of distributing samaybaji in the name of the jaḥdhuṃhiti  on the Makara Saṅkrānti day (1st solar day of the month of Vaiśākha). However, this is not the case any longer.

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, caitya, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: The lower part of the Licchavi caitya is made of bricks. Images of the Dhyānī Buddhas are placed on the four faces of the caitya. The stone that the Buddha images are made from seem to be different from those of the caitya, suggesting that the images of the Buddha were added some time after its construction. The pedestals of the eastern and western images contain broken inscriptions. One can read the date Saṃvat 65 (?) on the eastern one, but the rest of it is too damaged to be legible.

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, statue of Umāmaheśvara, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: This statue is placed inside a nice of the western wall of the hiṭī. The faces of the deity and some other parts are broken. Images of more than 30 other demigods have been carved from the same stone. Bangdel (1995, 224) has dated this image back to the 13th century.

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, statue of Umāmaheśvara, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: A four-handed Śiva is embracing Umā with his two left hands and performing mātuliṅga and abhaya with his two right hands. Umā is leaning slightly towards Śiva and supporting herself with her right arm. Left of Śiva, one can see Nandī, and Kumāra is above him. An attendant of Umā stands to her right in the tribhaṅga posture. She holds a pot and a sword with her lower two hands, whilst her upper two hands are in a gesture of prayer.  Bangdel (1989, 309) dates this image back to the 12th century and mentions that, after a few attempts were made to steal the image, fences of iron rods were installed to protect it.

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, statue of Śivaliṅga (mukhaliṅga), view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: Bangdel (1989, 227) mentions that the 11th-12 century śivaliṅga was standing here, but that it was stolen in 1983. See also the list of stolen images here A new this new śivaliṅga has been erected on top of the same jalahari (pedestal).

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, statue of Prajñāpāramitā, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: Prajñāpāramitā is sitting in vajraparyaṅka. His lower two hands are performing dharmacakra, whilst his other two hands hold an akṣamālā and a book.

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, stone pedestal, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: This empty pedestal is near the caitya. Local people assume this to be the pedestal of Viṣṇu's lost image.

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, Jalahari, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: This Śivaliṅga was constructed in vesara-style, though it now only has its lower (jalahari) part. The upper part is missing.

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, statue of Śrīdhara Viṣṇu, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: Viṣṇu is standing in a samapāda posture. He holds cakra and padmabīja in his right hands, and gadā and śaṅkha in his left.  Lakṣmī stands to Viṣṇu's left and Garuḍa is to his right. Bangdel (1989, 271) dates this image back to the 12th century. He mentions that this image was lost. See also the list of stolen images here. However, an image of the same god is attached to the wall of the hiṭī, and appears to be very similar to the original one. That said, when one compares the present one with the photo of the original as published in Bangdel it becomes clear that the motif under Viṣṇu's pedestal, the shape of the vajra, and the hole to the left of the vajra are not the same.

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hitī, statue of Śrīdhara Viṣṇu, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, Licchavi caitya, view from NW; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: This broken Licchavi caitya is joined together with cement. Legend has it that this caitya was formerly located in Cikã Bahī (LAL1620). However, at some point a flame burst forth from the caitya and the bahī caught fire. After this, the caitya was brought here.

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, Statue of Gaṇeśa, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, Jaḥrũhiṭī, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: The jaḥrũhiṭī (water reservoir) is now in a condition of disuse. It is attached to the western wall.

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, statue of Buddha, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: Buddha is holding a tip of cloth (cīvara) with his left hand and performing varada with his right hand.

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, statue of Bhagavatī, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: This image of Bhagavatī is to be found in a niche of the western wall. Bhagavatī standing in ālīḍha posture steps one foot on a lion and another on a lotus pedestal. The four-handed goddess is holding a sword and a flower with her two upper hands and performing abhaya and varada with her two lower hands.

Object image caption: Cyāsaḥ Hiṭī, statue of Sūrya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-03-07
object short description: This east-facing image of Sūrya is placed in the niche of western wall of the hiṭī. Sitting in vajraparyaṅka posture on top of two horses, Sūrya is wearing an armour and holding stalks of lotuses on his two hands. Bangdel (1995, 224) has dated this image to the 17th century.

Object image caption: Iku Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from N (October 2018)
Iku Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya inside the shrine, view from E (October 2018)
Iku Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu, view from N (October 2018)
object short description: The octagonal dharmadhātu from VS 1991 depicts images of eight Lokeśvaras: Vajrapāṇi, Gaganagañja, Ratnapāṇi, Kṣitigarbha, Padmapāṇi, Viśvapāṇi, Ratnagarbha and Sarvanivaraṇaviṣkambhin.

Object image caption: Pūrṇacaṇḍī Mandira, statue of Mānabhairava, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-03
Pūrṇacaṇḍī Mandira, statue of Bhīmasena, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-03
Pūrṇacaṇḍī Mandira, statue of Siddhilakṣmī, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-03
Pūrṇacaṇḍī Mandira, Dakṣiṇakālī, view from W; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-03
Pūrṇacaṇḍī Mandira, Yajñaśālā, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-03
Pūrṇacaṇḍī Mandira, Lion Pillar, view from N; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-03
Pūrṇacaṇḍī Mandira, Caitya, top-down view; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-03
Pūrṇacaṇḍī Mandira, aniconic statue of Yogeśvara Mahādeva, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-03
Pūrṇacaṇḍī Mandira, Śveta Bhairava, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-09-17
Pūrṇacaṇḍī Mandira, Statue of donors, view from E; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-03
Pūrṇacaṇḍī Mandira, Siddheśvara Mahādeva, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-03
Haugaḥ Phalcā at Haugaḥ, Patan, statue of Nāmasaṃgati, view from W (July 2019)
object short description: This statue of Nāmasaṅgīti is embedded in the eastern wall of the Phalcā. Nāmasaṅgīti is one of the important manifesta­tions of Mañjuśrī, the embodiment of wisdom of all the Buddhas. He has one head and twelve arms. The statue shows him seated with dhyānamudrā. His uppermost arms are raised above his head in the uttarabodhi mudrā i.e two hands folded in prostration. His two hands at breast level are in dharmacakra mudrā. Two further hands perform tarpaṇa mudrā i.e are about to offer water from the alms bowl, whilst two hands hold his alms bowl in his lap. His two shoulder-level hands hold a sword and a scripture on a lotus whilst the final two hands hold a bow and arrow.

Object image caption: Kuikānā Pañcadevala, eastern side of the southern temple, view from E; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-25
Kuikānā Pañcadevala, southern side of the eastern temple, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-25
Kuikānā Pañcadevala, western temple, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-25
Kuikānā Pañcadevala, northern temple, view from NE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-25
Kuikānā Pañcadevala, southern side of the central temple, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2014-09-25
object short description: The temple's pediment is partly collapsed.

Object image caption: Khapiṁchẽ Phalcā, statue of Nārāyaṇa in the shrine facing the street, view from W; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2019-02-18
object short description: The north-western corner (the rear) of the Phalcā contains a shrine in which a statue of Nārāyaṇa is kept. The statue stands on a jalahari pedestal. Nārāyaṇa is flanked by two small icons of his śaktis: an icon of Lakṣmī stands to his right whilst an icon of Sarasvatī can be seen to his left. Lakṣmī and Sarasvatī are both shown standing in a samapāda posture. The statue of Nārāyaṇa was installed by a Maharjan family around 1974 who replaced the previous image of the same deity after it was stolen some time between 1950-70.

Object image caption: Trivikrama Viṣṇu Mandira, statue of Trivikrama Viṣṇu, view from W (July 2019)
Śiva Mandira, statue of Sūrya attached to the southern wall inside the sanctum, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-10
Śiva Mandira, statue of Nandī in front of the main entrance, view from SE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-10
Śiva Mandira, Śivaliṅga in the sanctum, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-10
Śiva Mandira, statue of Bhagavatī attached to the western wall inside the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-01-10
Dune Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-03-03
object short description: The base of the caitya is covered by the courtyard's raised stone flooring. Four Bodhisattvas have been placed at the four cardinal directions of the caitya and four Buddhas can be seen on the upper part. A metal roof supported with four iron rods has been fixed here to protect the caitya. A fire alter can be found to the north of the object.

Object image caption: Dune Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-03-03
object short description: A statue of a three-headed and four-handed Mahākāla is placed to the right of the sanctum entrance. He sits over two crops in āliḍha posture holding a sword and kartṛ in his right hands and khaṭvāṅga and kapālapātra in his left hands.

Object image caption: Dune Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-03-03
object short description: Gaṇeśa is placed to the left of the sanctum entrance. He sits on a rat in pratyāliḍha posture holding an axe and a sweet ball in his left hands and a radish in his lower right hand. The object in his upper right hand is not visible.

Object image caption: Dune Bāhāḥ, Akṣhobya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-03-03
object short description: The stone statue of Akṣobhya is placed on top of a high pedestal and two layers of lotus petals. He wears a metal crown.

Object image caption: Hyana Bāhāḥ, stone statue of Akṣobhya, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-03
object short description: Akṣobhya, the kvāḥpāḥdyaḥ of the Bāhāḥ, is in bhūmisparśa posture inside the shrine.

Object image caption: Hyana Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-03
object short description: Jñānajoti, Puṇyarāja and Nhukṣarāja established this Dharmadhātumaṇḍala in the memory of Harṣajoti inside the courtyard. The anniversary worship the maṇḍala is performed on the day of Śrīpañcamī.

Object image caption: Hyana Bāhāḥ, stone statue of Sarasvatī, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-03
object short description: The statue of Sarasvatī is attached to the wall of a house. The goddess is standing and holding akṣamālā and a book on two hands and showing varada and abhaya gestures with rest two hands.

Object image caption: Hyana Bāhāḥ, aniconic hole of Hanumāna, view from N; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-03
object short description: This triangular hole is worshipped as Hanumān. It is made on a wall south to the entrance.

Object image caption: Hyana Bāhāḥ, aniconic stone of Lukumahādyaḥ, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-03
object short description: South to the kvāḥpāḥdegaḥ shrine, a stone is established on the ground. It is worshipped as Lukumahādyaḥ every year on the 14th day of dark fortnight of Caitra (Piśāca Caturdaśī).

Object image caption: Hyana Bāhāḥ, statue of Sāriputra, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-03
object short description: Sāriputra stands to the north of the entrance. The statue is severely eroded.

Object image caption: Hyana Bāhāḥ, statue of Maudagalyāyana, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-03
object short description: Maudgalyāyana stands to the south of the entrance. The statue is severely eroded.

Object image caption: Hyana Bāhāḥ, statue of Sarasvatī, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-03
object short description: Above the statue of Maudgalyāyana is placed the statue of Sarasvatī. She holds vīṇā with two hands and akṣamālā and book with rest two hands.

Object image caption: Hyana Bāhāḥ, stone statue of Mahākāla, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-03
object short description: This statue is attached to the wall of a north-eastern house of the courtyard.  Mahākāla is standing on a corpse holding a kartṛ (cutter) in his right hand and his left-hand holds a kapāpāpātra (skull bowl) and claspses a khaṭvāṅga.

Object image caption: Hyana Bāhāḥ, stone statue of Mahākāla, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-08-03
object short description: This statue is attached to the wall of the Akṣobhya shrine.  Mahākāla is standing on a corpse holding a kartṛ (cutter) in his right hand and his left hand holds a kapāpāpātra (skull bowl) and claspses a khaṭvāṅga.

Object image caption: Cibāhāḥ Nani, full view of Śikharakūṭa Caitya, from N (January 2019)
object short description:
This caitya stands on a single plinth and holds statues of Lokeśvaras and Buddhas at each of its four faces. The eastern face is also home to two lions, whilst the other three sides contain statues of the Dhyānī Buddha. A horse, the vehicle of Ratnasambhava, can also be found on the southern face, whilst the northern face is home to Garuḍa, the vehicle of Amoghasiddhi. This statue is badly worn down. 

Generally the peacock, Amitābha's vehicle, is found on the western face of a caitya, however this one has an image of an elephant seemingly in its place. Upon closer inspection, however, one can also see a small image of a peacock on top of the elephant. A stone inscription between the lions on the eastern face describes the construction of the caitya. Above this inscription are images of the three gems of Buddhism (Buddha, Prajñapāramitā and Lokeśvara).

Object image caption: Naka Bahī, Dhaḥmā outside the main entrance, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-26
object short description: In front of the entrance of the bahī is the dhaḥmā of red Matsyendranātha. Oldfield's 1854 painting also shows the dhaḥmā there. It is therefore difficult to say how long this dhaḥmā has been there.

Object image caption: Naka Bahī, an aniconic Hanumān, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-26
object short description: To the left upon entering the bahī is a niche without any image. The niche itself is worshipped as Hanumān.

Object image caption: Naka Bahī, full view of Mahākāla, view from E; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-26
object short description: This image can be found in the phalcā to the right-hand side when one enters the bahī from the west. It shows Mahākāla holding katṛ and kapāla with his right and left hands. Above the image is a toraṇa with an image of Akṣobhya Buddha at its centre.

Object image caption: Naka Bahī, full view of the śikharakūṭa caitya from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-26
object short description: This caitya is located to the east of the aśoka caitya. On each side of the caitya are images of bodhisattva. Above these images are two layers of lotus petals, garbha, harmikā, and 13 bhuvanas.

Object image caption: Naka Bahī, views of ashoka caitya from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-26
object short description: This caitya stands in front of the image of Akṣobhya Buddha, and is a construction of the Licchavi era. It is surrounded by an oil-lamp balustrade. There are images of five Buddhas on all sides, and above each of these images is a turret. Above the turrets is the garbhagṛha of the caitya and above it is a saptabhuvana, which seems to have fallen down at some point and been fixed using cement. Previously, two standing images of Buddha could be found at the northern and eastern corners of the caitya, but these were stolen in the 1970s.

Object image caption: Naka Bahī, caitya outside Naka Bahī complex, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2018-11-26
object short description: This caitya is located at the north-west corner of the bahī. On each side of the caitya are images of four Bodhisattvas. Above these are four images of Buddha. Above these, in turn, there is a nāgabandhana and a saptapadma. This saptapadma is placed so as to represent the sahasradalapadma. Above this are caityagarbha, harmikā and 13 bhuvanas.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Kumāra, view from SE (July 2020)
object short description: This large aniconic stone has been erected inside the sanctum. Locals worship this stone as Kumāra.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Gaṇeśa, view from SE (July 2020)
object short description: This idol of Gaṇeśa is located inside the sanctum of the temple and looks very new. It was installed by a local man. Gaṇeśa is performing the abhaya gesture with his right hand and holding a sweet ball with his left hand.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Sarasvatī, view from SE (July 2020)
object short description: This statue of Sarasvatī has been placed to the west of the Gaṇeśa statue. The deity is shown sitting in a lalita posture and stepping on a duck with her right foot. She is holding a rosary with one of her right hands and a manuscript with one of her left hands; her other hands clasp a vīṇā. Kṛṣṇanārāyaṇa Sāhī established this statue. On the day of Śrīpañcamī, locals perform a special worship of the goddess.

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Gaṇeśa, view from SW (July 2020)
object short description: A statue of Gaṇeśa has been erected in the sanctum of the temple. The statue has four hands, faces south, and is seated upon a mouse. He holds a rosary and a radish in his right hands and an axe and a sweet ball in his left hands. The previous Gaṇeśa statue was badly damaged, and so Kṛṣṇasiṃha Bhāro made this new one in 1787 (NS 907).

Object image caption: Gaṇeśa Mandira, Bhairava, view from SW (July 2020)
object short description: This stone is located inside the temple precinct and is worshiped as Bhairava. There is a toraṇa on its side. Some people believe that if someone is bothered by evil spirits, they should worship Bhairava and he will cure them of this. This Bhairava is said to be kept under wraps, as he is very strong.

Object image caption: Nau Bāhāḥ at Uku Bāhāh, Mahāṅkāla, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-02-19
object short description: The Mahākāla shrine lies at the left corridor of the entrance. Four-headed Mahākāla is holding a sword and kartanī with his right hands and khaṭvāṅga and kapāla in his left.

Object image caption: Nau Bāhāḥ at Uku Bāhāḥ, Ramyakūtāgāra Caitya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-02-19
object short description: This Caitya bears similarities to a śikharakūṭa caitya. However, Śākya (1994, 101) calls it a Ramyakūṭāgāra Caitya. Images of Lokeśvaras and Dhyānī Buddhas are placed at each of its four faces. The upper part of the Caitya is clad in copper, and a copper parasol has been placed on top of it. This parasol has four nāgas (snakes) in each of its four corners.

Object image caption: Nāmasaṅgīti Phalcā of Pinchẽ, statue of Sarasvatī, view from S; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2019-02-26
object short description: This image of Sarasvatī shows her sitting down and with four hands. One right hand holds a rosary of beads, whilst her left hand holds a book. The remaining two hands hold a vīṇā.

Object image caption: Nāmasaṅgīti Phalcā of Pinchẽ, statue of Nāmasaṅgīti, view from S; photo by Bijay Basukala; 2019-02-26
object short description: Nāmasaṅgīti is one of the important manifesta­tions of Mañjuśrī, embodying the wisdom of all the Buddhas. He has one head and twelve arms. He is seated in the position of dhyānamudrā. His uppermost arms are above his head and are performing uttarabodhi mudrā (meaning that they are folded to indicate prostration). The two hands level with his breast perform dharmacakra mudrā whilst two of his lower hands are depicted in a gesture of tarpaṇa mudrā (i.e. about to offer water from the alms bowl). Two further hands hold an alms bowl in his lap, whilst the two hands at his shoulder level hold a sword and scripture on a lotus. His last set of hands hold a bow and arrow.

Object image caption: Gāḥ Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S (January 2020)
object short description: The faces of this dharmadhātu maṇḍala are made from a single block of white marble and are left blank. The object is 92 cm high and its base measures 120 cm × 120 cm.

Object image caption: Gāḥ Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from NE (January 2020)
object short description: The base of the object is a lotus throne with four lions in the corners and images of caturmahārājas (the four great kings) at the four cardinal directions. These kings are named Vīṇārāja, Khaḍgarāja, Caityarāja and Dhvarāja and have been placed to the east, south, west and north of the structure respectively. Four Dhyānī Buddhas are shown sitting on the lotus throne. Above these Buddha images, there are three layers of lotus petals, a dome, a harmikā and thirteen spires. Four Buddhas and four Tārās have been placed on the base of the dome. A metal plate joins the harmikā to the dome. The section above the thirteen tiers is broken.

Object image caption: Due to local regulations no photo available.
object short description: Akṣobhya, the bāhāḥ's main deity, is enshrined in the sanctum. This statue was found in the excavation work that took place in 1956.

Object image caption: Gāḥ Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: A stone statue of Gaṇeśa is attached to the front wall of the bāhāḥ building. He is shown holding a rosary and a radish in his two right hands and an axe and a sweet-ball in his two left hands.

Object image caption: Gāḥ Bāhāḥ, Mañjuśrī, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: A stone statue of Mañjuśrī is attached to the front wall of the bāhāḥ building. He is depicted holding a sword and an arrow in his right hands and a bow and a book in his two left hands.

Object image caption: Gāḥ Bāhāḥ, vajra installed on top of a small stone pillar, view from N (January 2020)
Gāḥ Bāhāḥ, Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: A stone statue of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara is attached to the front wall of the bāhāḥ building. His right hand is shown performing the gesture of varada (blessing) whilst his left hand holds a lotus stalk.

Object image caption: Gāḥ Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla, view from N (January 2020)
object short description: A statue of Mahākāla is attached to the front wall of the bāhāḥ building. He is standing on a corpse holding a kartṛ (cutter) and a kapālapātra (skull bowl) in his hands whilst clasping a khaṭvāṅga.

object short description: The statues have been identified by local informants as Subhadrā (in the middle) with Balabhadra (left) and Kṛṣṇa (right).

Object image caption: Sipkhanā Devala, south-western corner of the eastern temple, view from SW; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2016-10-03

object short description: It is possible to identify three topping parts (stūpa) of śikharas as well as diverse wall elements of śikhara temples.

Object image caption: Bhaiṣajyabāhāḥ Phalcā, Mañjuśrī statue, view from S (February 2019)
object short description: The stone statue of Mañjuśrī is attached to the northern wall of the phalcā. Mañjuśrī is sitting on a lotus. One of his left hands is performing the abhaya gesture whilst holding a book. He holds a bow in his other left hand and vāṇa and khaḍga in his right hands. This image was installed recently as the previous one was stolen.

Object image caption: Sijaḥ Bāhāḥ, vajradhātu caitya, view from SW (June 2019)
object short description: This caitya is made entirely from brick. It has four Buddhas at each of the four directions. According to locals inhabitants, it was constructed by Rañjitakāras.

object short description: This image of Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara standing upon a lotus pedestal has been attached to the wall of the Phalcā. Lokeśvara is wearing a flower garland, holding a lotus flower in his left hand and performing varada with his right hand.

Guji Bāhāḥ, Lāmā Caitya, view from N (July 2019)
object short description:
This licchavi caitya is located outside the bāhāḥ courtyard, in front of its northern entrance. All four side niches of the caitya are empty and surrounded by derivative motifs. The harmikā is badly damaged. There are 11 bhuvanas on top of the harmikā. The part above the bhuvanas has also been damaged. One can also find a statue of a sitting devotee in a dhyāna posture here.

It is believed that when Sūryadeva brought the image of Trailokya Vijaya from Tibet, the Lama followed him and arrived at this bāhāḥ. When the Lama saw that Trailokya Vijaya had already been installed in the āgama of the bāhāḥ he thought that it would be better to stay, and so he sat nearby this caitya and began to meditate. Whilst meditating to his deity, he became liberated.

People worship this caitya when their children are struggling to learn how to walk. The connection between walking and this caitya originates from the Lama’s journey from Tibet to Kathmandu.

The caitya has suffered water damage and is cracked in places. The stones of the plinth, niches and the garbha of the caitya are in a deteriorated condition. The garbha and the harmikā have been attached using cement plaster, with the consequence that the harmikā is slightly covered. The image of Lāmā sitting to the north of the caitya is very worn.

Object image caption: Guji Bāhāḥ, Trailokyavijaya shrine, view from E (July 2019)
object short description:
The āgãchẽ of the Guji Bāhāḥ contains an image of Trailokyavijaya with Hevajra. This image of Trailokyavijaya was brought from Tibet. Only the daśapāramitā aḥjus of the bāhāḥ are allowed to worship in the āgãchẽ. To make Trailokyavijaya accessible to the greater public, the deity was installed at the northern corner of the western wall of the bāhāḥ complex. There is no image; instead, a stone vajra decorated with ornaments has been established there. A bronze toraṇa can be found above the vajra, and it is flanked by kakāsyā and ulakāsyā. People worship Trailokya Vijaya in the hope of removing obstacles from their work. Before the Harisiddhi dance begins, a gvaydā̃ is offered to Trailokya Vijaya (Vajrācārya 2000, 69).

A Lama from the Potala Palace of Tibet heard about the scholar Sūryadeva, a son of Vaiśradeva, and invited him to Tibet. Whilst in Tibet, Sūryadeva came to know that a fire was ragingi in his Guji Bāhāḥ. WIth the power of some tea from his cup, he extinguished the fire. Amazed by his tantric power, the Lama requested permission to worship his deity Trailokyavijaya. Pleased with this, the Lama requested Sūryadeva to ask something from him. Sūryadeva asked for the image of Trailokya Vijaya. The Lama felt it difficult to deny this request directly, and so told him he would discuss it the following day. Sūryadeva became suspicious of the Lama and left Tibet that same night, taking with him the image of Trailokyavijaya. Upon his arrival back in the Kathmandu Valley, he established the deity in the āgama of his monastery. The physical condition of the object is good.

Object image caption: Guji Bāhāḥ, Acala, view from W (July 2019)
object short description: The image of Acala has been placed inside a small niche to the north of the gumbā entrance. Acala is depicted holding a sword for subduing demons in his right hand and a rope in his left hand. The image has been damaged. The repeated application of vermilion powder has destroyed the face of the deity; as such, it is now hardly recognisable. Some of the other body parts are also worn away.

Object image caption: Guji Bāhāḥ, Sarasvatī, view from W (July 2019)
object short description: An image of Sarasvatī has been installed inside a small niche to the south of the entrance to the gumbā. She is holding a rosary in her right hand and a book in her left hand. Her remaining two hands hold a vīṇā. Frequent touching and the application of vermillion powder has led to the image being quite worn down.

Object image caption: Guji Bāhāḥ, aśoka caitya, view from E (July 2019)
object short description: This licchavi caitya is located outside of the bāhāḥ courtyard, in front of the northern entrance. The upper structure stands on a rectangular plinth and has three layers of empty niches. There are only 9 bhuvanas on top of the caitya, which attests to its antiquity. Āmalaka and yaḥsĩ are both clad in bronze. The caitya has been damaged by water.

Object image caption: Guji Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W (July 2019)
object short description: Only four faces (east, south, west and north) of the maṇḍala have the image of Bodhisattva. The dharmadhātuvāgīśvara maṇḍala residing on top of the dharmadhātu has been covered with bronze sheet. A metal fire alter exists towards south from the maṇḍala. This object is in good condition.

Object image caption: Guji Bāhāḥ, Viśvakarmā, view from E (July 2019)
object short description: This image of Viśvakarmā can be found in a niche on the western wall of the bāhāḥ. The image has largely worn away due to repeated touching and the frequent use of vermillion powder.

Object image caption: Guji Bāhāḥ, śikharakūṭa caitya, W (July 2019)
object short description: This śikharakūṭa caitya stands to the east of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala. The upper part of the caitya (above the harmikā) has been painted in a yellow color. This object is in good condition.

Object image caption: Guji Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātujinālaya caitya, view from W (July 2019)
object short description: Four vajras have been placed on the four sides of the caitya's plinth. Four Bodhisattvas have also been placed in each of the four directions. Above the lotus petals, one can find four Buddhas. The upper part of the caitya (above the garbha) has been painted in a yellow color. A metal vajra has been placed on top of a small cement pillar, which in turn has been placed to the south of the caitya. The caitya is in good condition.

Object image caption: Guji Bāhāḥ, Nāsaḥdyaḥ, view from E (July 2019)
object short description: Nāsaḥdyaḥ (Nṛtyeśvara) can be found in a niche on the western wall of the esoteric shrine. There is no image here; instead, three small holes are worshipped as the deity. The shrine is flanked by two painted images of characters holding drums. The painting below the niche has worn away. Above the niche, a toraṇa with an image of Nṛtyeśvara can be seen. This toraṇa is damaged.

Object image caption: Lũkhusi Bhajan Phalcā, statue of Balarāma, view from S; photo by Rishi Amatya; 2020-10-15
object short description: Balarāma holds a club on his right hand and a plough on his left hand.

Object image caption: Devarāja Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from S; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-01-05
object short description: The Caitya’s finial is clad in brass, whilst other parts of it have been plastered with cement. A metal canopy (ilā̃) hangs above it.

Object image caption: Devarāja Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2020-01-05
Sūryavināyaka Mandira, base stone (ilvahã) of gate, view from S (November 2018)
object short description: Towards the east of this temple is a street which leads from Bahalukha to Kāyegu Nanī (LAL0240) there is a base stone lying on the street touching the eastern wall of this temple. Over 30 years ago (writing now in 2019) there was a wooden gate standing over this stone which served as an entrance for Kāyegu Nanī. Now, this stone is all that is left of this gate. The Newari word lukhā means gate; the name of this ṭola (‘Bahalukha’) therefore originates from this gate, even though it was actually used to enter the bāhā (i.e. Kāyegu Nanī).

Object image caption: Guitaḥ Phalcā 2, Dharmadhātu Maṇdala (A), view from NW (February 2020)
Guitaḥ Phalcā 2, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala (B), view from N (February 2020)
Guitaḥ Phalcā 2, Nāmasaṅgīti shrine, view from W (August 2019)
object short description:
The Nāmasaṅgīti shrine is embedded in the eastern wall of the Phalcā. A stone statue of Nāmasaṅgīti has been placed in a niche of the shrine. Nāmasaṅgīti is one of the important manifesta­tions of Mañjuśrī, the embodiment of wisdom of all the Buddhas. This statue shows him with one head and twelve arms and seated with his hands in a dhyānamudrā position. The arms above his head are in the uttarabodhi mudrā position i.e two hands folded to form a gesture of prostration. Two hands are at his breast level and are performing dharmacakra mudrā. Two other hands are in tarpaṇa mudrā i.e about to offer water from the alms bowl. Another pair of hands holds an alms bowl in his lap, whilst the hands at his shoulder level hold a sword and scripture on a lotus and the last set hold a bow and arrow.

A caitya-shaped pinnacle has been placed on top of the shrine.

Object image caption: Guitaḥ Phalcā 2, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from N (February 2020)

Object name: Stone statue of a Guru Lekhamāna Maharjana
Object image caption: Guitaḥ Phalcā 2, statue of Lekhamāna Maharjana, view from W (August 2019)
object short description: This statue has been placed on the right side of the Nāmasaṅgīti shrine. The inscription below the statue mentions that Maharjana recited Nāmasaṅgīti in the Phalcā from 1963 to 2009.

Dolã Māju, Mā̃simā, view from E; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-05
object short description: The nettle tree (kharī) in the middle of Lagankhel bus park area is also called Māju Simā. According to the legend, associated with the arrival of Rāto Matsyendranātha to the Kathmandu Valley, his mother and a host of yakṣas, ghosts, and goblins followed the procession back to Nepal in order to capture him and bring him back to Kāmarukāmākṣa. When she was noticed, she was tied to a tree at Lagankhel in care of tantric powers and thenceforth remained there. According to another opinion, this is the very tree where King Narendradeva halted when he brought Matsyendranātha to the Valley (Nepali G. 1965, 369-370).

Object image caption: Dolã Māju, maṇḍala representing Dolã Māju, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-05
object short description: This is the circular maṇḍala in the middle of the shrine. In some chronicles, this shrine is also referred as Yogāmvara Maṇḍapa (cf. Owens 1989, 200).  In order to worship the mother of Matsyendranātha, who was sitting on a tree, a shrine was built by pulling her down with the help of tantric powers. According to another legend, Acārya Bandhudatta and King Narendradeva invoked Matsyendranātha to the middle part of this place, Lagankhel, by making a stone Padmāsana. On special occasions, a kalaśa is placed in the middle of the maṇḍala as a symbol of Rāto Matsyendranātha. The kalaśa is decorated with ornaments, symbolizing the motherly protection of the son.

Object image caption: Dolã Māju, gavākṣa representing King Narendradeva, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-05
object short description: A stone, enshrined in a niche to the west of Hayagrīva Bhairava, represents King Narendradeva. There is a stone manḍala, surrounded by tree leaves, inside the niche. King Narendradeva's crown is believed to had been preserved in this place (Śākya B. NS 1125, 20).

Object image caption: Dolã Māju, gavākṣa representing the Karkoṭaka Nāga, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-05
object short description: Karkoṭaka Nāga who is surmounted by seven snakes, played an important role in bringing Rāto Matsyendranātha to the Kathmandu Valley as well. An aniconic stone is enshrined in the niche, symbolizing Karkoṭaka Nāga.

Object image caption: Dolã Māju, gavākṣa representing Hayagrīva Bhairava, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-05
object short description: This Bhairava lives on the dhaḥmā of the chariot of Rāto  Matsyendranātha. He is flanked by a pair of lions.

Object image caption: Dolã Māju, Nhavãdabū (bathing platform), view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-12-05
object short description: There is a nhavã dabū (a platform for the bathing ritual of Red Matsyendranātha) on the western side of Mā̃simā (Mother Tree). The platform is accessible through a staircase, located on the same side of the tree. It is not clear when the platform was constructed, however it was repaired in 1965 CE (VS 2022). Every year on the first day of the dark fortnight of Vaiśākha, the statue of Rāto Matsyendranātha is bathed on this nhavã dabū. After the bathing ceremony, the chariot procession officially starts with the making of the chariot.

Object image caption: Bālakṛṣṇeśvara Mandira, statue of Nandī, view from N (July 2019)
object short description: A stone statue of Nandī is placed to the west of the temple. It is heavily damaged. The statue was placed poorly during the road widening process and the construction of the stone pavement.

Object image caption: Bālakṛṣṇeśvara Mandira, stone relief of donor figures, view from E (July 2019)
object short description: The statue depicts a seated couple praying and facing the śivaliṅga inside the sanctum. The inscription is dated NS 832 and names the donors as Bālakṛṣṇa and Arpūvāni. The statue is heavily damaged.

Object image caption: Ghana Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-05-16
Ghana Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya statue; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-05-16
Sikucā Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S (August 2019)
object short description: Eight Bodhisattva images are placed on the eight faces of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala. It is topped with a metal vajra which was fixed in VS 2045.

Object image caption: Sikucā Bāhāḥ, Aśoka Caitya, view from E (August 2019)
object short description: Four Buddha images have been placed in the niches of four directions on top of the plinth. The upper niches of four directions are empty. The dome of the caitya has lotus petal motifs and on top of it are harmikā, and trayodaśabhuvana. The caitya is topped with a metal ilā̃, placing the image of Vairocana in its middle. The caitya is surrounded by oil lamp balustrade. Small metal images of donors are fixed on the balustrade. Small metal monkeys have been fixed on the four corners. There is no inscription to record the history of this caitya. Some of the stones of the caitya are broken.

Object image caption: Sikucā Bāhāḥ, Bhīmasena statue, view from E (August 2019)
object short description: This small statue of Bhīmasena facing east is placed on the north of main entrance of the bāhāḥ. He is pressing down his enemy with the knee of his bent left leg. He rips open the enemy’s chest with his left hand and raises his right hand holding a club over him.

Object image caption: Sikucā Bāhāḥ, Garuḍa statue, view from S (August 2019)
object short description: This small Garuḍa statue is placed on the wall to the north from the main entrance.

Object image caption: Sikucā Bāhāḥ, Mahākāla statue, view from S (August 2019)
object short description: Mahākāla statue is attached to the wall towards north from the main entrance. He is holding khaḍga and kartṛ with his right two hands, and khaṭvāṅga and kapālapātra with his left two hands. In front of Mahākāla is a square shaped stone maṇdala. Śākya (1994, 96) claims this to be a part of a 14th century dharmadhātu maṇḍala.

Object image caption: Sikucā Bāhāḥ, Gaṇeśa statue, view from N (August 2019)
object short description: This image is placed on the wall towards south from the main entrance. Gaṇeśa is holding japamālā, and probably (not clearly sculpted) radish with his right two hands and an axe and sweet ball with his left two hands. The statue has been eroded due to vermilion powder.

Object image caption: Kani Bāhāḥ at Oku Bāhāḥ, Durgatipariśodhana Caitya, view from NE; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-03
object short description: This caitya is smaller than the Durgatipariśodhana caitya at Oku Bāhāḥ and Ilā Nani. Images of various deities are placed on the caityas of these places. However, this caitya does not have any such images. The vehicles of the Four Buddhas and eight auspicious symbols have been placed in the four directions of the vedi are placed: to the east is an elephant (the vehicle of Akṣobhya) and śrīvatsa (the endless knot); to the south is a horse (the vehicle of Ratnasambhava) and a water vessel together with a banner; to the west is a peacock (the vehicle of Amitābha) and a fish, and to the north one can see Garuḍa (the vehicle of Amoghasiddhi) and a conch together with a parasol.

Object image caption: Kani Bāhāḥ at Oku Bāhāḥ, statue of donors, view from S; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-03
object short description: North of the dharmadhātu maṇḍala, one can find a statue of three donors facing north who appear to be praying. Bhājudeva and Dhanapati installed this statue, and the figures represent their father and two mothers. The top of the statue also functions as a place to light oil-lamps.

Object image caption: Kani Bāhāḥ at Oku Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-03
Kani Bāhāḥ at Oku Bāhāḥ, Bhīmasena statue, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-03
object short description: This image of Bhīmasena is attached to the western wall, inside the main entrance of the bāhāḥ. Bhīmasena holds a club in his right hand and is charging towards his enemy.

Object image caption: Kani Bāhāḥ at Oku Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-03
object short description: This image is attached to the eastern wall inside the main entrance of the bāhāḥ. This four-handed Gaṇeśa stands on top of two shrews and holds a garland and a radish in his two right hands and an axe and a sweet ball in his two left hands.

Object image caption: Kani Bāhāḥ at Oku Bāhāḥ, statue of Hanumān, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-03
object short description: Hanumān is placed on the eastern side of the main entrance to the vihāra. He is holding a club in his right hand while his left hand rests on his thigh.

Object image caption: Kani Bāhāḥ at Oku Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from W; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-03
object short description: This image is attached to the eastern wall inside the main entrance of the bāhāḥ. Mahākāla is standing on a corpse holding kartṛi (chopper) and kapāla (skull bowl) and clasping khaṭvāṅga.

Object image caption: Karuṇāmaya Mandira; statue of Karuṇāmaya (Padmapāṇi Lokeśvara) view from E; photo by Pankaj Nakarmi; 2021-06-02
Nhū Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-27
Nhū Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātujinālaya Caitya, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-27
Nhū Bāhāḥ, Vajradhātu Caitya; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-27
object short description: The Buddha statues in the small niches of the caitya were added later. Images of the two donors are depicted on the eastern plinth.

Object image caption: Nhū Bāhāḥ, Vimba Caitya, view from S; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-27
object short description: The stone sculpture showing three donors with an inscription below was a later addition to the base of the caitya. This caitya seems older than the others. There is a statue of the three donors on the southern side of its plinth. The statue is slightly bending and seems to be a later addition. Flower motifs have been made with cement. These were added during the process of its reconstruction.

Object image caption: Nhū Bāhāḥ, Nārāyaṇa Shrine with tulasī plant in the background; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-27
object short description: A remnant of the pinnacle of a temple is placed on top of this Nārāyaṇa shrine. Local inhabitants maintain that this remnant was brought and placed there some years ago. Each of the four niches contains an image of Nārāyaṇa. The lower niche contains an image of a tortoise.

Object image caption: Nhū Bāhāḥ, stone sculpture of Durgā, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-27
object short description: The glass showcase contains an image of a ten-handed Durgā. Her four right hands are holding cakra, a flower, an arrow and sword whilst her last right hand performs a fearless gesture. Her five left hands hold a conch, a trident, a shield, a bow and a club. This image was installed some years ago by local inhabitant Siddhirāja Śākya on his return from India.

Object image caption: Nhū Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya statue; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-27
object short description: Akṣobhya statue is placed inside a glass showcase.  A local inhabitant Siddhirāja Śākya established this shrine some years ago.

Object image caption: Nhū Bāhāḥ, stone sculpture of Śiva and Pārvatī, view from W; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-27
object short description: The glass showcase contains images of Mahādeva and Pārvatī. Some years ago, a local inhabitant Siddhirāja Śākya brought and installed the images on his return from India.

Object image caption: Nhū Bāhāḥ, shrine at the south side of the Bāhāḥ, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2019-04-27
object short description: The cement-plastered shrine and the stone sculptures are poorly designed and seem to have been recently added.

Object image caption: Siddhi Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from SW; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-11-19
Siddhi Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from N; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-11-11
object short description: This octagonal Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala has no images of the eight Lokeśvaras on any of its eight sides.

Object image caption: Siddhi Bāhāḥ, statue of Mahākāla, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-11-19
Siddhi Bāhāḥ, the statue of Akṣobhya, view from W; photo by Sabrina Dangol; 2020-11-11
object short description: Inside the sanctum sanctorum, a small statue of Akshobhya has been placed on a high plinth facing west. After the old idol was stolen, a new idol was erected by the locals. The body of Akṣobhya is covered with colorful cloth as lhegā.

Object image caption: Kvātha Bāhāḥ, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from S (July 2019)
Kvātha Bāhāḥ, Vimba Caitya, views from E (July 2019)
object short description: This caitya is different from other caityas. It has flower motifs instead of images of Lokeśvaras or Buddhas placed on top of it in each of the four directions. Images of monkeys have been carved into the caitya, and four statues of Buddha can be found in its niches. On top of it, one can find kumbha, harmikā, trayodaśabhūmi and a metal parasol.

Object image caption: Kvātha Bāhāḥ, dharmadhātu maṇḍala, view from E (July 2019)
Kvātha Bāhāḥ, Pūrṇakalaśoparipadma caitya, view from E (July 2019)
object short description: This caitya is different from other caityas. There are vehicles of Buddhas in each of the four directions on the vedikā: an elephant, the vehicle of Akṣobhya, is located on the eastern side; the vehicle of Ratnasambhava, a horse, is placed on the southern side; the western side houses a peacock, which is the vehicle of Amitābha; and on the northern side one can find Garuda, the vehicle of Amogasiddhi. Monkey figures can be seen in the four corners of the vedikā. On top of this, there is a pūrṇakalaśa with lions and lotus petals with Buddhas in each of the four directions. The upper part displays kumbha, harmikā and trayodaśabhūmi. The bottom half of the caitya, from the plinth to the vedikā, seems to have been constructed in the same type of stone. However, the upper part appears to use a different stone material. The original part above the pūrṇakalaśa was stolen, and so a new one has been fixed in its place. The caitya is surrounded by a wired fence, which should serve to prevent further theft.

Object image caption: Śambhunāth Mandira, temple façade, view from N; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-06
object short description: Architectural elements from medieval monuments are insterted in the masonry.

Object image caption: Śambhunātha Mandira, minature śikhara 003, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-06
object short description:
The upper part is missing. The monument is oriented to the south.

It can be dated from the 13th-16th century.

Object image caption: Śambhunātha Mandira, memorial pillar 009, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-06
object short description:
The pillar is oriented to the south.

The pillar can be dated from the 13th-16th century.

Object image caption: Śambhunātha Mandira, memorial pillar 008, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-06
object short description:
The pillar is oriented to the south.

The upper register contains a bas-relief representation of a bitrd turned towards the left.

The pillar can be dated from the 13th-16th century.

Object image caption: Śambhunātha Mandira, fountain 006, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-06
object short description:
According to local informants this fountain was at some point moved here from another location. Water is channeled through a plastic pipe.

The fountain may be dated to the 13th-16th century.

Object image caption: Śambhunātha Mandira, architectural remains, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-06
object short description: Elements of miniature śikhara temples (most likely KLK0130-002 and 003) are stacked up.

Object image caption: Śambhunātha Mandira, memorial pillar 007, view from S; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-06
object short description:
The pillar is oriented to the south.

The upper register contains a bas-relief representation of a star. The lower register seems to contain the representation of a stūpa.

The pillar can be dated from the 13th-16th century.

Object image caption: Śambhunātha Mandira, minature śikhara 002, view from N; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-06
object short description:
The upper part is missing. The monument is oriented to the north.

It can be dated from the 13th-16th century.

Object image caption: Śambhunātha Mandira, fountain 005, view from SE; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-06
object short description:
There is no water since at least 1968.

The fountain may be dated to the 13th-16th century.

Object image caption: Kusi Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-15
Kusi Bāhāḥ, Akṣobhya Buddha in the sanctum, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2021-03-15
Buramāṃ Vaidya Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Jinālaya Caitya, view from S (January 2019)
Lo Gekar, Padmasambhava, view from E; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2021-04-13
Bāsimali Phalcā, Siṃha, view from W (February 2020)
object short description: A lion statue is attached to the eastern wall of the Phalcā. Locals believe that he is Garuḍa. The inscription on the lower part of the statue states that the lion statue was installed by Vijayahari Siṃha in NS 853 (733 CE). This statue seems to be older than the Phalcā itself. It is evident that it was brought from somewhere else and placed here.

Object image caption: Bāsimali Phalcā, Vāsuki Nāga, view from E (February 2020)
object short description: A statue of a male deity is attached to the western wall of the Phalcā. Locals worship him as Lord Viṣṇu. However, it seems that this statue is in fact Vāsuki, the king of the serpents. Vāsuki generally holds a lotus stalk in his one hand and the tail of other nāga in the other. One of his hands is broken and another is not visible.

Object image caption: Gajendramokṣa Nārāyaṇa Mandira, well, view from N; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-12-18
Gajendramokṣa Nārāyaṇa Mandira, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala (right); photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-12-18
object short description: The dharmadhātu maṇḍala has an octagonal base and statues of Lokeśvaras in its eight faces. It is surrounded by an oil-lamp balustrade, and was established by Kriṣṇalāl Maharjan in VS 2045 (CE 1989).

Object image caption: Gajendramokṣa Nārāyaṇa Mandira, Svayambhū Caitya, view from SE; photo by Thomas Schrom; 2018-12-18
object short description: This caitya was established by the predecessor of the Maharjan family living in one of the houses that lies to the west of the caitya. Gopi Maharjan states that his great-grandfather Lakṣmīdāsa Bhāva established this caitya sometime in Shumsher Rana period. On each of the four sides of the caitya are small images of Dhyānī Buddha. It is surrounded by an oil-lamp balustrade.

Chāya Bāhāḥcā, statue of Gaṇeśa, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2020-03-07

Rārā Temple and Fountain, view from south; photo by David C. Andolfatto; 2018-05-03
Dattātreya Mandira, Garuḍa, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-04-11
Ikhālakhu Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, statue of one of the four Buddhas, view from N; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-03
Ikhālakhu Bāhāḥ, Caitya; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-03
object short description: In the southern part of the courtyard, one can find a small Caitya on a plinth. The northern, eastern and western lower parts of this Caitya are open, while the southern part is closed off due to the wall attached to it. Only the northern side of the middle part contains a niche. The upper part has been worn down.

Object image caption: Ikhālakhu Bāhāḥ, Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala, view from NE; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-03
object short description: This octagonal Dharmadhātu Maṇḍala contains eight Bodhisattvas in eight directions and was established in NS 1056.

Object image caption: Ikhālakhu Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-03
object short description: A statue of Maitreya can be found in a niche on the nemī. A statue of Mañjuśrī has been placed in the southern niche, though normally he would be found on the northern side. In the western niche, one can find a statue of Padmapāṇi. The niche at the northern side is empty. Towards the south are two statues of sitting lions. An oil lamp balustrade surrounds the Caitya. Towards the east, one can find an image of a doner facing the Caitya. To the west, meanwhile, there is another statue of a doner of which only the lower body remains. At the north-western corner, one can find an image of a monkey. It seems that images of monkeys were once also placed at other corners of the Caitya.

Ikhālakhu Bāhāḥ, Śikharakūṭa Caitya, statue of a monkey; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-03

Ikhālakhu Bāhāḥ, bell, view from W; photo by Nashib Kafle; 2019-01-03
object short description: The bell is made of ḍhaloṭa, an alloy of copper and zinc.

Object image caption: Naḥ Bāhāḥ at Cāka Bāhāḥ, Aśoka Caityas, view from E; photo by Yogesh Budathoki; 2019-02-23
object short description: Three white painted Caityas have been built on a plinth in the Bāhāḥ's courtyard. Two of them are from the medieval period (Locke 1985, 227). New images of Dhyānī Buddhas have been placed in its niches. An oil lamp balustrade with 108 lamps surrounds the Caityas.
